text: This Seagate 2TB external drive is replacing a 500GB Iomega drive I have been using for my Mac.  I do not have USB 3.0, so I cannot evaluate the speed difference, but I can say this drive is extremely quiet compared to the Iomega.  I can't really tell when it's doing a Time Machine backup.One of the key things to note if you are going to be using this on a Mac:You have to reformat the drive, because it comes formatted for Windows.  You can do this with Disk Utility, and reformatting with Mac OS Extended (Journaled) format, which will work for Time Machine.When doing my first backup of about 150GB, the drive did not get hot...only slightly lukewarm.  Things are looking great so far, so I highly recommend getting this one.

Compared to his first novel, "Spycatcher," Dunn hones his skills in number two of the series, "Sentinel."  The new novel is a full 100 pages thinner, and shows tighter prose than what was on display in the first novel.Also, whereas "Spycatcher" had some unbelievable dialogue (or monologue) towards the end, there is a better ending to "Sentinel" with more believable events and dialogue.  Because of this, I would be willing to read the third book when it is released.  At the end of the first book, I was a bit skeptical of whether I wanted to read anything further from Matthew Dunn.As a former MI6 agent, Dunn has the necessary knowledge to write a character such as Cochrane, but he does need to polish his writing skills, and appears to be doing just that.  I would recommend reading this if one is interested in spy novels, since the author shows promise of becoming an engaging writer in the genre.

The main thing I'd like to do in my review (as so many others have addressed specific details about this particular addition to the series) is to alert prospective readers to the fact that this is the fifth book in a series, so if you think you're interested, it would be best to read them in order, in my opinion.This is the order:Napoleon's Pyramids (2007)The Rosetta Key (2008)The Dakota Cipher (2009)The Barbary Pirates (2010)The Emerald Storm (2012)For a historic adventure series, you really cannot go wrong with the Ethan Gage set.  Dietrich has written several other standalone novels prior to and in between the release of the Gage novels, but this series is the best part of his work so far.

This will be a simple review:  If you're looking for a rugged case that is waterproof (including waterproof zippers!), you cannot do much better than this.  Pretty typical of Thule products, as well as Swedish craftsmanship in general.  It is lightweight, but provides just a little more peace of mind for your Macbook Pro.

One good thing about cases like this is that it helps the user hold on to the iPod Touch (extra friction for grip), and it provides some extra protection, at least for the back and sides of the iPod.The new cases by Belkin are elegant, perhaps overpriced (better in the 10-20 dollar range), and snap snugly onto the back of the iPod Touch, just flush with the front edge.  Of course, this means there is little protection for the front of the iPod, but if you're minimalist, like me, you may prefer to have nothing interfere with the interface of the iPod and your finger.  Personally, I cannot even stand to use screen protectors, and from my experience with the glass on newer iPhones and iPods, there is hardly any need.However, if dropped, there is still the possibility of breaking the front glass.  You must decide what is more important for you, the unadulterated experience, or the ultimate protection for your electronic device.  This case enhances the prior, while doing very little for the latter.

Because of the information already included on the Amazon page for this product, it should not be a surprise to anyone that espionage plays a part in this novel, so I will admit without fear of giving spoilers that I have always loved novels related to espionage.  However, I have never read one in which the protagonist was female, and espionage is not really the main story in this novel.In keeping with my desire to not give spoilers, I will refrain from explaining character backgrounds and major plot points, at least with any specificity.Kate, the protagonist, is married to Dexter, and they both have each other fooled, to very different extents, and in very different ways.  They have a commitment to each other that transcends the deceptions, and both have very good reasons for their deceptions, though perhaps not reasons with which everyone will have sympathy.The plot is one with many twists -- a veritable roller-coaster ride -- and takes the reader across various countries and continents, mundane and exotic.  It also jumps back and forth in time enough to cause vertigo.The only serious weak point of the novel, in my opinion, is that the author has the characters' actions mostly occur in their memories, rather than simply showing us all of the action as it occurs.  A great deal of the story, action or back-story, is simply explained in dialogue, which is not ideal, but it is still quite interesting.In my copy, it is stated that this book is "being developed for major theatrical release by CBS films."  I think the story lends itself well to a movie version, and possibly will be even stronger as such, but there is little doubt that Pavone is a talented writer (a former editor and ghostwriter), and I expect to see much more of his work.The strongest recommendation I can give for this novel is that if there were a sequel, I would read it.

Yes, I'm sure it will charge my Kindle (as that has already been verified), but it says it is for Apple products.  So, as some others have mentioned, there may be some products not compatible with this device.This is another one of those very simple, small USB car chargers, but there is one advantage I can think of to this one.  Though it is tiny, the design allows for relatively simple removal, something that can be a difficulty with some other products of this nature.

As a pharmacist, I would recommend that pharmacists, doctors, and any other medical professional with interest, as well as pharmaceutical company executives, familiarize themselves with the issues explained in this text by Davison.  He explains the issues we face, whether safety or business oriented, and lays out methods to handle the issue of counterfeiting drugs.  This is, of course, more relevant for the companies that produce pharmaceuticals, as well as the governmental administrations that are responsible for regulation, but all parties from there to the end user, the patient, should be educated.

***UPDATE 8/12***SEVERAL MONTHS LATER, I was still getting the same information from Crucial, double checked with Apple, and apparently the two companies do not see eye to eye on what should go into the MacBook specified.  So, I went with Apple's information, and purchased this item, and have been using it for a few months with no problems, so I upgrade the review to five stars, and inform anyone reading this that Crucial has faulty information on their site about what can work in this MacBook.**********************I ordered this item, then a few hours later, looked up the part number on Crucial's website, because when I originally checked Crucial's website for RAM, this part did not show up when using the advisory tool for my new MacBook's specs.When I searched specifically for this part number, the part came up on the site, with an advisory tool to the left of it, asking if I wanted to check to see if this particular part is compatible with my computer.  This is the result:"This part ct2kit51264bc1339 is not compatible.View compatible parts for the MacBook Pro 2.4GHz Intel Core i5 (13-inch DDR3) Late-2011."Now, I don't know how accurate Crucial's own site information is, because when clicking on the "view compatible parts" link, one of the choices was a 16 GB kit (8 GB x 2), and that particular MacBook only takes 8 GB.Anyway, I decided to cancel the order, because while it may work, check out the one-star reviews that mention kernel panics, etc.  Those reviews are not specifically about the MacBook Pro 2.4GHz Intel Core i5 (13-inch DDR3) Late-2011, and it may work for all I know, but I think I'll wait a while to see if Crucial's information looks more reliable.

Have you ever watched "Airplane"? If you have, you know what slapstick is, which is similar to the type of humor primarily used in this parody of Sherlock Holmes stories. The stories have absolutely no purpose but to tickle the funny bone with frequent displays of repartee with little or no attention to plot. Hence the last statement of the book, below what appears to be a 19th century illustration:"You call that a plot?"One may also be reminded of Monty Python to a degree, but perhaps not up to the quality standards of Monty Python.I was going to read this after another book I was reading, but decided instead to take a break from the other work. It was funny and relaxing for a change, though I regret it is a self-published book with some lack of editing. This was not severe, but simply noticeable to one that pays attention to detail -- catching the occasional misspelled word, unintentional repetition, or grammar flub. In my opinion, a major publisher could do far worse than taking on this writer's work, and polishing it for mass production.I was a little surprised to come upon a similar title by someone else, Sherlock Holmes and the Zombie Problem, that was released a couple of months before this one.

This review will take the pros and cons approach:Pros:1. Lightweight2. Locking serrated knife with lanyard hole -- wicked looking blade, stainless steel3. LED flashlight emits bright light for size, removes from knife and has magnet base to attach to metal surface, with pivot to direct light.4. Very loud whistle in base of handle (seems to be an odd thing for a knife)5. Clip to attach to belt or other item.Cons:1. Size is not convenient, mainly because of flashlight attachment -- also the heaviest part, and the part that will surely break eventually.2. Flashlight uses four button cell batteries at a time that are taped together (comes with one replacement)3. Flashlight turns on by unscrewing the head of it -- so not too far, or it falls apart.4. If the flashlight stops working, you will still have the cavity for it attached to the knife.In summary, the flashlight is the weak point of this item, and may have been better as an entirely separate item within the package.

I am not rating the trilogy, but the deluxe box set. If you have not had a chance to get into this popular Swedish crime trilogy, this is your perfect opportunity to buy them in the best way without wasting any money on lesser products. When the regular price for this set is set at 99, getting it at 39.50 is a perfect steal.The person that received the two separate packages with torn packaging was just unlucky, or something. The package I received reveals a flawless, massive slipcased set of cloth bound books without dust- jackets...a real luxury setup with a binding that *should* last.I recommend jumping on this while you can. Price check other book stores to see what a steal this is right now.

This was on offer from the Vine program almost a year ago, and at the time, even though I am normally interested in books that deal with Russia, I passed on it.  Big mistake.  Since then, the second book in the series was released, Shadow Pass, and I decided to take that one, which got me hooked. I had to go back and read the first book. One does not necessarily have to read this book before "Shadow Pass," but I think it may help a little.If one is drawn to the history of Russia and the Soviet Union, and thinks even the darker components of Russian history have something of a romantic nature, Eastland's novel will please. If one has ever read a Tom Clancy novel -- one of the older ones -- and found oneself at least partially intrigued and respectful of the Soviet characters, that reader is likely to find something of interest here.The main character, Pekkala, is a Finnish man that became the special investigator for the Tsar of Russia (before the Bolshevik revolution), and is known as "The Emerald Eye," a name that comes from a special badge issued to him by the Tsar, a unique disc with the appearance of an eye and an emerald in the center. Stalin was supposedly known by some as the Red Tsar, so the title refers to Pekkala becoming for Stalin what he initially was for Tsar Nicholas II.Pekkala is sent to Siberia for many years, after the revolution, only to be brought out of exile by Stalin to investigate the murders of the Romanovs. Now, this is not strictly historical -- it is fiction -- and it has characters and plot points that do not necessarily reflect actual history.  There is no intention to claim an alternate history. In fact, in the end of the book, there is a section entitled "What Really Happened to the Romanovs?" In that section, he gives brief points of items that happened on certain dates, even up to present times regarding discoveries of various Romanov bodies and DNA evidence. Much of this does not match the novel. Just suspend disbelief and move on.That I decided to go back and read this book after reading "Shadow Pass" should show there is something attractive about this character, setting, and the writing of Sam Eastland. This author and his Inspector Pekkalashould be priority reading for anyone interested in historic Russia/Soviet Union.

This is a comparatively small volume, which contains some of David Hume's most critical arguments related to religion and god from a "natural religion" or "natural theology" perspective, but do not allow that to deceive you, potential reader, as it is incredibly dense with thought and meaning, and cannot be read lightly if one expects comprehension.Hume, an 18th century Scottish philosopher, and one of the greatest philosophers ever, is known as an Atheist, though it is difficult to come up with that conclusion from reading these particular materials. Sure, he may have been, but he seemed to avoid any type of label, preferring to "suspend judgment" with regard to things that are ultimately unknowable. With that perspective, it would be reasonable to consider him an Atheist, in the sense of not having a belief in a god. It would also mean he was Agnostic, not knowing whether there was a god or not, and reserving judgment on such matters, but that term would not be used for such views until T.H. Huxley.This wonderful book put out by Oxford University Press, edited by J. C. A. Gaskin, contains "Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion" and "The Natural History of Religion." The first is a dialogue set up in the tradition of Cicero, with three persons arguing from different points of view, and the latter is simply a straightforward treatise on its subject.In addition to an excellent introduction by Gaskin, there are also other minor additions:1. My Own Life -- a brief summary by Hume.2. Section XI of An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding, one of his greater philosophical works -- a section related to religion.3. A letter concerning the Dialogues -- from Hume to Gilbert Elliott, requesting input for the dialogue portion of one of the "believers," Cleanthes.This is a fairly good introduction to Hume, at least with regard to his religious and nonreligious thoughts, and I wish more people, both believers and nonbelievers, would challenge themselves with reading such as this, rather than resorting to some of the inane, superficial hype put out by both sides in recent years.

One thing about a book like this: I cannot divulge many details at all, because it would destroy the surprises (such as sex, drugs, and violence), and there are quite a few surprises. I do not feel it appropriate to provide more details of the plot than the blurb from the back of the book, and then I will give my impressions:____________________________________________________________"A murdered woman. A grieving husband. Between them, their mentally handicapped son with a long history of violent outbursts. It's a simple open-and-shut case. Or is it?Leo Hewitt, a former Assistant DA once blamed for setting free a notorious child-killer, is eager to redeem himself with this intimate and grisly crime. He's not convinced that anything is as it appears. As he digs below the surface of visible motives, he discovers more than he ever anticipated-including an emotionally disturbed wife, a husband who'd do anything to escape his disastrous marriage, and an accused young man with no apparent means of defense. But with each shocking new revelation come only more disquieting questions, leading Leo deeper and deeper into the inescapable darkness of blood bonds and twisted family secrets."____________________________________________________________This is without doubt one of the fastest page-turners I have read, an easy read, and an average reader could complete it within a few hours without interruptions. It is an extremely dark novel with no true heroes or villains comparatively, but shades of gray permeating the entire story. It is not exactly real life, but one could imagine the situations occurring in real life, as long as someone was truly inspired in a dark, surreal way. I think some threads of the storyline could have been tied up a little more neatly, because of implausibility, but it was still a fun experience.The writing starts off so simple, I was thinking "yes, it is a debut novel," and it is, but the simplicity is only a sort of deception to draw the reader in. The language is basic and the chapters are short, especially in the beginning. Some chapters are only half a page, and are frequently followed by a blank page. This actually works to great effect, making the reading light and easy, causing the reader to turn pages faster in anticipation of the next small chunk.It has been optioned by writer/producer/director Nicholas Kazan for a motion picture. The book reads like it was written specifically for that purpose, but I doubt it would do as well as a movie as it should do as a book. I hope Grant Jerkins keeps his focus on writing more books, because he has talent worth watching.

The first article in the entire collection, the one that kicks off the best American science and nature writing, is an article from GQ.GQ.Seriously.It is an article devoted entirely to the worship of Elon Musk.I have no intention of offending anyone with this review, but potential readers of this volume should be aware of what they are getting. If this is the "best American science and nature writing," America is in trouble. However, I know for a fact it isn't the best writing of that type, because I read science articles frequently.Since so many other reviewers have done an admirable job of providing a blow- by-blow description of every single article, I will just give a summary of my thoughts. Perhaps the best articles in the entire book are the ones pulled from National Geographic, The New Yorker, and The New York Review of Books, though it is best to be clear on the nature of most of this writing, all of which was written in 2009.The writing of the various articles, as an art form, really is excellent for the most part. However, the nature of the writing is best viewed as stories, frequently biographical, with science or nature themes. This is not the type of science writing I am accustomed to, perhaps with the exception of a few National Geographic articles, but even the NG articles get on my nerves with all of the useless details given in order to tell a story. The other ones, even the ones from The New Yorker, are much more airy with ethereal details that have nothing to do with the science. I'm sure this appeals to many, but when I select a science article to read, my intention is not to read a novel or a short story -- I can do that at other times.Allow me to give another example of the light nature of this book. In the back of the book is a list of the articles that were not selected for this collection. Any article from Scientific American was conspicuously avoided, as well as one from the premier journal, Science. Scientific American may not be what it used to be with regard to the level of science writing, but the long articles were still mostly by scientists in 2009, though that is changing in the end of 2010. There were not many articles selected for this collection that were written by scientists.Dyson even alludes to the fluff nature of this writing in his introduction. Not only that, but for some reason, though he states that people tend to like nature writing more than science writing, and one can almost detect his disappointment, only about the first fourth is science, if one actually counts the GQ piece. Dyson, a climate-change skeptic, selected what he considered to be environmental pieces, including climate change subjects in the last 57% of the book. He divides those into "Doom and Gloom," "Small Blessings," and "Big Blessings." It almost appears he is trying to create skepticism of climate-change, as if that were the purpose of the book. While I agree with his assessment of Environmentalism as a new secular religion, I am left wondering why he would have made the majority of the book about exactly that. I have some ideas.Personally, I think if someone is interested in science writing, it is better to start out with a science magazine, preferably above the level of Popular Science. Discover or Scientific American would be good starters, Discover for beginners and Scientific American once Discover is outgrown. Science News is good if you want to keep a light touch on many fields of science. For nature, science, and a smorgasbord of other topics, National Geographic and Smithsonian are great selections. American Scientist may be good once someone is ready to graduate out of Scientific American, normally only for someone with a science degree, or an actual scientist -- many consider it to be what Scientific American used to be many years ago.A book like this may give the impression of selecting the best of what science writing has to offer, since it is selecting from many different sources and being narrowed down, but it is only the best of science light.

I know. How can one be an earbud connoisseur? Let's just say she goes through them like water.Compared to the previous earbuds she has used, and she has used many of them, she says these sound about as good as anything else she has tried.Pros:1. Crisp sound2. Can use on phone, mp3 player, or combo, talk through headset mic, hear calls through headset earbuds, and call quality is decent on both ends. No need to disconnect earbuds for phone use.3. Comes with different size earbud adapters, so a comfortable fit is relatively easy to find.4. Comes with a male adapter for a different size headphone output jack.Cons:1. Clip that can be used to attach wire to clothes breaks off easily. It can be reattached, but breaks off the wire again.As far as price, I don't know if these are a good value without comparing this type of earbuds against others of the same type, and that is something we have not done. The only ones my wife has used that have the ability to use with a phone are the ones that came with the iPhone 4, and she does not like that one because of the standard Apple large discs that go in the ears.

David P. Clark is a microbiologist with educational experience at Cambridge University, Bristol University, Yale University, and University of Illinois. He is a professor of microbiology at Southern Illinois University currently.This book has much good information in it, though there are no references for any of it. I believe the reason for this is because it is intended for a lay audience, but I have read other books intended as such with copious references. I think most of the information is fairly accurate, though his mention of Al Capone dying in jail was not accurate -- he died on his estate -- but that is not Clark's area of expertise.There are copious helpings of speculation, but that is to be expected in science . . . one of the driving forces of experimentation. Clark adds humor to the depressing subject, and that may offend some, but I enjoyed his sense of humor. We must laugh at ourselves and our situations, or we become miserable.The one thing about the book that causes me to give an average rating is exhausting repetitiveness, as though one were reading a series of microbiology lectures that had much overlap in subject matter, all cobbled together to form one volume, with no editing to make it appear as though the book were written with the intention of writing a naturally flowing narrative (or perhaps the writer and editors are senile). It would be speculation to say whether the fault was more that of the author or the publisher, but this is the second book I have read recently published by FT Press, and I intend to read no more of their books. They must not have editors.This book has many high points that are enjoyable, it did not kill me to put up with the back to back unedited microbiology lectures, and it has made me stronger in the will to avoid FT Press.

My impression of the writing of this book is that it is an impressive debut novel by a promising writer. It was not engrossing, and was not a page-turner, in my opinion, but it was descriptive enough to bring dimension to the characters and at least give the potential for the reader to care what happens to the characters. Something does happen to one of the characters that caused me to be disappointed, so Col Buchanan did his job pretty well.One point that I have mixed feelings about is the way he takes so obviously from religions on Earth (though this setting is not Earth, at least not with two moons), hardly disguising the names, such as "Dao" or "true prophet Zabrihm." Even the religion of "Mann" is a thinly disguised suggestion of "Man" worshipping itself, with mention of "the divine flesh," as opposed to the religions that have a more selfless focus. I understand the need for this if the purpose is to provide social commentary, such as Star Trek.The map within is reminiscent of the Mediterranean Sea region, in more ways than simply shape. Even the locations of some of the peoples mirror the Mediterranean region today, with the "Alhazii" (Arab) region to the east, or the evil empire (Greece or Rome) to the north.Buchanan's writing has its rough spots and cliches, and he does some things in his writing that writers are really not supposed to do. Too many adverbs and too many spots where he substitutes other creative words in place of "said." However, he has obvious talent, and judging by the quality of the first book in the series, I am going to keep an eye out for the next one.

As far as the Kindle, Adam Bede seems to be the best "Adam Bede" as far as the free classics go, though there are formatting errors and misspellings (I checked against the online version on Princeton University's site). I also tried the other free file that is available right now, but it was missing some text entirely.One paid version of "Adam Bede" I tried was this Penguin version, thinking it would be so much better (as well as a good deal for a Penguin version), but it wasn't. I got no further than the introduction before noticing errors that were not in the print version, which one can preview on Amazon. I got my money back for it, and decided that for the Kindle, free is good enough. If I pay, I'm likely to prefer a physical copy.

I tried reading "Adam Bede" on a couple of paid versions, one of which was this Mobi version that contains all of George Eliot's works. It appeared to be a good deal, but I noticed formatting and spelling errors as much as in the free versions. Plus, all of the works are in one enormous file, so that one sees virtually no progress on the Kindle when reading a certain novel. I got my money back, and decided that for the Kindle, free is good enough. If I pay, I'm likely to prefer a physical copy.

As for the book, "Adam Bede," there is perhaps little to review, after > 150 years, but I will also focus on Kindle issues I have noticed.As far as the novel, this was the first real novel written by Mary Ann Evans, as "George Eliot." At ~600 pages in print form, it promotes the feeling that the author has all the time and room in the world to explore and expand on any idea or character at her whim. The reader can truly get lost in a world built by George Eliot, and feel as though one knows the characters intimately.I will not give any spoilers, but it is essentially a novel exploring provincial life at the end of the 18th century. The main character is not the most colorful of the characters, being the one that is the most stable, while a few characters surrounding him, especially one he is in love with through most of the novel, serve to make the novel more interesting through controversial actions.As far as the Kindle issues, this particular file seems to be the best "Adam Bede" as far as the free classics go, though there are formatting errors and misspellings (I checked against the online version on Princeton University's site). I also tried the other free file that is available right now, but it was missing some text entirely.I even tried a couple of paid versions, one of which was the Mobi version that contains all of George Eliot's works. It appeared to be a good deal, but I noticed formatting and spelling errors within that. Plus, all of the works are in one enormous file, so that one sees virtually no progress on the Kindle when reading a certain novel. I got my money back.The other paid version of "Adam Bede" I tried was the Penguin version, thinking it would be so much better, but it wasn't. I got no further than the introduction before noticing errors that were not in the print version, which one can preview on Amazon. I got my money back for that one, as well, and decided that for the Kindle, free is good enough. If I pay, I'm likely to prefer a physical copy.

I recently bought this for my wife for her birthday, an upgrade from one of the previous 20" iMacs, and it makes my 24" iMac look small...appearing much wider, but not taller. (The screen is larger vertically, also, but the 24" has more aluminum below the screen.) I have to say, there is more computer screen real estate on this beauty than anyone would likely ever need, but if you're game for overkill, order one of these.Some noticeable improvements over previous versions: Twice the previous RAM (now 4GB standard), 1 Terabyte HD, SD card slot below the optical drive slot on the right side, wireless keyboard and mouse (one may see this as an improvement -- or not), the mouse is upgraded to the Magic Mouse with no ball/wheel, but works partially like a mouse, and partially like a laptop track-pad. Plus, the one we received just a couple of days ago included iLife '11. We'll have to see if that's good or not. It does not come with the remote, as it did in previous versions.Possibly, the next time I get an iMac, I may just order the 21.5" or whatever the entry model is at that time, because personally, I have no need for something this massive. However, it is the smart thing to present something large to one's wife for her birthday...and she's very happy.

The title quote is from novelist Gustave Flaubert, advising a friend who was wondering how to approach Montaigne (pp 10-11).Allow me to put your mind at rest about one thing first: This is not a self-help book. I know "How to Live" sounds like something in that category, but be assured that this book is of a much better quality and nature, ascholarly work on Michel Eyquem de Montaigne (1533-1592), French essayist and philosopher.Essayist? Yes...he is the one that coined the word, from French "essai," meaning test, try, attempt, etc. Philosopher? He was an excellent observer of himself and his surroundings, from the very simple to the absurdly complex, and wrote what we know as the "Essays," his life's work.Sarah Bakewell has performed a wonderful service in putting together some chapters which may be described as essays of her own. The book is really a history of the life of Montaigne and the life of his written work. The impression one gets of the man and his work is that there were inconsistencies, contradictions, rambling, self-centeredness, possibly false modesty, and scores of other possible criticisms. Yet, there is a tremendous amount of wisdom in his thoughts, statements, and observations. It is impossible to really give an example of his wisdom that would appeal to everyone at every stage of life, but it is likely that anything he said would hit a chord with anyone at some point, if they are thoughtful.One of the beautiful aspects of his personality, in my opinion, was his realization of what humans share with other animals, the idea that we are part of the same family. Almost everyone over 450 years ago in his milieuwould have assumed that humans were completely set apart from the animal kingdom or nature in general. Humans were to be thought of as divinely appointed to rule and judge over nature, not be part of nature.Montaigne saw through this. Descartes later had a problem with Montaigne's view. Descartes saw animals as automatons without thought or feeling."When I play with my cat, who knows if I am not a pastime to her more than she is to me? We entertain each other with reciprocal monkey tricks. If I have my time to begin or to refuse, so has she hers." -- MontaigneHe had an entire section that dealt with stories of animals performing acts of sacrifice, bravery, altruism, and other forms of goodness thought only in the realm of humanity. Modern science has confirmed that good and evil are not only human traits again and again, so Montaigne was onto something, and well ahead of his time.My first introduction to him was in regard to his skepticism, but he had some devotion to various ancient philosophies, such as Stoicism, Epicureanism, as well as Skepticism. He was also supposedly a good Catholic, but if one takes much of what he wrote into account, it seems unlikely that he was a "true believer" in any sense. He also tried to play himself off in his writings as slow of intellect, with major memory problems, though he did not come off that way to people that knew him.  There is every sign of unparalleled shrewdness.Perhaps a few quotes regarding his religious thoughts may be of help:"How many things served us yesterday for articles of faith, which today are fables to us?""Philosophy is doubt.""To know much is often the cause of doubting more.""Nothing is so firmly believed as what we least know.""Man is certainly stark mad. He cannot make a flea, and yet he will be making gods by the dozen.""It is setting a high value upon our opinions to roast men and women alive on account of them.""Men of simple understanding, little inquisitive and little instructed, make good Christians."During the time in which Montaigne lived, though, skepticism was an important part of Catholic faith, the focus being on us not knowing how so many things work, so faith becomes so much more important. Those views gradually changed, presumably as the skepticism focused more on the faith itself.This book is worth five stars, not least for the desire it has created in me to read and study the "Essays" of Montaigne, but also for learning much of his personal life, habits, and views.

This review will be primarily about the CD-ROM companion.Now, when you have a company that makes a product like this for a potentially large customer base, you would think the company would get it right. Pay close attention to the other reviewers in regard to Windows issues with this product. Apparently, there are issues with Vista and Windows 7, and you may as well forget about using it on a Mac.What does the company say about its own product?*****"This Windows-compatible resource includes:+ Three computer-adaptive practice tests+ Six 30-minute Quantitative practice tests+ Six 30-minute Verbal practice tests+ Answers to every question and detailed answer explanationsThe software on this CD-ROM is Windows-compatible only. It was *not* designed to operate on Apple Macintosh (MAC) computers. You will be able to take maximum advantage of the CD-ROM if you use it on a computer with the following features: Windows 98/98SE/NT4.0/ME/2000/XP/Vista (32-bit only)..."*****So, in regard to the review that said they had no problem with the CD on a Windows 7 computer, was it 32-bit? Maybe that will work, but not on 64-bit (because of the similarities to Vista)?As far as my computer...I have a Mac. Fortunately, I have a Windows XP partition through Boot Camp that I have not upgraded to Windows 7. Where does it state on the product description (on Amazon) that it is for Windows only, and only for old versions? A potential purchaser would only know by looking at the reviews and the Amazon preview on page 5. As far as I can tell, it isn't even stated on the Kaplan website.

This item is exceptional as a alarm clock-ipod player, but would be better if not for a few things. There are several reasons I would say it is overpriced. In my opinion, the sound is not good enough to merit the price. The EXB function increases the bass quality, and you pretty much need to have it on from the beginning, because nothing will sound decent without it. The functionality is lacking, as well.An iPod or iPhone can be placed on the dock to charge, but there is also an auxiliary line in the back in case you do not wish to charge your iPod/iPhone every time you have it hooked up to the iP28 to play music. I don't think the alarm would work that way, but contrary to what another reviewer wrote, the alarm does work with music rather than the buzzer if you have an iPod hooked up to the alarm clock, without the need for the iHome app. At least, it did for me.If you want to use it as an alarm clock without an iPod/iPhone, you can do this as well, because of the included buzzer alarm. This is important to me, because I have no need to keep an iPod or iPhone connected every night, and do not wish to, since charging often or constantly, especially when not necessary, is really not good for the battery.One very important requirement for using a device as an alarm, for me, is that the alarm must not shut off automatically after a minute or so. I'm embarrassed to admit it, but sometimes, for me, it takes a while. I allowed the buzzer alarm to go off for more than five minutes. It starts off low and slow, then gradually increases in frequency and volume to a pretty noticeable clatter.It would be nice to have more than one alarm, and to have a headphone jack. Being able to control song play from the machine itself or from a remote would also be desirable. An irritation is the battery indicator blinking when you are not even using batteries, and I'm not speaking of the small flat battery that saves settings in case of power failure, but even that one blinks that it is low sometimes, even though I just got it and am using the battery included. If one is on AC power, why have the battery power indicator blink?A nice touch is that the clock display has four different brightness settings, one of which is completely off, which is a good thing at night if the light bothers you. I'm not sure why the brightness doesn't auto- adjust, as so many other average alarm clocks do, but at least it is adjustable.Altogether, it is a good device to have, at the least for being an alarm clock and iPod/iPhone charger, but also for being portable. However, there must be more functionality and sound quality included to be worth the price.

Rick Riordan's "The Lost Hero" is, to me at least, an even better start to a series than "The Lightning Thief" was to the Percy Jackson series. I could be biased, of course, because I already have read the entire Percy Jackson series, and thus was already hooked before beginning. There is another reason, though.I have always been fascinated by Greek and Roman mythology, and studied them both extensively in my younger days. Why is that any more important for this series than the last? In "The Heroes of Olympus" series, it is not just Greek mythology that undergirds the story. Now, he interweaves threads from Roman mythology, the very close counterpart to Greek mythology.Now, a couple of important points:1) In tradition, when the Greeks finally defeated Troy, Aeneas flees Troy and has his adventure, as told in the Latin classic, the Aeneid. As a former citizen of Troy, and a demigod (son of Aphrodite and Anchises), Aeneas makes it to Italy, where his descendants become the founders and rulers of Rome, worshiping the same gods as before, but most with different names and personalities.2) Another crucial part of the story deals with a stronger threat to the demigods than what they dealt with in the last series. There is a greater and more primeval threat to the order of things than the Titans of Percy Jackson fame.Why are these things important? No, I'm not going to tell you the story, like so many others -- you have to read it yourself to discover the significance of these points I have put forward (or read reviews that contain spoilers). I do recommend reading the Percy Jackson series, first, if you haven't yet.

I regret to admit that this is the first book I have read by Sir Salman Rushdie, having known of his work for many years, and having long wished to read The Satanic Verses: A Novel. As mentioned by so many previous reviewers, this particular work is a sequel, but I did not find difficulty in reading the work as a result of not having read the previous work, Haroun and the Sea of Stories.There is much to commend Rushdie's writing in this volume, though I would not consider it necessarily a great work of literature. He does incorporate elements from various great works of literature, however, and some of the most entertaining, to me at least, were references to those elements studied by classicists the world over. The story is shot throughout with lively references to mythologies and the old gods and goddesses of the ancients, something that has always produced a fascination within me. Perhaps this is the main reason I enjoyed "Luka."Another reason this book was pleasing to me is that Rushdie's prose, though on a level that could be understood by a ten to twelve year old, is eloquent enough to be pleasing to someone with a much higher reading level, with language and subtle suggestions thrown in that hold the attention of the more mature in the audience. We see techniques like this in almost all animated movies that are produced, and though we adults may watch them for the children we bring along, there is always something that flies right over their heads, intended for us.I give this four stars, as any book deserves (at the least) when it makes me want to read more of an author's material.

It is a pleasure to have completed the second volume of Janet Browne's magnificent ~1200 page biography of Darwin, perhaps the only biography needed to review the life of a much greater man. Part one, can be found here: Charles Darwin: A Biography, Vol. 1 - Voyaging. Volume two begins with preparations and publication of "On the Origin of Species," and continues until his death 23 years later. His autobiography, edited by Nora Barlow, The Autobiography of Charles Darwin: 1809-1882, is a wonderful addition, mainly to get his own thoughts on a few things, but autobiographies are inadequate to fully examine someone's life.Allow me to explain a little why Browne's biography is a stellar piece of work. Perhaps you are interested in reading a much shorter treatment of Darwin's life, and there is no shortage of works by competent authors, even writers that can make it all so much more exciting. You may notice a certain spin or a thesis around which all of these authors build their stories of the subject's life.To an extent, perhaps even Browne does that, but after reading the whole, I cannot easily come away from her work believing she did it all for some political or ideological reason. What I am trying to convey is that she has presented an extremely thorough, wide-ranging, utterly exhaustive treatment which has been done in fairness, showing the great and minor events, even the virtues and vices of Charles Darwin and surrounding significant characters in his life. One can truly walk away from this reading feeling like one has known the great scientist.So many other articles, books, or even forms of video seem to have gotten so much wrong. One major message I have received from this more authoritative source is that Charles and Emma did not seem to have had much problem because of the differences in regard to faith and belief in Christianity. Emma apparently did not have enormous issues with the things Charles wrote, and was even quite involved with helping him with editing and anything else he needed, as were his sons and daughters, especially Henrietta.Another revelation (to me) is how late in life it was when he lost faith. "I never gave up Christianity until I was forty years of age." -- pg 484. That was part of an interview with some freethinkers that were asking about that particular subject. Earlier in this volume, on pg 391, it is recorded "he felt decisive -- these were the most godless years of his life." This is speaking of the last decade of his life, after the publication of "Descent of Man" and "The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals."One last example of a treasure mined from this book is a quote from writings of his son, Francis. Only part of this quote is in the book, as Browne was discussing the primitive methods used by Darwin when so many technologies were springing up to modernize his type of experimentation. I went to the source to widen the context a little:"I have always felt it to be a curious fact, that he who had altered the face of Biological Science, and is in this respect the chief of the moderns, should have written and worked in so essentially a non-modern spirit and manner. In reading his books one is reminded of the older naturalists rather than of the modern school of writers. He was a Naturalist in the old sense of the word, that is, a man who works at many branches of the science, not merely a specialist in one."The odd thing is that even though he shunned much of the technology available to him that may have standardized and increased the accuracy of his work, he still was more accurate in his assessments and predictions than the vast majority of other scientists working at the time in state of the art facilities, while Darwin was working in his home and the surrounding grounds.There is indeed beauty and genius in simplicity.

0:20 Mins I traveled out of the country with this product and I had no issues. I don't remember where I purchased this from.  I have not done extensive travel with the Travel Neck Wallet, Boarding Pass Ticket Organizer Pouch for Passports and Kindle that I will discuss as well. I was sent the Raqpak product to review.Pros-The Raqpak is about 1.5 inches longer than the Victorinox product.-I was able to place a   full 50 count pack of Huggies baby wipes inside of it, I would not have been able to do that with this product because it is not long enough.-My Samsung Galaxy 3 phone, car keys, small pocket camera fit inside securely.-The material for the Raqpak is easier to clean but the material for the Victorinox seems to be more durable. I have not washed it but I think I can place this in the washer machine.-The zippers are made well.-The Raqpak's two zipper pockets on each side are very convenient.-I like the zipper pock on the front. I wish it were a little bigger. My passport fits into it properly.-The neck strap is comfortable and easy to adjust. My husband and I both have one of these and it worked well.Cons-I have this product in black. It does attract lint but not the end of the word.-I wish it were a little bigger.

0:20 Mins I was sent the Raqpak travel wallet to review. I already own a black Victorinox  Deluxe Concealed Security Pouch,Nude,One Size for years. I will compare the two.I traveled to Israel and Rome with the Victorinox product, so I am very familiar with it. I have not done extensive travel with the Raqpak product.Pros for the Raqpak- Its about 1.5 inches longer than the Victorinox product.- I was able to place a  3/4 full 50 count pack of Huggies baby wipes inside of it, which is gravy in my world.- My Samsung galaxy 3 phone, car keys, small pocket camera and wipes all fit inside securely.- The material is easy to clean.- The zippers are made well.- The two zipper pockets on each side is very convenient. I really like that design.- The small pocket on the front flap is nice for change or a small key. The Victorinox product does not have a pocket on the flap.Cons- The security window sounds like a good idea but, it doesn't seem secure to me. I would not place my passport in it. The security window needs a zipper or some Velcro to close the window. My husband would have no problem placing his passport in it, but I would not take the risk.- The Victorinox product has a zipper on the front pocket of it which is a better design and my passport fits in it.- The neck strap is okay. But, the strap on the Victorinox is easier to adjust.I am giving this a 4 because its bigger than my previous travel wallet and I can make it work for what I need it to. But the front security pouch is not secure. I used it for our activities this weekend with no problem. The kids were running around at the Easter egg hunt and my items were secure in this pouch. I was sent the product to review.As soon as my husband saw it he immediately started taking one every morning. He says he feels a boost in energy. He placed the bottle in his car; therefore, I couldn't find the pills so I could take them when they first arrived.When I was finally able to get the bottle from him I started taking one in the morning with a small glass of Almond milk. I do feel refreshed when I take these.  The one morning I forgot to take one I could tell the difference. I have made this a part of my morning routine.I have two young kids and more energy is necessary.I have been taking these for two weeks. I have not noticed any negative side effects.  Pills, especially vitamins can easily make me nauseated if I swallow them on an empty stomach but these do not.I am glad that I was sent this product because I may not have noticed it otherwise.I would recommend this product.

We purchased this mattress with the fuchsia cover in Nov 2013 from Walmart.com.Pros- This works well for our 2 year old.- I have slept on this on three different times when she was not feeling well. It is comfortable for me, but I wouldn't suggest doing it more than a few nights.- The cover is easy to come off and put back on.- All the Disney sheets we purchased fit with no issue- I would recommend this product as long as its under $100. I purchased on Walmart.com for $79. I am not sure I would pay $130 for this mattress. Its just foam.Cons- My daughter is potty training. There is an accident sometimes. At first this was not an issue. But, now it is soaking through the moisture protector. I have washed the protector so I am not sure if that has contributed to the issue.- We have started placing a pad under her sheets to keep the mattress from getting wet.- I cleaned the mattress twice without the cover. I pushed it up the window and allowed it to air dry.  It dried with no problem. I plan to get a twin mattress protector for it soon.

I was sent an electronic copy of this to review. I decided to read eat while eating lunch my desk.I must say its very funny. I grew up in a rural town in the South. A good Yo Mama joke always got a good laugh on the playground.  These jokes are truly funny. I love the Yo Mama is so old jokes in the book. I could not recall any good Yo Mama so old jokes.  It was a really nice flash back to my childhood.I must admit that I personally would not buy a book of yo mama stupid, ugly or fat jokes for my kids.  They will here this in their own time. I dont have to present it to them.  This may not be a bad idea for some parties. I know jokes are jokes but I dont need to reinforce the words fat, ugly and stupid to my kids. I catch myself saying other things around them that I shouldn't. I want them to use better language than I did when I was young.I ran across one profane word in the book. It is not terrible, but I didn't understand the reason for it. The stop the funeral joke could have been re-written.  The word is so unnecessary for a 5 year-old to read. The books description on Amazon states that the beginning target age is 5.This book is totally hilarious for people who like Yo Mamma jokes. I am going to give the book a 4 because I dont think it should be marketed to kids at age 5 and because of the one profane word I read.

I was sent this product to review.I usually stick with The Body Shop Seaweed Line of Skin Care Products. I am out of the toner I usually use. After 15 minutes I washed it off and my skin. My skin did feel cleaner. It definitely acts more like a moisturizer than other muds I have used. However, I do think it will be necessary for me to us my normal toner with this for a true comparison.- My skin was not dry when I used this. I did use an additional moisturizer on my skin but it wasn't entirely necessary for me.- My husband used the product and he really liked it.Compared to Body Shop Seaweed Mask- You get more for the money with this product than the Body Shop product. Therefore, I am more inclined to purchase this product.- This product feels better on my face. I purchased for about $15 I think for 2 bags. Normally I would not spend that much for a shopping bag. But, I was very curious about this product. I was sent this product to review months ago.I decided to make a cup of hot cacao.  I often drink Hot Chocolate at work because I get cold quickly. We have 2.5 year old and 1.5 year old girls. I researched activity tables for a few days. I asked my siblings to purchase this one from amazon for my daughter's birthday.Pros-  My husband put it together without any complaints-  It is sturdy. The kids broke the RiverRidge Kids Table with 2 Chairs and 3 Plastic Storage Bins after 10 months. But this one is still in good shape. The girls stand on top of it all the time if I am not watching. Surprisingly it has not broken. The other table could not handle my kids abusing it :-).-  I like the cups that hold markers and crayons.-  So far it's been easy to clean off crayon marks.-  We have had this table for almost 10 months.Cons- The storage bins are too small for their coloring books. They need to be wider for our usage.- The storage bins fall off the sides very easily. I am thinking about placing some Velcro on the bottom.- The kids constantly fall off the stool. It is very slippery. They stopped using it. I wish the table came with two chairs that have backs on them.- The molded storage areas come off very easily. My 1.5 year old constantly takes them off. They are often on the floor. I wish it had some type of child proof latch. But, when they get older I may feel differently.

I purchased this activity table from Walmart.com in March 2014 for our 2 girls.Pros-  It looks nice- The shelves and trays are very functional. The coloring books and crayons fit nicely. Unlike our other table where the trays are too small for most of their items.- It's not expensive.Cons- Unfortunately, 11 months after we purchased this its broken and unusable.  My girls have not treated this table well. But, I am disappointed with how fast it came apart.- The first thing to break was a chair about 3 or 4 months after we put it together. My 2 year old stepped on the top part of it and it cracked. In case you are wondering, she is not over-weight. It was too dangerous to continue to use it and my husband, who is handy, couldn't fix it for safe use. Therefore, we threw it away.- Ten months after we had it some of the bars for the shelves were broken by one of the kids.- Finally the table started rocking to the point where some bars for the shelves came out and my 1 year old was able to take the screws out.-  We can no longer use the table. One of the chairs is alive. I will continue to use that. I am so disappointed.- This is not made of wood which is expected for the price, but I did need 2 years out of this.- I am giving this 2 stars because we got almost a year of use out of it. But, for $100 I did expect more.

I have two children. Therefore, I use many pre-treat products. This actually gets out very NEW spaghetti stains.I had two bibs with spaghetti stains on them for about 4 days before I washed them. I used Tide sport or Tide color guard as the detergent. This product did a poor job of removing those stains. I washed the bibs a 2nd time by spaying some OxiClean Max Force Stain Remover Spray, 12 Ounce (Pack of 2) on them. They looked a little better. Then I washed with a 3rd load and used bleach in the dispenser. I did not poor the bleach directly on the bibs. That did the trick. I only use the bibs when they eat so I was not worried about any potential color deterioration.My kids love spaghetti with red sauce. This product works well to remove very new spaghetti stains from their bibs. If the stains have been there for a few days it doesn't work as well.In general the OxiClean Max Force Stain Remover Spray, 12 Ounce (Pack of 2) works better for us. But, I can't say that I use the same process all the time. I don't always pre-teat and wait for the number of minutes that the bottle says too. Time does not always allow for that.  Maybe the all are pretty good if the directions are followed :-).

I know I will have to update this review at some point. There are much more thorough reviews than mine.Pros:- We purchased the 7 inch for our 2 year old daughter. I could not complain about the monthly price for prime members. Our budget doesn't allow for lots of gadgets like it used to.- It downloaded the movies well. They play really good. I had no issue with that.- Anything that has a picture of Dora on it gets my daughter's attention. So she liked the Dora app.- For the price it's all worth it.Cons- The 1 year old and 2 year old are constantly at war over my first generation iPad. I thought this would be a good solution. But, not exactly. The apps on the iPad that the 2 year old loves are really good. I have not found comparable apps on the HD Fire yet. With that being said. I have not had time to research. This device doesn't keep her preoccupied like the iPad so I am not sure how that will work on a long road trip.- I personally had a hard time with the device because I am so used to an iPad. These were my own issues. Simple things like getting the home button to pop-up drove me crazy for the first two days. I could not find a tutorial online to help me with the small things like that. So I had to leave it for a few days and come back to it.- The battery life does not seem to be best. But, I am not sure how long it actually lasted. For a long road trip this may not make the cut.- I have a steep learning curve with this device...:-)

I was sent this product to review.I must admit that I had not heard of coconut flour until very recently.  I was very curious about ways to use it because I love coconut in general.  We usually use olive oil to fry items. I have just started using coconut oil to fry with recently.1. First, I fried some pork chops with this Coconut flour because that is the meat I had already seasoned and thawed out.2. I fried in olive oil. It started to brown really fast and I didn't expect that. Just plan ole lack of knowledge. I turned the pan down a little and all was not lost.3. I was very pleased with how it turned out. As expected it didn't taste like white flour. It was different in a good way. It was not as heavy as the bleached flour I grew up with.4. A few days later I decided to fry some chicken breast in coconut oil with this flour. Now that was the jack pot for me. The toddlers loved it. My husband thought it was great. I was very nervous because I am experimenting. There were no complaints in the kitchen after I added some green beans.5. This is pricey compared to what we usually pay for any flour. But, considering that we need a better option than the white stuff I will purchase this again.6. I must say a small amount went further than I thought it would. I also think because it cost more I am a little more conservative than I would be if it were the white flour.7. I also love that the bag is resealable and doesn't leave such a big mess like the cheap stuff.8.  I must say that it doesn't have a strong coconut taste to it. At least I don't think so. But, I really like coconut so I may not have noticed as much. My husband did find it to be a little sweet.9. I also should mention that with regular flour you can reuse the same pan to fry another batch. This doesn't really allow you to do that. It becomes more solid in the pan when cooking. So if you have a 2nd batch I found that I need to clean the pan and start over. Now there may be a way around that but I didn't figure it out. That could be more a product of using coconut oil now that I am thinking about it. That is new to me as well.10. I can't wait to use this product for baking.

"From Asia With Lust - Volume 1" provides 2 Japanese exploitation fliks for the price of one - a factor which slightly sweetens the deal as these type of films are, generally, relatively short in length (approx 70 min each).  As 'stand-alone' features these two movies might also seem somewhat disappointing, but as a two-pack their individual deficiencies become somewhat less annoying, for the price.Both films have been released by Troma, but are NOT Troma productions. It would appear that Troma signed a deal to secure some low end Japanese weirdness to cash in on the surge of interest in Asian exploitation product and have released, to date, 2 separate 2-4-1 packages under the "From Asia With Lust" banner.Having checked out the premiere offering (as a 'fan' of the genre) I'd remark that these were pretty lackluster forays into the venerable realm of the traditional Pinky Violence style of Japanese cinema.  Both of the films in "From Asia With Lust - Volume 1" (AND Volume 2 as well!!) feature Jap AV 'star' Miyuki Yokoyama in the lead female role(s). Mz Yokoyama is attractive enough, and doesn't mind shedding her clothes when required, BUT her ability to deliver a performance with any passion is sadly lacking... a factor that contributes to the somewhat low-key vibe of both of these, supposedly strongly transgressive, films.The first feature: "CAMP" contains more sexually perverse action. Two quibbling sisters become stranded when they have a car accident and they take shelter at an abandoned 'summer camp'. Ironically, their time at the titular 'camp' is short as they are  discovered by a 'neighbor' guy who invites them to spend the night over at his place. The 'sisters' relief at this 'hospitality' is soon ended, however, when four more men show up at the cabin and things get weird. It turns out all the men are 'sexual degenerates' that were released from a near-by 'bankrupted' mental institution and they have continued to live together, trying to control their perverse libidos.  The presence of the two cute and  vulnerable women make them immediately revert to their wicked ways and each member of the group enacts their particular fetishistic fantasy upon the captives.  Torturous indignities are heaped upon the two girls- including: pee fetish, abuse w/ a BBQ lighter!, rape, and ultimately even necrophilia - after the younger sister is grimly killed by being put into a plastic garment bag from which all the air is sucked out by a vacuum cleaner! Pretty 'nasty' stuff.  The older sister (Miyuki!) escapes and fortuitously/improbably! hooks up with another woman who is also trying to hunt the perverts down (with a bow & arrow) and the whole affair moves into a classic feminine vendetta scenario as the women wreak their vengeance.  No 'surprises' here and, consequently, not a lot of excitement generated via the 'by-the-numbers' action.The second feature "Hitch-hike" focuses on a road-trip by a husband and wife who share a pretty abusive relationship.With Miyuki again in 'the driver's seat' they pick up a hitch-hiking man who turns out to be a dangerous bank-robber criminal on the run.  What follows is, again, plot-line territory that has been well mined over the years - as the psycho in the backseat proceeds to reveal his true identity and terrorize the couple for the duration.  Lots of fights and shootings, and a rape (while the 'husband' is forced to watch) provide the thrills in this one - right up to the predictable ending.Both of these films provide over-the-top exploitation situations that are, unfortunately, dulled by clunky scripts, character development, and acting. Situations that could be considered as extremely shocking end up feeling sorta mundane due to the formulaic nature of everything.  There is a fair bit of female nakedness displayed in the film "CAMP" and a lot of sexual brutality! "Hitch-hike" relies more on guns and shocking murders to provide thrills and Miyuki is only briefly nude during her rape scene.Ultimately, I found these 2 films to be an 'OK' watch - but not great.  Makes one appreciate the quality and craftsmanship that went into many of the 'older' Pinky Violence productions.  Technically - the DVD image quality is excellent (widescreen) - Japanese language w/ English sub-titles - no 'extras' of note.

Having just about exhausted the potential for outrageous "Shark' films - One must imagine that the folks at Asylum pictures were casting about for other genres to plunder - and hit upon the concept of mimicking the venerable 'Pinky Violence' style films that have long been popular in Japan and other parts of the far East.In typical Asylum fashion, they managed to get 'some' of it right but the final product definitely feels like it was hastily slapped together (a suposition that is verified in the 'Making Of...' featurette that is included on the disk). However, in this case, that is not necessarily a 'bad thing' due to the fact that most 'true' Asian made Pinky Violence features are also sort of 'thrown together' cheap exploitation affairs.To their credit (in my warped opinion) Asylum has created a fairly watchable product because they didn't shy away from some nice gratuitous sex & violence and included ample scenes of female nudity within the simplistic 'rape/revenge' plot-line... at least this is the case in the 'UnRated' version!The story follows the exploits of 4 (you guessed it) Asian Schoolgirls (based in L.A.) who get drugged & raped by a ring of bad guys who, apparently, basically drug and rape schoolgirls.  One of the abused schoolmates kills herself (because of the shame of it all) and her, similarly ravished, buddies determine to avenge her (and themselves) by taking out the organization that assaulted them.  The 'police' are little help so they decide to take matters into their own hands and arm-up with a variety of Western and Eastern style weaponry which they pay for by doing what every underage Asian Schoolgirl knows is the quickest way to earn big bucks - they become strippers. This is good news for the audience as it provides the opportunity for lotsa T&A action as the gurlz begin their vindictive program of pay-back.In this type of 'film' who really cares if the acting is good or the continuity is spot on - you've got a bunch of cute girls running around in school uniforms and/or less! righteously blowing away their foes.  And that's about 'it'.  What's not to like?!  Personally I found it a great mindless watch & would recommend it to those who enjoy such fare.  The DVD image quality is very crisp/widescreen - extras include a short 'Making Of' segment and a brief 'Gag Reel'.  There's a broad hint at the end of the flik that the 'grrrls might be back' - do I sense the potential for an Asylum Asian Schoolgirl franchise??.... here's hope'n!

"Sexandroide" is a French 'film' made in 1987 that attempts to mix horror and eroticism.  How successfully this blend has been achieved may ultimately be a matter of personal taste.  Por moi - I found the imagery & concepts to be 'interesting' if not particularly 'inspired'. Given the time of the film's original release some of the things depicted were pretty avante-garde.The format presents 3 separate, unconnected, segments that all feature naked women and some 'horror' element.The first scene is, perhaps, the most imaginative - in it: a woman at a bar is affected by a remote individual who is inexplicably tormenting her via a wax voodoo doll. The woman takes refuge in a lavatory and is compelled to rip her own clothes off and is then subjected to a series of 'tortures' as the unseen voodoo manipulator pokes and prods the wax effigy in a variety of 'intimate' areas.  Pretty creepy & bloody!The second vignette follows a lanky brunette down into a satanic basement setting where she dances around and flagellates herself a little before she is set upon by a demonic individual whose make-up, strangely, reminded me of the look of the flying monkey creatures in the old 'Wizard of Oz'.  This segment featured a lot of cringe-worthy graphic depictions of long needles thrust through sensitive body parts on the naked woman, eyeball gouging, bowie knife carving, and even a depiction of hari-kari!  I particularly appreciated this 'act' because it had an authentic 'Grand Guignol-esque' feel to it - seemingly recreating the experience one might have had at that infamous Victorian period Parisian 'theatre of horreur & comedy'. This is emphasized as the 2 'actors' in the piece stand up and 'take a bow' at the end of their torturous sequence...  It was quite satisfying (in a sick & depraved way).The final episode of the perverse trilogy is the most mundane in terms of 'horrific' content.  An attractive, ashen faced, widow sits by a coffin, until the vampiric 'corpse' pops out of it and rips her clothes off. The, totally nude, dancer then basically does an 80's style 'stripper' act next to a coffin for an extended period. Any guy who has ever sat thru a typical strip-bar show  will recognize all of 'the moves' and the camera does not 'shy away' from from any of the action - making this the most explicitly erotic of the scenes... somewhat reminiscent of similar sequences in director Ed Wood's: "Orgy of the Dead".  It should be generally noted that, although full female nudity is abundant, there is no XXX porn action (in the original French film).Interestingly, there is no verbal dialog in any of the segments (no pesky sub-titles to detract from the viewing experience) - the sound trak consists of music and a lot of panting, screaming,  grunts and groans - as appropriate to whatever bit of weirdness is transpiring on screen at the moment.  While this, relatively brief, Franco foray into erotic-horror doesn't really have much to recommend it beyond its' hefty dose of full female nudity - in THAT department it scores admirably and could be considered as a 'fun' watch by the sort of bent individuals who gravitate to this type of (s)exploitational strangeness.The visual quality of the DVD transfer is 'appropriately' grainy but good. The 'extras' include some (even grainier) scenes from a version of the film duped from a Japanese VHS release that featured additional XXX footage not actually related to the original French release, This, fairly lengthy, series of scenes appear to be out-takes from some European made hardcore BDSM movies - a male midget is a prominent player in several segments.  Because these clips were in a Japanese release they are 'plagued' with the annoying digital censorship that is imposed on much Japanese hardcore material and make the sex scenes difficult to watch - but it is nice that the DVD authors thought to include them!  There are also some trailers for other 'Massacre Video' oddities.  Gratuitously vacuous as it may be - I liked it!

"Super Eruption" is a made for the SyFy Channel product that chronicles the effects of a potential eruption of the massive volcanic caldera that houses Yellowstone National Park. Personally, I love a good disaster flik and am particularly drawn to scenarios that involve volcanic and/or tsunami imagery. "Super Eruption" definitely delivered lotsa lava action, but was pretty flawed in many areas of its' basic plot development and editing - thus detracting from its' enjoyment level.Perhaps one of the most disturbing elements, for me, was the fact that the film was obviously NOT shot in Yellowstone Park - or even America. As is the case with much SyFy Channel product the end credits revealed that the production took place in Eastern Europe and the landscape just didn't look 'right'. I have had the pleasure of visiting Yellowstone and know what it looks like - this factor alone made it hard to get into the feel of the film. The acting was all reasonably well done, but the story line was so 'by the numbers', that it didn't manage to build any kind of suspense or intrigue and, ultimately, relied on some rather improbable plot twists and ridiculously un-realisitic actions that totally destroyed any credibility in the plot. The CGI effects were pretty decent throughout but they felt sorta 'wasted' due to the sloppiness of the screenplay.A vastly superior take on the same Yellowstone eruption premise was realized in the Knowledge Network generated docu-drama "Super Volcano" which is available on DVD (albeit somewhat scarce), and the Yellowstone sequence in the film "2012" also gives much better 'bang for the buck'. Still - "Super Eruption" wasn't the worst thing I've seen come out of the SyFy pipeline and it could be recommended for some light weight diversion by fans of the genre.

As others have stated - this particular DVD doesn't really deliver on the promo hype presented on the DVD box cover.  Perhaps the biggest 'error' is the fact that the subject matter covered isn't really the San Andreas fault!  It would appear that the distributors have rushed this product out to take advantage of the release of the Hollywood blockbuster, of the same name, and have done the BBC a disservice in the process. The box cover art and promo write-up are both quite deceiving as they would lead one to believe that the contents might depict a story and visuals of a dramatic nature - showing simulated earthquake disaster effects.In reality this is an  'interesting documentary' of a relatively mundane nature that 'speculates' on the effects of a major earthquake along the so-called "Cascadia fault line" located offshore in the Pacific Northwest - well above the San Andreas fault.  The program presents  lots of archival footage of the tsunami disaster in Sri-Lanka to allude to how devastating a coastal earthquake can be.and many stock shots of angry ocean waves and people walking around in cities full of tall buildings as the narrator does a lot of ominous "what if" speculation about a potential Cascadia quake.  Perhaps the most intriguing material provided focuses on scientists who demonstrate historic & geologic evidence of previous times when this fault shifted. As far as 'simulations' of tidal waves and/or land-based earthquake disaster goes - there are only a couple of limp CGI effects of swaying buildings and rippling roadways to allude to how such an event might manifest. Over-all, however, this is a pretty dry little scientific extrapolation with little 'exciting' visual material.The DVD actually includes a second 'bonus' feature of equal length entitled "Earthquake Storm" that features a similar scientific investigation into the phenomenon of 'sequential' earthquake patterns - such as have apparently been observed in parts of the Middle East.This feature also mostly shows present day 'crowd scenes' and scenery of the regions being discussed - but no earthquake simulations.While both of these programs are interesting enuf in their own rights as a light weight educational experience - they sure don't provide anything visually exciting and left me feeling sorta ripped off by the 'hype' of the product description for 'action' that was not delivered.  Maybe a 'renter' - not much of a 'keeper' - unless, perhaps, you are a grade school science teacher who might want to show it as an educational film about fault-lines. Time would be better spent re-watching the San Andreas disaster segments from the film "2012".

A couple of purported reviewer comments on the DVD box cover for "The Lesser Evil" (2015) refer to it as: "The most disturbing film of the year" and "An unrelenting squirmfest!" Having given this (latest) of mega low budget horror auteur Bill Zebub's offerings a watch I'd have to agree - BUT - likely NOT for the reasons  stated in the promo hype. Mostly I was 'disturbed' that I had actually been duped into paying money to purchase this bit of junk and "squirming" in frustration at the lameness of it all - praying that it would 'get better' as it went along - which it never did.As I have noted in some previous reviews of Zebub's works - it is sometimes difficult to determine whether the 'director' is taking himself seriously or if he is attempting to pull off a parody of sorts... "The Lesser Evil" continues this tradition of genre confusion. Regardless of whether this IS supposed to be satirical in nature or a truly 'disturbing' film I'd have to say that Zebub has pretty much failed in achieving either goal with this flik.The premise that is, doubtless, intended to provide the 'squirm factor' is the concept of: a young mother who is grabbed by a freakish ner-do-well who tells her that he has kidnapped her daughter and will harm the child if the mom doesn't participate in all the 'debasing' sex acts he has planned. This 'set-up' occurs in the most perfunctory manner in the first few moments of the plot and it's almost the only portion of the film where there is any spoken dialog. The 'bad guy' then takes the woman to a hotel room and begins to film her as he 'directs' her to perform a series of 'humiliating' sexual acts.  While this might sound like a formula to stir the libidos of the 'sick & twisted' amongst us - Zubub, and his 'actress' de jour (Rachel Crow), manage to make the perverse action seem totally banal.  A lengthy interview with Ms Crow is provided on the disk (ostensibly to 're-assure' the viewer that all the 'disturbing' action was just 'make-believe' - DUH!) wherein she speaks of 'pushing herself' as an actress... well she coulda fooled me! Throughout the entire proceedings Rachel shows not one ounce of 'emotion' and woodenly goes through the paces of whatever 'embarrassing' act she is miming at the moment!  As previously noted - there is virtually NO 'dialog' in the film - the action all takes place 'silently' - accompanied by a collection of weird satanic tonalities blaring away in the background - Zebub is a huge fan of this sorta 'death metal' dirge.On the 'prurience meter' "Lesser Evil" DOES provide A LOT of nudity as the 'victim' is commanded to strip, right off the bat, at the start of the feature and remains basically naked throughout - whilst her 'tormentor' looms over her with his video camera recording all the lack-lustre action for posterity.  The camera moves vary between annoyingly jerky POV type shots to bland static set-ups that create little excitement or drama as the girl is forced to: dis-robe, crawl around on the floor, use the toilet, and lay on the bed to be 'ravished' and stimulated with a Hitachi vibrator for 'our viewing pleasure'.
