I kept picking the book, reading a paragraph or two, then putting it back down.  I just could not get into the story.  And I really, really wanted to.Maybe if I had read other books by Ms. Valente, it would have made a difference.  But I don't think so.  A book should be able to stand on its own.

I found EAT BRAINS LOVE to be a fun, fabulous piece of brain candy - a great mental vacation from the rest of the world.  EAT BRAINS LOVE won't change your life, but it will make you grin broadly and laugh out loud.  Irreverent, corny, and oddly romantic, EAT BRAINS LOVE is definitely worth a read.EAT BRAINS LOVE is a YA novel which begins in (you guessed it) a high school.  Jake, your average, random, teenage boy wakes up feeling sick and weirdly hungry at the same time.  The next thing he knows, he has eaten his best friend (and 1/2 senior class) and is on the run with Amanda, the super popular hot chick that every high school has.  It seems that there is a virus on the loose, and it is turning people into zombies.  Now they are running from certain death at the hands of the government, learning how to control their "zombification," and trying figure out what is happening to them and the world.  There are rumors of a zombie sanctuary in Iowa.  But can they get there safely and without eating too many people?EAT BRAINS LOVE is a quick, light-hearted, easy-breezy read just perfect for a vacation or the beach.  The pacing is quick, the action is constant, and the romance is oddly appealing.  The ending is a cliff-hanger, but that just makes me eager for more.  I read the book cover to cover in about a day.  It was exactly what I needed to brighten my spirits.  EAT BRAINS LOVE is funny, quirky, and definitely unique.  I loved Warm Bodies, and EAT BRAINS LOVE definitely has the same appeal.  I can't wait for the next installment.

I love my red TYLT BAND FLAT DUAL CAR APPLE/USB CAR CHARGER.  First of all it is RED, which means it is identifiable a MINE and NOT one of the kids.  Otherwise, all my charging cables "mysteriously" disappear.  Second, I love that it is wide and flat.  It comes right out of the glove box (does anyone actually use the glove box for gloves anymore?) straight, untangled, and ready to use - no attempting to untie knots while driving.  Also, it is easy to find by touch, so you are never taking your eyes off the road.  Next, it will charge either an ipad (we always need more charging capability on long trips!) by itself, or two smaller devices (iPhone, blackberries, etc) at the same time.  That is a really, really nice feature.The only note that I would point out here is that the built in ipad connector is the old style.  If you have an ipad mini or an iPhone gen 5, you will need to provide the correct cable and plug it into the USB port.  But that would not stop me from buying more TYLT BAND FLAT DUAL CAR APPLE/USB CAR CHARGERs.  I find this cable really convenient and easy to use on long trips, and it is definitely well made, sturdy, and reliable.

Yes, I said sexy. Its also sleek and strangely enough, exciting. The WD MY PASSPORT has 1TB of storage with a USB 3.0 interface that is only about  of an inch deep and easily fits in your pocket. The odd part is the transfer speed. I plugged it in to my husbands Windows 8.1 desktop machine where it was recognized immediately. It comes with a bunch of stuff on it from Western Digital, but I shouldnt need any of it to transfers files. So I dragged 600GB of files from his machine to the Passport. Thats 828 files, the majority of which were over 1GB. The transfer started off with a bang, once hitting 90 MB/s but over the course of 2 1.5GB files, averaging between 60-70 MB/s. But after those 2 files went over, the bang turned to a whimper, dropping to an astonishing 1 MB/s. Okaaaay. I waited. It was now transferring consistently under 10 MB/s. Finally, I stopped it. My husband checked his drivers, the connections, etc. All were current but Windows had discovered a new Western Digital driver available through the Windows Update, so he installed it, and I tried again.This time, I tried a 100GB transfer. This time, the performance was much more reasonable, but still uneven. For long stretches, the transfer speed ranged from 60-70 MB/s. Then it would drop to 40-50 MB/s. For one small stretch it was between 90 and 100 MB/s. Throughout, the source drive was not being used for anything else. I wasnt looking at pictures of cats who cant spell or updating my Facebook page. Nada. So I dont understand the inconsistency, especially since all of the files in the second batch were over 1GB. And I dont understand why a new driver was required, but it seems to have made a big difference.After the transfer was complete, the unit was warm to the touch, but barely. Throughout, the unit was silent, or at least didnt add to the ambient noise.Id like to understand why the transfer speeds are not consistently in the 100MB/s range (or consistently within any range!) but I still plan to use this drive when I travel. Large capacity, small footprint, low weight, fast transfer. Martha says, Its a good thing.

This telltale game series is great! I have been playing every series released by them and they all are fun and entertaining including this one! I am not a huge fan of the borderlands but this game is great! All in all 4/5 stars for sure!
Well written espionage-for-kids story, using classic elements of the genre and adding a lot of cool twists. A great series for young readers to devour.
Lot of ingenious smoothie recipes here. It's a good idea to organize them around calories as sometimes smoothies can be deceptively fattening. These can all be enjoyed without adding on the pounds.
Nice anthology for avid Bible readers. I was reminded of a lot of amazing passages. A very pleasant way to pass a Sunday afternoon.

I like reading these books to stay fresh. Even if you've heard a lot of it before, there's often something useful gleaned. Kim Lambert's book is above average in this regard, with a lot of new, stimulating ideas for independent authors, wide-eyed greenhorns and cynical pros alike. For 99c it's an absolute must read for anyone in the business.
John Legg has rapidly become my favorite contemporary Western author on Kindle. Pitch perfect, very entertaining. Love it.

The first book was solid and this was a great sequel. With its strong female characters this should especially appeal to distaff fans of Westerns and pioneer stories, but recommended to either gender. A satisfying read.
Great page turner that riffs on the haunted house theme to good effect. The radio is a clever device. Recommended to fans of paranormal and anyone who likes a good scare!

Smart and comprehensive weight training guide which combines health advice with weight lifting instructions. This was just what I needed to get back into lifting. I keep it in my Kindle, read it at night and by morning am excited to implement what I learn. This is a substantive book and a real bargain at the current Kindle price.

Occasional paragraphs of insight are buried in endless pages of links which are a real chore to wade through. Worse, about half-way through, the book turns into a random anti-government rant which has nothing to do with Thailand - just a random rant about governments in general. There are also long 'chapters' of text listing 'super-books' - presumably collections of other books by the author (It is unclear as there are no links or no explanations as to what these random 'super-books' are, where they can be acquired or what they are doing in the middle of a book on Thailand).Weird, because the few lines of text about Thailand are actually quite smart and on the money. But the formatting is a disaster, the ridiculously long listings of links are absurd and the anti-government rant which has been smuggled into this book is offensive and has nothing to do with Thailand. Hence 1 star.
I've wondered for a while what all the fuss about coconuts was. This book explains why they are so good for you and also provides 50 recipes! A great deal.

A juicy, pulpy, twist-filled adventure-romance-mystery that kept me up late moving through the thrilling chapters. Author Lorraine Carey throws all kind of unexpected turns at the reader and the result is an enjoyable and entertaining guilty-pleasure read. Fun!
I enjoyed the first three books in this series and this (Book 4) was great. A good book to read on your Kindle with your young ones. Based on a Russian fairy tale.
I learned a lot from this book. After many years I am now able to broaden my spice use beyond peppers and salts! Lot of inspiring ideas here.

This is Book 3 in the Gordonston Ladies Dog series and it is a real winner. Fans of the first two books will relish the unique wit and phraseology of author Duncan Whitehead. Sit back and relax. Great read!

The theme of mortality is explored from many different angles in this new collection of verse from William O'Brien. It's a new theme for O'Brien and one he handles with his usual aplomb. If you haven't read him before, O'Brien write short haiku-like poems packed with emotion with turns of phrase that are novel and stimulative for the brain. He is a real wordsmith.

The set comes with 24 brushes, held inside a nice PU leather bag with a full range of brushes of different sizes and shapes that are nicely balanced.The brushes are sturdy and professional, great quality for the price.
I've really been enjoying these Alex Desephano books and this is the best one yet. The plotting is slick and it's action from the get-go. Good escapist read.
Cool new verse collection from William O'Brien, creator of the Peter books. The short poems are like floating thoughts, inspiring and stimulating.
This is a great collection of four smart works. A lot of wisdom here for the price. I especially enjoyed the book on neuro linguistics.
If you've ever wondered what you're doing wrong when self-publishing your books, it's probably not quite as bad as what you could be doing if you follow this guide! Very funny!

This is one of my favorite external batteries that I have purchased, and it works great for smartphones and tablets.Pros:Extremely smallExtremely InexpensiveNice colorsGreat texture (doesn't get scratches or fingerprints)Comes with adapters for different devices, and comes with flashlightCons:None!Overall, a fantastic external battery especially for only $12.99

(By far best feature, and can charger w/ any light source)Rugged DesignCharges smartphones and tablets.Cons:Only 1 USB portVery big for a 7200mAh External Battery (Because of solar panel)Charging via light is very slowOverall, a great product, a little pricey, but you get the extreme convenience of having solar powered charging capabilities.

Review by: iTechWorld11 (YouTube Channel)I received this product, and expecting it to be a pile of junk like the other reviewers were saying, I was actually surprised at the quality of the case.For starters, it is extremely easy to put the case on your Nexus 7, and when you do, it is kinda snug. It isn't super tight, however it certainly won't come off on its own. However, if you pull at the sides, it may start to peel off, but it's not that bad.The material is also pretty nice: a soft, durable, and smooth TPU type case. It is this material for the whole case, so you shouldn't have any problems with it scratching your screen.The cutouts for all the ports are perfect, the only problem being that the volume buttons and power button can be a but mushy, but it really wasn't that bad. Overall, from a cutout standpoint, it excels.However, the reason this case does not get a 5/5 is because of this: NO MAGNETS! The Nexus 7 has magnets built in for the ability to lock/sleep/unlock your device (I know because I accidently turned off the Nexus 7 with an iPad smart cover), however this case does not have magnets built in. This also means that the front cover flap falls open while being picked up/moved around. And this case is made by ASUS!! Asus is the manufacturer of the Nexus 7! I just don't get it!However, that is my only complaint, and with nice colors, I don't think that your $20 is being wasted.If you want to see a video review of this, check out iTechWorld11 on YouTube for a video review and more reviews of New Nexus 7 cases.

1:48 MinsReview by: iTechWorld11 (YouTube Channel)This is a pretty nice keyboard, especially for the ~$20 price tag. It looks just like the $69 Apple Wireless keyboard, connects very easily to bluetooth devices, and the battery lasts a long time. The typing experience is also pretty good. Definitely Recommend.You can check out the full review at youtube .com/itechworld11

Review by: iTechWorld11 (YouTube Channel)So I've been using this for over a week, and I have tested this out and drawn my final conclusions.SCREEN/CAMERA/DESIGNSo starting out with the screen, it has a 1920x1200 resolution full HD 1080p IPS display coming in at 323 pixels per inch, and man it's a beauty. The colors are vibrant, the viewing angles are fantastic, and everything about it screams high quality. This is the best screen I've seen on a tablet, including the Nexus 10 and iPad 3/4. The only problem about this screen is that few websites and apps support such a high quality display, so you'll have a diversity of clarity when using your New Nexus 7.On this Nexus 7 there is also a new rear-facing 5 MP camera with autofocus, and it's decent. It gets the job done, and for a tablet you can't ask for more. The front facing camera is decent, however the lack of autofocus can be a bit annoying.We also have a new backing to the Nexus 7. The old Nexus 7 (2012 Model) had a very nice back, but this one is even nicer. It is extremely smooth and slick looking. You have the Nexus and Asus logos, as well as your speakers and rear-facing camera. I'm a big fan of this polycarbonate-plastic back.Speaking of the speakers (get it?), they are fantastic. With stereo sound and Surround Sound built in, they sound fantastic no matter what you're listening to. They also get very loud, and you can just hear the great clarity with the new speakers.This tablet is also much thinner, at only 8.65mm thin, it is 1.8mm thinner than the original Nexus 7. Now, it is still thicker than the iPad Mini, but the Mini is scary thin. It is also very light, at .64 lbs (290 grams) it is 50 grams lighter than the 2012 Nexus 7. So obviously it is super portable, and part of the portability would be the new side bezels-or lack there of. Google has massively slimmed down the bezels and it makes holding it one hand a breeze for almost any hand type. However, sometimes it is hard to get a grip of the tablet without accidently touching the screen. But for some reason, Google made the top and bottom bezels much bigger, and it is pretty awkward to hold in landscape mode because your hands will be so far apart.SPEED:Google brought the 1.5 GHz Snapdragon S4 Pro CPU to this tablet, and it is super fast. Mixing it with 2 GB RAM, and you get a gaming powerhouse and performance screamer. Everything about this tablet is fast. (The only lag I found was in the web browser (Google Chrome, which is stock), which I found to be a very bad experience).The Wifi is also pretty fast, with Dual Band 2.4/5 GHz support, which is pretty much stander, but nonetheless still pretty fast. (Of course it mainly depends on the speed of your router)FINAL OPIONS/VALUE:So I am very impressed with this tablet. The only downsides would be the bad web browsing experience and the lack of QUALITY apps. Apart from those two, and you have a perfect (ish) tablet. For $229, it's a fantastic value. If you want to see more videos/reviews on the New Nexus 7 (including case reviews, unboxings, etc.) check out iTechWorld11 on YouTube.

Well, for one, this product was lost in shipment and ended up coming two weeks late. That does not have anything to do with my review.Some of the side pieces did not fit on my phone, and when I put a case on they started to peel. The back protector is slightly small, and does not cover up a part of the very top and bottom of my phone.Apart from those three problems, it was also difficult to apply correctly. This case looked very good in the pictures, and I decided to get it because it was pretty cheap. I was a little disappointed when I first got the case. I used it for a little while than took it off. Inside the package is a very nice sized microfiber cleaning cloth, which was a very nice addition.I put the case back on recently, and I really like it now. I can see the Apple logo on my white iPhone (doesn't work on black) with the light shining at a certain angle. The plastic bumper fits on nice and snug without any problems. The camera cutout is fine, and doesn't effect the flash. The buttons are all covered, and they work VERY well. I really like the feeling when I press the power/volume buttons. The case also offers a nice lay-on-the-table design which is also very nice.Overall a very nice case, I have the black version (which is no longer available from Amazon). Definitely worth the price. I also have an Anker Glaze Screen Protector, which I love. You can't really go wrong with this case.You can check out a review and unboxing of this case on my YouTube channel: iTechWorld11 or youtube .com/iTechWorld11

I got this looking to be able to take my Macbook Pro around without worrying about it getting dirty or hurt. When I first got this, (you can watch my unboxing at my YouTube channel: iTechWorld11) it was very difficult to put on. It didn't fit on very well, and it felt that it wasn't carefully designed.  The bottom piece often came of my Mac, and it left the battery indicator unreachable. It does have little white foam pieces to cover up the four rubber bumps on the bottom of your Mac, which is nice.  The top of the case was also difficult to put on, and didn't stay on completely. I finally got it to fit, but not after a while. This does allow the Apple logo to glow through, but only when your Mac is turned on.  This is a matte black polycarbonate case, and you CANNOT get rid of any liquid, fingerprints, or smudges (well, it is very difficult). Once on, it's on. This is a little annoying. I actually had a little mark on it, so I licked my finger to try to remove it, and it left a streak on the case from my finger, I got it to minimize, but there is still a good amount of evidence that it was there.  The included keyboard cover is awful. Don't get excited about it. I know I was, because I wanted to protect my keyboard from finger oils, crumbs, water, etc. It makes it VERY difficult to type on, and it can peel off if you accidentally if your arm brushes against it.  This case also adds a lot of thickness and weight to your Mac. Which makes me even  more envious of the MacBook Air, with this bulky case on it.  Overall, a decent case, but I wouldn't recommend it. To watch my full review visit my YouTube channel: iTechWorld11

I have had enough time with this case to know it is a keeper. The iPad mini sits in the four corners snuggly and I'm not afraid to go around with it. The stand postions work perfectly, and you are not limited to the positions that are on the case. It fully protects the iPad, and the magnets work great and do not get in the way. Would 100% recommend this case to anyone who is looking to protect their iPad and give it great functionality at a decent price.To see a full review of this case, check out my YouTube channel: iTechWorld11
I bought this looking to charge my iPhone 5 and iPad 2 with one charger, but only the top slot worked. My Ipod shuffle and iPhone worked charging together, though. For the price, not a bad value.

I purchased this screen protector looking to protect my screen (duh) to keep it in perfect resale condition. I was never a big screen protector fan, because it took away from the screen's nice smooth feel, and would fade some of the retina display's coloring. Well, this screen protector shattered those feelings.This screen protector was very cheap, which is the first pro. It also came with a dust removal sticker, bubble remover, 3x screen protectors, and a large cleaning cloth, another pro. And then when I installed it, I had zero bubbles or dust under the screen protector.This screen protector is invisible, (I even had the matte version), I could not find any proof that the screen protector was actually installed (besides the fact that I can't see fingerprints :). My favorite part about this screen protector is that it feels like it isn't installed! The screen is still as smooth, still as sleek, but has less glare/reflection (hence the matte part). I absolutely love this, and I will eventually forget that it is installed!Overall a very nice screen protector, well worth the price, considering you get 3 and all the extras.

I had one of these squeeze balls a few years ago and I loved it. I lost it a have since been looking for something similar to it. And viola! I found this. I was willing to take the risk of buying this (not knowing if it was exactly what I was looking for) since it was pretty cheap ($4).This stress ball is harder to squeeze than most stress balls, but far away from a tennis ball (it is hard enough that I can feel my veins when I squeeze hard enough). It is a nice size that can easily fit in your hand. The description is accurate: The inside feels like gel. You will not be able to break/rip this just by squeezing it. It is kinda bouncy. If thrown against a solid surface hard enough could get ~4 feet in the air.Overall  a very nice product for a low price, and helps with by keeping me occupied/calmed down throughout the day.Hoped this helped.

First let me tell you what I look for in a case: Something that protects the phone, without adding too much thickness or weight, something that adds or doesn't take away from the iPhone's great look, and something that is accessible with all the ports.This case isn't too bad for protection: has good sturdy sides with a clear plastic back. It also doesn't add too much thickness or weight.This case also looks nice..for the first five minutes. It smudges very easily, and the smudges don't want to get wiped off. The biggest problem, though, is the scratches. This thing scratches as much/more than a Speck Candyshell. It makes the iPhone looked scratched because of the clear back. It also shows scuffs very easily. The camera cutout doesn't interfere with the camera or flash, but I don't like how the cutout is below the glass on the back.The accessibility to the ports is fine, no problems with the buttons. The volume and power can be a little hard, but not a problem. The 30 pin to lightning connector normally works for me, but it doesn't feel like it would stay in forever.Overall, I wouldn't recommend this case to anyone, unless the price dips under $10, but for $20 (when I bought it), definitely not worth it.

This case is exactly what I was looking for. I have a white iPhone 5 and was looking for a case that had some protection, maintained most of the iPhone 5's thinness, and looked great. I got all of the things I was looking for.Protection:First of all, this is obviously no Otter Box or Speck Candyshell, but it's not meant to be. This case has a good lip on the front which allows you to put it face down without any problems. The back has the four raised orange parts, which will slightly elevate the back of your iPhone from the surface. This case will survive minor falls (from a few feet probably), but nothing drastic.Thinness/Size:Although you get okay protection from this case, it is pretty minimalistic. It is extremely thin and light, so you will barely remember it's there.Look:This case downright makes the iPhone 5 look gorgeous. It is not clear/orange like the case advertises, but a frost/orange. It adds a nice clean look to the back of the iPhone. You can very easily see the Apple logo and iPhone branding on the bottom. The orange also compliments the iPhone(both black and white). The front also looks nice with the orange border.Material: This case is a matte feeling polycarbonate case,with polyurethane borders(orange part). The back material is seemingly unscratchable. It also is anti-fingerprint. A great look and feel to the iPhone 5.Cons:I have three cons (only two big ones)1. The camera cutout does not in any way disrupt pictures taken on the device, but the cutout is a little big for my liking.(not big)2. Bottom piece below home button isn't supportive. It will sag with any amount of pressure. If you drop your phone and it hits the bottom, it will likely crack.3. EXTREMELY difficult to remove. Took me 5+ minutes, no exaggeration. If you are a person who changes cases a lot, I don't think I can recommend case for you.Overall, a very case. Would probably buy this case again if anything happened to it.Hope this helped.*Update* 11/13/12I have since stopped using this case for two reasons.1. The bottom piece has become very irritating.2. I don't feel safe enough with this case on my iPhone 5; not enough protection.

This earphones are great..for the price.I have been using these for almost all of my listening, apart from when I use my over-the-ear noise cancelling headphones. These earphones provide great sound quality, good bass, and stay in my ear very well.The design of these earphones are a little different than normal earphones, but that is a very nice feature to these earphones. They allow you to have the earphones in your ear comfortably without them coming out. The rubber that goesin your ear is oval shape, and the plastic that is used to keep it in your earOverall a very good buy if you're in the search for even a sub $25 pair of earphones. The only thing that would make this a little nicer (and could potentially add a little more to the price) is if they had a mic and pause/volume buttons attached.

We live in a cold climate and I have Reynaud's which means my hands and feet go white in the cold! These have been a complete lifesaver. They heat quickly and last for many hours. I often put them in my gloves about 30 minutes before heading outside to shovel or go for a walk, and by that point, they've warmed up the entire mittens ahead of time. You can just put them in when needed too, but I find that pre-heating the gloves works wonders for keeping the cold at bay. Love having a massive box of them so I don't try to skimp out on using them.

Bought this for my 14 month old nephew for Christmas. He was a bit unsure of how to use it at first, but has quickly become rather obsessed with it. It's very stable and perfect size for him. My sister loves that it folds up nicely - it's easy to store away for a few days if he gets bored of it, or to put it underneath the stroller for a trip to the park. It's really well made and I think he'll get quite a lot of use out of it. Highly recommended for the toddler set!

These are my mom's favorite tissues. She claims they're far superior to the regular Kleenex mini-packs. I can't really tell a difference but whatever makes her happy :-)They're really hard to find in stores now, and she was so excited to get them delivered. She wants me to buy a few more packages in case they discontinue selling them online as well.
Great gift for my 14-month old nephew. He likes to pull it around by the rope and take his toys for a ride. Very well made and sturdy.

Love this! I've tried lots of bubble baths and this is one of my favorites! Lots of bubbles and they last for the entire bath. It is moisturizing without being greasy. It has a faint scent of lavender but isn't overpowering at all. Definitely planning on restocking when this bottle runs out - that is the best compliment of all for a bath product fanatic :-) highly recommend!
Nice olive oil. I didn't realize how small the tin would be. It's still a good value but I've attached a photo next to a jar of jam for reference.

So many great combinations of veggies! I was so sick of leafy salads but this has helped take our salad game to the next level. I love how it's built around concepts - take Salad A and add Protein B or C. It helps to expand your cooking repertoire rather than just a bunch of recipes that stand alone. Delicious!

Love this case. After buying a few others that didn't work very well, this is a real winner. The iPhone 6 is a bit too big for my hand but the grip on this case help keep it from falling. The buttons work perfectly and the whole thing fits nicely. Going to buy another one (in another color) for someone else in our family!

Works well once it's paired. But there are a few downsides:(1) You have to re-pair it each time you want to use it. I'm not sure how long it 'remembers' the bluetooth pairing but it's annoying to go into the phone settings and reconnect to it each time. I'm on an iPhone 6 with iOS 8 so maybe other folks have had a better experience with that.(2) It can only be paired with one device at a time. If you're used to a Sonos speaker, this will be more annoying because only one person's phone can be matched with it at the same time. In our house, we're always removing the connection or re-adding the connection.(3) Gives some new life to an older Bose sound system. I'm glad to get some more use out of it, but I'll still save up to get a Sonos soon!

It seems a bit crazy to love a newly discovered laundry detergent, but this stuff is AWESOME. It really cleans like no other HE detergent out there. Whites are white. Clothes smell fresh without overpowering perfume.I want to buy a crate of this stuff so it never leaves my life! The detergent for colors is awesome too.

Love this! We have some cafe lights strung across our backyard, and they are plugged into an outlet in our detatched garage. Now I can turn them on from our backdoor! Super handy. Will probably get another kit for our Christmas lights this winter!

Bought these as replacements for my Clark desert boots. The original laces were frayed and these are wonderful replacements. The waxed coating helps to prevent them from coming untied throughout the day. The round laces look a bit dressier than the flat laces.

I've had about 8 or 9 different high end headphones over the last 5 years. These are awesome for a few reasons:WEIGHT: Really lightweight. They are much much lighter than most of my other headphones. This means they are comfortable on your head for many hours, and don't add much weight to your bag when you're carrying them around. Cannot overemphasize how comfortable they are.SOUND: Very full and rich sound. They are not officially "noise blocking" but the earcups are very solidly built and I can barely hear any ambient sound when they're on. They might not be as nuanced as some $300+ headphones but they are absolutely great.COMFORT: Ear cup material is very soft and comfortable. They don't press into the side of your head, nor do they slip around. I cannot believe how comfortable they are.USABILITY: I'm always forgetting to charge my noise-cancelling headphones and never seem to have enough batteries. It's such a pain to have one more thing to charge and maintain, and these do not require anything of the sort. You never have to wonder if your headphones will die in the middle of a flight or during a workday.All in all: there are higher-end headphones out there, so if you're a huge audiophile geek, you might want to look around a bit. While I'm not an audiophile, I am very particular about sound and ambient noise, and these absolutely fit the bill. They are the most comfortable headphones I own and are -- HANDS DOWN -- my new favorites.These would also make a great gift!

This is a great mask: - no velcro straps to get caught on your hair - ergonomically designed to prevent pressure on your eyes - extremely effective - very little light gets through - comfortable for wearing every nightUnfortunately, they do not last very long. I've had mine for about 5 months and the material is separating away from the inner foam. It has now peeled back almost entirely and I'll have to order another mask. I'm not very tough on it - I don't move around much when sleeping, haven't smooshed it in my bag for travel, and let it air out during the day.It's a great product for a few months, but does not stand the test of time.

I'm sure these have a great soundscape and fidelity and blah blah blah. But if you just enjoy listening to music at your computer, I think you'll find these are too bulky and too heavy. I'm planning on selling mine and getting something else.

Buy a bunch of these for new moms! They are so useful to keep on the changing pad while doing diaper changes - that way you're not constantly having to remove and replace the entire changing pad cover! Babies seem to love the feeling of cold air on their bottoms which is adorable but seems to result in a big mess ;-)
I actually really like the cherry flavor! They chew easily and it's helped my iron levels improve. It isn't constipating like other iron tablets either!

The material is really nice; it is soft like cotton but with a bit more structure. The top half of the shirt fits well and I like the length of the sleeves - not too small and not too large. The crew neck is also well designed and not too low. However, this shirt is extremely long and seems primarily designed to be tucked in, as it is shown in the photo. I bought the shirt to wear while working out and it looks really silly with my workout shorts and pants. It's not baggy at the bottom, but instead is quite slim, which is useful if you're tucking it in, but looks terrible if you have any sort of hips or butt and want to wear it untucked!I'll probably keep it as it seems annoying to return, but be warned that this shirt is designed to be tucked into your pants!

This is a great bubble bath! I start pouring a very fine line of bubble bath into the tub, right into the stream of water coming from the faucet. This technique gives me mounds of fluffy bubbles for soaking! Love the lavender scent - it's present but not overwhelmingly strong.

Love this fabric wash for my fine sweaters and shirts. The best part is not having to do a rinse afterwards - just soak, drain, roll up in a towel and lay out to dry! Lovely faint scent and seems to work well as a wash.

We used this in my partner's office. There is already wall-to-wall carpeting in her office, but she wanted to put down a cool vintage kilim. This worked perfectly. It's basically a huge double-sided sticker. Before you use it, make sure you've got the rug in the place you want it -- leave it there for a day or two just to be sure. It's not easy to move after you've put on this sticker-pad, so get it right the first time!This prevents the rug from flipping up on the corner, or moving around as people walk on it. A great problem solver!

My jade plant had some weird insect problem. It wasn't easily identifiable, and none of my usual remedies worked. Finally I saw this on Amazon and used it as a last ditch effort. It took two applications, but my jade is apparently pest-free again! Hurrah. It's probably toxic though, so keep it off of plants near kids or pets.

I bought a HUGE package of Epsom bath salts on Amazon and needed a place to store them in my bathroom. I love this simple glass jar without lots of scroll-work or other design. Simple and modern and perfect!

Love not having crazy fragrances coming out of my dishwasher - who needs Fake Rose or Faux Geranium stinking up their kitchen? This is phosphate free, pre-measured, and works perfectly well. We've got it set up as a subscription so we never run out!
Great replacement strap for a messenger bag. The material is comfortable and it looks like it was made for the bag!
My package says they are good until 2015 but they are very hard and brittle. Are they supposed to be this hard to eat?

We usually buy Musher's Secret, but at some point is stopped working as well. Maybe our tin was just dried up, or maybe it just wasn't working for our dog.This was featured in one of our local pet stores, and I picked it up as the material looked quite malleable compared to the stiffer Musher's Secret. This stuff is awesome - it's much softer and more "mushy" than Musher's Secret. This helps to really get it into the depths of the paw pads and saturate the fur around that area. It's not runny at all, just more like a thick paste rather than stiff wax.Highly recommended if you live in a snowy or cold environment. Our dog used to last a block before the salt and cold would start to hurt his paws and he'd do the whole "lift a paw and whimper" routine. After one paw was out, he'd hop along on three, but soon enough all of his paws would be too uncomfortable to continue. This stuff is truly "magik" and has allowed us to take wintery walks of up to an hour or more! In snow, on ice, on salted roads, etc.I'm not affiliated at all, just impressed with this product. It appears to be mostly natural ingredients such as beeswax, palm oil, almond oil, shea butter, coconut oil and a few others.We put it on right before a walk and so far haven't had any issues with it staining our floor or furniture.I'm purchasing another tub to have before this one runs out!

I had an Otterbox Commuter case, which I loved until it broke. It was also rather bulky and I am willing to go with a slimmer case now that my phone is older and I'm due for an upgrade :-)This case fits very snugly and has a nice feeling to it. Most charge cables are fine with it, but I have a few that don't fit at all, including the one that connects to my Bose speaker set.It's cheap enough so I'll keep it, but I wish the opening was a bit bigger.

No idea why people love this cutting board so much. If you don't need to save precious space and store a cutting board on top of your toaster oven, go with another option. This is tinny sounding (not solid) and even with oiling and taking care not to let it get wet for long, it seems to be dried out and splintering. I regret buying it and wouldn't recommend it.

I bought these for freezing herbs during the summer harvest. The cubes are bigger than standard ice cube trays and are awesome for this purpose! I freeze cubes of chives, parsley, cilantro, basil and various kinds of pesto. They are wonderful additions to soups, beans, sauces and even salad dressings all winter long!

LOVE these epsom salts. The shipping was fast (with Prime) and the salts were well packaged. I love epsom salt baths after working out or in the middle of winter, and this is a great package of high quality salts!
Farro is awesome. Healthy, substantial, versatile and delicious. It's a great substitute for rice. The pack of 3 is always well wrapped and has never ripped open while in transit.
Needed some non-slip socks for my Pilates reformer classes. I didn't like the socks with individual toes. These fit well and work as expected. Highly recommended!

Love this thin lap desk! Other lap desks tend to be very bulky and unwieldy with speakers and pillows and lights and little designs. This is a simple piece of rubber-like material that slips under your laptop so you don't get scalding hot thighs, and so your laptop fans run properly. Highly recommended!
I checked all the measurements, but this cushion did not fit my office chair (Steelcase Leap). It's much too thick and pushes my back forward too far. Seems like a decent construction though.

My dog actually likes this flavor! He refuses many other flavors of doggie toothpaste but actually likes the Vanilla/Mint. The enzymatic action is useful even if you can't clean your dog's teeth with a brush.
Great prop for our photobooth! It fits adult heads just fine and made everyone laugh. Would also be good for a halloween costume.
These are apparently delicious! They're small, soft squares. My dog loves them. We cut them into smaller pieces for training.
We used this as a photobooth prop. It would also be fine for Halloween or another costume. Not great quality but for the price, it worked well for the night!

The thermometer beeps after 30 seconds or 1 minute. It's supposed to indicate that the reading is complete, but it is NOT ready. Keep the thermometer in your mouth for a few minutes and you will know when the temperature stops changing on the display screen. It's annoying to have meaningless beeping!Otherwise it seems to work well. And yes, you can switch to Fahrenheit from the default Celsius. It stores the previous 10 temperature readings.

We've had those little packets of peanut butter for years, but I saw these on Amazon and decided to give them a try. I love the little dish of PB - it makes it easy to dip in crackers, vegetables, etc. The little squeezable packets are good in some occasions, but in general, this is a super handy little snack!

We purchased them as extra props at a photobooth at our wedding. The props were all a hit - I highly recommend some boas, fake glasses, 80s sunglasses with slats, some chalkboard bubbles for signs, and a few other quirky props like a huge magnifying glass, old fashioned phone handset, etc.

These protector seem to work well and have helped us reduce allergy symptoms. However, this model is a bit irritating - it's SO waterproof / airtight that air gets trapped in the pillowcase, and makes a kind of balloon effect out of the pillow. Then I have to unzip the zipper a bit, to squeeze out the excess air. Irritating. Does this not happen to other people? It doesn't happen with my other bed bug proof pillow protectors, so I'm not sure what the problem is here.

Got this as a blanket to cover our couch. We had another woven Ikea blanket that has worked perfectly for 3 years, but it's getting a little grubby, so I decided to try this one. Within two days it already had pulls in it, probably from our small dog's nails. Other blankets haven't had a problem so it must be something about this weave in particular. It's a nice color, good size and soft, but already looks terrible :-(

Love the entire Whitelines collection. The grid gives a bit of structure to your writing without being as distracting as regular lined paper. This is a great size to keep by your computer or in the kitchen for lists, notes and other reminders. Love them!
Bought this to recondition my hardwood cutting boards, wood spoons, salad forks and other wooden bowls. It worked well and gave them all a nice new shine!

The weave isn't as fine as the Chilewich placemats. But they are a close enough replica and good value for the price. A simple wipe cleans them after most meals, and they're easily rinsed when needed. No ironing needed :-)

The little clips don't fit into the fan grate on the back of my TV. And the mount itself isn't a good fit for the Roku 3. I'll make it work on both accounts, but it should probably be updated to reflect new TV styles and the new Roku.

Got this for a friend in the hospital. She's a fashionable 30-something and this has helped to pass the time while she undergoes chemo for cancer. I sent it with a big pack of nice markers and colored pencils, and it was apparently a hit. Send along some nice fuzzy socks with non-slip bottoms and you've got the makings of a nice care package :-)

A friend is in the hospital undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia. She is in her 30s and exhausted but a bit bored. She doesn't have much concentration for reading long pieces of material, but a coloring book was just the right amount of brain exertion! You often cannot send flowers, food or many other gifts to hospital wards, so I'm always looking for a good alternative. Get a bunch of adult coloring books, complete with a big pack of colored pencils and nice markers. They're great for the patient as well as visitors! There is lots of 'waiting around time' for visitors and family members, and this is a great little thing to have around the room to pass some  time.

A truly delightful look at 123 varieties of apples: their strengths, their weaknesses, and their uses.This is a not boring recitation of information about apples. The author injects some humor and interest into all the descriptions. He also includes history and fun facts. For example, did you know that the character of Rambo by David Morrell was named after the Summer Rambo apple? That the apple that led Isaac Newton to ponder gravity was a Flower of Kent?Other fun comments about various varieties:Of the Blue Pearmain: "This is the apple Elrond would have tended in his backyard in Rivendell, and it would have been off-limits to any dwarf or hobbit."Of the Knobbed Russet (a very ugly apple): "Uses: Terrify your children."Of the Dabinett: "Use: Don't eat fresh, unless sucking on tea bags is your idea of fun."Of the Red Delicious: "Texture: Both good and bad examples have that horrible leathery skin that likes to slide between your teeth and lacerate your gums....Use: Makes a great logo."Definitely recommended for foodies and lovers of apples.

2.5 starsMystic is a thoroughly unexceptional coming of age story. There is some promise to the plot and characters of Mystic, but the writing can be quite clunky, and for the most part it is derivative and formulaic.For example, Sim is the childhood friend of the young heroine Pomella, and Quentin the attractive newcomer. If Quentin was a fine, noble feast, Sim was comforting stew beside a warm fire. (P. 107 of the advance reader copy.) Regarding the High Mystic: Her slippered feet left no discernible footprints, as if she walked above the ground and not on it. (P. 112 of the advance reader copy.)There are no plot surprises, and I couldnt really picture any of the characters except Pomella. She is of color, which is a plus. Her nervous habit consisting of picking at her fingernails however  ugh.In an attempt to build his fantasy world, the author has the characters say yah instead of yes or yeah and use phrases like skivering luckn. I found the alternative spelling of common words like fathir and grandmhathir jarring and wondered why the author didnt just use English, as these words pulled me out of the story instead of in to it.It does not seem like this book is being marketed for kids or even young adults, but I found the plot and narrative to read quite young. I would suggest it is most appropriate for kids rather than adults or teens.I read an advance reader copy of Mystic.

"Keep your eyes peeled for a small black iron door. Down the road from a working-class British pub, along the brick wall of a narrow alley, if the conditions are exactly right, youll find the entrance to Slade House. A stranger will greet you by name and invite you inside. At first, you wont want to leave. Later, youll find that you cant. Every nine years, the houses residentsan odd brother and sisterextend a unique invitation to someone whos different or lonely: a precocious teenager, a recently divorced policeman, a shy college student. But what really goes on inside Slade House? For those who find out, its already too late. . . . ."That's the premise behind the newest offering from bestselling author David Mitchell. This fall, nine public libraries in Central Illinois partnered to celebrate reading through a program called Central Illinois Reads. Penguin Random House generously donated 100 advance reader copies of Slade House for us to distribute, and discussions took place in October before the book was officially released.I've never read Mitchell's Cloud Atlas or The Bone Clocks, but I don't think that affected my reading of Slade House too much. While Slade House does not bristle with originality, I was pulled in to the story after a slow start, and it is a very quick read. The language is rich and playful, and I was even surprised by some English phrases I didn't recognize. If you are looking for a short, spooky, seasonal novella to creep you out, look no further than Slade House. It's like a sweet but insubstantial Halloween treat.Bonus points for mention of the abbey on the Hebridean Isle of Iona (which I have visited and is suitably spooky) are slightly reduced by an eye-rolling mention of Hotel California (which I've been singing on and off since I first read the description of Slade House).Thank you to Penguin Random House and netgalley.com for advance reader copies of Slade House.

The Haunted Season is the fifth book in G.M. Malliets Max Tudor series. Max is a former MI5 agent who left after his partner was killed in front of him. Now an Anglican priest in the quaint village of Nether Monkslip, he is married to his soulmate Awena, a pagan and owner of the local New Age shop. They have come to terms with their different beliefs and have a new baby, Owen.Much to the chagrin of his bishop, Max keeps getting involved in murders. This is a textbook cozy mystery series, full of quirky side characters, coincidences, and the occasional dead body to cause gossip and give the vicar an excuse to show off his deduction skills and intelligence.None of the books have lived up to the first, but this one was pretty enjoyable. Life seems a little too perfect for Max, and Owen is the most ridiculously well behaved and intelligent baby. There is a nice nod about halfway (p. 183 in the digital advance reader copy) to Agatha Christie, the master of the cozy mystery:I was just thinking that the genius of Agatha Christie was not that she saw the universal traits of mankind, like Shakespeare, but that she saw we are all quite different people, with differing motivations.The book has some flaws. The murder itself  decapitation by a trip wire while the victim was riding a horse  seems unlikely to come off so seamlessly or to take off a head entirely. The author relies a little too heavily on coincidence (the new curate overhears two of the main players in the crime discussing it miles from Nether Monkslip, for example), and there is a long, long (too long) section in which details of the crime are explained by Max and Cotton to Awena. A scene in which Max runs towards danger while carrying his baby is ridiculous. I cant believe Max wouldnt have thought first of the babys safety. But I have these kinds of minor complaints about many cozy mysteries.The book ended strongly, with the last line catching me off guard and piquing my interest about the next book in the series.I read an advance reader copy of The Haunted Season.

Shadow Mountain Publishing has a line of books called Proper Romance. They are clean romantic reads without sex, violence, and bad language. I've read quite a few Proper Romances and find the line a welcome addition to the world of romance novels.The newest is Lord Fenton's Folly by Josi S. Kilpack, which has a gorgeous cover. I really enjoyed A Heart Revealed, Kilpack's previous Proper Romance, which concerned a woman during the Regency period suffering from profound hair loss.Lord Fenton's Folly also addresses an issue of the times - what to do with a child with mental impairment - but it's a minor side plot this time around. Lord Fenton does not respect his father and tried to embarrass him by playing the foppish fool and adopting macaroni fashion. His father, fed up with the behavior, lays down some ultimatums that Fenton must agree to or be disinherited. One of the conditions is that Fenton must marry. On his mother's advice, he proposed to Alice, a young woman he knew as a child. She has had a crush on him for ten years and thinks he feels the same. She is angered and hurt when she finds out otherwise.They marry all the same, and the novel watches them deal with personal crises, learn family secrets, and gradually come to rely on and love each other.I did not enjoy Lord Fenton's Folly quite as much as A Heart Revealed. It was very slow moving, and I would have liked more character development during the long period in which the young married couple was estranged. Lord Fenton in his foppish persona annoyed me as much as he annoyed his father. There are frequent references to witty banter, and yet there isn't much witty banter in the dialog. I was definitely ready for the "falling in love" stage of the marriage before it finally happened.Still, I am happy to have this category of romance to recommend to readers who want a clean love story, to lovers of Regency romances, and to Jane Austen fans. I read a digital copy of Lord Fenton's Folly.

This is more of a 3.5 star book than a 4 star book, but since Amazon doesnt allow half stars, Ill go with 4.The narrative of An Inheritance of Ashes grabbed me right away. It is hard to figure out whats going on, but still I wanted to KNOW. Hallie is 16. She and her older sister Marthe are trying to hold on to the family farm. Marthe is pregnant with her first child, and her husband has not returned from the far-off war he travelled to fight. Marthe and Hallie have an angry, uncommunicative relationship. Their father forced his own younger brother off the farm years ago, and now Hallie is afraid her sister will do the same to her.The world building is, frankly, odd. Its dystopian, but whatever returned civilization to a more primitive time happened decades ago. Now, strange, twisted creatures that burn whatever they touch have come into our world from another. A hero named John Balsam ended the war against them by tearing a hole through the other world, but the twisted things are still showing up on the farm. Hallie, her neighbors, and a mysterious veteran who arrived at the farm seeking work and shelter for the winter must band together to figure out what is happening and save not only the farm but their entire community.I found the twisted creatures on top of the dystopia a bit much. It seems unlikely that both scenarios would happen  the twisted things are never connected to whatever events crashed civilization in the first place. It might have been more effective to set the story in an unnamed primitive society rather than a fallen civilization. It just really didnt make sense to me, but it  also didnt bother me *that* much. I still enjoyed the story.I liked some of the overwritten but unusual language, such as Heron stood before me, stiff and unshaken, his peculiar grace bleeding into the very air. It wasnt just northern manner, it was his sense of calling: the way a person held themselves high when they were devoted, without compromise, to something greater than themselves. (p. 45 of the advance reader copy) There is some cringe-worthy dialog, especially between Hallie and the young man who wants to court her, to balance out the nice stuff.The relentless negative relationship between Marthe and Hallie was hard to take at times, and the identity of the mysterious veteran is likely to be obvious to every reader even though it is not to the characters in the book. But I raced through this book and recommend it to readers who like dystopian coming-of-age stories. (Also, it has a gorgeous cover!)I read an advance reader copy of An Inheritance of Ashes from netgalley.com.
For the price, this was just what I needed to wear to a library Batman Day. I will note, I am not a teen or in my 20s and I wore a thin black shirt underneath as well as capri pants.

Hundreds of years in the future, Earth is run by an artificial intelligence. Originally human, turned into an AI in a quest for immortality, Talis took advantage of access given to him by people at the UN and forced the people of Earth to stop fighting wars. First, he blew up cities to get their attention. Then he took the children of all the leaders  the Children of Peace  to hold hostage against their good behavior. If there is war, the children of the leaders die.Greta, the narrator of Erin Bows book The Scorpion Rules, is one of those children. Canada is now the Pan Polar Confederacy, and she is the daughter of their Queen. If the Children make it to the age of 18, they are sent home and new hostages are taken. If their countries go to war, the Children disappear to some unspeakable end.We see Greta and the other Children her age studying in their classroom and doing chores on the farm. The characters are not particularly well drawn or memorable. Greta takes great pride in maintaining calm and control. The new boy, Elian, does not. He takes pride in defiance and anger, no matter how he is punished. There is much punishment in this book, and torture. The torture is not graphic but it is extremely evocative, and I found it hard to read.For the most part, the narrative engaged me. Despite my intense dislike of torture scenes, I did feel compelled to keep reading. I often enjoyed the authors way with words, like in this passage: Elian reached up and took one of my wrists, stopping the motion, looking me up and down. Im sure he was trying for as a man looks at a woman, but it came off rather more as an engineer looks at a bridge pylon. (p. 63 of the advance reader copy). At other times, the language was a bit overwrought (I closed my fingers around the gun, and rose to my feet like the Lady of the Lake. (p. 173))The ending of The Scorpion Rules surprised me, and the plot took a few turns I did not expect. There is a love triangle of sorts. Granted, it is an unusual triangle  a girl with feelings for a boy and a girl  but still, cant we be done with love triangles? That aspect of the plot was so, so tired. Greta also develops strong feelings of some sort for Elian almost immediately  not quite insta-love, but insta-something.Some cultural references fell flat, like a bad football joke and mentions of the Road Runner.  In his Utterances, Talis actually says, Resistance is futile. (p. 26 of the advance reader copy). Also, some scenes were a little too reminiscent of The Hunger Games series. For example, Greta is to be tortured, with coverage sent to her mother by video. The producer, Burr, paces about checking camera angles and noting things on a clipboard. He wants the other Children nearby for reaction shots. This scene reminded me very strongly of The Hunger Games (as did the repeated use of the words Tick Tock Clock Drop). But I guess it is hard to write a dystopian teen novel and not be compared to The Hunger Games.The Scorpion Rules is a first book in a series. It does not stand alone. This is a good thing if you really enjoy it and want more. The ending really left a lot of room for exploration in the next book. I would recommend The Scorpion Rules for readers of young adult literature who arent yet tired of dystopian works and also for questioning teens, as Greta is also questioning.I read an advance reader copy of The Scorpion Rules.

Kitchens of the Great Midwest is a series of short stories set in the Midwest all loosely connected to one main character and to food. I dont normally care for this kind of narrative, but at least Kitchens of the Great Midwest moves forward chronologically instead of jumping around in time.I found it slow starting but really enjoyed it once I got into it. Chapters are set in Minnesota, Illinois, Iowa, and South Dakota. Sad things happen, and touching things, but there is joy as well. We see inside the heads of a variety of Midwesterners, all of whom have a deep connection to food. Some recipes are included, and the plot is very up to date with the latest foodie trends.I was left wondering what happened to some of the characters we met in various chapters and heard little or nothing more about, but thats a sign of a well written short story. I do wish the book had a character chart, because Im sure I missed some of the connections in the final chapter (which brings many of the characters together).The book serves as a sort of recipe itself  a recipe for the life of one child born in the Midwest to Midwesterners whose life is focused on food.I recommend Kitchens of the Great Midwest most for foodies from the Midwest, but other lovers of quirky literary fiction should also give it a try.I read an advance reader copy of Kitchens of the Great Midwest.

M.C. Beaton has been publishing books about Agatha Raisin since 1992. I am a loyal Agatha Raisin fan and have read all 26 books in this cozy mystery series. There hasnt been much new in recent titles, but a new entry is still a fun read. I enjoyed Dishing the Dirt more than the last three books. It seemed a little more light-hearted.Having said that, the thing that intrigued me the most as I read Dishing the Dirt was the body count. Three dead bodies by page 34. Four dead bodies by page 57. Five dead bodies by page 70. Six dead bodies by page 96. Seven dead bodies by page 124. This is not a plot that takes itself too seriously! And weaving in and out amid the carnage is Agatha and her normal crew  James, Charles, Bill, Toni, Phil, Mrs. Bloxby. Mrs. Bloxby even gets a fun plot development of her own! (About time.)This is a great read for a plane ride, an afternoon at the beach, or other circumstances where total concentration is not necessary or possible. Its verra silly, as Beatons other series character, Hamish Macbeth, might say. And as has happened before, there is practically a whole other book in the Epilogue, with a teaser for the next book in the series.Dishing the Dirt is a definite recommend for die-hard Agatha fans. Settle in for a visit with our aggravating but lovable old friend in the charming Cotswolds village of  Carsely.I read a digital ebook from netgalley.com.

"Mischievous adult bear, No matter how hard it bites, scratches, or how far he goes, I have faith that its a gesture of Love!!!"I collect all the Dals dolls ever produced, and Gloomy Bear Dal was the first I seriously considered not buying. However, I'm glad I did. She is utterly ridiculous in her massive bear suit, and her little under-outfit is very odd (but based on a character). However, she actually has a very clean, pretty face. Her lips look odd in photos but are much cuter in real life. She has gorgeous dark brown eyes. Her wig is of normal quality - not fabulous, not terrible. She has as much appeal as a novelty as Gloomy Bear does, but her faceup also makes her a unique and interesting Dal.If you are a fan of Gloomy Bear, I recommend her. If you are a fan of Dal doll, she's an interesting addition to a collection (especially as long as she is priced below $40 - way below her original price).Dal dolls are not for small children. They are jointed plastic and will break with rough play.

The Perilous Sea is not quite as good as The Burning Sky, but I still enjoyed it tremendously.With no explanation, the narrative switches back and forth between two timelines involving Titus and Fairfax. In one, they have no memories of themselves or each other but are in grave danger in the Sahara Desert. In the other, they are back at Eton with their classmates.There is a lot more romance in this book than in the first in the series. Minor characters are fleshed out and secrets are revealed. The plot definitely moves forward and ends with a grand set-up for book three. A well-built world, interesting characters, and a twisty plot - what more could I ask for? Looking forward to the third book. Now I'm going to get my hands on the audio version so I can hear it again to pick up what I missed the first time through.I recommend the series for Harry Potter and other fantasy fans who enjoy alternative looks at our own world and don't mind a bit of romance. You need to start with the first though - you would definitely be starting in the middle with The Perilous Sea.

In The Mathematicians Shiva by Stuart Rojstaczer, Rachela Karnokovitch, a ground-breaking woman mathematician, has died. A large cast of eccentric mathematicians and family members gather to honor her, mourn her, remember her  and try to find her notes on solving the Navier-Stokes problem, one of the most important (and real) problems of the math world.I picked up this book because of the presence of an African Grey parrot (spelled Gray throughout the book but not on the cover; youd think an editor would have caught and fixed that), but the parrot does not have a large role in the plot. The parrot speaks only Polish, and some of the mathematicians think the parrot might unknowingly provide clues to Rachela Karnokovitchs work on that math problem.A Pole who escaped to Russia with her father during World War II, she eventually immigrated to the United States and settled in Wisconsin. The book is narrated by Sasha, her one son.I found this novel a bit of a slog. I knew a book called The Mathematicians Shiva would mention math, but I did not expect it to contain actual math problems! And diagrams!  What a nightmare!If you understand, agree with or are amused by this quotation, you might enjoy this book: Maybe the most insulting thing you can say to a mathematician is something to the effect that math is all about numbers. Arithmetic is all about numbers and none of the people in the room gave a damn about arithmetic. (p. 195 of the ebook)The book is filled with words and phrases in Polish, Russian, Hebrew, and Yiddish (at least, I think there are words from all those languages), which made the reading slow going for me. The words are not always translated, and understanding them from context was work. The many references to traditions of the Jewish faith and culture that are unfamiliar to me also slowed down my reading.The Mathematicians Shiva is well written, it was just hard for me to relate to. The book ends very strongly, if you can make it that far. I recommend this book for readers of fiction set in Wisconsin, stories about trailblazing women, and books about math. (Not arithmetic.)

Youve heard of the Marshmallow Test. A child is presented with a desirable treat and given a choice  eat one now, or wait a bit and get two later. Versions of this test have been in use for over 50 years. In his book The Marshmallow Test: Mastering Self-Control, Walter Mischel talks about the test and also about its implications for behavior later in life.The ability to delay gratification, it turns out, is critical for a successful life, and reading this book made me think about my own behavior, goals, and self-control. Its not a fast read but contains thought-provoking statements like this:To resist a temptation we have to cool it, distance it from the self, and make it abstract. To take the future into account, we have to heat it, make it imminent and vivid. To plan for the future, it helps to pre-live it at least briefly, to imagine the alternative possible scenarios as if they were unfolding in the present. This allows us to anticipate the consequences of our choices, letting ourselves both feel hot and think cool. And then hope for the best. (p. 108 in the ebook)And this:The traditional belief that willpower is an inborn trait that you either have a lot of or you dont (but cannot do much about it either way) is false. Instead, self-control skills, both cognitive and emotional, can be learned, enhanced, and harnessed so that they become automatically activated when you need them. (p. 171 in the ebook)I am not a scientist, and some of the text was a little too scientific for me. But there are plenty of fascinating stories about the techniques kids use to resist the treats to balance things out a bit. The text seems very well researched. I wasnt riveted, but I found The Marshmallow Test well worth reading. I recommend it for fans of Freakonomics, Mindless Eating, Stuff, and Quiet.

Death Comes to London is the second book in the Kurland St. Mary mystery series by Catherine Lloyd. The series is set during the Regency.  The second book isnt quite as good as the first, Death Comes to the Village, but it was still a four-star book for me.The growing romance between the independent Lucy Harrington, attempting to find her beautiful sister a husband during Londons season, and Major Robert Kurland, still recovering from a war wound and now being offered a baronetcy by the Prince Regent for his heroism, is slow but steady.  Some of the science seemed a little modern for the time, but on the whole the historical details seemed true. The mystery is a bit over the top, with too many plot details and too many deaths, but the book was still an entertaining and diverting read. I recommend the series to cozy mystery and fans and lovers of Regency novels.

Finally, a Dal with freckles! They seem randomly scattered too, so I wonder if each Chenille will look a little different. Her hair has a nice silky feel to it, and her faceup is adorable. I'm not a big fan of the animal suits, but I have to admit I like Chenille's just because she is so ridiculous, and because she is an Alice character, and also because the backside is easily removeable. She is a cute character and a cute Dal - I'm sure she will be lovely out of her caterpillar suit. And she is a normal priced release! (And an incredible bargain on Amazon right now.)Please note - these dolls are for the responsible collector. They are not intended for small children.

Under a Silent Moon is the first in a new series. I love a good British police procedural, and this is a good one. The main character is Louisa Smith, a new Detective Chief Inspector. She had a brief relationship with one of her now subordinates, before she knew he was married. Shes attracted to the geeky Canadian analyst.The author is a police intelligence analyst, and it shows. The investigation and language feels authentic. Lou is an interesting character, and a number of supporting characters were well drawn with room to grow.The mystery was okay; I find the whole BDSM angle a little overdone these days but it was fine. I enjoyed reading this book and look forward to a sequel.

Imogen Rockford is a normal American teenager with a secret  she is part of the British Rockford Dynasty. Her grandfather was the Duke of Wickersham  a title just below royalty. Although she never expected to inherit the title and the manor, as her father was the second son, she finds herself with both. Her grandfather is dead, his two sons and their wives are dead, and her cousin Lucia is dead. Imogen is all that remains of her family.When Imogen leaves New York for England, she does so under a mysterious warning that came in an anonymous letter. She is filled with questions about how her cousin died, whether she is in danger, whether she herself is quite normal -- and how that cute boy she had a crush on as a child will react to her return.The attempt at gothic suspense is a bit over the top at times. (Lucias hairbrush, perfume, and makeup are arranged in orderly fashion on her vanity, and its then that I recognize the jasmine scent that has been wafting in and out of my bedroom over the past weeks. The scent is HER PERFUME. (p. 157 in the advance reader copy))Suspicion is competently written and is sure to delight any teen who would enjoy a slightly spooky paranormal mystery with a likable heroine and a touch of romance (despite the completely unbelievable plot twist at the end). The book cover is breathtaking and it alone will convince many a teen to give this book a try.Although not presented as such, Suspicion is surely meant to be the first book in a series, and I see more adventure (and much more romance) for Imogen in future books.I read a digital advance reader copy from Netgalley.

I read What Makes This Book So Great by Jo Walton for a couple of reasons. First, I love Jo Walton. Her book Among Others inspired me to start a science fiction/fantasy book discussion group at my library. That brings me to my second reason  I was hoping to get some good titles from this book for my group to read.Jo Walton has read a lot more science fiction books than I have. Wow, has she ever. Reading What Makes This Book So Great was so similar to Among Others in some ways that I started to wonder if Among Others is not a novel but a memoir, and there really ARE fairies in Wales. In both books Walton throws out a lot of titles and authors for the science fiction readers consideration.I enjoyed the book overall because it was like chatting with someone I dont know well but like. The book is made up of a series of blog essays that were no doubt meant to prompt online discussion. The online discussions are not included. Some of the essays were fairly meaningless to me because I have not read the books or authors being discussed. However, I was definitely able to glean enough information about many works to decide whether or not to add them to my potential book club titles list. (Whether I can get my hands on enough copies of out of print books is another question.) By the time I finished What Makes This Book So Great, it was filled with little pieces of paper on pages I wanted to go back to.Some of my favorite musings from this book:There are two kinds of people in the world, those who re-read and those who dont. No, dont be silly, there are far more than two kinds of people in the world. There are even people who dont read at all. (What DO they think about on buses? (p. 17)Fantasy, post-Tolkien, has been largely involved with retelling Tolkien, or revolting against Tolkien. (p. 342  too true, but I like the way she said it)The Suck Fairy is an artefact of re-reading. If you read a book for the first time and it sucks, thats nothing to do with her. It just sucks. Some books do. The Suck Fairy comes in when you come back to a book that you liked when you read it before, and on re-reading  well, it sucks.  Suck Fairies travel in battalions. Her biggest siblings are the Racism Fairy, the Sexism Fairy, and the Homophobia Fairy.  Then theres the Message Fairy. The lovely story you remember as being a bit like The Phantom Tollbooth has been replaced by a heavy-handed Christian allegory! (pp. 420-422)If you are a hard core science fiction reader, or want to be, I definitely recommend What Makes This Book So Great. Even if I cant choose some of these titles for book club, I will add them to my own to-read list!

Unlike some of my friends and coworkers, I was not a huge Laura Ingalls Wilder fan growing up. I read the Little House books, but I dont remember them having a big impact on my childhood reading. Laura Ingalls Wilder is woven into the literary mystery that is the plot of Bich Minh Nguyens novel Pioneer Girl.Narrator Lee Lien is the daughter of two Vietnamese immigrants. Her father is dead; her mother and grandfather run a restaurant in the Chicago suburbs. Lee has disappointed her mother by getting a PhD in literature instead of something more practical. She continues to disappoint her mother by searching for work in her field, instead of resigning herself to the family business.Lee is jealous of her older brother, who she sees as her mothers favorite, and complains about her mother constantly. The family has an heirloom and a story. In 1965 a woman named Rose visited her grandfathers caf in Saigon and left behind a small gold pin. The pin sounds like a gift given to Laura Ingalls Wilder by her fianc and described in one Wilders books. Lee becomes obsessed with trying to discover whether the Rose from the family story was Wilders daughter Rose.There are some great passages in Pioneer Girl. There is a spot-on description of American Chinese buffets at the start of Chapter Three and this musing on small towns in the Midwest:"Mansfield, Missouri reminded me of how the past will not be banished. So many small, dying, basically dead towns in the Midwest looked like this. Where once-graceful, ornate courthouses and libraries  back when libraries meant something important, something civic  had been, if not torn down or boarded up, converted dozens of times over into shops and offices and apartments and barely surviving historical societies. There might even be the remains of an ambitious opera house. The nicest building in town was likely to be a funeral home.Main Street had been built broad, to accommodate horses, buggies, and hitching posts. And surely local efforts tried to preserve the historic downtown area. Surely there were sad little parades on Memorial Day or the Fourth of July. In Mansfield a few local shoppes offered olde-fashioned ice cream and sewing notions, but it looked like most of the money was flowing in and out of the paycheck advance and pawn shops." (p. 140)Still, I had some issues with the novel. The narrator is not very likable. In addition to being a whiner, she is a thief. While doing research, she steals a photograph, a letter and a book. She talks about racism, ignorance about Asian culture, and stereotyping, but she herself stereotypes, and not in a self-aware manner."A small band of researchers squinted over Hoovers notes and newspapers, setting up cameras on tabletop tripods to record their findings. They were a standard lot  frumpy and frowning, pallid and disheveled." (p. 76)At times I felt that the author was judging the Midwest and finding it wanting (and once the narrator refers to the University of Illinois as UI, something no true U of I graduate would ever do). There is a random, out-the-blue sex scene between Lee and someone she just met that seemed pointless.However, especially in light of recent high profile cases in the U.S. of unarmed black men being killed by white police officers, the themes of this book are quite timely, and I loved the books cover. If you are a fan of literary mysteries or novels dealing with stereotyping and race in America, you may find Pioneer Girl an interesting read.

I'm a big fan of the film The Princess Bride, so I eagerly anticipated As You Wish, a book about filming the movie written by Dread Pirate Roberts actor Cary Elwes.The making of The Princess Bride was clearly one of the highlights of his career and life. If you are looking for dirt, don't look to As You Wish. Elwes is effusive in his praise of his costars and the crew behind the movie. Everyone was beautiful, talented, and perfect for their roles.The sugary sweetness of the narrative was a little hard to take at times, but I thoroughly enjoyed As You Wish all the same. Elwes spends a lot of time talking about what he and Mandy Patinkin went through to create what Goldman described in The Princess Bride script as the "second-best" swordfighting sequence on film (according to Goldman, the "best" comes later in the movie). The fight and the training were very interesting to read about. The only part of the fight not filmed by the two leads were the flips - wow! That had to be a lot of hard work.I definitely got the impression that Elwes is trying to give his career a shot in the arm by publishing this book. However, his true affection for The Princess Bride and its cast and crew came through.As soon as I finished the book, I was ready to run off and rewatch The Princess Bride. If you are a fan, that alone is a good reason to read As You Wish. I definitely recommend it for all Princess Bride fans.I read an advance reader copy from Netgalley of As You Wish.

Vendettina is the second Dal to be released in 2014. She was made for San Diego Comic Con and is a Tokidoki collaboration superhero with a limited edition of 250. So far as I can find, she does not have a Feel Like So.The box is adorable, covered in Tokidoki artwork.Vendettina has a gorgeous faceup, with blue and purple accents. Her hair is a bit kinky out of the box, but soft and lovely with streaks of neon yellow and pink. Mine has a nice stiff body.Her outfit is mostly pleather. It will likely stain over time. The inside of her cape also sports Tokidoki artwork. She comes with a mask, a staff, and a hair accessory. She does not come with a collector card. In all that black she is clearly the anti-hero!All in all, she is a great Dal, dark and full of attitude. If you are a fan of Dal, I highly recommend getting her.

In 1932, a man named Harm Drenth (also known as Harry Powers) was executed. He had been convicted of killing a woman named Dorothy Pressler Lemke in his home of Quiet Dell, West Virginia, but it is thought that he killed dozens if not hundreds of other women.
