The bodies of Asta Eicher, a widow from Park Ridge, Illinois, and her three children were found in the same grave as Dorothy Lemke.Author Jayne Anne Phillips was told the story of what happened in Quiet Dell by her mother, who was six years old when her own mother walked her past the scene of the murders. Jayne Anne Phillips was inspired by this family connection to write her novel Quiet Dell.Quiet Dell is well researched and contains many known facts about Drenth and his crimes. It contains a few black and white photos and quotations from newspapers of the time. But it is not true crime nonfiction. It is a fictional retelling.The book begins in December 1930, focusing on the Eicher family. The narrative is gripping; I was pulled into the story from the start. Asta and her three children prepare for Christmas dinner with their friend and former boarder, Charles OBoyle. Asta is in desperate financial straits, and although he is gay, Charles wants to marry her and help raise her children. He already considers their family his family and dreams of changing his ways. Asta dreams of the letters she keeps hidden upstairs and of the man who wrote them. The correspondence began through a lonely hearts ad; she hopes to meet him in person in the spring.The Christmas celebrated in Quiet Dell is a charming look at a loving family. The children put on a play. They enjoy a fine meal and go sledding. The beloved family dog, Duty, participates in most aspects of family life, including the Christmas play. But the sad thread of what the future holds for the family runs underneath the narrative.Although the narrative is fictional, it is mostly based on real people. That changes after first Asta and then the children are taken away by a man known as Cornelius Pierson. Fictional characters are introduced. One of them is a modern professional woman, a journalist who covers the trial. She forms a very sudden and lasting attachment to one of the real people depicted in the book, which was a bit jarring. Another fictional character becomes friends with Charles OBoyle. I wondered whether any relatives of the real people are still alive and what theyd think of the liberties the author takes.I was very interested in the coverage of the trial, but found the romance heavy-handed and distracting. It reminded me of how I feel about the movie Titanic. There is so much real drama in these stories that the added fictional drama feels unnecessary.The novel is also a bit fanciful. We are set up from the beginning to know that Annabel, the youngest Eicher child, is special. You are not like others, her (fictional) grandmother tells her. Your dreams see past us. (p. 8) Indeed, after Annabel is murdered, her spirit remains and narrates some chapters of the story.This book is well written but will not be to everyones taste. I enjoyed it as an alternative to reading a nonfiction retelling, but theres much speculation, and its hard to know what is real and what is made up. I recommend Quiet Dell to people who like books that meld fact and fiction and who enjoy imagining what real people in a sensational event thought and how they felt.

I wish I could give this book 4 and a half stars, but since Amazon won't let me, I'll give it four. I explain why at the end. It's a great book - a long tale that you just want to keep going. The world building is excellent. I'm looking forward to the last book in the Kingkiller Chronicle.The main character, Kvothe, is fascinating. Flawed, likeable, mysterious, proud, with a grim and terrible sense of right and wrong. He is intelligent and talented but does not always know his own limits. And what has brought him to his current situation, an innkeeper unable to defend himself against two robbers and waiting to die?Some passages in this book were an absolute delight. One of my favorite sections was the end of chapter 123, when Kvothe is tested by the Adem. His solution is novel and clever. "You are one great gaudy showboating bastard, you know that?" asks his teacher afterwards. "Seriously, it's like you stepped out of a storybook."I loved the Adem and their hand language. I would have liked Tempi to leave with Kvothe so we could see more of him.Another intriguing character is Master Elodin. A kook, but one of great depth and power, with a method to his madness. I wanted to know more after Kvothe idly asked him (thinking of his friend Denna), "What would you think of someone who kept changing their own name?""What?" [Elodin] sat up suddenly, his eyes wild and panicked. "What have you done?" ... "Oh, CALLING names. God's bones, boy, I thought...." (p. 978) We know names are important and give you power, but can one really change one's name? I hope this is explored more in the last book.Anyway, Rothfuss is a great writer, and if you like a good long adventurous fantasy tale, you definitely should read The Name of the Wind and The Wise Man's Fear (and get in line for book 3).I give this book four stars instead of five because of the endless, meandering, boring interlude with Felurian in the world of the Fae that interrupted the fascinating story of Kvothe and his team of bandit hunters and ground the narrative to a halt. It runs 11 chapters and felt three times that. OK, we needed to know a few things that occur during this period but a chapter or two would have done the trick. I hope Felurian does NOT make an appearance in book 3.

This is a very short story about an event that took place in India when Bess Crawford was 10. It sheds a little light on Simon, but I wish there'd been more.It is not a must read, but if you are a fan of Bess and can get your hands on a copy (it's digital only), I recommend it. I borrowed my copy from my library.

A Beautiful Blue Death is set in Victorian London. Charles Lenox is a gentleman with an interest in solving crimes. Lady Jane Grey is his good friend from childhood, now a widow.This book reminded me of Anne Perry's mysteries and of the stereotypical perception of Sherlock Holmes. However, I never felt I got to know Lenox or Lady Jane very well. There are extremely subtle hints of a possible romance, but nothing of note happens in this book.The book is very readable, but I found it a bit slow, and the mystery convoluted but not clever.  In particular, the last chapters after the climax felt  well, anti-climactic. The historical details seem well researched. I had a hard time believing Lenox's familiar relationship with his butler. Lenox's good friend Thomas McConnell is somewhat of a cardboard cut-out of a doctor who drinks. We are told that McConnells marriage to his wife Toto is pretty much over, but that's not how it comes across the rest of the book. The police inspector of course is not clever enough to solve anything without Lenox's help. The book feels like a cookie-cutter Victorian mystery. (Also, seriously, the main character has the same first name as the author?)My favorite character was Sir Edmund, Lenox's brother and a baronet, but also an eager partner in investigating with Charles.This series is now up to eight books, so it must be popular and fairly well received. I'm not sure whether I will give the second book a shot or not. I might, for Edmunds sake.

Absolutely delightful, the best Georgette Heyer I've read. There is a romance reminiscent of Colonel Brandon and Marianne's, and the main couple is patterned after Darcy and Elizabeth. And the main character has a penchant for meddling like Emma. The historical elements feel accurate, and the exchanges are witty and endearing. The language throughout is a treat.Sir Horace is a large, loud widower who is travelling more than he is at home. He has one daughter, Sophy. When he becomes engaged to a woman who does not wish to be seen as Sophy's stepmother, Sir Horace arranges to leave Sophy at the home of his sister, Lady Ombersley, in hopes that she can get Sophy married off.All is not well at Lady Ombersley's home. Her husband is a gambler who has endangered their home and lifestyle. Her son Charles has come into enough money of his own to take control from his father, but this role has turned him into a stodgy and humorless fellow. His many younger brothers and sisters don't feel they can confide their troubles to him. His oldest sister is determined to marry a dull and clueless poet instead of the fine gentleman who is in love with her, and Charles hasn't the sense to let the romance run its course, instead taking steps that make her all the more determined. Charles is engaged to an intolerable and dreary young woman his family cannot abide.Sophy arrives at the Ombersley home in all her glory - in a chaise drawn by four horses, with a greyhound, a parrot, and a monkey - and turns the lives of the family upside down. She interferes right and left until all are engaged to the right people and she has found love as well.If you are a fan of Jane Austen style romances and haven't read The Grand Sophy, I recommend putting it at the top of your To Read list.One note: there is an offensive racial stereotype of a money lender that somewhat mars this otherwise delightful novel.

I give this book five stars because (1) it's Beowulf, (2) it's Tolkien, and (3) it has a lovely cover. I confess to being thoroughly lost much of the time, both while reading the poem and while reading the commentary. But how fabulous it would have been to attend a Tolkien lecture! At least I got some sense of that. I most enjoyed finding little items in the commentary that resonated with my knowledge of The Lord of the Rings.The most readable part of the book for me was Sellic Spell. Tolkien wrote:This version is a (emphasized) story, not the (emphasized) story. It is only to a limited extent an attempt to reconstruct the Anglo-Saxon tale that lies behind the folk-tale element in Beowulf .... Its principal object is to exhibit the difference of style, tone and atmosphere if the particular heroic or historical (emphasis) is cut out. ... And by making it timeless I have followed a common habit of folk-tales as received." (p. 355)Whatever its principal object, Sellic Spell was very readable and understandable compared to Beowulf itself.My absolute most favorite part of the book is this line from Christopher Tolkien about including the Old English version of Sellic Spell. "[T]he interest of this text lies chiefly, in my view, in its demonstration of my father's fluency in the ancient tongue." [p. 407] It's touching that Christopher Tolkien is so fiercely proud of his father's accomplishments.

Oh Agatha, Agatha - will you never learn? Apparently not, and perhaps that's why we love her, but it would be nice to see some emotional growth in our beloved Agatha Raisin.The Blood of an Englishman is the 25th book in the Agatha Raisin series, and it is for the die-hard Agatha fan only, not someone new to the series. This is a typical Agatha Raisin novel - mildly amusing narrative, outrageous plot, Agatha on the prowl for a husband and jealous of her young assistant Toni. This book requires no effort to read.If you like cozy mysteries set somewhere in the United Kingdom - this series is set in the Cotswolds - I do recommend the Agatha Raisin series. Agatha is a middle-aged detective who is ferocious in her pursuit of a crime's resolution. She is insecure, and her gruff exterior hides a good heart. She is an unashamed smoker who adores her cats. Her surprising best friend is the vicar's wife. The first book is Agatha Raisin and the Quiche of Death.I read a Netgalley advance copy of The Blood of an Englishman.

I'm a big fan of fantasy novels and have had friends tell me I should read Outlander. I've seen it on "best of" lists for both novels and science fiction-fantasy. With the new Starz TV show, I chose it as this month's selection for my science fiction-fantasy discussion group.It's well written, and I had no trouble finishing it. The historical details seemed accurate to me, and I didn't get bored. However, I didn't love it.Outlander is a historical romance. At least in this book in the series, the only "fantastical" thing that happens is that the main character, Claire, falls through time from 1945 to 1743. Don't get me wrong, I like a good romance, but I had an issue with this one. Jamie, Claire's 1743 husband and apparently her True Love, whips her because she deserves it. He forces her to have sex and reminds her multiple times that she has promised to obey him. This may be 100% accurate for a man of his time, but these are not qualities I'm looking for in a husband. At least as presented in this book, I found Claire's 1945 husband Frank much more attractive than Jamie, and this is probably why I had trouble really being engaged by Outlander.I'm glad I've finally read Outlander so now I know what the story is about, but I won't be reading more books in the series. If you like historical fiction, romance novels involving Scotland or Scots, and fish-out-of-water romance plots and don't mind bawdy references and detailed sex including rape, I recommend Outlander for you. I don't recommend it for fantasy fans unless they also like historical romance.

I just listened to the audio version of the American edition again. I first read this book when it came out and have read and listened to it many times since. I rate this sixth of the Harry Potter books, but they are all brilliant in their own ways and critical to the series. This one feels like it was rushed to print and needed another round with a good editor.I have a particularly hard time with how stupid Harry is in this one, although it's not really his fault given his complex connection to the soul-shattered Dark Lord. Also, reading it always makes me wonder what J.K. Rowling has against librarians.  The only other sound was the slight squeaking of one of Madam Pinces shoes as the librarian prowled the aisles menacingly, breathing down the necks of those touching her precious books. (ch. 24)"Madame Pince was swooping down upon them, her shriveled face contorted with rage. 'Chocolate in the library!' she screamed. 'Out  out  OUT!' And whipping out her wand, she caused Harrys books, bag, and ink bottle to chase him and Ginny from the library, whacking them repeatedly over the head as they ran." (ch. 29)Two of my favorite parts of book 5:Percy sends Ron a letter to warn him off Harry, part of which reads:"I gather that you are still seeing a lot of Harry Potter. I must tell you, Ron, that nothing could put you in danger of losing your badge more than continued fraternization with that boy.It may be that you are afraid to sever ties with Potter  I know that he can be unbalanced and, for all I know, violent"Ron gives the letter to Harry to read, and when Harry finishes it, he looks up: Well, he said, trying to sound as though he found the whole thing a joke, if you want to  er  what is it? . Oh yeah,  sever ties with me, I swear I wont get violent.Give it back, said Ron, holding out his hand. He is   Ron said jerkily, tearing Percys letter in half, the worlds  he tore it into quarters  biggest  he tore it into eighths  git. He threw the pieces into the fire.Its a poignant reflection on Harrys personality that he tries to make a joke to Ron, while no doubt secretly fearing that a brothers opinion is more important than his own friendship. Its also a touching reflection on Ron that he immediately lets Harry reads the letter and tears it up and burns it without giving it a seconds thought. And its also a glimpse into Hermiones feelings for Ron, as after this episode she agrees to correct their homework when she had been refusing and scolding them about falling behind.Another favorite passage is when the advance guard from the order come to Privet Drive:Harry descended the stairs, very conscious of everybody still staring at him, stowing his wand into the back pocket of his jeans as he came.Dont put your wand there, boy! roared Moody. What if it ignited? Better wizards than you have lost buttocks, you know!Who dyou know whos lost a buttock? the violet-haired woman asked Mad Eye interestedly.

Calico Joe is a lovely and lyrical short novel, a bit sentimental at times but very nicely done. I am a Cubs fan and particularly enjoyed that one of the main characters is a Cubs player in the early 1970s. I remember so many of the real players who are mixed in with the fictional ones.This is my first John Grisham novel, so far as I remember, and I thoroughly enjoyed listening to the audio version. The voice of the narrator rang true. Definitely recommended for baseball fans, and also those who like a good story about family issues and resolutions.

In the end, the Daughter of Smoke and Bone series is more like Twilight than Harry Potter, but Dreams of Gods & Monsters was a satisfactory ending to a fine series. (And there is room for a sequel series!)

Im a huge fan of Jane Caseys Maeve Kerrigan series, so I was quite interested to read How to Fall, her first young adult thriller/mystery.I wouldnt call How to Falls plot terribly original (identical cousins, anyone?), but the writing kept me thoroughly engaged. The author gets points from me for having her main character read the novel Cold Comfort Farm. While How to Fall is not as good as her adult mysteries, it is well written. Jess, the main character has dimension. I think young adults will tear through this book.How to Fall might have been more suspenseful if not written in the first person, and I felt a bit let down after the climax. The ending is abrupt, but oh wait, thats because its the first in a series. I did not see THAT coming. I will definitely watch for and read the second book in the series. The Jess Tennant series could develop into something really good.I recommend How to Fall to readers who already like Jane Caseys Maeve Kerrigan and to anyone who enjoys well written young adult thrillers with okay plots but interesting characters and settings.I read an advance reader copy of How to Fall.

I'm sorry to give this camera such a terrible review, but I've had it four months and it is falling apart. The lens opens and gives a lens error, and two pieces have fallen off the front of the lens. It's easy to use and takes great photos, but a camera should last more than four months.

I enjoyed The Silkworm, although not as much as The Cuckoos Calling. I dont mind a gritty mystery, but the level of gruesomeness and depravity around the murder in this book was higher than I care for.Cormoran and Robin are very well drawn, and I liked the character development that continued for them and even Matthew (to my surprise). I found the plot a bit convoluted. There were so many new characters that I had a very hard time keeping them straight. Still, I did not guess the resolution of the mystery. The oh-so-literate quotations before each chapter did nothing for me.I enjoy J.K. Rowlings style and sense of humor, and her use of British words and phrases. I will read the next book in the series.
Love these shoes, great fit and support.

Fin & Lady by Cathleen Schine is a sweet novel about half siblings in New York in the turbulent 1960s.Fin is 11 when his mother dies, leaving him an orphan. His father, also dead, had a daughter by a previous marriage, and Lady is the only family Fin has left. Lady is 23, and not exactly the model guardian. She retrieves Fin and his dog Gus from the Connecticut farm where he grew up and takes him back to New York City with her.Lady is a wild child, a glamorous figure Fin hardly knows. Shes seeking something, and even she is not sure what. Fin is seeking a family, and he finds it, awkwardly, in Lady and her black maid Mabel.Lady is the kind of person everyone falls in love with. She has multiple suitors and three in particular. Fin has a favorite, a Hungarian named Biffi, and Fin adds Biffi to his family as well, although Lady is reluctant to settle down with any of them.The dialog in Fin & Lady is smart, a little too smart sometimes, but enjoyable. Information about the 1960s is woven into the plot in a believable way for the most part. Fin is always reading, various real books that also reflect on the times and Fins life with Lady.I liked spending time with Fin and Lady, and I enjoyed Cathleen Schines writing style. I recommend this book to anyone who enjoys a nice character-driven novel.

Ive never read any Joe Abercrombie but was intrigued by the cover on the advance reader copy of Half a King. What a great story! I thoroughly enjoyed the book. The main character, Prince Yarvi, is sympathetic, believable, and imperfect. Although some characters, like the ships captain, are stock, Yarvis closest companions are well drawn. It was easy to tell them apart.After about 40 pages of world building and otherwise setting up the story, the action begins in earnest and doesnt let up. Yarvi is cast into the wild world friendless and alone, and he makes his own new family. The plot took a number of turns I didnt expect, and there was one twist at the end that both surprised and delighted me.I enjoyed the dialog, especially when the mysterious man called Nothing was involved.  If you have a plan, hissed Sumael from the corner of her mouth, now would be the time.  I have a plan, said Nothing.  Does it involve a sword? asked Jaud.  A pause. All my plans do.  Do you have a sword?  Another. No.  How will your plan work without one? muttered Sumael.  A third. Death waits for us all.I fell into this book and just wanted to stay there. I look forward to the next book in the series. I recommend Half a King for any lovers of high fantasy.

Allison Brennan is the bestselling author of a number of series. Notorious is the first book in a new series. It stars Max Revere, the investigative reporter on a cold case television series.Ive never read any Brennan before but I enjoyed this book. Once I started I was engrossed and wanted to keep reading to see what would happen next. I didnt guess where the plot was going or the resolution of the mysteries. The beginning was excellent, the middle was mostly good if a little draggy, and the end was and intense and terrific (*see spoiler below). For the most part, the information about the police and the investigations seemed well researched and realistic (*again, see spoiler below).I did have a little trouble connecting with Max. Abandoned by her mother as a child, she doesnt know who her father is but inherited millions from her great-grandmother upon her death. However, there is a lot of room for character development of both Max and her new love interest in future titles in the series.This is a fine start to a new series. If you like an investigative mystery, I recommend Notorious.Spoiler alert:*Aside from the too Hollywood climax involving a dangerous stunt on a car for the heroine and a cop shooting out the tires of a car with small children inside.
Good, quality cable at a great price.  What more could I ask for?
Great hose at about 1/4 the cost of big box stores.  Plus its' extended length of 8 feet makes it even better.

Do you want to guess how many books have been written about Jesus?  Me neither.  This one, though is unique.  It covers the impact of Jesus on many aspects of life including the arts, business etc. etc. as well as Christianity itself.  You will be amazed as you learn the impact Jesus had on so many things that we say and do in today's world.  The author has a way of holding your attention and wanting more as you work through this book.  Underlining and creating notes will slow you down a bit as this book unfolds, simply because so many memorable events are described.  Ortberg is obviously a gifted author that really researched before writing this book.  "Who is this man?"  You'll enjoy meeting him in a new and refreshing way.
Works great in my wife's 55 gallon tank.  Easy to adjust.
Great product.  I just ordered another one.

Very, very nice product.  I really don't know how we got along without this.  The stoppers are exactly what is needed to keep a partially consumed bottle fresh.The vacuum pump is stainless steel and well made.  I received this product in exchange for my honest review

Get ready for a wild ride.  This book is action packed from cover to cover.  The author did his homework well.  The story is basically of a WWII submarine and its' crew vs. the Japanese Navy and its' destroyers.  You will experience the day to day life of a submariner both at rest and at battle stations.  The characters are well identified and easy to follow.  This is a one day read.  Why?  Because you can't put it down.  I'm ready for another book by this author.

The writer of this book makes a good comparison between the people of Noah's time and  of people today.  Sin was rampant as Noah tried to tell everyone of God's coming judgement.  As always, God offered them salvation, safety from the coming flood.  Just as today, Noah was ignored exactly the way we ignore today's prophets.  God is a patient God but eventually follows through with His judgement.  Think of this.  It took Noah 120 years to build the ark.  During that time, God delayed judgement and Noah preached, but no one listened.  Sin is again abounding on planet earth.  God is again exercising patience, but in due time the door of (today's) ark will close, the righteous will be saved and the lost will be just that---"lost"

This is perfect for traveling or for daily use.  The sleek design makes it easy to even wear under your clothes.  Of course the RFID protection is simply necessary in today's world.  I received this item in exchange for my review but have no problem giving it 5 stars.  It is also useful if you are driving and don't want that bulky wallet in your pocket.

This is a perfect item for jewelry repair as well as tedious electrical jobs.  It's easy to hold, heats well and can really get into small spaces.  I was given this in exchange for an honest review.  All my reviews are honest and I am really happy to have this tool.

These were sent to me in exchange for an honest review.  My little 10 year old Yorkie has bladder issues that require us to keep her in diapers.  Obviously, we have used different brands/companies.  We found these to fit very well, and the material is soft and comfortable for Sasha.  I would recommend these to any person that has a dog in need of this item.

I have known the Lord for many, many years and have always been open to discuss Him with other believers.  The author sent me a complimentary copy of this book for my review.  As with all my reviews, I call them as I see them.  It's obvious this book was a labor of love for Kenneth Ruffle but, unfortunately I must tell you that there are many areas that could lead, especially a new Christian, down the wrong road.  Concerning Matthew 2:1 thru 11, the author's statement was "Some call this star 'the star of David' but in reality it was satan."There are other comments on the Trinity that are just simply wrong.  My purpose here is not to 'trash'  Ruffle or his labors but, as a Christian I am compelled to say that this book is a bit off base.  It would take more room than I have here to go into verse by verse the misconceptions portrayed in this work.I do not know the writers Church/Religious affiliation  as it was not revealed.

This is a great lantern.  I was going to use it for camping, etc.  However, I changed my mind.  In Oklahoma, we are sometimes frequent visitors to our storm shelters which generally have no electricity in them.  This will be hanging in my shelter.  What a great item for this use.  I'm sure there are many 'unusual' situations that would call for this lantern.

What a perfect book for the study of Christ in both the Old and New Testament.  This book is exciting, informative and very readable.  There are so many facts and prophesies contained in this small but significant work.  The mathematical equations applied to the probability of these events happening are nothing less than mind blowing.  The author obviously has a deep understanding of his work.  Add this to a gift of being able to transfer his thoughts to the reader and you have a real treat waiting for you.  I have a habit of underlining what I feel are important statements in a book.  I don't know why I didn't just underline the whole thing.  Great read.

I guess anyone that thinks the Crusades can be covered in just over 100 pages might be a little delusional.  This book was never meant to be an in-depth study, of course.  I would say this could be used as an outline for the Crusades and maybe a guide into which point you may desire to study further  Because of the nature of the subject, you are literally bombarded with dates, characters,and kingdoms.Read this one first, before you really jump in on in-depth study of these events.
This bra was as advertised.  The fit and comfort were very good.  My wife wants more like this one.

These bands are really nice.  They are in a good pouch so easy to take with you.  These bands are no junk but are high quality.  I like the fact that you can use whatever resistance you need for the day.  There is no limit to the number of exercises possible with these.  My wife and I are senior citizens and really find these helpful as well as fun.  I was given a set by the manufacturer but all my reviews are honest and I would give a 5 star rating anyway.  The price is right also.

A five star rating is the only way to go on this one.  The section on the Civil War was as thrilling as any 'Civil War' author could have written.  The ' Conspiracy' section was written as if written by a 'True Crime' author.  The section on 'The Assassination' contained the most detail I have ever read on the subject.  The section on the Chase and demise of Booth could easily have been written by a 'Wild West' author.  The section on the 'Trial and sentence' of the co-conspirators could have been written by a great lawyer.  Add all of this to the vivid descriptions of all parties involved and you have a brilliant, important work of history by two gifted authors.

I read/studied this book back in the 70's.  The mathematical equations proving Bible prophesy are nothing short of amazing.  This  is a classic and can be a little hard to find.  I bought this for my Pastor, as a gift.

I wasn't sure if I would like this but decided to try it.  This is a great product.  I have allergies and sinus problems.  I could not believe how well I slept on this product.  I now use this exclusively.  We're going on vacation in a few weeks.  I'm taking my pillow with me.

I got this for my wife.  It fits into her purse easily and has several double sided brushes for whatever make-up she needs to use.  The only reason for not a 5 star is that I wish the case would have been a little sturdier.  but, overall, a nice item.

This lock is the right size.  Not too large or bulky.  Yet it is strong.  I like the feature where you can choose (or change) the combination at will.  It works smoothly and actually can be used for any application you wish.

I wonder how it felt to be called 'A friend of God'?  Abraham was just that.  Not because of something he did;  Not because of who he was; But because of God's grace.The life of Abraham is a life that is not necessarily any different than our own.  Yet God called him His Friend.  He was Gods' friend when he was weak, when he was strong, when he did right and when he did wrong.  Why?  He had faith in God and exercised that faith in his daily life.  Abraham's life was not always pleasant but his faith was among the strongest of Old Testament and New Testamentcharacters.  The author brilliantly compares the parallel of the Old Testament to the New, while taking you along on a journey that leads to promises.  Promises only God could fulfill.  What a delight when, at times I could see myself in Abraham's shoes.  And I could see my 'Friend' standing next to me.  If you could only read one book of faith and love this year, I would hope it would be this one.One clear message I received from this book is that, "If you want God to be your friend, be careful where you pitch your tent."

I was given my set in exchange for an honest review.  My reviews are always fair and unfortunately I cannot recommend this product.  They are cheaply made and one broke the first time I tried to unzip it.  They are also overpriced.

Actually, I like this one.  I was given one in exchange for my honest review.  I hate to have to dig for my phone while on the road AND I generally won't even talk on it while driving.  This fit right up to my vent with no problem and I can now talk hands free if necessary.  Why only 4 stars?  It is a bit difficult to remove your phone from the holder if need be.
This is really nice.  it's bright, looks good and charges [plenty during the day to keep in going all night.  I use it to illuminate the gate to our front yard.

I just got rid of three different chargers after receiving this.  It's convenient, looks good and is a really fast charger.  The 'smart charge' technology is an exceptionally nice feature as it delivers the proper charge to any device.  When you plug this in, the USB ports give off a blue light that is soothing and also leads you to the ports even if it's dark.  I just could not find anything negative to say about it.

This was an enjoyable read.  The unusual twist by having the narrative done by Christ Himself was, in itself rather compelling.  I would say this book is a combination of 'The Passion of the Christ' and 'Pilgrim's Progress.'  It is well worth the read, but as in any book of this type the author does take 'liberties' with some of his conclusions.  Just over half way through, it is as though another book was written as you read a narrative of the combination of all the Gospels.  I think the book would have been better if it had concluded without the addition of the, rather redundant telling of the story again.  Before some of you go off on me, I must affirm that the Gospels are the authority of the Passion of Christ and are not, in any way 'redundant.'  It's just that in this format it was like reading the same book twice.
What a great addition to your KONA coffee press.  This is quality merchandise.  It looks great and works effortlessly.  You can't even compare this to those cheap, electric grinders.

What if there was bus service between Heaven and hell?  What if you were on that bus?  Where did you get on?  Why did you board it?  What was your destination?  Who was the driver?  Can the trip be altered?  From the mind and heart of C. S. Lewis, these questions are dealt with in a vivid, portrayal of an unusual trip to------well to a destination of your choosing.

If you enjoy reading Bible Prophesy and haven't read this one, you are missing out.  This is an in depth study presented in an easy to read format.  The authors have gone to great detail to back up their conclusions with scripture.  Do I agree with 'everything' they have written?  Of course not.  Do I believe in almost everything?  Absolutely!This will be my 'go to' reference as far as prophesy is concerned.

I have constant and moderately severe back pain due to past injuries and degenerative disks.  I have had similar cushions before but none really lived up to their claims.  This one is so much better.  For one thing, the design is not square but ergonomically shaped. Secondly, the foam does not 'flatten' out when you sit on it.  Third, the outside material is soft and comfortable.  It also has a zippered cover that can be removed and washed.  I used this the first day at my computer desk and loved it. The second day, I put it in my car and again I loved it.  Then came the problem.  Which would win out?  Well, how about using it when I drive then bringing it into the house when I'm done?  Best of both worlds.This is a nice versatile and useful product.

The title of this book clearly explains its' content.  The 'unknown warriors' are, for the most part men you have never heard of.  That does not diminish their role in history however.The book cover several unsung heros from different countries and wars.  From the American Civil War through WWI, WWII, Korea and Vietnam the author brings history that you may be very unaware of.  This not a fast or easy read.  At times you may find yourself a bit overwhelmed with statistics, characters and places but read on.  It is worth it.

This is so simple to use, even by yourself.  It is loaded with features. ie: blood pressure, pulse, memory (for two people)  The digital read out is quite visible.  We gave away our old monitor after receiving thisI can't imagine a better unit and the price is right..

Well made and fits perfectly.  An easy way to make your favorite coffee, etc. in a Keurig.  With these, you might even have fun blending different coffees to make your own 'perfect' blend.  Also, you do not have to pay department store prices for this item.
Beautiful 'glass' design.  Easy read-out.  Thin enough to put under your bed, nightstand, etc.  This is a good one and is highly accurate.

What can I say?  I love coffee and I love the writing of Max Lucado. This story was just the best of both worlds for me.  The story of this special coffee house, its' owner, patrons and 'other' guests is such a breath of fresh air.  Even though it deals with real life problems and frustrating issues it does it in a beautiful way that will hold the reader's interest all the way through the book.  It is also a story of hope, healing and faith.  I have always called Max Lucado a 'word artist' and this fresh, new novel absolutely confirms his gift as a Christian author.  I hope he continues to write novels as well as his many other genres.

Just like you, I read, read, then read some more.  I'm picky about what I read.  I research  before I choose what to read next.  For that reason, I usually like what I read.  However sometimes I pick up a book that goes way beyond my expectations.  A read that grabs me and won't let go.  A Masterpiece.  This is one of those masterpieces.  What is the purpose of a true story?  What is the purpose of a 'not so true' story.  If it's done in the right way, what does it matter?  Tim O'Brien, a Vietnam Veteran himself, takes you along into that terrible time when men went off to fight in a distant place for a somewhat distant purpose.  The things the foot soldiers carried with them into the jungles were both tangible and secret.  Never have I read a more difficult but brilliant expose' on the horrors of war.  Do soldiers kill so they won't be killed?  Do they kill because they are told to?  Do they kill because of a personal ghost, or fear that drives them beyond any moral or religious feelings?  Reality hides itself way back in the soldier's mind while it also screams at him with another reality.  He must do what he must do.  Many fine warriors carried a lot more out of Vietnam than they carried in.  Many continue to carry it today.  The weight of their rifles, knives and other killing tools have been lifted from their shoulders. The internal demons, thoughts and dreams they continue to carry.  The burden is overwhelming.  God Bless Tim O'Brien for fighting and especially for sharing his personal war and its' consequences with us.

Isaiah is a book of contrasts---From judgment to deliverance and all in between, this book is a must have if you are a serious student of prophesy.  Have your Bible handy as the author takes you on an extremely  comprehensive study of Isaiah.  This work is not a 'sprint' but a 'marathon'.  It takes time to follow along, but the effort will be well worth it.  This is not a commentary.  It is much more than that.  If you thought you liked the book of Isaiah, you will absolutely love it after reading this important work.  You will walk with Isaiah as he sees the past, interprets the future and lives in his own time.  You will understand more about the nation of Israel and its' relationship (or lack of relationship) with God.  Where do we stand (personally and as a nation) as the prophets of old share their 'Words from God'?  If you are one that likes to underline or make notes of key portions of a book, save yourself a lot of trouble and just underline this whole book.This one's a keeper.  Don't miss it.

I did enjoy this book, but just not as much as I had anticipated.  The actual Books of John when read from a modern version of the Bible, I feel are more rewarding and just as easy to read.This book will however, lead you to a deeper study of God's Word. That, in itself compels me to give a four star rating.

Before starting my review, I strongly suggest reading 'The Harbinger' by the same author. It will help prepare you for the explanations given in "The Mystery of the Shemitah."  "The Mystery of the Shemitah" is probably the most exciting, deep, thorough and informative of any prophetic book I have ever had the pleasure to read.  I must warn you that this is not an easy read.  The facts and figures contained are absolutely mind boggling.  You must read this with no distractions.  You must concentrate on every word.  This work will also lead you back to your Bible.  Jonathon Cahn has done an incredible study of ancient Israel and its relationship to God.  The overwhelming theme is that of a nation blessed by God, and then turning away from Him. The Shemitah is a series of Sabbath Years that begin in 586 BC and continue up to the time we are now living in.  Some have asked, "Where is the United States in bible prophecy?"  No one knows for sure but this book will give you some direction toward that question.  The author compares the U.S today with the nation of Israel throughout ancient history, up to modern times and how the Shemitah appears in these time periods.  Are we as a nation still following the One that has blessed us so much or have we turned our back on Him?  What might we expect in the future?  Blessings, judgement, pride, redemption and restoration are all covered here.  Where does the Shemitah fit in?  Can we change our destiny?  Only if you are serious about the condition of the world and the United states,  should you read this very, very important work.

I really enjoyed this one.  We study about the Disciples all the time, but how much do we really know about them?  This question is skillfully answered by this author.  About one third of the book is primarily about Peter.  That shouldn't surprise anyone as Peter was the most outspoken and was generally at the forefront of all that was taking place.  It's impossible to know 'all' about each of Christ's closest followers but what is known (and more) is well covered.  I personally enjoyed trying to identify which of these men I was most like.  I picked two.  One was the person I definitely identify with and the other was the person I would rather identify with.  Whether you are a relatively new Christian or have been a Christian all of your life, you will find this book very informative, interesting and easy to read.  Your Sunday School class or small group could easily use this as a study.

I received this mouse in return for my review.  When I first opened the package, my first reaction was "What"?  Its design is really unique.  It was an easy install (plug and play) so no issues there.  It is a bit contrary at times and you may have to left click if it stops working, thus the 4 star review.  However, this is by far the most comfortable and natural feeling mouse I have ever come across.  It is well worth the money.  It seems to be more responsive on a wooden surface than a mousepad.

My wife has a 55 gallon aquarium.  I like to watch it but do NOT like the noise of a pump.  This pump has all the power you need, two outlets and extremely quiet.  The tubing that comes with it is more pliable than most.  It feels like it may be rubber instead of plastic.  This is the pump to have.Enjoy the tranquility of your tank without the annoyance of noise.

This is a really nice, flat desk calendar and goals planner.  The cover is heavy plastic,it is a spiral planner so it lays flat on your desk.  Both the daily calendar and the goals planner are large enough to make notes, etc.  You will especially like how you can follow and track your progress on both personal and business goals.

I see that I am going against the grain in giving this book only 2 stars, but as in all my reviews I give my honest opinion as I see it.  The 'editorial' comment was that it is "The most important story of the Christian faith."  I don't know what that comment is based on.  I read historical fiction on a daily basis.  This book is a novel.  An author can and does take certain liberties and embellishments when writing a novel.  Wangerin took this to a new level as he attempts to introduce you to Christ.  He portrays Jesus as a somewhat rude, self centered taskmasterthat comes off with an almost abrasive personality at times.  To his credit, this author is a good story teller.  I just find it unfortunate that he chose to alter the person of the 'real' Jesus to a point that in my opinion could do a lot of harm to someone that reads this book.  Please get a Bible and read the book of John in order to find Jesus.  It is much smaller than this novel and is filled only with truth.  You will see a vast difference between a 'novel' and the true 'Word of God.'
This is a very sturdy and versatile cable for your Samsung Galaxy.  the 6 foot length is great..  the connections fit tight.. the nylon braiding is attractive as well as high quality.

I was sent this by 'Skybot' in exchange for my review.  This is really nice, both portable and useful.  I charged mine all night as there is no indicator as to whether it is charged or not.  As a flashdrive it does a good job.  The recorder is beyond nice. Small and virtually undetectable it offers you discreet recording when needed.  I would recommend this product even without a charge indicator.  Very useful.
The card slots are too small and the cover really doesn't close.  Make sure you have a screen protector on your phone as it closes right on it.  This is one of those 'get what you pay for' items.

This was a tremendous book.  By using David As a boy with a stone for a backdrop the author takes us along a rather unusual trip with a man that was truly a man in God's favor.  But a man is what he was, with all his strengths and weaknesses.  As you take this venture you will find yourself and your life in comparison with that of a man that would be King.As always, God's plan will be be worked out in His way and in His time.  That way is not always easy and sometimes not even easily understood.  One thing that really stands out in this book is the fact that God can and will use us in spite of ourselves.David starts out as a young boy with a great love for God.  It is his faith in God that removes his fear and challenges Goliath.  We all know in this age old story that Goliath is defeated and falls.  However Goliath is not the only 'giant' David will meet throughout his life.The author puts us in the 'shoes' of David not only in his spiritual life but also in times of defeat, doubt and mistakes that weave through his life when he becomes complacent or shall we say lazy due to his own ego and agenda.David's life in many ways can be compared to today's church and today's Christians.  The book is a page turner and the lessons learned will be a great asset to your walk with God.

Sometimes I read a book and then wonder "Why?"  This story fits into that category quite well.  Take an undertaker, sheriff and preacher (same guy).  Add a devastating fire and a deadly contagious disease.  Put all this into a small town.  Add a large portion of madness, and confusion.  There you have it.  A book that basically has no beginning, no end and not much in between.  Right up to the last page, I searched for a plot but alas, it eluded me.  At times, I leave my usual genre just to explore something new.  Sometimes, it's a new adventure down a different path, but in this case it was a path to nowhere.

The author ask me to review his book in exchange for a free download.  Somehow, the download didn't work but I already had my interest at a high level so just bought it on my own.  It proved to be quite a bargain.  For anyone that has ever wondered just where America fits into 'end times', this is a 'must read.'  There are a lot of theories out there and one must, at least try to look into them all.  If you read this book and are not encouraged to study further, I suggest you might read it again.  Nathan Ford is not totally dogmatic in his interpretations, but actually delves into others' thoughts also.  This is a small but very important read and I surely hope many will be drawn to further study on there own.  The author has done a great job of backing up his thoughts by Scripture references.

This was a much smaller book than I had expected because just over half way through it ended.  The rest of it was commercials of his other books and then portions of the Bible that one could have read in their own.  The examples he used of Flawed but Faithful characters were not really anything new as the characters he used and their stories are so familiar to most of us.  I believe his personal notes were at times questionable.  As an example, he stated that Lincoln was a Christian.  Abraham Lincoln never made a public  profession of his faith, and although a good man was somewhat 'wishy-washy about religion in general.  I know this is a fairly critical review but I just was not able to glean a whole lot new from it.

I really liked this one.  If you are reading this review, you already know that the 'Wild Goose' is actually referring to the Holy Spirit.  The author presents us with several stories and incidents that clearly identify the work of the Spirit, how to recognize it and how to follow Its' leading.  This is a very good read for new Christians as well as those that may feel they Have been a believer so long that their life, bot physical and spiritual has become rather useless.  Actually, I picked up this book for .50 cents at a garage sale at a time I was having some of those feelings.  Coincidence?  I don't think so.  God's Spirit is alive in us no matter our age or circumstance.  You can/will be used by God as you enter on your own "Wild Goose Chase."

Now and then I step away from my usual genre just to try something new.  Sometimes, I'm disappointed---This time, I wasn't.  It was hard to put this one down.  The fight between good and evil is not something unusual in books.  After having said that, I must admit this one really stands out.  It all comes back to the author.  A book tells a story but there's more to it than the story. HOW the story is told is actually more important.K.J. Bryen knows HOW to tell it.  I really hope this young author continues to write in this manner.  Read this one.  You'll like it.
This was a smart move by author K J Bryen.  This short read is just interesting enough to nudge you over to her book, "Lokte."  It worked for me.  i'll be starting 'Lokte' this week.

You will fall in love with Private Sam.  Actually, you just may fall in love with love again.  The author, again takes us on a journey during the Civil War;  mainly Shiloh and Pittsburgh Landing.  However, the best part of this journey is again, His imagination and his storytelling ability.  His system of twists and turns that all of his books have are very much alive in this work.  The history is correct.  The human interest is, once again valuable and outstanding.  This is the third book of Richardson's I have read in the past week or two and I certainly was not disappointed.  This story has a surprising but beautiful ending.

Just like C.G Richardsons' "The Cellar", this book is written with great imagination.  Malchus was the servant of the High Priest, Caiaphas during the time of Christ's Crucifixion.  He is only mentioned once in the Bible.  He is the one that lost an ear to the sword of Peter.  The author takes you on a trip seen through the eyes of Malchus as he follows Christ.  This method of story telling was brilliant as it  is used to tell the 'real, true Biblical story of the trial, crucifixion and resurrection of the long awaited Messiah.  We don't know what happened to Malchus, but it would be nice if we could imagine his life as it is told here.  I would highly recommend this read for the believer as well as the non-believer.  The author shows great depth and understanding of the Bible and presents this story in a manner that is both fact and fictional.  I really liked the way Malchus was developed into a story of what he may have seen and how it impacted his life.  This book is a wonderful example of how one can be led to Christ through the avenues of fiction along side of fact.I have just started Richardson's third and final book with great expectations.

As basically a 'low tech' person, this charger fits all my needs in a simple, basic and attractive item.  There is just not a need for any car charger but this one.  Charges fast also.  The smaller size is also a plus.

I have had no difficulties with the screen that came with my press, but was asked to review this replacement.  It is just a better form of the original screen ,as it is heavier and thus will probably last longer.  Maybe it is possible to improve on an already good product.  It sure appears that way.

Just a quick review here:  I have seen most of Mike Leigh's films and really enjoyed them, but this one unfortunately didn't work for me.  It's very slow, very dull, and most of the time I couldn't understand what the actors were saying.  There's very little insight into what made Mr. Turner the artist he was, and I just didn't care about the characters at all.  I usually am a fan of Timothy Spall and the other Leigh regulars, but it seemed like they weren't given much to work with.  I can't recommend this movie except for the lovely cinematography and the set designs/decoration, which were excellent.  It's sad, because I really wanted to like this movie.

4/5 stars.  This is a really interesting book.  I enjoy books that explore legal/ethical questions and this one does that and then some.The book is structured like a novel.  We are introduced to Eric Blair (real name of British author George Orwell), a fictional district officer and police magistrate in 1920s Burma.  He's in his mid-twenties, inexperienced, not a lawyer - yet is expected by his superiors to deal with some fairly knotty legal issues in the town of Moulmein, with little help from said superiors.  Through Blair's interactions with both the local people and the British officers and civilians living in the area, we are shown various criminal, legal, social, cultural, moral and ethical problems to mull over.  Blair is sometimes more of a social worker than a police officer or magistrate; he's a bit of an odd duck and doesn't really fit in with the "Raj" type of English officer.  He doesn't have the sort of automatic prejudice that seems built into the British attitude towards the "natives" (meaning that their problems or needs are automatically assumed to be somehow less than white people's problems).  He also isn't able to deal with things by the book - he tends to look at things on a case-by-case basis, and sometimes gets in trouble for it.  He befriends a local Indian doctor, Dr. Veraswami, and they have many discussions about how Eric is going to deal with the problems that crop up.Some of the issues include rape/murder, child abuse, domestic violence, murder committed in a fugue state, attempted murder by a mentally disturbed person, illegal drugs given to a dying patient, and the question of whether a child should be left with a parent or adopted by a family that can give him a better (more prosperous) life.  Given that Blair is not a lawyer, he naturally struggles with what must be done in each case, and he often feels inadequate to the task and very bothered by the aftermath.The style of the storytelling is very leisurely, sometimes a little too much so, but I liked that each story is given time to develop the background so the issue or crime is fully understood.  I also liked the way the author used Blair and Veraswami's discussions to show all the possible ways to look at the ramifications of each case and its possible conclusion.  The questions raised in each case are fascinating and could be very useful in an ethics or philosophy class, as well as the obvious use it could be in a law class.The only reason I'm taking off half a star is that the book falls apart a bit at the end.  The author has Blair participating in an sexual affair with a married woman and this part didn't really work for me.  It's too melodramatic and didn't fit in with the rest of the book and seemed to be just filler, plus a way for the author to get Blair to leave Burma (because of the "scandal" of the affair).  I would have left this part out and ended the book in a different way.Overall, I would highly recommend this book for students of the law, and as a useful book in philosophy or ethics classes.  It will stimulate a lot of discussion.  And it will stay with you for a long time after you read it.

I'm always forgetting to charge my phone - it's my first smartphone and I use it a lot more than my previous phone.  So I was happy to get the chance to use this car charger.  We used it during a recent two-hour car trip and it worked great!  The phone was completely charged by the time we reached our destination.The charger works for either phone or tablet.  The black 2.1 amp port is for tablets; white 1.0 amp port for phones  There are slots for either device.  I haven't tried it on our tablet yet because we always charge it overnight, but when we go visit our son we'll most likely use it since we'll be there for a couple of days.  The charger will work in cars, trucks and buses.This is a great, easy-to-use product and one that I will enjoy using for a long time.  Highly recommended.

I found this book brutally hard to read, but it's so good, and so important a topic, I had to say so in a review.  Author Katy Butler's experience with her aging parents and their final years is so close to what my family went through with my parents that at times I had to turn away from the book,because it stirred up so many emotions and memories.  I wish I had been able to read the book before my parents left the world; it would have made it a little easier to feel that someone else has had these experiences and got through them, and maybe I wouldn't have felt so inadequate.  People caring for elderly relatives often feel completely alone, and it can be very frustrating to try to figure out what may be the best course of action in a given situation.  Butler perfectly captures this feeling and honestly explores her relationship with her often-difficult parents and siblings while navigating the medical system during her parents' last years and illnesses.I highly, highly recommend this book to everyone.  If you haven't yet gone through your parents' final years, you will.  If you've already gone through them and you have children, buy them a copy, because they will be going through it with you in the future.  Yes, it's that important.  Butler spells out everything you need to know for yourself or a loved one, emotionally and about things like advance directives, DNR, nursing home/assisted living vs. keeping an elderly person at home, and hospice services.  It's very hard to read, and it's hard to think about, but we're all going to be there at some point.  Our medical system is not set up to help people deal with end-of-life issues; doctors want to preserve life at all costs, and sometimes people are better off not going through heroic medical procedures at age 80+.  Read this beautifully-written, extremely moving book, and talk with your family about it.  It may be the most important discussion you ever have.

I recently finished watching the 6-hour television documentary based on this book, so it's hard not to compare them as I was reading the book.  I thought the documentary sometimes veered into "weepy backstory" territory (my term for the unfortunate practice of reality shows' pulling viewers' heartstrings by having a participant tell about a family member with cancer or disability), but overall I thought the filmmakers did a good job with the book's material.  Oncologist Dr. Mukherjee is an engaging writer (and an engaging presence in the film) and I think he does justice to the sometimes dry facts he has to work with.  The first 150 pages or so are the best.  The history/biography of cancer is very interesting and the early treatments seem either ridiculous or brutal, as well as nearly always ineffective, as seen through modern hindsight.  Where the book sort of fell apart for me, and where I had to take a break from reading, was in the endless chapters about chemotherapy drug trials.  This material gets a little repetitious.  I wish Mukherjee had included more of his own patients' stories in these sections rather than reciting endless facts about chemotherapy trials.  I think it could have made this material a little more accessible.  (There are some patient's stories included, but I would have liked a little more.)I learned quite a bit about how the U.S. "war on cancer" came to be: through doctors and through philanthropic individuals who felt strongly about making the fight to beat cancer a priority, and pressuring the government to fund research.  We have a lot to thank these people for, and we also owe a huge debt to both the patients (many of them small children) and their families for being willing to go through often-futile treatments in search of the "one cure" that always eluded them.  These people were incredibly brave.This book highlights the fact that we still sometimes view cancer as a forbidden subject and that doctors sometimes still don't tell patients all the information they need once they're diagnosed.  However, books like this one, and films like the one based on it, will definitely help open up discussions and help both patients and doctors communicate effectively about how to treat this disease.  I highly recommend this book for those with an interest in medicine and the history of medicine, and especially for potential medical students.

Let me say right off the bat that Dietland's humor and attitude won't appeal to everyone, but I loved it.  Author Sarai Walker says she was influenced by Chuck Palahniuk's Fight Club, which probably would have been enough to get my interest in her book, but she's done a great job of creating her own crazy world.Main character Plum is a plus-size woman who has always had a problem with her weight.  She's considering bariatric surgery as a last resort, having tried the usual barrage of diets without success.  She buys clothes for her future thin self and imagines the day when she'll be able to walk down the street and be noticed for her attractiveness (Walker calls it something that is unprintable here) rather than her size.  She works for a popular magazine aimed at young girls, but remotely, since her employer apparently doesn't think it would be good for business if anyone saw a less-than-perfect (read: not thin) woman working at the magazine's office.  Plum answers readers' questions for an "Ann Landers" type column.  It's mind-numbing work, but she's happy to be employed.  She spends a lot of time at a local coffee house, where one day she notices a young woman who appears to be following her.  Wondering why anyone would do so, she investigates and finds a sort of underground community of women who refuse to live by what they consider the standards of men.A subplot of the novel involves a strange guerrilla group begins to commit terrorist acts against those who mistreat women.  As repugnant as their acts would be in real life, in the fictional world, I applauded them.  Sometimes I have wished the same fate on men in groups like ISIS or other extremist organizations who want to keep women under their thumbs (or under burkas).Plum eventually is accepted into the underground community, and begins to examine her own views on sexuality, appearance, size and her place in the world, with empowering results.As I said above, I really enjoyed this book.  As a plus-size woman who has also tried many diets and given up, I can vouch for Walker's depiction of Plum's journey from young girl on her first diet to her realization that size may not matter that much, and that it's important to live in the now rather than the nebulous future.  Walker also accurately skewers the diet industry with her very funny sendup called the "New Baptist Plan".  I loved her dark, dark humor and honesty about what it's really like to be on the fringes of "normal" (thin) society and never really fit in anywhere.  She's got a great writing style.  The book flows well and never gets dull or caught up in preachiness.  There's just enough of an angry edge to keep it away from being a pity party for Plum.  There are many memorable characters.  This is a first novel, but it reads like it was written by someone with a lot of experience under her belt.  It really spoke to me on a lot of different levels, and I look forward to more by Walker.  Very highly recommended, with the caveat that it's not a light, fizzy book - but it IS a very satisfying one.

I loved this book!  Author Ellen McCarthy has taken the many interviews and stories she has written as a wedding reporter and boiled them down into a sort of relationship guide book that includes a lot of dating and wedding do's and don'ts.  The short pieces are arranged by subject - dating, commitment, breakups, weddings and "making it last".  Some of the pieces are funny, some touching, others smart-alecky, but all contain a lot of truth (especially about marriage - I've been married almost 31 years and can vouch for what she says about long-time commitment) and are very enjoyable to read.  It's one of those books you can pick up and put down and skip around reading various sections.  I particularly liked "Good on Paper (But Not Good Enough for You)", "Online Dates to Avoid", "Planning Hell", and "Be Nice".  But almost all the pieces are very good, and, as I said, filled with truth and real wisdom about relationships.  This is a book I would love to give to a young person who is starting out in the dating scene, along with "He's Just Not That Into You", which for all its snarkiness also contains a ton of good information about the dating world and relationships in general.I recommend reading this book even if you're not dating or heading towards a wedding, just because it's is so heartfelt and enjoyable.  It would make a great gift, too.

The Bad Doctor is a graphic novel that chronicles the experiences of a small-town general practitioner called Dr. Iwan James, in Wales.  Dr. James has some issues of his own, which help him to understand some of his patients and help them.I liked the graphic novel format.  I don't have a lot of experience reading graphic novels and often think of them as being only about superheroes or supernatural type stories, and it's nice to discover that there are other types of stories available.  The illustrations here are black-white-gray, which I also like.  I have problems with the highly colored, densely packed kind of graphic novel; my visual issues don't allow me to easily read them.  This one was very pleasant and enjoyable to read.  The illustrations also suit the text perfectly.The story is darkly humorous - Dr. James sometimes fantasizes about shooting himself after seeing certain patients, and he has a history of OCD.  His patients are sometimes easy to help and sometimes almost too complicated, and he spends a lot of time trying to figure them out.  For relaxation, he goes on long bike rides with a friend.  He has an understanding wife and some good colleagues.  So why isn't he happy?  Why doesn't he think he's a good doctor?  The novel explores all this in a funny and entertaining way.  The author makes the point that although doctors are often thought of as exalted beings, they're really just people like their patients, sometimes with the same weaknesses and problems.This book would be a great gift for a medical student, but I would recommend it to almost anyone, because it's both thought-provoking and enjoyable to read.  I would like to read more from this author/illustrator.

Wow, I can't tell you how shocked I am that this awful, awful book got so many 5-star ratings.  I have no idea what people see in it.  It was highly recommended to me by two good friends who both "loved" it and read the whole series.  I had a very hard time getting through it; I kept putting it aside to read other books, because it wasn't enjoyable.  I am getting rid of this book as soon as possible and have no interest in reading any more by this author.I'm not going to bother with a synopsis; there are plenty of them here for you to read.  Although the book is billed as a time-travel historical romance, I have to say I found it extremely unromantic and the time travel element was merely a device to get the heroine to where she needed to be for the storyline.  As for the historical part - the book didn't seem well-researched to me.  The author focused so much on sex and violence that the daily lives of the characters were given short shrift.  Such a shame, because part of why I expected to like it was because of the historical context.  Claire seemed to take about five minutes to easily adapt to her altered life.  I'd have expected a little more difficult adjustment period.The book is not well-paced and should have been edited down to half its 600-page length.  There are many stretches that are extremely dull and I kept wondering how long it was going to take me to slog through it.As to the characters, I don't feel they're well-developed or sympathetic and I don't feel Jamie and Claire have any chemistry as lovers.  Having a lot of sex doesn't constitute a relationship, and they both come across as stupid.  Most of the other characters are uninteresting.  The depiction of the bad guy as gay or bisexual and the implication that he was evil-because-gay was disturbing.I tend to agree with those reviewers who say the author needs therapy.  I really don't know what is going on in her head either.  The constant scenes of rape, torture, beatings and more rape were sickening.  I don't find that sort of thing sexy or romantic, and I am by no means a prude.  I also understand that life in the past could be brutal.  But that doesn't mean an author needs to constantly and disgustingly describe such scenes.  There are ways that a more competent author could have implied that things happened to a character without spending 5 pages lovingly describing them.  I don't think she's that great of a writer or stylist anyway; this story could have easily been told in many fewer pages and with a lot more charm and verve.  It's much closer to torture porn than romance novel.  And I have read a LOT of romance novels in the past.  Even the bodice-rippers of the 70s and 80s were nothing like this.  I also agree with the reviewer who said she's read all the Game of Thrones books and didn't find them as creepy as this book.It's just not a good book, folks.  I know I'm going to get dinged by all the Outlander-Lovers out there.  I don't care.  I don't recommend it to anyone.Now I have to figure out what I'm going to say to my two friends when they want to know how I liked it....

I recently got my first Tracfone smartphone.  It's not easy to find covers/cases for this size phone, so I was happy to find this one on Amazon.  I wanted one with a skull motif.  It's easy to pull apart to put the phone in and I like both its appearance and function.  Very happy with my purchase.

I'm sorry to say that I wasn't overly impressed with this book.  In brief, it's the story of two neighbors who live in a somewhat remote area where theirs are the only two houses.  Emily grew up in her grandfather's house, Howie lived in the other house with his wife and daughter.  They've never spoken; they only know each other by sight.  Howie is sort of a hermit and fairly uncommunicative in general.  Emily has night terrors as a child and something called "sleep paralysis" as an adult.  She manages to function, but barely.  Both are what I would call dysfunctional on a number of levels.The book gives Howie's backstory, then Emily's, and then transitions to present day, where Emily has returned to her grandfather's house after he is taken ill.  He dies, she stays, but is so unable to take care of herself that Howie ends up being sort of a caregiver for her, in his own house, which turns out to be beneficial for both.Part of why this book didn't appeal to me is that Howie is so affectless that he's sort of annoying to read about.  There just isn't much to him.  He has an equally annoying daughter, Harriet, who comes in and out of the story and also isn't very interesting.  I found Emily's medical/mental issues interesting but overall she, too, is not a compelling character.  I just didn't feel any emotional connection to any of the characters or to the story.  The blurb on the back of the book states that the book is "powerful, poignant and bighearted" but I did not feel that way at all.I think the book needed to be a lot weirder or more offbeat.  There isn't much to the story, and although author Wodicka has a nice writing style, without a really strong story to pull me in, I can't get into a book.  I can't recommend this one.

I recently read Corban Addison's debut novel, A Walk Across the Sun, a novel about human trafficking, and enjoyed it.  Addison is a lawyer and activist who writes about human rights issues.  This new book concerns crimes against women in Africa, and attempts to honestly depict the corrupt police force and legal system of that country, along with explaining some of the cultural/societal reasons for their behavior.This novel's main character is Zoe Fleming, a well-connected American human rights lawyer working in Zambia.  When a young girl with Down's syndrome is sexually assaulted, Zoe teams up with police officers and social workers to find the perpetrator and bring him to justice.  They are constantly thwarted by an unethical police department and a legal system that does not seem to care about the most vulnerable members of society.  Zoe has personal reasons to take this case to heart and see it through to its end.  She also has problems making inroads with the people she meets, since many of them distrust whites.  In addition to the crime of child rape, the book addresses the continuing issue of AIDS and the stigma attached to the disease.I didn't find this book to be as compelling as the previous one.  It's not badly written; I wouldn't call Addison a great stylist, but he keeps the story moving along fairly well.  I think part of it is that although I have great sympathy for the women and children who are being victimized, the story got a little bogged down with Zoe's personal angst (directed mostly at her father, a bigwig in American politics).  Another problem is that Kuyeya, the rape victim, is essentially a symbol for disabled children in Africa, who are victimized and mistreated simply because they're disabled.  African society apparently views them as a curse and according to the author, four in five of these children die before their fifth birthday.  This is tragic, but the problem with this character is that she's not very compelling to read about; she's more of a catalyst than a real character.I also had a problem with the fact that in almost every instance, the bad guys in the story were able to steal evidence or threaten Zoe and her team.  This often happens in television shows (Orphan Black, I'm looking at you), where, for the convenience of the story, doors are easy to jimmy or a window is somehow left unlocked.  I would think, if this story were happening in real life, that these people would have better security, check their doors and windows, make sure whoever is guarding the entrance gate can't be paid off!  It just makes the story less believable for me when the writer needs his characters to be stupid or careless in order to make the story work.However, having said this, I think these issues are very important and I appreciate Addison shedding light on them.  We may not be able to change laws or cultural views overnight, but making more people aware of them is a good thing.  I recommend this book to those who, like me, have an interest in global humanitarian causes.

Small Mercies isn't a bad book, it just isn't what I would call a great one.  It's a portrait of grief.  The story of a blue-collar Irish-Italian family in Staten Island, some ten years after 9/11, it covers a week in the family's various lives and goes into their history through flashbacks.  Gail and Michael Amendola have three grown sons, two living, one dead in the wreckage of the Twin Towers, and the family is still grieving, including dead son Bobby's widow, Tina.  Tina is finally trying to move on and has a new boyfriend, the news of which causes the rest of the family fresh pain.  Living sons Peter and Franky have a multitude of problems of their own.  Peter may lose his job and is estranged from his own family due to a major indiscretion at work.  Franky is a raging alcoholic with anger management issues, who can't hold a job.I liked some of the characters - Gail and Tina particularly, and in flashback, Michael's immigrant parents Maria and Enzo.  Franky is pretty hard to like, and Peter I found annoying because his problems are really due to his own foolishness.  Gail will probably never move on from Bobby's death - she keeps his room as he left it, and won't consider moving to another state because she would have to leave his grave behind.  Tina's brave attempt at having a fresh start is admirable.  I think the author did a good job depicting both the problems and the deep attachments of a multi-generational family, and I found parts of the book to be very moving.Some of the things that didn't work for me in the book were the overly graphic sex descriptions, which didn't seem necessary.  Maybe it's because I'm getting older, but this kind of writing seems more like filler to me than actual content.  I also found some of Franky's behavior in one of the last chapters disgusting.  He's a violent, racist thug and it's easy to imagine him dying from alcohol poisoning after his nightly drink-to-blackout benders. (The author makes brief reference to Gail's father Sean being the same type of drinker.)  I think these things brought the book down a few notches in quality.  It's also a fairly depressing book.  Yes, it's about grief, but I think it would have benefitted from a little humor or levity at times.I also wasn't crazy about the back-and-forth in time during the same chapter.  Some authors are more adept at this than others.  I was often confused about the time period in this book.Overall, I liked, but didn't love the book.  I think parts of it are well done, with the caveats above.  I would cautiously recommend it for book clubs as long as you don't mind some vulgar language and sex.

This book effectively depicts the horrific practice of human trafficking by giving it a face - that of Indian teenage sisters Sita and Ahalya, orphaned by a tsunami and picked up by opportunistic traffickers on their way to another town where they have relatives.  The plot of the novel could be taken from any one of a number of trafficking cases: the girls are sold into prostitution and slavery, treated about as horribly as you'd imagine.
