Added into the mix is American lawyer Thomas Clarke, on leave from his high-powered law firm in Washington, he ends up working in India for an anti-trafficking organization while trying to get his estranged Indian wife back.  Soon he's on the case of tracking down Sita, who has been taken from India to parts unknown.The novel is a good, quick read - you'll want to read quickly to find out what happens, and Addison is adept at getting the reader from A to B to C in a page-turning fashion, without a lot of fuss.  I wouldn't call him a great stylist by any means, but he gets his point across well.  This subject needs light shed on it in any way possible, and I think books like this are an effective means.  I didn't find the novel overly preachy, and it's also not overly zealous in depicting what the trafficking victims go through - we know what's going on, we don't need the graphic details.I liked the book and I recommend it for anyone interested in the topic of human trafficking - hopefully it may inspire people to take up the cause.

Did You Ever Have a Family is one of those rare books where storytelling, characterization, and a beautiful writing style come together to create an emotionally authentic literary experience that will stay with you for a long time.  I haven't read any of Bill Clegg's other writings - this is his first novel - but if his previous work is anything like this, I'll be reading all of it.The story takes place in a small Connecticut town where June Reid is planning for her daughter's wedding.  Through a terrible accident, her daughter, future son-in-law, ex-husband and current boyfriend are killed.  In the aftermath of this unimaginable loss, June takes a road trip to the other side of the country, where she holes up in a beachside motel.  Each chapter of the novel is told from the point of view of a different character - first person narrative for some, third person for others - and so we get to know both the Connecticut townspeople and various people in the beach town where June is staying, and gradually understand their connections to one another.  Clegg is very adept at giving each character a distinct voice.  I particularly liked Edith, the flower shop owner who was supposed to provide the wedding flowers, and Rebecca, the co-owner of the motel.  The depiction of the town, through the eyes of its long-term inhabitants, is great - it's one of those tourist towns mostly populated by weekenders and renters, where the "have-nots" serve the "haves".I really like how Clegg is able to get to the emotional heart of the story without being maudlin or wallowing.  That's rare.  I need the emotional connection to be invested in a story and characters, but I hate fake or cheap sentiment.  I also like the "shoulda, coulda, woulda" aspect of the story, where various characters are either sorry or grateful for the fact that they did or did not take a certain path in life.Although the book will certainly sound like a depressing journey, I found it very balanced because Clegg provides enough instances of past or present happiness to counteract the sad scenario that drives June on her road trip.  I also think the emotional honesty and sincerity, plus the wonderful characters and beautiful, almost poetic writing, make the story so appealing that even those who normally shun "sad" books will find this one worth their time.Very highly recommended.  It's definitely a keeper for me.  I look forward to more from Mr. Clegg.

Hyacinth Girls is a terrific exploration of teenage behavior and emotions.  It tells the story of Callie, a 13-year-old girl accused of bullying a schoolmate to the point of the other girl withdrawing from school.  Callie's guardian, Rebecca, can't believe that the girl she knows is capable of such behavior and jumps to her defense, but gradually finds that things in Callie's life may not be quite the way she thought.  Along the way, author Frankel explores Rebecca's past and her relationship with Callie's parents Joyce and Curtis, both of whom she knew since childhood, and the reason Callie lives with her.  It's a strong and affecting narrative, and I read it very quickly over the course of a day.The bullying angle in the book reminded me strongly of two other novels, one from the past (Margaret Atwood's Cat's Eye) and one I finished a week ago (Ruth Ozeki's Tale for the Time Being), both of which feature severe bullying of a young girl mostly by other girls.  It's a difficult subject to read about, since no parent ever wants to believe that their child is either being bullied or actually is a bully.  It's hard to imagine that your child might have driven another person to the brink of suicide.  But since this scenario seems to play out daily in America, despite anti-bullying school campaigns and schools being declared "no bullying zones", it's obvious that Frankel thinks we need to continue to discuss and shed light on this societal problem, and I agree with her.  I would highly recommend that anyone with a young teen in the house read this, and that the teens read it too.  As Frankel points out toward the end of the story, getting parents and children talking about bullying - hopefully leading to a real solution to the problem - should be encouraged.

This isn't an easy book to review.  Kate Bolick's Spinster is part memoir, part sociology, and she gives the reader quite a bit to think about.  Why are so many women single these days?  Can a woman make a life for herself that is satisfying without marriage?  Although I found it slow in the beginning (after the all-over-the-place first chapter I was ready to rate it at two stars) it really picks up after a while and creates a lot of food for thought, so much so that it's hard to boil it down in a brief review.  Sometimes I felt the memoir part could have been cut down a bit - Bolick sometimes veers into navel-gazing territory, and her prose is occasionally over-flowery.  I'm from the "get to the point already" school of thought, so I found it a little irritating.But it gets better.  Bolick examines various stages in her own life - she's in her 40s - by weaving in stories about several women from the past, including social reformer Charlotte Perkins Gilman and poet Edna St. Vincent Millay, who either remained single or lived as if they were.  The life stories of these "spirit guides" were often a lot more interesting to me than Bolick's own stories.  Bolick uses their example as a starting point to examine how modern women can choose to forge a life without marriage and not be viewed by society as either "failures" or "lacking" because they choose to live alone (or to live separately from a partner).  She also brings in her mother's story of having been a working mother who never realized her potential as a writer because she never had the time, assuming she'd have time once her children were grown, only to die early.  Bolick's mother's early death seems to have heavily influenced her self-examination and decision not to lightly enter into marriage and child-bearing just because others she knew were doing so.  The book shows that our modern idea of "having it all" has been around a lot longer than we realize, and that we are still far from an easy solution.Spinster isn't so much about single women as it is about women living life on their own terms, and realizing that not having a partner or spouse might actually end up being an advantage in some ways.  It's also a brief history of working women in America and workplace problems that women still face, such as pay disparities and not being taken as seriously as men.  It raises issues that all parents should discuss with their daughters, granddaughters, nieces, daughters-in-law...about developing their own resources, career, and personality independent of a partner or spouse first, rather than dreaming of the prince who will take them away.  Our society's seeming obsession with dream weddings tends to overlook the fact that we still have a pretty high divorce rate, so obviously those princes aren't the answer to women's prayers after all.I really enjoyed the "spirit guide" stories, especially that of journalist Neith Boyce.  And navel-gazing aside, Bolick makes so many good observations and points that I found myself underlining and making margin notes all over this book.  I highly recommend it as both a book to savor by yourself and one to share with any young woman of your acquaintance (and having that discussion I mentioned above).  And you know, it really wouldn't hurt for men to read it, too.

I'm very pleased with the results after using these print-yourself business cards.  We needed a few cards for my husband to occasionally hand out because we own rental property and sometimes deal with repair people who ask for a business card.  Since we only need a few, it was more convenient to print them ourselves than to have to order a large number from Staples or another store.As to the process itself:  It's not difficult to start; you go to Avery's website and enter the number of the product, then start looking at the templates available.  There are quite a few choices so it takes a while to find just the right one.  They're grouped by type of business.  Some are extremely specific, others more applicable to various types of businesses.  Some designs I found too busy-looking, others too boring, but eventually I narrowed it down to two and got to work inputting my information into the first template, which I eventually rejected because I couldn't find an ink color for the font that looked good with the colors on the card's design.  This was a problem with a number of the cards - oddball colors and "busy" designs taking up way too much room on the card.  The second choice ended up working much better and after a lot of fiddling around with the text boxes (with quite a bit of help from my husband), it came out quite well.I will point out that I'm not experienced in doing this kind of project, so I definitely needed more help than someone who is experienced.  I got a little frustrated at times and it took me longer to get the cards done than it would for someone who knows what they're doing.The quality of the cards is pretty good.  They punch out of the perforations well, if not always perfectly, and the colors look good.  We experimented with both "standard" and "best" quality settings on the printer and did not notice a great difference between the two.  Using the "standard" setting saves some ink, always a good thing.  I also made a sheet of cards for my jewelry instruction business, and I like the homemade cards better than the ones I got made at Staples a while back.  I had more design choices on the Avery website, and the colors and layout are more attractive.Another plus about making your own cards is being able to save your template for future use and being able to make changes, such as if you need to change a phone number or email address.  You can add text boxes to the designs if you need to (which we did on my card).  There are a lot of color choices for the fonts and lots of font choices as well.  Once I got used to playing around with the text boxes, I had fun with the colors and fonts.Overall I would highly recommend these cards: they look great, they're enjoyable to make, easy and convenient to print out as many as you need, and you can save the template for future use.

Although I have not read the first book in Jane Smiley's ambitious 100-years-in-America trilogy, I didn't have much trouble following the events in this second book.  And I loved it!  Smiley's books have always been hit or miss with me - I loved Good Faith, hated Lidie Newton, loved Duplicate Keys, Moo was OK.  I think she's at her best here, chronicling and observing the everyday events of a large family in mid-century America.  This book's narrative runs from 1953 to 1986.  Each chapter is a year, and each year is depicted as a sort of snapshot of various family members and whatever they are doing at that time.  Judging from the first book's reviews, I would guess that this second installment will enthrall some readers and totally bore others.It should be noted that there is a large cast of characters.  The Langdon family is pretty big, but Smiley helps out by providing a family tree at the beginning of the book, which I referred to often for about 50 pages or so, until people started to fall into place.  Those who have read the first book, Some Luck, will find it easier to follow the narrative and it's probably a richer experience to know the people who came before, but I didn't have a problem getting to know and care about all the various characters.  Like Forest Gump or Zelig, her characters sometimes appear in the context of larger world events, such as the Vietnam war or the infamous People's Temple.  And some just go about their lives more anonymously, like many of us.  I liked watching some of the characters grow up throughout this book; Smiley does a masterful job of depicting a person's life through the years, often with just a quick scene here and there.  She has the gift of knowing what to include and what to leave out, often giving a complete look at a person's character with a very quick scene or two.People may complain that nothing much "happens" in these books - a complaint about many authors who write about everyday people going about their lives.  I find it fascinating that Smiley can take mundane events that we all take for granted - going to college, marriage and children being born and growing up, working - and make me want to keep turning the pages to see what happens next.  This book is about us.  I see my own family in it.  I hated to put this book down and I didn't want it to end, because I grew to love the Langdon family, even though some of them aren't very lovable, and I'm so glad there will be another book.  It's a beautiful book and a great achievement.

If I had to use only one word to describe this book it would be "true" -  my mother died in 2013 and my experience with her decline, move to a "Place", and eventual death - the feelings, the problems, the hassles, the pain - is almost exactly mirrored in Roz Chast's wonderful graphic novel/memoir about her own parents.  It's both laugh-out-loud hilarious (on almost every page) and very emotional, bringing me to tears more than once.  Chast vividly captures what it's like to deal with aging parents and deal with the never-ending issues that come with it.  Her honesty about her own feelings is admirable - I remember wishing I could be that "perfect daughter" who selflessly takes care of her parents while simultaneously wishing myself anywhere else in the world.  It would have been great to have had this book back when we were going through my mom's last two years because it would have really helped put things in perspective.  I loved it, and I highly recommend it to anyone who has aging parents.  It's the kind of book I want to buy multiple copies of and pass around to everyone I know.  I've enjoyed Chast's work in the New Yorker for many years, but this is a huge cut above, and very well worth your time.  Check it out.

These binders are perfect for organizing my many knitting and beadwork patterns.  They look great and are durable.  The rings are heavy-duty and hold a lot.  I'd say they're a little stiff when opening, but they stay shut; some binders' rings don't and then you have papers everywhere.  There is a plastic sleeve on the spine so you can make a label and slide it in, or do as I do and make a label with a label-maker and stick it on.  I always need these binders since my collection of patterns (and recipes, and other papers) is always growing.  Great product and one I will keep using.

A little bit of Hitchcock, a dash of Gaslight, a little Ripley, some Gone Girl...that's The Girl on the Train, and please believe me when I say that in this case, being somewhat derivative is NOT a bad thing.  I loved this book and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good character study with some twists and turns into a darker place.  It's very well-written and the characters are sharply drawn.  I won't say these characters are exactly likeable - I don't think I would want to spend much time with Rachel, a jobless alcoholic who spends a lot of time gazing out train windows on her way in and out of London; she imagines lives for all the people she sees, two in particular, who turn out to be nothing like the ideal couple she fashioned in her mind.  They happen to live near her ex-husband Tom, who is now married to Anna, with whom he has a baby.  All of these characters end up interacting through Rachel and the result is a very compelling story that will keep you up late to finish it.The book makes an interesting commentary on the shifting qualities of memory and how it can be difficult to pin down what actually happened in a given situation.  It's also a cautionary tale about not seeing people for who they really are or discrepancies in their behavior, because you love them or you don't want to see the truth about a relationship.  There's a lot to think about after the novel is over.  I finished it last week and I'm still thinking about it.  It's very, very good.  Definitely recommended for fans of Gone Girl, and for anyone who likes a riveting story.

Before reading this current entry, I'd read only the first two novels in the Maisie Dobbs series.  I enjoyed them but I wasn't bowled over, and I feel similarly about this new entry.  I've been struggling to figure out why these books don't wow me - I'm also including Winspear's last book which was NOT a Dobbs novel - and I think it's partly that Winspear doesn't seem to be able to vary the mood in any of her books.  They're all kind of depressing or sad throughout and there's no apparent effort to add any joy or humor to balance things out.  I think Winspear is a good stylist, but compared to some other mystery authors, I think she falls a little short.  Her books are almost too low-key and well-mannered.  It's not that I'm looking for violence or bloodshed, but a little more emotion, warmth and occasional humor wouldn't be a bad thing.The action in this book takes place in Gibraltar in 1937 during the Spanish civil war, where Maisie has ended up after a tragic accident takes the life of her husband.  Winspear quickly catches up readers on events in Maisie's life and then gets on with her story.  Maisie doesn't intend to stay in Gibraltar for long, but after stumbling over the body of a local photographer, she decides to remain there to investigate, resurrecting her old detective skills.  It turns out that work is a good healer.  Maisie finds a new outlet for her nursing skills and helps out a field hospital in Spain before heading home.Gibraltar is an interesting location and Winspear creates a nice sense of place in her story.  I know very little about the Spanish civil war, so I took the author's word for the events depicted that had to do with it.  The characters are well-drawn and I liked Mr. Salazar the caf owner very much.  As I said above, I just wasn't blown away; the central story about the photographer isn't that compelling.  This is the kind of book I want to like more than I actually like.I would recommend this book to Maisie fans and for fans of well-mannered British mystery.

I have a great interest in medical, legal and social issues in modern society, which this book explores in detail through the perspective of Brendan Reilly, M.D., one of a dying breed: the general practitioner.  Reilly discusses many of the problems of modern health care, such as lack of continuity of care (leading to many mistakes in treatment), too many doctors going into specialty practice due to the high cost of medical school, end-of-life issues and the question of how medical care should be managed in the elderly, affordability of health care, and many others, all through presenting real case histories.  Reilly's clear, flowing writing style make the book a pleasure to read; I found it more riveting than many novels.  His cases are fascinating, and his obvious compassion for his many patients is touching and seemingly rare in today's hurry-up medical environment.  Reilly is very open about his own mistakes in treating some memorable patients (I think he's too hard on himself, though) and, in hindsight, discusses how he might have better served them.I didn't find Reilly's views on modern medicine preachy, probably because I totally agree with him on most points.  Our current system does not work and does not serve us well, and we need doctors like Reilly to help us reform it.I would highly recommend this book to anyone with an interest in current medical practices and our failing health-care system, and I would especially recommend it to anyone considering medical school.

This little heater is perfect for under the desk either at home or in an office cubicle.  It heats up quickly and gives off a nice warmth with a low-noise fan pushing the air out.  I didn't notice a lot of difference between the "low" (170 W) and "high" (250 W).  The fan does not blow any harder on the higher setting, the unit just pushes out slightly more heat.  It has a "cool housing" - the red part - but the front is pretty hot and would probably burn if you left a hand there too long.A nice feature is that it turns off the heat if you knock it over.  The red "on" light remains lit to let you know to turn it off.I would not use it around small curious children or animals because of the front grill being hot to the touch.Overall, I recommend it and plan to use it whenever we have some cold weather.  My bead work area gets cold and it would be nice to be able to warm up my feet.

Sisters of Heart and Snow is a good family saga and I found it an enjoyable read.  There's a lot of emotion and it's sometimes a little melodramatic.The book is composed of two narratives.  The main story, about Rachel and Drew Snow, daughters of a Japanese mother and Caucasian father,  takes place in modern-day California and traces their troubled upbringing by their emotionally distant parents.  In the present day, Rachel is a wife and mother in San Diego and Drew, a musical prodigy, is struggling to make a living and has no close ties to anyone.  Their mother, Haruki, has been diagnosed with dementia and Rachel and her father Killian are butting heads over her care.  The other story is from an old book about ancient Japan, featuring a real-life female samurai named Tomoe Gozen.Haruki was sort of a mail-order bride and for whatever reason, Killian has always treated her like a servant and she accepted it.  Both their daughters have had issues with their parents' behavior and Rachel was kicked out of the family as a teenager because of her unacceptable, if natural, rebelliousness.  She eventually married and had children.  Drew, on the other hand, became somewhat of a drifter, without real relationships or a career.It's hard to have much sympathy for the parents.  Killian reminds me a lot of one of my grandfathers, who likewise looked at all women as servants and wasn't a person anyone wanted to spend much time around.  As I was reading, I wished the author had spent more time exploring his background and less time with the ancient samurai story, which frankly wasn't very interesting and didn't really inform the modern story that much.  Haruki is a sad character.  I can understand her behavior a little better, since she was a stranger in a strange land and had no means of support other than her husband.The book really shines with the stories of Rachel and Drew.  I loved them and their efforts to overcome their emotionally stunted childhood.  They are the kind of people you root for.My only quibbles with the book were the samurai story not being that interesting, and I didn't like the way the author tended to use present and past tense in the same paragraph, and switched from first person to third person in the narrative.  I found it jarring and wasn't always sure if she was talking about the past or the present.  Overall, though, I enjoyed the book and I recommend it.  It reminded me somewhat of some of Lisa See's Chinese family saga novels and would most likely appeal to readers who like her books.  It would also make a good book club choice.

I'm a long-time Law & Order junkie, so The Job was right up my alley.  A collection of short pieces depicting life on the job from the perspective of a New York City police officer, The Job is by turns funny, touching, weird, and scary.  We all think we know what cops go through in the course of their days, but this book really makes you think hard about what it's really like to deal with death and crime on a regular basis.  I particularly enjoyed the stories "Mug Shot", "Growing Pains" and "Big Day".While the style is not literary and the stories are liberally sprinkled with profanities, The Job is a very entertaining mix of the personal and the professional.  Author Osborne started writing down his tales shortly after retiring and then got a spot on a storytelling show called The Moth.  All of the stories feel like you're sitting in the audience listening to him, or as one reviewer noted, like you're sitting next to him in a bar.  The down-to-earth style makes the book more appealing than it would be if it had been "told to" a professional writer, IMO.  The only downside to the writing is that it sometimes gets a little repetitive, but I can't really hold that against him.If you're interested in real police stories or considering police work as a profession, I think you'll enjoy this book.

I have to agree with reviewers who couldn't finish this book because of the author's extremely irritating writing style.  I couldn't either.  Both her writing style and slow, dull narrative really turned me off.  I had high hopes for this book's interesting premise - tracking down an eccentric underground filmmaker whose daughter has died - but it got so bogged down with unnecessary detail and annoying italics that I stopped reading about 100 pages in.This book bears some resemblance to the imaginative and flawed House of Leaves (a much better book IMO), in that it uses made-up emails, photos, illustrations, Facebook posts, and so on, to help tell the story.  I admire that creativity and I would be completely behind a WELL-WRITTEN book that uses those devices, but here: not so much.  This book got a lot of press when it came out, and that is beginning to be a red flag for me that I need to wait a while and read a lot of reader comments before committing to it.  (I bought this one in hardcover...)I can't recommend it and I suggest any interested readers check out the one- and two-star reviews; there's a good reason they are there.

Exactly what I was looking for and for the right price.  I needed a couple of standard pillowcases for some of our extra pillows, and I got sticker shock at my local stores ($22 and up), so I came here to find some at a reasonable price.  I'm very happy with these pillowcases.  They fit perfectly and the cotton is nice and crisp.  Bear in mind they come out of the dryer wrinkled, so if you like them unwrinkled, you have ironing in your future.  Otherwise, I recommend them highly.

These light strings can be a little pricey, but they really add a lot to Snow Village/Dept. 56 displays.  We put up a large display of Snow Village this year and I wanted a few more lights to brighten up some areas.  The little houses and shops usually have lights inside them, but unlit trees and other accessories need a little help to stand out.  The lights make it very pretty.  My only complaint about this one is it's very short for the price.

The Furies is a very good character study and psychological drama set in what Americans would call a "continuation school", or a school for kids who have issues with drugs, crime, bullying, or other problems that have caused them to be removed from the regular school system.  This school is in Edinburgh, Scotland and main character Alex, a teacher and theater director, is hired by her friend Robert to come and work with the students at "the Unit" after her fianc Luke is killed.  Although Alex is barely functioning, she rises to the occasion and tries to engage her charges by having them read Greek plays.  The teens are, as one would expect in their situation, difficult to communicate with, but Alex eventually forms a bond with them, and things seem to be going well until one of the girls, Mel, begins to stalk Alex and finds out more than she needs to know about her life and past.  Mel makes a terrible decision which results in a tragic outcome.I thought author Haynes did a great job with both the story's setting and with her characters.  You can feel the cold in the winding streets of the city. The teens - Carly, Mel, Jono, Ricky and Annika - are very well done and realistic.  Like a Greek tragedy, the story unfolds in a way that seems inevitable, even though you want to shout "No!  Don't do it!".  I also liked the character of one of the lawyers, Lisa Meyer, and Alex's friend Robert, the kind of friend everyone would love to have.As well as a character study, this book is also a very realistic portrait of grief and how everyone deals with grief in a different way.I would recommend this book to fans of Tana French or Kate Atkinson.  It's a page-turner that will stay with you for a while after you finish it.

I wanted to like this book more than I did.  A wedding story set in Provence sounds like such a nice idea, but the execution didn't work for me.  I haven't read any of Sussman's novels before, so I don't know if this is her usual style, but I guess I was expecting something a little more genteel or classy (more about this below).The novel's story concerns older bride Olivia and fianc Brody traveling to France to be married at Olivia's friend Emily's (and husband Sebastien) inn.  Olivia's grown daughters Carly and Nell join them.  Everyone seems to be at a crossroads - whether in a relationship that isn't working, one that is prematurely over, work issues, infidelity, you name it, it's here.  That's part of what didn't work for me.  It seemed like there was just too much angst and not enough of anything else to balance it.  There was no joy or levity or happy feelings that I would associate with a wedding, and the wedding itself is a tiny part of the book, which is mostly an exploration of every character's issues.  The story also seemed too focused on everyone's sex life, which for me became rather boring.  Given the location, I was hoping for a happier sort of story, but the author apparently wanted to make the novel more dark or edgy and it really put me off.  I'm not sure who she was trying to appeal to in writing this book the way she did.  As other reviewers have noted, the use of constant f-bombs seemed unnecessary.  It was almost like she took characters out of another story and stuck them in this one, with dissonant results.I would not call this a beach or vacation book; it's too dark for that.  (I'm wondering what book some of the other reviewers read - this isn't a happy light read.)  I would recommend it for those looking for a family drama.  It's a quick read and one that probably won't stay with you for long.  I'm sorry I can't say anything better about it - it was a nice idea for a book, but just didn't work for me.

I found this book to be a refreshing, unsentimental and honest look at the way Americans deal with death - which is to say, not very effectively.  Author Doughty spent time working in a crematory and later went through mortuary school, and her memoir is by turns darkly funny, fascinating, disgusting, and touching.  I have a lot of admiration for anyone who works in a crematory, does embalming, or deals with mourning relatives - it's very challenging work and I couldn't do it.In addition to her own story, Doughty skillfully weaves in a history of embalming, American funeral traditions, other cultures' funeral rites and beliefs about death, and how the mortuary industry works, and it's all quite interesting, if sometimes a little difficult to read.  If you're squeamish, it might be best to steer clear, as Doughty spares no description in her quest to open the reader's eyes to what really happens to our bodies after we die and how we can best understand and deal with death more honestly and directly than we currently do.I don't know if I should say I "enjoyed" this book the way I would enjoy a novel, but I certainly appreciated it, especially since I have gone through the deaths of family members and am getting on in years myself, and I feel it's important to explore and be able to talk about our own ends openly, rather than tiptoeing around the subject.I would recommend this book to anyone with an interest in the mortuary/funeral industry, medical students (doctors in this country don't deal with death very well), and anyone who, like me, wants to understand more about death and how to plan for it.

First, let me say that I can understand some of the negative reviews of this book.  Much of it is not cheery or sweet and it's not what I would call a light summer read, which it sounds like some reviewers were expecting given the book's cover and blurb.  The characters, a large and varied Catholic family, aren't the most charming people in the world, and their matriarch, Alice, is downright unlikeable most of the time.  However, I loved the Kellehers' family saga, and I thought author Sullivan did a magnificent job of handling a large number of characters and a story line that did some back-and-forth in time.  I found the book very involving and really couldn't put it down.  (I felt the same way about Sullivan's The Engagements.)  I think she has a real gift for creating believable characters and conflicts and I admire her for not tying everything up neatly - real life never works that way and real families can be just this difficult and heartbreaking.  I also admire her clear-eyed view and refusal to become soapy or sentimental.  Women's fiction sometimes really irritates me, with its emphasis on happy endings and sentimental wallowing.Some readers may be put off by each chapter being from a different character's point of view - I got used to it and it didn't bother me.  In fact, I grew to like it, since some events end up being shown from varying viewpoints, and it's interesting to see how the different people see things each in their own way.Overall, I thought Maine was great and I highly recommend it as a very well-written family saga with the caveat that those who are looking for a light, breezy read might want to steer clear.  However, if you're game, this one will stay with you for a long time after you finish it.  I look forward to more from this author.

This book is interesting and involving, but I felt the title was a misnomer.  It's not so much about the actual "death class" as it is a biography of the instructor, Norma Bowe.  I'm not saying this is a bad thing - Ms. Bowe's extraordinary resilience in overcoming a horrific childhood and becoming a nurse and teacher is very compelling reading.  She is apparently an extremely giving person and much beloved by those who know her.  I admired her very much.  Where it sort of fell down for me was in the other stories of her various students and their ordeals.  It became a little like a soap opera and that is not what I was expecting from a book entitled "The Death Class".  I was hoping for insight into how people feel about death, cope with deaths of loved ones, prepare for it, etc.  So, because I felt somewhat misled, I can't give it the highest mark.  However, I do recommend it for Ms. Bowe's story; it's very inspirational.

I absolutely LOVED this book.  The first chapter alone is so brilliantly, edge-of-your-seat dramatic and involving that you can't help being drawn in, and Turner's beautiful prose and great pacing make this long book seem too short.  I never wanted it to end.  If you love historical fiction and are interested in early America, you can't miss with this one.  Be aware there is some violence (I'd say it's hard to write a book involving pirates without some violence).  The story never flags and Resolute Talbot is an unforgettable heroine.  Highly recommended.  Can't wait to read more from this author.

I really enjoyed Liane Moriarty's Big Little Lies (could have had a better title, though).  Taking place in the suburb of Pirriwee in Australia, the story follows the lives of a group of "kindy mums" - mothers of kindergarteners - as they prepare for a school fundraiser.  Madeline (mom to Chloe and teenager Abigail from her first marriage), just turned 40 and on her second marriage, meets Jane (mom to Ziggy), a younger single mom, and they form an immediate bond - Madeline is sort of a rescuer type and she sees quickly that Jane needs a helping hand.  Madeline's wealthy friend Celeste (mom to Max and Josh) rounds out the group.  They're pitted against the "Blond Bobs" - the school's alpha moms, along with the many other types of parents that will be immediately recognizable to anyone who's had a child in kindergarten.Each of the three women is at a difficult point in her life.  Celeste's Facebook-perfect marriage is showing some cracks.  Madeline, although happy in her second marriage, is smarting over the fact that her ex-husband and his new hippie wife are living in the neighborhood and seemingly luring her teenage daughter into living with them by offering more freedom.  Jane suffers from a past sexual trauma and can't seem to get past it, but her bond with son Ziggy is strong and she has good family ties.I liked the depiction of the three women's friendship - especially as opposed to the gossipy, mean-girl behavior of many of the other parents at the school.  Friendships like theirs can be such a refuge and Montgomery did a great job of making the women and their relationships real.  The other parents were by turns hilarious and frightening.  The power of gossip and the menace of bullying (both in children and adults) is very much a theme in this book - the destructive behaviors kids learn early and many adults never seem to outgrow is shown here in all its ugliness.  As I said above, anyone who has had a child in a public school - whether in America, Australia, or another country - will be reminded of how hurtful it is when your child is the only one who doesn't receive a birthday party invitation (given out in front of everyone, to make it worse) or when your child is accused of doing something without any proof.  There is also a great divide between the haves and have-nots in the school, also a subject I'm sure many people can relate to.The funnier parts involved "helicopter" parents who seem to need to micromanage every aspect of their children's lives, and parents who give their kids oddball names (one character observes "that kid is going to spend her whole life correcting people about her name"), in this case "Amabelle" instead of "Annabelle".  Although these parents may be somewhat stereotyped, they're very entertaining at times.This book is a real page-turner - I had a very hard time putting it down.  If I have a quibble, it would be that some aspects of the plot are a bit of a stretch, it's a little soapy sometimes, and the book in general has a bit of an agenda regarding domestic violence, but that isn't enough to take any stars away.  The characters are wonderful, I enjoyed the story from beginning to end, and I loved the ending.  I can't really say much more than that.  Highly recommended for book clubs and summer reading.

Although the blurb for this book makes it sound like it's going to be about Diane Berg, a Swiss psychiatrist who's just taken a job at a remotely-located criminal asylum in France, Diane is actually a minor character and something of a plot device in this bloated and fairly boring mystery-thriller from Bernard Minier.The actual main character is Martin Servaz, a police investigator who is called in when a body is found suspended from the edge of a frozen cliff a few miles from the asylum.  However, the "body" is a horse...yes, a horse, belonging to a local master of the universe, Eric Lombard.  The plot also involves an old case of a series of teenagers who committed suicide, a local man being killed, a dangerous serial killer in the asylum, a few red herrings, and a lot of needless description of the female characters' attributes and clothing.  Sadly, all this doesn't add up to a very entertaining book.  It takes quite a long time for anything much to happen (and the book is almost 500 pages long) and it's very slow-paced, which didn't work for me - a mystery-thriller should be fast-paced and keep me turning the pages.  I had to force myself to finish this one.  It didn't seem like the author was able to bring all the story lines together in a satisfying way.I agree with the reviewer who said the translation of this book from the French is partly at fault.  It seems like all the slang and idiom have been taken out of the dialogue.  I would also recommend a good editor - the book is easily 150 pages too long.I can't recommend this book even as a summer read - it's just not good enough.

Debbie Macomber's work has always been predictable - in a good way, like McDonald's - but it seems to be getting more and more formulaic as time goes by.  This latest book is fairly soapy and weepy, which may appeal to some readers but it didn't do much for me.  I've also noticed that the various series (Blossom Street, Rose Harbor, Cedar Cove) are becoming hard to distinguish from one another: melodramatic situations, one character always inconveniently pregnant or running away from a difficult situation, a relationship on the rocks, but always a happy resolution.  If that is what you crave in a book, you will be happy with this one.Plotwise, we have innkeeper Jo Marie continually musing over her dead husband Paul; mysterious handyman Mark always around but never giving anything away about his life; guests Ellie (in town to meet, in person, a man she met online) and couple Roy and Maggie (the requisite couple on the rocks).  The subplot about Ellie and her cyber swain strains credulity even for women's fiction.  I give Macomber credit for bringing her somewhat time-warped fiction into modern times by internet and Facebook references, but I just didn't buy this story.  Ellie has an annoying helicopter mother who is always texting her regarding her worries about meeting someone she found online, which is understandable, but the character is such a control freak it's hard to feel sympathy for her.Roy and Maggie's story is more conventional: sexting/emotionally cheating husband, unhappy wife, possible divorce on the horizon, you do the math.  Lots of tears.Jo Marie's constant inquiries (as she plies him with cookies and muffins) about the private life of her handyman, Mark, get old fast.  I wanted to slap her upside the head and say "leave the poor man alone!"  They have an odd relationship, which looks like it may be kicked up a notch in the inevitable sequel.The "letters" premise is somewhat thin and doesn't really enter into the story as much as one might expect from the blurb.  This is mostly a soap opera in book form.  It wouldn't be that important if the book weren't called "love letters".A couple of other quibbles regarding language use and format: the use of first person in Jo Marie's chapters and third person in the others bugged me.  And when people use phrases like "couple dollars" or "couple dozen", it bugs me, because it sounds lazy or uneducated to my ear.Do I recommend this book?  Only to die-hard Macomber fans, fans of this series (this is the third book), or for those wanting an easy beach or vacation read.

I wanted to view this recording of Balanchine's Nutcracker ballet because of a book I've owned for a long time called A Very Young Dancer, a photo essay documenting a young ballet student's participation in this production, back in the 70s.The production and filming of it are overall good - the DVD picture is fine and the photography is good - it's not easy to capture dance on film - some productions edit too much or don't focus on the whole dancer.  Some reviewers have noted that the production looks a little dated, but for me that's part of its charm.  It's true that the costumes and sets haven't changed much over the years, judging by photos I have seen, but I like that it has that continuity.I don't like the narration, but I think it's good to have it for first-time viewers and kids so they understand the story line.I wouldn't have cast Macauley Culkin, but I realize they probably did it because he was well-known at the time and I imagine the filmmakers were thinking that a "name" would bring in people who don't normally watch ballet.  I'd have preferred an anonymous young dancer, the way it would be in the actual stage production.As far as the performances, the child dancers sometimes look nervous or stiff - understandable because they're kids and if one were watching the performance on stage, their faces would be too far away to see the expressions.  I like the fact that Balanchine used children in his productions when it was appropriate, rather than short dancers impersonating children.  As for the adults - WOW!  The "Coffee" dance and the Sugar Plum Fairy/Cavalier pas de deux are worth the price of the DVD alone.  Both are absolutely breathtaking.  The "tree angels" were great - I loved how they looked like they were floating across the stage.  The rest of the cast are across-the-board very good too.If watching this with kids, bear in mind that the first part is mostly the party scene and there isn't much dance.  I got a little bored and I can see kids losing interest quickly.  It really picks up in the "land of sweets" second act.  While I was watching, I kept thinking that I prefer the first act of Baryshnikov's Nutcracker and the second act of this one.  It's probably better live - most things like this are - but as I said, I think it's worth watching for the performances of the adult dancers alone.I think this recording is valuable because we need to preserve performance - whether dance, music, or theater - as a cultural reference for the future.  I would highly recommend watching this if you are a ballet fan or if you have an aspiring dancer in the house.  It's also fun to watch the other well-known version starring Baryshnikov and Gelsey Kirkland and compare the two, as I was doing in my head while watching this one.  They're both quite worthwhile.

I really enjoy the 1st book and this one is just as absorbing and fascinating. The Wilde brothers are outstanding characters and I love their bond. The plot has me glued to my seat, I never guessed how it all panned out in the end.  1840s New York is a fascinating setting and the plot revolving around the inhuman treatment of the Blacks is honestly insightful, at times  heart wrenching. Love Tim's narration, his bond with his brother who is one fascinating character and his friendship with the Blacks and NY police comrades. Great series.

I jumped into this one right after Speak the nightbird and I am not disappointed. Excellent historical mystery with a touch of horror. Great plot and characters especially Mathew. kept me glued to my seat, unwilling to take a break. And now onward to book 3 and I am glad the writer is working on book 6!

As I am not into horror much, My only book from this writer was Boy's Life which I love a lot. So glad to pick up this historical crime mystery. Love the plot and most of all the protagonist's character. Looking forward to reading the reast of the Matthew Cotbett series.

I love this book when I read it in 2002, when it was first published under a different pen name. 13 years later I still remember the plot and characters because it has remained one of my favourites. Below was my review then:"This book is so good that I finished it in one sitting. There is not one wasted word and I was in for a thrilling ride once I started. The mystery is taut, intense and captivating, the entangled romance sensitive and touching. The hero, Kyle, with a weak heart, is immensely likable and well potrayed. It is a rarity that a character could stand up so well in short mystery novel but Kyle does. Kyle finally accepting the loss of his father and the revelation of a half brother he would never have a chance to acknowledge gives a touch of melancholy to the story. Definitely one of my favourites."This one certainly deserve to be rerelease to be enjoyed by Josh's "newer" fans !

I have been disappointed with contemporary mm romances in the past few months until this one. This has to be my favorite from this writer and one which I will reread, which is very rare for me as I have such a lot to get through. Deeply emotional and touching, Jimmy and Shane characters are so beautifully written and have me rooting for them till the last page. So glad for the last chapter which gives such a satisfying ending to these two men who have gone through so much and finally found a home with each other. Especially Jimmy who got under my skin right from the beginning and have me all teary eyed in parts. The story is told from Jimmy's view but in no way is Shane's character sidelined which is what fine story telling is all about. I also enjoy the town itself with its solid cast of characters. The atmosphere is quiet, the pace almost slow but never dull, which fits the story so well. This one is easily the best contemporary romance I have read this year. Such a gem. Highly recommended.

When I read that this one will also focus on a hetero sexual couple I decided to skip this and went straight to the Mako Shark series. Nothing against bella and casey but I prefer my MM to solely stick to the gay couple. But I did so miss Vincent and Frank when they appeared in Mako Sharp 2 so have to pick up this second one in the Chance Assassin series. Very glad I did as the unique and fascinating plot and characters kept me entertained throughout. Not for the squeamish but if you want something completely different in this deluge of MM books like I do after reading so many stereotypes, there is nothing better than these 2 series (Chance Assassin and Mako Shark) about a group of sociopathic gay assassins with their romance and murders. it was wonderful to watch how the relationship between Vincent and Frank played out in this second book. I get to understand Frank more who somehow come across more humane. Vincent is of course his delicious bratty self and I just love him. I can't get enough of these two and wish that the writer has not interrupted their story with that of casey and bella. Looking forward to the 5th book which the writer mentioned in her blog that she intends to merge the two series' characters.

I so enjoy this writer's imagination and style. I love Vincent and Frank in  Chance's Assassin. Mako  could not be more different from Frank and Vincent but Mako is just as distinct and fascinating as a character. He is a damaged child who never got to grow up. The revelation of what happened to him when he was eight and thus moulded his young life was quite a punch to the guts. I love that the writer held nothing back in these stories of assassins both in plot, their victims but most of all in the study of these characters including the supporting ones, which in this case we have Nasai who is just as intriguing. In the romance angle I really enjoy how different Mako was from sweet Toby and I look forward to the just released book 2 because I so want my poor and damaged Mako to be happy. And the way this one ended just made the second book a must read.

I really like this refreshing take on wolf shifters. There is real depth in both characters and plot. The writing is skilful, intelligent in parts and kept me glued till the ending. I enjoy the dynamics among these werewolves and I love both protagonists' background. What kept this from a full 5 stars is the frustration that the story is not 100% complete.  The story on  Albeus' intriguing background was sort of left hanging. I want to understand this supernatural aspect of their "conversion" more. And the what about more background on the other were wolves who are just as interesting. If the writer does decide to continue this as a series (I hope he does) I will return and up this review to 5 stars. However I still highly recommend this because it is so unique.

I love Jory and Sam and it is indeed lovely to revisit them. However this one like another reviewer commented is really all over the place, with too many other known characters. Should have just concentrated on this little family (including Dan of course) and more on their wedding plans, that little bit of excitement is ok and needed because Jory is our trouble magnet. On the other hand this is available free and I have to say it's nice of the writer to do that. But I would have paid a novella price for a better crafted little story because this couple deserves it

Sounded promising but when the sexual overtones kicked in on the very day they met I just got irritated and gave up. Can't these people write a MM romance plot without starting with the guys getting all sexually aroused on their first meeting?

I enjoyed the first 45% of the book as it was entertaining, light with lots of fun as Davo navigated his attraction for Lee. But after the two guys got together it was just meh. Too much distractions which did not contribute to the romance or the  plot. The situation with baby Maxine was funny at first but it soon wore thin. So did that childish thing with that Mr Magic 8 Ball. All the talks about Australian soccer and cricket was boring as were the talks with troubled gays in the centre which Lee worked in - what was the purpose with introducing all those small characters? The romance side was under developed except for the sex. No angst. The only excitement was when Lee was handcuffed by a crazy female and even then I question the purpose of that scene and found it stupid and how the heck did Lee get himself into such a position. At the end I even question if there was any plot. The only thing going for it was the writing but even that had a limit as I got more and more bored and could not finish it fast enough. So 4 stars for the 1st half and 2 stars for the 2nd half

Read 26% and did not bother finishing even if this is under KU. Lost interest when the guys get aroused for stupid reason. Such simple writing almost amateurish. No background and I could  not differentiate between the 2 characters.

I love this idea of the pilot and his wing walker, theirs was a sweet, at times touching romance, the beginning a tad sad. But one can always be assured of a happy end with this writer. I like both MCs especially Charlie. Took a bit of time to warm up to Nick as the man was pretty nasty in the beginning. There were parts which really goes for the heart. Like another reviewer I too appreciate that this writer is under KU.

The beginning of the story was promising as Titus "talent/problem" was revealed. I like where the plot was heading with the 5 ghosts united in death haunting Titus to get the justice due them. However Titus and Charlie as characters just felt a tad flat and sometimes it was as if the writer could not make up her mind as to their personalities. Especially Charlie. Charlie was a mid thirties closeted detective who had his share of death and crime. But his interaction with Titus was like a besotted teen. And Titus was Charlie's 1st man, really?! Then towards the last 1/3 or so, part of the story was bogged down by scientific info overload. And as for the killer identity it was so obvious to this reader and when his motives were revealed it was just the same old same old. I also have problem with the way the story was told, with Titus as 1st person alternating with Charlie as 3rd person. Titus' narration got me absorbed into the story but when the story switched to Charlie's 3rd person viewpoint, I was just less engaged as a reader. And of course the romance was the usual instant thing but that I could overlook as this was foremost a crime mystery. The writer hinted a sequel. As I like my ghosts, murders and mysteries I might follow the series but not a must.

This is so freaking-crazy-hilarious-funny.  Love every minute of the over 9500 locations. If you are this writer's fan do not miss this one. It is Klune at his frenzy best. Just-freaking-amazing. Love Gary and Sam.

This is one book I am not about to forget anytime soon, if at all, and that is saying a lot since I say the same about my favorite books. It is however not a story I will reread because of the revelation of the murderer and the ending which I found so tragically sad and wished it wasn't so. But please do not let this point from deterring you from reading it. Very well done murder mystery with a heartwarming romance weaved in. The reverend has a wonderful and engaging voice and all the supporting characters are equally wonderfully depicted. If you have read this writer 's works you will know he is great at comedies even if I did not enjoy some of his humor. Here the humor scattered about provided the relief and light heartedness very much  needed. Still as I came to the end I just felt heavy hearted but well done John Inman.
This one packed so much in less than 100 pages. Suspenseful, heartwarming, unique and even touchingly  romantic in a way. So glad the sequel is out.

Too much sex, the writer just overdid it. The story was too darn long with too  much rambling to and fro. Too much on the relations side and not enough plot to keep this reader interested. And some self indulgence by the writer naturally. I love May December relationship but this one was just unconvincing. Forget about the BDSM aspect as it is laughable that the needs of an experienced sub like Laurie could really be fulfilled by a spring chicken like Toby. Theirs was really a romance with some kinks kicked in.  Believe me Toby was no Dom! The beginning was promising but the characters soon started to unravel with Laurie behaving nothing like a jaded and world weary doctor he was suppose to be.  Laurie came across like a young fool who just got dumped by his first love as the story progressed. Toby was fine until the last part. Guess the writer was trying to give us non stereotype Dom/Sub roles but this reader was far from convinced. And now to dig into my pile of MMs for a normal Dom/sub couple to satisfy my sudden craving for a true BDSM relation.

This is a marvellous follow-up and even better than book 1. I love the writing as both very intriguing MCs and the exciting and original plot kept  me engrossed till the very end. The pace just kept on building and I was literally at the edge of my seat  as they confronted the evil which was absolute and believable. I love Nikolai's narration and it is wondrous to observe the mercurial Aleksey through his eyes. This couple is just wonderful, their love, fears, pain and doubt palpable. The writer need to give us more of this couple's story and adventure in this primitive New World. Please!

I am surprised by how much I like this as I have ignored this writer's books for years. Very touching in parts. Child abuse is not an easy read but the writer pulled it off "gently" and I like how Alex's plight pulled the two guys together. I commend the writer on Alex's character as this little boy just melts my heart. The two MCs are likeable and credible.  For once I am not annoyed with the almost instant love thing as the plot keeps me engrossed. The little twist towards the end is too good to be true but hey they deserve it. Good story.

The writer could not have ended this series in a better way. Dave and Nicholas have come a long way as this 3rd book revisit them 7 years later. No 7-year-itch for this married couple. They remain totally devoted to each other and could not be more in love. Nicholas' brain aneurysm remains a shadow but they never allow it to overshadow their lives as they live every day to the fullest. The writer has done a marvelous job expressing their love. The feelings and emotions  when Nicholas health turned for the worse is just excellent writing. I also love Robin's character. This eighteen year old is adorable as he remains adamant in his own kind of love for his precious uncle Nicholas. Ah.. the innocence and purity of youth!Of course the writer has to focus on the couple's beloved waterhole, filled with mystique and magic. After all the waterhole, with its enchanted pool, wattle and blue butterflies, was where it all started for Dave and Nicholas. A sense of urgency permeats the plot when the discovery of iron threatens its survival. There is a touch of mysticism and enchantment in the story as the song lines worked its magic to deliver a fitting resolution to the fate of their beloved waterhole. But most importantly Dave and Nicholas have their love which is even more precious and irreplaceable. Love the writing.

I really enjoy this series even if I favor this one less than the last three. This one does evoke a lot of mixed feelings. The main problem is the murdered victim Ivan Holmes. It is easy to get engrossed with this character as the crime mystery centered around this controversial character. I started off feeling for this character. This turned to dislike when his perversions surfaced, then turned to sympathy again as Ivan's tragic pasts were revealed. David's investigation works were just as detailed and interesting but there were times when I questioned how easy it was for David to secure his interviews. Surely it is harder for private investigators to get strangers to talk to them! I like the plot as David dwelt into the mystery that was Ivan and in the process discovered much more than he could handle. However towards the end I have to say the twists and turns and the action got to be too much. And some questions were answered too briefly just to wrap up the story.As for the characters David remained his true likable self. However there were one or two instances when I disliked him because of the way he approached his case. A bit of empathy on his part would have been nice because the David I knew from the last three books was a better person than that. I also would have preferred to "see" more of Jamie. One way was of course for Jamie to be more involved in David's investigation like in the 3rd book. The romance was secondary as these guys were already in a committed relationship and this one is foremost a crime mystery but I still felt the love between these two. There was a little family drama on Jamie's side to keep their private lives interesting.Lastly one thing really bugs me. A heinous action, more like a crime, committed over twenty years ago with devastating consequences was never punished. This really frustrated me. Life is not fair but I at least want it to be fair in my fiction. Another enjoyable addition which kept me reading till the end so please do not end the series.

This may be less than a two hours read but this little story is just beautifully done. Quiet, gentle, tender, kind and honest it left a lasting impact long after I finished it. It may be a short story but there is nothing short about the slow burning romance as these guys learn about each other to finally accept and love each other. I love Jesse's patience as he slowly draws Con out of his shell. I love Con's care for Jesse who will always come first. And I thought the impact of Con's PTSD on their relationship is so well portrayed. There is no miracle cure but to be accepted and lived with and as a result become stronger in their love for each other. I wish the writer has given this little gem a much better cover.

How to put this. As a mild gay romance this one reads fine. The beginning of the story is interesting as we get to understand both guys and what they have been through. But once they are together, the story is quite boring as there is not much to the plot. This one works better as a novella. However I will read the next one offered by this writer as long as it is under Kindle unlimited.

I do declare this second book is even better than the 1st one Death by Silver (Julian Lynes and Ned Mathey series Book 1) in this series. As in the 1st book, I enjoy the well crafted setting of Victorian London. I love that the writers have taken the guys' British reserved romance, restrained by the times,  to a more realistic level where they are forced to examine their feelings if what they have is to survive. Both guys are such charming characters, Julian the more rebellious one with less regard for the law and Ned the more restrained one but no less valiant. The mystery part of the plot with its magic and supernatural aspect is most intriguing as layers are revealed with each death, the last part have me riveted to my seat even if I know our heroes will make it! The new development with Ned's permanent engagement by the police certainly adds more depth to the guys' investigation.What really stands out in this book is how well the writers examined the gay community during that time. The dangers if discovered, who could protect them, not only from hostile outside forces but from their "own kind", the malice within the gay community itself where the vulnerable ones are abused, and yet the need to preserve the community and its clubs because it is so vital for their sanity. All these is seamlessly weaved into the story which at its core is a supernatural mystery permeated by a sense of urgency as the number of bodies piled up. This second book with its quality writing is such a pleasure to read and I hope there is much more to come, Please!

This one kept me thoroughly entertained, laughing aloud (and that is right weird with people around) for close to 2 hours. Jay and Simon are such a cute pair. You already have an idea from the cover. I enjoy the tongue in cheek humor and numerous parts are downright hilarious. My favorite is Jay (in his bird form) preening, shimmying, proudly performing his mating dance in front of a clueless and stunned Simon. This is so original and hysterically funny. Then there are the birds puns which are just crazily funny. A most unique avian shifter story. Some may complain about the instant attraction/love but it fits the story because it is a comedy. My only niggle is its length but no complaint about the price because it is worth it.

I really enjoy this one. I was on holiday in New Zealand for two weeks and really love this beautiful and peaceful country. So the setting of the story in NZ with the wonderful descriptions is such a pleasure to read. I especially enjoy the camaraderie among the sheep shearers and the writer has certainly done her research, including the slangs. I like both the MCs and their slow burning romance. Sex only starts about 60%+ into the story which is just fine by me! Some maybe frustrated with the guys not having a heart-to-heart talk to sort out their problems but given the time they knew each other I thought it was realistic. Also there was a 15 years difference between Shane and Lachie. This is not a May-December romance but I could understand Shane's hesitation and the impression Lachie gave, before the earthquake forced him to man up, was really of a carefree bloke. Also these are real men with a blue collar job so sitting down and chat about their emotions is probably hard to do.What made this story special was the Christchurch earthquake and its impact, which I thought the writer has done a great job weaving it into her story. Those pages were such touching scenes. However I do have a few niggles. The brief epilogue is rather disappointing, as if it was just an after though. It sort of created a gap to the story line. It would not "kill" the writer to give us more details on what had transpired to lead to that point which was obviously years later. It is also a pity the writer did not give us more emotional connection between the guys once the major misunderstanding was cleared. The leapt straight to the brief epilogue after they understood each other was such a let down, as if something missing in the flow of the story.

This is such a wonderfully written fantasy. This marvelous trio of a magician, a sailor and their hippogriff really got under my skin. Magical, vivid, charming this little story is gorgeous. And I love the slow paced of the romance. A tad sad but the ending more than made up for it. I just wish there is more adventures of this trio. I have always felt this writer is great in short stories and this again proves my point.

This is your typical MM romance which is easily forgotten one or two weeks later. Nothing really stands out even if it was fun in the beginning when these two guys met and got to know each other. The usual sex and misunderstanding and reconciliation. Even if this is self published, careful editing is appreciated. In the first part of the book, I have no idea who is saying what and the switching between the two guys' viewpoints is so frequent that it is irritating.

I read this straight afterThe Picture of Cool (Trager Family Secrets Book 1)as I was interested in how it will pan out for Charlie and Joshua. I have to say The Picture of Cool ended very awkwardly even if it was meant to continue, something which a good writer should not do even if it was to tempt the reader to read the sequel. I do not think I miss much in skipping Book 2, nothing essential to Book 3, anyway.Back to book 3. The writing held my attention as the plot raced on at a good speed but never rushed. Charlie's work as a TV producer of a live talk show is interesting. His keeping his divas in line is a fun read. We also get glimpses of Joshua's round the world preparation to run for Congress . I was never bored but as a relationship and romance between two guys, much more could have been explored. I never got the connection between Charlie and Joshua. I am not talking about the lack of graphic sex because I am all for no graphic sex in my gay romance. There is just not enough focus on their romance or relationship development. I can count the number of times these two were physically together. There were more scenes on Charlie hanging out with his best friend! Is it because this is the writer's first full blown MM novel and she really does not know how to write a gay relationship adequately? Joshua's asking for space and time, Charlie wanting to be patient, illicit meetings, phone conversations over distance, misunderstandings then all is forgiven as the major problem hanging over Joshua's custody of his kids was miraculously and conveniently resolved. That about sum up their relationship. There was no heart-to-heart emotional exchanges between the two. I could not find the love between them and I still do not understand what Charlie saw in Joshua. Another major issue was that these guys' relationship was a result of an illicit affair. This is never an easy subject in a story and the writer has really not handle it well. Too conveniently and easily resolved. I recommend the writer to read the excellent In His Secret Life to get a lesson on weaving this taboo subject in a gay relationship/romance.

First this is not a YA story. It is a touching love story so well expressed, spanning years, from the time the guys were teens until in their twenties. I especially love Cooper. Cooper's love for rocks is such a fascinating aspect of the story. A sensitive child, Cooper's need for rocks to ground him and soothe his pain just moves me.  So many different types of rocks, with the writer giving details on their meanings and even some of their origins. How the meaning of each rock is woven into the story is a marvel, even magical. But it is not only a love story. It is also about families, a family born into and a family made not by choice but forced by circumstances but ultimately just as important.The beginning of the story really pulls me in. A twelve years old Cooper forced to face betrayal by the most important person in this young life, forced to choose sides, except that it was not even possible to choose. How he and his sister grew to accept and love their two "new" families is such an integral part of the story, at times heart breaking.How Cooper met Jace for the first time is an unforgettable scene because it was such a betrayal at the same time. These two boys were really tested through the years as their relationship grew from Cooper at first wishing only to hate this boy who broke his family, to grudging acceptance, to friendship, to brothers and finally to love. But a love with a shadow hanging over it, an unrequited love, slow burn, aching and so much yearnings. There were a lot of times when I wish to shake Jace because my Cooper was suffering so. But the story is told with Cooper's voice. I soon realize Jace was suffering too. And the years as these two boys yearned for each other only strengthen their love. The day when they came to an important crossroad, when the answer to "that question" is no longer needed or even mattered is such a beautiful moment in their love.I also have to say something on the secondary characters and their impact on Cooper's live. Cooper's two best friends support during Cooper's coming out was wonderful. Cooper's headstrong sister is such a credible character and their sibling love is so real. Last but not least are the parents. These "adults" are so well portrayed, their love for their sons, the pain they went through palpable and real.This is such a gem of a story, filled with emotions and love. Love the writing and highly recommended.

This one really taxed the highlight function in my kindle as I kept highlighting sentences, phases which I wish to reread and reread. Josh is really in top form here. His writing is amazing. A great mystery which kept me interested and guessing, witty dialogue, interesting secondary characters, cameo appearances of my number one favorite couple and most of all Kit and JX as they enter the most emotional phase of their relationship. I love Kit's character. I love his directness, self deprecating, irony, self absorption and anti social behavior. His inner monologue is just so crazily lovable, whacky, funny, self absorbed and involving. It is just amazing how Josh intersperses the serious aspects of the plot with witty, at times hilarious, and memorable smart lines.The mystery itself with a lot of thrilling moments (my favorite is that creepy motel) is top notch as I never could have guessed how it all enfolded. The stalker aspect is really good as it adds creepiness to the plot and somehow managed not to sidetrack the main plot. What I appreciate most is that the romance is as much the focus as the mystery, if not more. It is such the perfect balance. There are real issues in their relationship as they struggle to make it work. I love that Kit is finally willing to take that leap of faith. I love that JX is not as cool as he seems when the guy just hurts when the insecure side of Kit explodes in his face. This two is so great together and I love that most of the book have them together. Really it is like having the pleasure of observing a favorite couple living a real life except that their life is filled with love, excitement and suspense.Now I just have to say something about that cameo. No fiction couple can replace Adrien and Jake who remain affixed in my brain because I frequently reread these two. I am certainly in the majority of Josh's fans who want more of them. To see them from the outside which is through Kit's eyes is quite something. So this cameo really "comforted" me because I "see" that my favorite couple is living well together.  OK I sound crazy but hey! So thank you Josh. I love this cross overs of couples from other books by Josh and this is the second time. I hope he continues to do that because I savor a "ah-ha" moment.I realize I am gushing a bit but this one is so worth the wait. It is a definite winner to be reread and reread. And those Ms Butterwith's titles are hilarious!

I love well written young adults books featuring gay protagonist and this one is just that and more because it is also a great fantasy. I was glued to the book until the last sentence because I just could not tear myself away. It is easy to make comparison to Harry Potter series but this is not Harry Porter. Fay, Sam and Tyler are older characters with their problems. The guys have sexuality and relationship to deal with while Sam never got over the death of her mother. I love the friendship between Fay and "kick-ass" Sam and the romance between the boys is sweet. It is not really a coming out story but I like that the writer treat bisexuality as if it is just a norm. The contrasting personalities between the boys and Sam provides a lot of fun in these three friends' bantering. But this is foremost a fantasy and the plot is really exciting with lots of suspense, action and magics. The battle scenes are captivating and vivid and handled so well. Winter is my favorite season and so Fay's magical abilities is just so cool! Even if this is Book 1, I did not see the final pages coming and therefore the ending really resonates. If this is the writer's debut it is very impressive and bravo indeed. My only problem is when is the next book. As Book 1 ends with "..Behind me, the stones on the beach were covered in a thin layer of frost..", I can't wait to read more of Fay's fate and such a lot of questions to be answered.

This story is filled with so much honest and genuine  emotions and feelings. What Travis had with his dead wife, the developing love between Travis and Wesley, the love between man and his dog, the strong bond among Travis's three children, the love between Travis and his kids, all are convincingly and movingly expressed. Travis, Wesley, the children, Wendy and even Shannon are such well developed and likable characters. Shannon may be dead but it seems she is still alive as she lived through Travis' love for her.The story is told from the two guys' viewpoints, interrupted by a viewpoint each from six important secondary characters and it works because we get to know and appreciate these secondary characters more. I especially love the children's views which give such a refreshing tone to the story. The writer really gets how a child feels. Quiet little Mason is just adorable, Caleb is such a great young man and little Avery acting out her favorite disney characters at the expense of her twin yet protective of her twin is sweet.This  is no girly fluffy romance between Travis and Wesley. Theirs is a credible and touching journey as one man could never cease loving his dead wife and the other has to take a leap of faith and believe he will not come second for the man and the family he has grown to love. There are no pages of filler sex, but real, moving and true emotions. I also like the small town setting and I though the writer has done a great job on the reaction of this small town to one of their own men falling for the gay vet, new in town. Over 360 pages, this book is so worth it and it has definitely earned a place in the best contemporary romances in the mm genre. Actually I will say gay romance fiction which gives this book more credibility. Highly recommended. And now to look up other books by this writer.

If you are a fan of Claimings, Tails, and Other Alien Artifacts you must read this continuation. This second book is even better. The writer really excels in her world building skills and her two characters. Ondry and Liam are just fascinating. I love this couple. Theirs is not the normal romance.
