Have over the years tried various remanufactured cartridges, some work, some do not.  These so far are working just fine.  As cost of HP cartridges continues to climb being able to use remanufactured is a great savings, provided they work.  So far very pleased with these.

Have used this under its various names for many years and always found it making the tax season much easier.  Started using it when moved from Turbo Tax in the days of dial up internet (shudder) because Turbo Tax took forever to download updates.  Also Tax Cut (as it was known then) gave you all states free (alas, no longer now you get one and have to buy others you may need).  Updates with Tax Cut (now H and R Block Tax Software) downloaded quickly and still does even with faster download speeds.  You need the Deluxe edition if you need to file a state return (how lucky can you Texans be!) as it includes one state return although not in e filing format.  Does include up to 5 free e files of Federal returns.  Overall it is excellent value and does the job well.  The edition from Amazon came in a plain envelope and oddly did not include quick start instructions.  For those of us who have used it for many years this is not an issue but for someone new to the software including the quick start instructions would be useful.

I have bought this book for many years for use in conjunction with HR Block tax software.  While much of this can be found in the HR Block software it is very handy to have this book for reference as issues come up during the year.  And the introduction which discusses items that are new this year is a helpful review.  As taxes get more and more complicated every time they try to simplify things having a reference in book form is extremely helpful.  If it saves you from making even more tax mistake it is well worth having in your library.

I have used this product under its various names for many years now and find it very useful in completing my returns.  This item from Amazon came in a plain wrapper but works just fine.  Only drawback was it did not come with instructions, even a quick start set of instructions.  That was main difference from the one you can buy in the stores.  For those of us who know how to use the product it is not an issue but for someone who has never used it before it could be a problem.  Of course when they gave away all states as part of the product in the very beginning that was a great value.  Now you get one state and have to buy others you may need.  Except that is for the business applications.

I started shaving....well it was many decades ago!  Started with a Norelco shaver.  Never did seem to give me a really close shave.  Over the years have gone back and forth between blade and electric hoping that one day an electric would give me a shave that is close to that of a blade.  Must say that my first shave with this razor impressed me.  First it was gentle and quiet especially compared to my Remington foil shaver.  And while it is not entirely as close a shave as a blade it is very, very close.  Alas, I have lost most of the hair on top of head and finally gave up with the comb overs.  Between barber trips every two weeks get a bit of stubble on top and neither my blade nor my electric would take that done.  But this razor does.  Of course to keep it giving me a good shave I will need to replace the head every year or so and that is not cheap.  But then neither are razor blades.  An electric is so convenient and I am pleased to have finally found one that actually seems to come close to a blade shave.  We will see as the months progress and should it decline in performance I will be back to add to this review.

Cute desk item for someone who likes dogs.  Is lightweight so not a dispenser you can take tape from without holding it.  But it is also a plus if you pick it up to pull piece of tape.  Anything to bring smile to day good in my book!
Fun item for kids.  My daughter in law is a PA and know she will have fun with this with the grandchildren.  Lots of little items here for them to have fun playing with.

Extremely useful especially with my induction cooktop.  Those will not work with aluminum or ceramic pots or pans and the Lodge pans are quite heavy.  But by putting this griddle on the induction cooktop I can use my lightweight aluminum pans and ceramics too.  True, I lose a bit of heat efficiency but not enough to make a difference.  The low lip on this griddle lets me use my pans with handles easily.  I have larger Lodge cast iron pans that will not let me do this.  So for use with induction cooktop this works great for me.

This is update to prior review.  I liked the eTrek 20 a lot but a question from Amazon got me looking at the Oregon 650t as well. Got question on review saying was comparing to Oregon. My kids ended up getting me that for Christmas.  It IS more expensive (a lot!) but the t model includes the 1:100K map preloaded so I can have that for travel while keeping my 1:24K map inside for use locally.  Also has a camera with flash that I can use to geocashe and general use.  Nice when sailing and do not want to take regular camera.  The Oregon 650t has a touch screen and its screen is quite a bit larger (3 inch diagonal vs 2.2) and only slightly larger overall(.3 width and .5 length with same depth).  But it is more expensive so if price a factor (and when isn't it!) then the e Trek 20 is a great choice. At the moment Oregon 650t is 4 times as expensive as the e Trek 20 on Amazon so you have to really want those added features (or get as a gift!) to choose the Oregon 650t over the e Trek 20. On other hand it does include the 1:100K topo which goes for $80-100 but even so it ends up more than double the cost.  But for those of us with Kindle Fire and I Pad (have both) and used to touch screen having that is very nice.  Writing this before Christmas so have not tried the Oregon yet as it is sitting under the tree.  Will repost after using a while and give comparisons.  As mentioned below I found the toggle on the e Trek 20 bit awkward and I kept hitting the menu button when wanting to zoom in or out (same side) but once you get used to it works great. Manuals are not great but if you are adept at all with equipment like this you will eventually figure it all out. I suspect manual issues will be same with Oregon.  For less than a third the cost of the Oregon (half if you want the 1:100K topo of US) it is a great device.Old review:  Use this while hiking and sailing.  Took a bit of getting used to with toggle vs touch screen.  Kept wanting to touch the screen.  Also menu can be bit confusing until you figure it out.  Lots of features did not plan on using such as the area calculation (useful in measuring grass area of yard for fertilizer) etc.  Bought with both 1/100K topo of entire US which is nice while traveling.  1:24K nice for my particular area.  Did find installing the maps in the micro SD bit of a challenge.  Overall extremely pleased and would buy again.

Buying anything with suction cups is always a gamble, and one with low odds of success. But I got this anyway because I couldn't find any other alternatives for a bathtub hoop. Well, the suction cups are a total failure. Even on smooth wet tiles, they won't stay on for more than a couple of minutes, and that's if you don't touch them. So, impossible with a baby/toddler in the tub. Luckily we have one of those old ceramic soap holders with a handle built into the tiles on the wall, at just the right height, so I was able to tie the hoop to it. It's the only way it will not fall. It droops down now, but whatever... Better than nothing. My daughter loves it anyway, and loves putting all her bath toys through the hoop. I ended up cutting the bottom of the net to make it a true basketball basket so things could fall through. I don't understand the people complaining about that. All you need is scissors. The balls from this set have become my daughter's absolute bath-time favorite. No matter what other toys she has in the tub that day, she always asks for the balls, too. She has to hold them while I'm putting her pajamas on, too. She's obsessed with balls in general, and these are definitely her favorite, for some reason. I wish they didn't have holes (I'm always suspicious of mold), but on the other hand, she loves that they squish down pretty flat when she bites them, which wouldn't have been possible without the holes. No mold yet so we're happy. I just wish the damn suction cups would actually work!

I got this when my daughter was about 15 months old. It was an instant favorite! She had a lot of fun putting the rings on the tentacles and taking them off again. We've had it for over 3 months now and it's still one of her all-time favorites. She likes pointing out his facial features and all the dots on his head. She likes playing with the rings separately, too - like looping them around her fingers or toes, or around mine. The octopus has a hilariously goofy expression, slightly cross-eyed. I love that none of the pieces have any holes in them to collect water and mold. Basically, the perfect bath toy. I don't know if it can serve as an actual ring toss - haven't tried it - but it works great as is for now.

This is a very nice, soft, comfy set. It's well made and the material is very pleasant to touch. It fits as expected for the size. However, there are no buttons or anything on the neck, and the seam isn't even stretchy - it's a rigid set size that has no give, which is very surprising for baby clothes. Usually they have at least a lap shoulder or something. The shirt on this set is VERY hard to get over the head of the child, and requires a lot of pulling and tears. My daughter is very average-sized in every way except for her head. She's in the 82% for head circumference and it's a torture to get this shirt on her. But that's why you make baby clothes with extra room or a button on the neck! Babies have big heads and they vary in size! I'm so very disappointed with this design, especially because I otherwise love the outfit and don't want to have to toss it or cut it, but I'll have to.

I bought this car seat because of its great reviews elsewhere, its new system of easier latching, and the fact that it will last us a long time before being outgrown. I got it after my daughter outgrew her first car seat (the bucket). After almost half a year of use, I can say that its definitely easy to install and secure once installed. The cushioning is plentiful and comfortable, and the seat looks well made and reliable. Its big enough to accommodate a growing child, but not so big that it wont fit in a small car. We have a small Nissan Sentra and it fits perfectly, taking up only the middle seat in the back with plenty of room for a passenger on either side. It doesnt obstruct the rear window or anything. Basically, a quality car seat.However Theres one big drawback, which is so infuriating that I couldnt help but drop two stars for it. The harness SUCKS!!!!!!!! This is the most annoying harness of anything Ive ever used, and having a toddler, Ive used a bunch of harnessed contraptions. Its absolutely infuriating. First off, the left and right belts are not anchored to the seat anywhere - its all one long belt loop, so if you pull on one side, it gets too loose and the other gets too tight. Then when you pull the tab to tighten the harness, it gets tightened unevenly on all 4 sides (left shoulder, left hip, right shoulder, right hip) so with EVERY single use you have to do this balancing act of pulling on the 4 parts separately until theyre even in length, or else the harness is not secure! To make matters even worse, the belts love to get twisted up behind the back of the seat and then get stuck in the slit they come out from on the front. But you cant see around the back It took me forever to figure out why the belts were so hard to pull, until one day they stopped pulling out altogether, and after some thorough checking of everything, I realized one of the sides was twisted up on itself at the back and wouldnt slide through the slit anymore. Now at least I know to look for it, but it does still get twisted up every couple of days, so I have to grope around the back to untwist it. Not what I want to do with a squirming toddler whos trying to jump out of her seat! The chest clip that holds the two shoulder straps together doesnt slide easily up and down the straps, so thats another point of frustration - more pulling on things that dont want to cooperate and get stuck. Also, the straps have no padding whatsoever and cut horribly into my poor daughters neck, especially in the summer when she doesnt have a lot of clothing to go between the edge of the strap and her skin. So in the summer, she has near perpetual friction burns on the sides of her neck from the damn belts. I sometimes try to tuck something under the belts, like burp cloths or napkins, but she wont let them stay there because shes 18 months old and ooh look whats that on my shoulders!!!If Id known about all those issues, I wouldve gotten a different car seat. There are plenty of options out there that are still safe and comfortable, but that dont make you miserable every day. We drive our daughter to daycare every day, so this is something I have to deal with daily, not like a minor flaw I can just neglect. Frustration is my main experience with this car seat. Im sure its great in every possible way, but with our next kid, Ill be getting a different model.

Weve had this stroller combo for a year and a half now, and havent had any problems yet. I really like it! Its lightweight, maneuverable, well padded and comfortable for the baby, gives a smooth ride and is easy to use. The car seat lasted about 14 months before my very average-sized daughter got too tall for it. She was about 20 lbs at the time. The car seats weight limit is 35 lbs, but most kids will outgrow it in height way before they reach the weight limit. So I dont see the big deal with the new model Graco car seats being 35 vs. 30 lbs and the same size Seems like an unnecessary bragging point. Unless you have a REALLY fat baby, I guess.The best feature of the stroller is that the back of the seat reclines all the way down to form a bed. Its very spacious. My daughter is 18 months old now and still loves sleeping in the stroller when we go for walks. She fits comfortably, with only her feet sticking out. The car seat clicks onto the stroller (and onto its base) very easily, but the setup is very temporary. I only rolled her around in the carseat+stroller combo maybe for the first month or two, when she was really tiny, but after that she really wanted her space so I ditched the cramped car seat and put her in the reclined stroller seat-bed, and she loved it! And the stroller is so much lighter and easier to manage without the car seat. The two together are a good deal in terms of price, but with this particular stroller, the fact that the car seat fits onto the stroller isnt as big of a perk as I thought it would be. With the next baby I might just put him/her straight into the reclined seat bed from the start.The basket under the stroller is HUGE. It can easily fit the equivalent of 3 full diaper bags, plus a couple of adult jackets stacked on top. Its a bit hard to get things in and out when the stroller is in bed mode, but thats not really a big deal. There are two parent cup holders and a wallet/phone holder in the parent tray. The baby tray has a wide area, a cup holder and a bowl thing. It swings open to let the kid out, which is nice. The stroller folds easily and stands upright when folded, but it can fall over easily if you bump into it, so I have mine clipped to the staircase at home (we dont have a closet on the first floor of the house). Its not the most compact stroller out there, but its not meant to be. Its our nice stroller - we have a compact bare bones one for travel. This one still fits in the trunk of our very small Nissan Sentra though, with room to spare, so it's definitely not too big for small cars.The stroller has a 5-point harness, and I really like that you have the option of not using the shoulder straps. Thats not the case for all strollers. I find the shoulder straps unnecessary in a stroller. You're not going at high speeds so you don't need the poor kid tied down completely (unless you have a Houdini who climbs out despite the rest of the harness, I guess). 5-point stroller harnesses immobilize my daughter unnecessarily, gluing her to the back of the seat. That way its hard for her to reach and use the tray, or to lean forward to look around. She likes her freedom of movement, but hasnt tried to climb out yet, so just using the hip and crotch part of the harness is perfect (by comparison, our travel stroller has a fixed harness and she hates not being able to lean forward!).There is only one thing I dont like about this stroller. The front wheels are too close to the wheel brackets that hold them and go over the top, so in the fall, after a rain, wet leaves and debris that stick to the wheels gets rolled up and stuck in the small space, jamming the wheels. You can dislodge the debris by rolling the stroller back and forth a few times, or by poking the stuff out with a stick. Its kind of a pain But it only happens if you roll over wet leaves, which only happens in the fall, so its not a deal breaker, and not enough to drop a whole star. I hope in future models they leave a bigger space above the wheels.After a year and a half of use, the stroller is still going strong with no signs of wear and tear, and no malfunctions. Weve long moved onto a bigger car seat, but for the time we used this one, it was fine - no complaints. I would definitely recommend the combo, and especially the stroller. Great features and comfort for a great price!

This conditioner has been working better for my daughter's fine 3b/3c biracial hair than the Mixed Chicks one. I use it as a leave-in. It reduces the frizz to an impressive minimum, and with an older child it would probably eliminate it altogether. My daughter is 18 months old so she can neither sleep on a satin pillow yet, nor with a bonnet, and her hair isn't long enough to tie up or braid for bed; plus, she's very active and rolls around and messes up her hair all the time, day and night. So this is basically the worst set of conditions for maintaining curls, and yet, this product keeps them impressively contained! Her hair stays in shiny ringlets all day, with only minimal frizz by the end of the day, but if I occasionally pet it with wet hands to "awaken" the conditioner, it resets the curls and extends their life. Our regimen is to shampoo her hair once a week and use "Shea Moisture Coconut Hibiscus Curl Enhancing Smoothie" for regular rinse-off conditioner, then apply "Ouidad Krly Kids No More Knots" as a leave-in. On non-shampoo days, I pet her hair with wet hands in the morning to revive the curls and get rid of the (minor) morning frizz, and then before bed I spray her hair with a little bit of "Ouidad Krly Kids No More Knots" dissolved in water, enough to get her hair damp and slippery enough to comb through it. Since I can't tie it yet, I have to comb through it every night or else it gets knotted. It still gets a couple of knots despite the daily combing, but they're pretty minor and easy to untangle. With Mixed Chicks she never got knots, but her hair got very frizzy during the day. While it's still short and easy to comb through, I prefer 2 minutes of combing every night but beautiful, shiny curls all day, to less combing but more frizz. Right now this has been working out well for us. The conditioner itself is pleasant to work with (Mixed Chicks was very sticky and hard to wash off of my hands afterwards), has a pleasant faint smell, and doesn't get crusty when it dries. It's expensive, but at this point we need very little of it so it's not a big deal.

I had this top when I was a kid, almost 30 years ago in Europe. I still remember the circles whose colors would blend and change when it spun! I was looking for a pump top for my toddler, and when I saw this, my heart melted with nostalgia. I was so excited, that I didn't pay attention to the handle's design, and now I regret it. Even though the bottom part of the top is the same as back in the day, the handle has been redesigned and made WORSE, like so many things nowadays! Why can't they keep the old design and construction?!? These old toys worked, and they were built to last generations!!! My childhood top's handle was easy to pump, moved smoothly, and if I could pull it out of whatever storage it's in right now, I bet it would still pump smoothly. This thing, on the other hand, has a cheap, flimsy design that falls apart quickly. The core of the pump is a metal spiral thing, and by the sound of it, when you pump it, there's metal grinding on plastic, so a lot of friction and resistance. As you can imagine, when metal meets plastic in a battle of friction, the plastic won't last long. I'd bought another similar top by another company recently, and it was literally spewing plastic shavings when I pumped it. Needless to say, the plastic got shaved down enough that eventually the top stopped spinning altogether, within a few weeks of occasional use. Now that I'm looking more closely, all pump tops that I can find have this same design! That's ridiculous! This particular model spun okay for a few days, but within a week of occasional use it was already grinding down and hard to push. Right now it's very hard to push it down and there's a lot of resistance inside, with the plastic starting to shave off. This is the most ridiculous design and I'm heartbroken that 1) the design has taken over pump tops and I can't find anything else, and 2) that they've ruined a beloved childhood toy which worked just fine as it was!!!! After two spectacular failures, I'm done buying tops with this design and will be looking closely at the handle of anything else I buy. I do NOT recommend tops with this type of handle!

This is a really fun book! The story is cute, and the tabs are engaging. We've had this book since my daughter was 15 months old (she's 17 months old now). She was never scared of the eyes. In fact, she loves them! She loves all the tabs, but especially the dog's ears going up and down. Overall, this is a great, engaging, fun and funny book. My only problem with it is that the tabs are really hard to pull, even for me! They take a lot of force for the pop-up parts to really pop all the way and not just sort of crack halfway through. Add to that the little hands which are pulling on the eyeballs and other moving pieces, and it's a bit of a struggle to go through the book. It will be a long while before she can pull the tabs herself! So, that I don't like. But other than that, it's a great book that I would definitely recommend!

This is a great book for young toddlers (or even babies). It's very well designed and packs a lot, but without feeling too busy. I got it when my daughter was 12 months old, and she loved looking at all the babies. Around 14 months she became obsessed with babies, and would enjoy any image of a baby - in books, on the packet of diapers, on the wet wipes, in a magazine, just anywhere she saw babies! So she also became obsessed with this book, and has been since then (she's 17 months old now). She flips through it or brings it to me every day. I don't think it's too busy at all, at least not for her. She loves finding all the babies and looking at what they're doing. It's great how the book also shows actions, not just body parts or objects, and it has a lot of daily activities, like playing with different toys, sleeping, eating, sitting on a chair, clapping hands, etc. She loves imitating what the babies are doing, or their facial expressions, and naming the toys they're playing with (and showing me which ones she has, too). All in all, this is one of the best executed books for this age that I've seen, and it has been tremendously successful with my daughter.

My daughter loves this little book! It's one of her favorites (she's 17 months old). I can't remember when exactly she started opening the flaps on her own... Maybe around 12 months? She's dextrous though, so flaps are not a problem for her. At first she enjoyed me lifting them for her, and then she enjoyed lifting them herself, and acting surprised when she found the animal underneath. The illustrations are bright and cute, and the placement of the flaps within the illustration is very smart. The flaps close very tightly though, and need some fingernail work to get them open even for me, so that might be an issue with less dextrous children. I keep my daughter's nails juuuust a bit longer than ideal, specifically to help her work her flap books, and that helps a lot. She learned to use her nails, and can get them open on her own. She also seems to really like the size of the book. This is our only book of this size, and she loves handling it, flipping through it, hugging it and just carrying it around the house.One thing I specifically love about the illustrations is how rich they are, and how much stuff is packed in them, without making them look too busy. In a lot of baby books, the background is pretty plain, with emphasis on one or two things per page. In this book, without feeling overwhelming, you can find a lot of little things on each page. For example, there's a chicken or two somewhere on most of the pages, so we play "find the chicken". Or the kittens are in a basket in the closet, so you can also see shoes, slippers, a coat, etc. My daughter loves identifying the random surrounding objects on each page, like the shoes. Or that the horse has a bucket of grain (which she has learned to identify as "pony food"). Her latest obsession is apples, and right now she is absolutely in love with the page that has apples on trees! When she learns a new word or a new concept, which happens to show up somewhere in this book, she'll seek it out and flip to it over and over.I really didn't expect much from this little book, but it has been a total gem!

This is a good, solidly made toy. I like that it's made of wood and the dyes are safe. All the parts are sanded smooth and feel safe to touch and mouth. They have a nice weight to them. The toy is quite small, but it fits my 10-month-old's hands perfectly, so I think it's the right size for her. I don't trust her not to poke her eye out on the base, so I only gave her the rings and ball for now. She absolutely loves this toy, even though she can't stack it yet. She loves handling, chewing and rolling the pieces, putting them inside containers, poking her fingers through the holes. And the red ball... Ah, the red ball. It's her most favorite toy of all time. I would've never thought she'd get so attached to a plain wooden ball!!! She carries it around everywhere, and will only give it to trusted people, and only for about 3 seconds max. She looks hilarious trying to crawl on 3 limbs because she has to hold the ball in one hand.All in all, the toy has been a total success so far. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is the price. Come oooooon... It doesn't get much simpler than this. What could possibly be worth $17.69 on this thing?!?UPDATE: My daughter is 12 months old now and the red ball from this toy is still her favorite toy ever. I don't know what kind of crack they put in it. We just celebrated her first birthday, and all the new toys ain't got nothing on the red ball! I had to hide it so she would look at the new toys. I think my baby likes the simple things in life.UPDATE #2: At 15 months she's an expert at stacking the rings on the pole. The red ball still holds a special place in her heart, though it has recently given way to a baby doll. The biggest ring fits juuuuust barely in her palm, and she insists on holding the rings in her palm and not by the edge, so I can totally see why this stacker is the size it is. I don't understand why people whine about its size. It's made for babies, after all, and needs to fit them, not you! The size is perfect. My daughter loooooves ringing this thing, dumping the rings, and then again and again. Great toy.

These overalls are adorable, soft, and generally well made. However, they're useless if the baby crawls, sits, stands or walks. In other words, if the baby is being a typical baby for the 9-12 month range. The crotch and leg buttons keep unsnapping all the way whenever the baby moves, until the pants are flapping wide open with the butt hanging out. It's really frustrating chasing the baby around the room to keep re-snapping those buttons. I really love the overalls otherwise and wish they were more appropriately designed! Zipper maybe, or regular buttons?

These booties are very soft and fluffy, and convenient to put on and take off. I was skeptical about the magnets at first, but surprisingly, the booties do stay on! I think that's more to do with the fact that my daughter doesn't pull on them though. If she really wanted to, she could take them right off, and they do occasionally come undone and slip off, so with a more active baby I don't think they'd work as well.I got the 6-12 month size when my daughter was 7 months old (average size) and the fit was fine. Roomy, but not too big. Then, when she was 10 months old, even though they still fit, I got the next size up so I could put them on top of her shoes when we go out in the winter (in the stroller or car). She was standing and trying to walk and needed soft shoes to keep her socks on, but it was too much of a hassle to put the shoes on and off to go out in the cold, so having the large booties to slip on top of the shoes has been a great solution.I wash them on cold and air dry, but still, after the first wash, they are never this soft again. Which is a shame, because they are so unbelievably soft when they're new! That's not such a big deal though. What I actually don't like about them, and the reason why I dropped one star, is because they collect dust, dirt and all kinds of grime that gets caught and balled up in the fleece and won't come out in the wash. I can't even pluck it by hand! Because of the light color, they end up looking REALLY dirty, even after being washed! It's quite gross. So I ordered them in dark brown, because I do like them, but at least the brown ones won't show when they have this non-dirty dirt on them...I also have the matching mittens (same applies to them - soft but not as soft after a wash, otherwise good mittens, light color sucks).

This is a nice light. Does the job. It's bright enough for my 15-gallon tank. The light is pretty neutral in color. Maybe a bit blue-ish, but not too much. Unlike other reviewers, I don't care that it has no switch, since I have it on a timer. My biggest problem with it is that the suction cups don't work!! I had it underwater suctioned to the wall of the tank, but it kept coming off and floating awkwardly. Then I suctioned it to the wall above the water line. Again, same problem. Though I have to say, one suction cup comes undone more often than the other. It looks pretty smooth on the inside, but maybe it does have a defect somewhere. It's incredibly frustrating that I seem to have no way of anchoring it anywhere, and it keeps floating at weird angles and illuminating the lid instead of the tank, or shining blindingly into my eyes instead.Another problem is that when I have it underwater, it's like steroids for the algae! I get ridiculous green beards on everything in the vicinity of the light! This is the first time I've ever used an underwater light, and the first time I've ever seen beardy algae of such proportions, so I'm going to assume it was the light. No algae problems when I have it up above the water line. WTF?I love the idea of an underwater light, but this just isn't working out for me. I don't mind using it above the water - I just needed something that's water safe and won't rust. But the damn thing just won't stay on!

This is a nice cardigan, heavy and warm. However, it's very stiff and hard, especially after a wash (I wash it on cold and air dry). I can barely thread my baby's arms through the sleeves, it has almost no stretch at all. Frustrating. I wish the material was softer.

These were my baby's first shoes. She started standing when she was 8 months old and needed shoes, because her socks were constantly sliding off (and footies moved and slid around too much). I wanted the softest shoes possible, so they wouldn't limit her range of movement. For that purpose, these shoes are great! They are very soft, with a soft fabric sole that's completely flexible. They look cute and comfortable. They are very easy to put on and take off (for me... the baby hasn't figured that out yet, thanks to the ties). They even have grips on the bottom.My only complaint is that, with less than a month of wear, the grips on the bottom are already falling off, and the shoes look very worn. And that's a baby who isn't even walking yet, just standing and crawling! So, not very durable, but inexpensive enough that I ordered a couple more pairs.

This is an awesome baby book, both in terms of content and presentation. It's my favorite, and one that I recommend to all my pregnant friends. The information is reliable and scientifically backed (something that's very important to me), but written by parents in an accessible way. It covers all the basics. I absolutely love the format, too! After some general descriptions of what's going on, it breaks down the first year into months, and each month follows the same pattern of layout - baby's physical development, emotional, social, feeding, sleep, play, etc. I love that it has a "toys and games" section with suggestions for age-appropriate fun. I read the whole book cover to cover while I was pregnant, to familiarize myself with what's coming, and then after the baby was born, at the end of each month I read the chapter on the upcoming month, to refresh my memory of what's immediately forthcoming.I have both the physical book and the Kindle version (there's a nice discount on one if you already have the other - I appreciate that!) I have an older Kindle model (with e-ink) and agree that the book looks pretty crappy on it. However, it's perfectly fine on the Kindle reader on the iPhone, so I just read it there when I don't have the physical book with me. No big deal, and definitely not worth dropping stars on such an otherwise awesome book!

I did a lot of looking, reading and comparing before settling on a baby carrier. There are so many options out there, and each lacks something. This one seemed to combine the best of all of them. And it does! I LOVE this carrier, and so do my husband and the baby! It's been one of our best investments in terms of baby gear. It's pretty much perfect. We used it daily for the first 6 months of our daughter's life. Then winter came and her bulky coat was just awkward to stuff into a carrier, and we just didn't go out for walks as much. And she got heavy. I'm looking forward to using it again in the back carry position when the weather warms up again.Here's a breakdown of what I love about it:- The baby loves it! Really, that's the most important thing :-) She'd fall asleep as soon as I put her in it, even if she started off crying. We'd call it The Magic Backpack.- The original bjorn's crotch issues have been resolved in this model. The baby is actually sitting, not just dangling.- It's very easy to use. Can be clipped/unclipped with one hand. I never unclipped the bottom pair of buckles though - it was easy enough just to undo the top ones and slide the baby in and out from the top. I could do that myself, no need for another person's help (unlike with some other carriers).- Very easy to adjust, so both my husband and I can use it with just a tug on the straps.- Safe. There's no way that it can slide off of you or that the baby can slide out while you're loading or unloading them.- Comfortable on the parent. The wide waist band is awesome! I have a bad back but this carrier was very comfortable. I could walk around for hours with the baby in it. Until she started getting heavy, then it was more like an hour... But still, given my back issues, better than expected!- Easy to wash. Just throw it in the washer, hang dry overnight.- Multiple carrying positions possible - front facing in, front facing out (!), and back.- Newborn and up, without the need of a special insert.I'm trying to think of anything I don't like about it, and I can't really... The fabric tends to attract dust and pet hair, but it's not too bad. The buckles take some finagling until you figure out how they work. I hadn't seen this kind of buckle system before. But once you figure them out, they're fine. That's it... I really really love this carrier!!!

I love this stroller. I used it almost daily all spring, summer and fall of last year, and it has held up great. It's very well built, sturdy and comfortable. It's extremely easy to steer, and moves very smoothly. Very lightweight, too, and easy to fold and unfold, though it looks smaller in the pictures when folded than in real life. I haven't had problems with the black fabric showing dust or stains. My baby has never spit up on it, so I guess it just hasn't been an issue for us. We have a cat and her white hairs are a fact of life in our house, but I haven't noticed them on the stroller (unlike the Bjorn, which attracts them like a magnet!)My favorite feature of the stroller is the fact that it reclines all the way back, creating a spacious bassinet! My daughter rode in this bassinet from birth until she could sit up, and even after that, she preferred to take her naps in the stroller with the back all the way down. She could sleep for hours like that. Now I'm looking for a more portable travel stroller, and the full recline is a must have. I don't think I'll ever buy a stroller that doesn't have that feature.We have the Graco click connect car seat that goes with this stroller. It clicks easily into the frame (the back of the stroller does not have to be reclined for that). However, we've used the car seat into the stroller maybe once or twice total. The two are too bulky together, and the car seat is unnecessary as an addition to this particular stroller, because the stroller reclines all the way back. Our baby preferred the spacious bassinet of the stroller to the cramped car seat, in which shes forced into a sitting position. Even with the car seat tilted back the way it fits into the stroller, her upper body is flat but then her feet are up in the air.I have taken the stroller out both on pavement and off-road. It's obviously not as smooth of a ride as tires, but it's not bad. My baby actually quite liked the bumpy rides, so almost all of our walks were on trails in the woods, or at least at the park, and she slept right through. On our way to the park I even started rolling her in the grass alongside the sidewalk, as opposed to the sidewalk itself, because a smoother ride would keep her awake looking around, but as soon as it got bumpy, she'd go right to sleep!There are only two things I don't like about the stroller, but neither is a big dealbreaker for me. One is that the canopy doesn't go down low enough for summer afternoons, and on top of that, the sides are mesh for some stupid reason, so the sun shines right through. So, on a hot summer day, unless the sun is directly above you, the baby will be blinded. Not very conducive to naps! The "breathable" mesh is completely unnecessary. No way the baby would suffocate without a "breathable" canopy, even if it went all the way down.The second issue I have is that on the front wheels, the part of the frame that holds the wheel is too close to the surface of the wheel tire, creating a small gap that collects fallen leaves, dirt and debris, especially after a rain. Even if you go on the sidewalk, inevitably there will be debris there. They get rolled up and stuck in that space, jamming up the whole wheel, which stops turning. It's really hard to get the debris out of there, too, and unjam the wheel. I ended up carrying a butter knife with me to poke the stuff out with. It's fine on dry days, but when the debris is wet, it sticks to the wheels and gets rolled up and collected in that gap, and is quite annoying.All in all, Im very happy with the stroller and can see us using it for a long time - birth to late toddler years. And all that at a great price, too!

I would've never guessed that these simple cups would be so much fun to my baby. I gave them to her when she was about 5 months old. She's 10 months old now and has loved them all the way through. They are constantly in her play area (I rotate other toys when she gets bored with them) and she plays with them every day, every time I put her down in her playpen. I just don't get it. She loves the damn things! She holds them, chews them, throws them, bangs them together, etc. She can't stack them yet, but loves un-stacking them if I stack them for her. This has been the most unexpectedly successful toy I've bought for her yet.

This is a nice lightweight cardigan. I wouldn't call it a sweater, it's very thin. But that's what I needed it for. I use it as an underlayer when it's really cold. I'm nursing/pumping so I needed an underlayer with access to the boobs, so this has been working great for me. I'll wear it just by itself when it gets warmer. The fit is good and it looks nice. My only complaint is the buttons - they are really frustrating! Very flimsily attached, they hang loosely and dangle on just a couple of threads, like they're about to fall off. Their holes are too small for that size buttons, which, combined with the flimsy loose attachment, makes it almost impossible to put the buttons in or out of their holes!! I got so frustrated the first time that in my anger I ripped two  of the buttons out. They all need to be re-sewn and the holes need to be stretched. I can't use the sweater straight out of the box. That's very annoying.

We have been using this glider daily for over 9 months and it's still working perfectly fine. It's a very comfortable, sturdy, versatile glider that has been a life-saver with the baby! The cushioning is thick and comfortable, doesn't show any signs of wear or compression yet. The surface is velvety smooth and easy to clean. Rich chocolate color. It has a lot of versatility in the reclining positions, and it can lock in the position you want. When I was browsing gliders, I wasn't sure if that was all necessary, given the added cost, but people seemed to love the versatility and think it's worth the extra money. Well, it really is! I love that the seat slides forward, too, in addition to the back reclining backwards, so you can get almost horizontal on it. After all this time, the glider is still perfectly silent, which is crucial where babies are involved. I absolutely love love love this glider!There are only two things I don't like about it, but even though they are annoying, I don't think they justify knocking down a star.1. The pads on the arm rests are very flimsily attached. They wrap around and stick with velcro, and there's a flap that hangs down between the arm rest and the seat of the chair. That flap is not anchored to the seat at all, but just hangs down. What happens whenever you sit and use the arm rests, especially if you have a boppy in the chair or otherwise rub against the pads, is they rotate and the flap ends up pointing up or sideways, the velcro gets pulled apart and exposed from the spinning, it crinkles and catches your clothes or baby blanket, and because it's exposed, it feels rough on your skin if you lean your arm against the arm rest. I keep having to rotate the damn pads so the velcro and the flap point down, but it keeps shifting, because it's not actually anchored in any way. Annoying, and could've been prevented, if there was another piece of velcro holding the flap down, attached to the seat. But it's too short and won't reach, if I were to sew a piece of velcro onto it...2. A much bigger annoyance is the ottoman. I hate that ottoman!!! It glides back and forth like the chair does, which initially seems like a cool feature. But only initially. If you have your feet on it and you're trying to rock yourself back and forth in the chair, you can't really push off because it rocks back and keeps moving from under your feet. If you are holding a 20-pound baby and trying to maintain the rocking motion for any period of time, this gets really annoying! I keep having to keep one foot on the ground just so I have something solid to push off of. The ottoman sort of "locks" in place if you pull the footrest out, but not really. It locks only in one direction - you can't push it back, but you can still pull it forward, which means that if you bump it in the dark, it will rock forward but then on its way back will run into the stopper and make a loud clanking noise, waking the baby after all that work putting her to sleep. I wish it would just lock and stay locked without moving in any direction, or at least without clanking! The foot rest is very useful, but also annoying because it, too, makes clanking noises when you push off of it to rock the chair. Something about the construction of that ottoman and its footrest make it feel very unstable and clanky and noisy, and it annoys me daily. I'd still recommend the recliner though, because the main part of it - the actual recliner - is awesome! Just maybe get another ottoman.UPDATE: It has been a year and a half now and the glider is still doing great! We still use it daily, though now it's mostly for bedtime stories, and the occasional comforting when my daughter is having a bad night. The cushions still feel the same - no compression that I can notice. It's still silent, except for one tiny pop that happens when you shift your weight forward in preparation for getting up. But I have figured out how to avoid or at least lessen the pop. If my daughter is asleep, it doesn't seem to bother her. No other complaints, and even that is a minor one. This glider was definitely one of the best baby purchases we've made so far!

This is the ugliest drapery material I've ever seen. It's hard and stiff, and plasticky! The material reminds me of those linoleum-like stiff plastic table covers you see in third-world countries. It looks and feels ugly, it doesn't slide over curtain rods at all, and if you want to tie it back, the bottom ends stick up stiff and look horrible. The only positive thing about it is that it does block light well. But man, is it ugly! I used it for about a year but I hate it so much that I just bought light-blocking curtains to replace it with. You know, actual curtains that look, feel and drape like curtains. I'll use those as a liner with the decorative (but thin) curtains I currently have, instead of the decorative curtains with this ugly board.

Seems like there are a lot of bad reviews for an older model of this sippy cup. The current one (as of December 2014) however is great! It doesn't leak, it's sturdy and well made, and it's easy for the baby to hold. I love that it's made from safe plastics, too! I gave it to my baby for the first time when she was 7 months old. She was very interested but couldn't quite figure out what to do with it. She'd bite the spout instead of suck it, and she held the cup with just one hand by the handle, so it was dangling awkwardly. She also hated water at that point. I took it away and waited another month. At 8 months I tried again, and to my surprise, she started sucking right away and drank her water without any grimaces, all by herself! She figured out the handles, too. After a few days of practice, she was able to grab it by both handles, lift and drink from it without assistance. So, it's been working out great for us! It's the only sippy cup we've tried so far, and it looks like it will be the only one.P.S. I got the blue, and the color is much darker than in the picture. In the picture it looks like a pale aqua, but it's actually a standard, darker blue.

I had seen the product description and the reviews saying that this is not a non-slip pad. So okay, I had rubber rug pads for that purpose and I was prepared. It does slide all over the hardwood floor, but the rubber pads solved that problem. What I did not expect, and what is unacceptable, is that the rug itself slides on top of this pad!!!!!!! Am I supposed to put something between the two of them as well? Isn't the purpose of this pad to go under the rug? I'm tired of seeing the pad poke out around the edges and having to slide and reposition the rug on top of it every day. The rug's edges go about two inches beyond the pad on all sides, so it's not a sizing issue. The rug just f-ing MOVES all over the pad!

These socks have weird proportions. The foot part is big, bigger than my 8-month-old's foot, but the elastic at the top is way too tight even for her, let alone a bigger 1-year-old who will have thicker legs, too. They pinch her calves so tightly that they leave deep, purple grooves. I know it's hard to make baby socks that stay on, but damn, babies need circulation in their feet, too! I ended up stretching them up to under her knees, where the leg is a little narrower, but then the heel is halfway up her calf... Grotesque socks. They should've used a wide stretchy band (like other brands of baby socks) instead of a narrow regular elastic band that cuts into the chub.

These boots are surprisingly warm, even though the shaggy part is just at the top. The inside looks vety thin but clearly has some sort of other insulating material. They are warmer than my Tims! I love that you can get warmth without needing bulky fluff on the inside, so the shoe can remain small and elegant. I haven't worn them in snow yet, but on a 20-degree day my feet feel warm, even with just regular socks on (not thick winter socks). I can't objectively comment on the fit, because I have wide flat feet, plus I wear orthotic insoles. So in my situation I needed these shoes a size and a half larger than my usual shoe size, to accommodate the width. With other boots I only need them one size up. So I guess these are a half size smaller/narrower than other boots.The only thing I don't like about them is that the treads on the main part of the sole have a fuzzy surface, like suede, and are very slippery on smooth ground (porch, hardwood floors, tile). I've slipped and almost fallen a few times. The treads on the heel are fine (and the reason why I didn't fall after all). Very weird design choice. They are okay on pavement, but I hope the suede wears down soon so I can have more traction...

I got this as an alternative to the ubiquitous giraffe, and have so far been very happy with it. It's much cuter (I think!) and the baby loves it! It's easy to hold and bite, and has enough give for younger babies (mine isn't teething yet at 8 months, but loves chewing stuff). It's easier to squeak than other squeaky toys we have, too. I love that it's made of safe materials! It's hard to find toys like that nowadays.I don't really have any complaints, just a funny sort of note The squeak hole on the belly of the zebra has a spray of pink paint on and around it, which makes it look a bit painful like her belly button got inflamed or worse - like a misplaced, inflamed anus! :-P Of course the baby doesn't care, but my husband and I can't help laughing whenever we see it. If you ever do a redo of Zeta, maybe you can hold off on the paint on that particular spot...

We don't use this at bath time (because I don't want water getting into it) but the baby still finds ways to enjoy it. It's her favorite chew toy, and she can go at it for a loooong time! It's soft and easy to hold, easy to squish, squeak and to bite. She stuffs the whole head in her mouth and chomps down, making squeaky sounds in the meantime. It looks very satisfying. She loves to hold the head and chew the body, too. I'm very happy that it's natural rubber and free of sketchy chemicals. There aren't that many toys like that around. So yeah, I don't know how this would hold up as a bath toy, but as a chew toy it's awesome!

We've been using this baby monitor daily for a year and a half now and love it. It's sensitive to the baby's voice, but not to other sounds in her room (for example, the white noise machine right next to the baby unit) so it doesn't get triggered by other things. Her voice comes through loud and clear. We haven't had interference or static issues at all. Haven't had to adjust frequencies either, it worked straight out of the box. I like that it has a built-in room thermometer, too. We've been using the monitor both at night and for naps, and it has been enough for us (I really don't see a need for a video monitor - this is just fine). I like that it can recharge its batteries, too.I've had a few small issues with the monitor, which have been adding up and now I'm taking off one star. One is that the halo night light button makes a VERY loud and sharp click sound when you press it to turn the light on or off, and it wakes the baby up. So that feature is useless to me, even though it would've been very convenient to have it. Also, less than a year after I bought the unit, the display stopped working. The little lights that illuminate the parts of the display started dying one by one. At first just parts of the number showing the temperature went black, but you could sort of still make out the number. Then there was no number at all. Then no more audio levels or anything else, so the display became useless. I loved the temperature display feature, because it allowed me to regulate the temperature in her room from the thermostat downstairs without going in to check a thermometer in the bedroom (our central air is wonky and it can quickly get either too cold or too hot in individual rooms). The last annoying thing is that while the parent unit is charging (which I do at night), there's no way to turn the display off but keep the unit itself on, it's always lit. It's very bright and casts too much light in our bedroom, and being that it sits right by my head, it's too bright for me to sleep. I tried taping over it, but I want to be able to see the monitor before I go to bed, and removing and replacing sticky tape every day was too much of a hassle. Even a dimming feature would've been enough, but as it is, it's too bright at night. I ended up knitting it a little hat so now it wears a hat at night :-)Overall, this is an excellent monitor that I would highly recommend. The cons are pretty minor. It served us well for a year and a half, and only now it's starting to actually degrade in quality. It recently started emitting strange staticky noises and waking me up at night, even when there's nothing going on in the baby's room. I'm considering getting another unit of this model though - that's how much I still like it.

I wanted to hold off on reviewing this until after we've been using it for a while, and most importantly, until after our baby has been eating solid food (I'd heard all kinds of horror stories about the smell of solid food coming out the other end) Well, it's been 8 months, and I still love it! The part about solid food was true. Impressive odors coming out of that baby! However, I haven't noticed any smell problems with the diaper pail. I don't get a whiff when I hit the foot pedal. The baby is in daycare during the week, so it takes us at least a week to fill the pail up and need to empty it, so stuff sits there for a week, with no smell problems. In 8 months there has been only one instance of smell coming out, and the whole room smelled like sh!t. Being that that was highly unusual, I opened the pail to investigate, and found that the bag had ripped and there were exposed diapers smelling up the place. I can't blame the bag though When it's late and I'm dead tired and the genie is full, the last thing I want to do is drag a heavy bag of crap out to the trash, so I stuff it and stuff it because it can always take juuuuuust one more And it seems that eventually, it ripped. So, user error. The genie and its bags have been great. It works with regular trash bags, too. It's easy to use, convenient, hasn't jammed on us yet, it's easy to empty and reload and it really does keep the diapers sealed during that process! Emptying it is a breeze and does not expose you to either the diapers or the smell. I also like that it's tall, so I don't have to bend down. We have two genies - one for downstairs, and one for upstairs, and both have been performing great. At this point I can't imagine sh!t getting any smellier, so I don't foresee any problems in the future. I can confidently declare the diaper genie a success!

This is a cute, convenient set. I like how well the bowls stack together and take up very little room. The colors are exactly as pictured. I have washed all bowls and spoons on the top rack of my dishwasher many times and have had no problems. The spoon is easy for little hands to hold, and soft on baby's gums. This was my baby's first feeding set and at first the bowls were way too big, but she grew into them after only a month! She loves them a bit too much - keeps wanting to play with them rather than eat. Especially the spoons. Makes mealtime fun!

The fleece is a bit thinner than other fleece footies, but otherwise it's well made, soft and cute. It washes well. The proportions are weird. It's too narrow for its length (or too long for its width?) compared to other footies of the same size. So if you have a tall, skinny baby it would fit better than if you have an average baby (like mine).

The drawings are horrendous, but the baby doesn't care and loves it, so whatever that's what matters. Esthetics aside, it's a well-made book with a lot going on to keep the baby's attention. I like that the pages have a firmer foam core, so while they are still soft, they hold their shape and can be turned easily by a young baby, like real pages. We have a couple more Lamaze cloth books, but both have the flimsy cloth pages that get bunched up when the baby grabs them rather than flip like a book. So at this stage (6-7 months) this book is more practical, for turning the pages at least.

This Christmas tree skirt is a joke. It's not a circle, but a lumpy oval attempt at a circle. It's one single solid piece and doesn't have the side and center cut like it is in the image, so out of the bag it cannot be used for the purpose it was intended for, unless you cut it yourself. Worst of all, it's so thin that you can literally see through it. I can see the floorboards through it when I put it down. It's not expensive, but it's not worth even that kind of price, so I can't even settle for "you get what you pay for". I can get a LOT of loose fleece fabric of much better quality for this price, and it will take me about 2 minutes to cut it.The only redeeming quality of the whole exchange was that the seller (BEGUM9) was great about it. Seems like they were unaware of the issue and they gave me a full refund without asking me to send their item back. So now I have my money back, and a bunch of see-through fleece wannabe.

This is not just a hoodie - it's a heavy winter coat, very thick, and hopefully very warm! It seems sturdy and well made. I washed it in cold water, tumble dry low, and it came out fine. For some reason I thought the outside was knit probably because of the pattern, and the picture on Amazon is very grainy and low-res and hard to see. It's not knit, the pattern is printed on the smooth surface. It looks a bit odd, but also like it was intentional. I don't really care, it looks nice. I got the green color and it looks very cute and cozy. It took a while to arrive because it comes from China, but I bought it ahead of time so that was okay. It came with the tags cut, which was very sketchy Just the plastic string thing dangling and no tag hanging from it but whatever.My only real complaint is that the hood is absolutely useless. It's so small that it can't even reach up to the baby's head, let alone actually cover it in any way! The rest of the jacket fits fine for the size baby it was meant for, but the hood *might* fit on my cat's head, maybe. So it just hangs around the baby's neck uselessly and is a bulky dead weight that looks (and probably feels) uncomfortable when the baby is leaning back against the stroller or car seat back, and this thing is bunched up behind her neck If you're gonna do a hood, do it well or not at all.

The people who flipped our house before we bought it lost all door plates when re-painting the doors, and the door knobs were all really wobbly. I didn't want to replace everything so I tried a couple of plates from Home Depot, which didn't work with our very old doors. Then I found these, and they fit perfectly! Well, almost perfectly They were just a couple millimeters too bulky, but that was quickly fixed with a couple of gentle taps with a mallet. And then they fit perfectly. I ordered a bunch more, enough to install on all doors in the house. I'm very happy with this purchase.Note: they come in packs of two, for either side of the door. So one "item" is enough for one door.

I like the convenience of a push-out tray like this one. The cubes take some work to push out, but once you figure it out it's not so bad. At first I thought it wouldn't work, but I was afraid to push too hard so as not to break the tray or the silicone piece. Then my husband gave it a good push and out popped the cube, so now I know to give it my all. It's a little annoying, but not a deal breaker. I also wish the cubes were larger. I use the trays for baby food so being able to push a single one out at a time is great, compared to twisting the whole tray and dislodging a whole bunch of cubes at a time when the baby only needs one or two.

UPDATE: After only a few weeks of use, one of the trays shattered in my hands as I was trying to fight a cube out. They need a LOT of pushing to pop out, and I guess the stress from the pushing, plus the freezing, was too much for the plastic to handle. Too bad... I loved the idea, but in practice it doesn't really work.Below is my original review.I like the convenience of a push-out tray like this one. The cubes do take some work to push out (push HARD with both thumbs), but once you figure it out it's not so bad. At first I thought it wouldn't work, but I was afraid to push too hard so as not to break the tray or the silicone piece. Then my husband gave it a good push and out popped the cube, so now I know to give it my all. It's a little annoying, but not a deal breaker. I also wish the cubes were larger. I use the trays for baby food so being able to push a single one out at a time is great, compared to twisting the whole tray and dislodging a whole bunch of cubes at a time when the baby only needs one or two.

I didn't want to spend a fortune on guest slippers, and I thought well, how bad can they be Well, quite bad, it turns out! The worst part about these cheap slippers is that they are dangerous! The underside of the sole is incredibly slippery and just does not work on smooth, hard surfaces like tile - you'll be sliding around like you're on ice. So don't go into your kitchen or bathroom wearing these. Hardwood floors are marginally better, though still quite bad. Our stairwell is uncovered wood and I'm just plain afraid to go down the stairs wearing these. They are also very thin overall, and the inside compresses so much that after just a few weeks of occasional wear, you can feel the texture of the rubber sole through the inside of the slipper! They are wide, flat and uncomfortable. They also collect dust, dirt and hair like crazy and are a pain to clean, because everything sticks to them. I even tried vacuuming them but even that didn't clean them completely, so they look horrible. The only thing they had going for them was their looks, but even that is compromised by all the crap they collect. I'm embarrassed to give them to my guests.

I hate to get a dull pizza cutter that you have to saw your way through a pizza and end up tearing it up because the blade never runs the same path twice.  This pizza cutter is sharp and gets the job precisely.  The handle and is curved and has a grip to prevent slipping and a finger guard. It feels like a rotary cutter in your hand.  It gives you a straight one pass cut.  I used it to cut pita bread pockets for pita chips and to cut sandwiches in addition to using it as a pizza cutter.  It's dishwasher safe so clean up is simple.  I purchased my pizza cutter at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I have a lot of different essential oils and make my own blends when I can and now the right ratio.  I saw this blend and wanted to try it mainly for skin tags.  I have a couple I've been applying the oil to with a q-tip and covering with a bandaid.  I can see a change but it has fallen off yet.  But I understand it can take weeks for it to fall off.  I wish I could use it on a tag on my eyelid but I'm afraid to try it there since it is a "hot" oil.  I definitely don't want to accidentally get it in my eye and burn it and blind myself. Tea tree oil and oregano are also good treatment oils for fungal infections, dandruff, ringworm, psoriasis, eczema, acne, MRSA,  and more. They are natural anti-bacterial, anti-viral, and anti-fungal and make great natural disinfectants for skin.  Be sure to dilute in a carrier oil like fractionated coconut oil.  I tried the kitchen disinfectant suggestion of mixing a few drops in a spray bottle of water and white vinegar and it work great and the vinegar makes your surfaces shine, especially my stainless steel sink that hard to keep clear of water spots due to hard water.  I purchased my oil at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I took a side a restaurant a couple years ago as a guest service associate and had to wear a blazer.  You would be surprised how hard it is to find a blazer of quality that doesn't cost a fortune that can be machine washed.  I paid more for blazers not as nice as this one. This one is can go from wearing it as part of a uniform to jeans and a tank. It looks great with slacks or skirts or over dress.  I was nervous about what size to order because I wear an 8-10 but in tops and jackets I have to try it on because I have a large chest. Sometimes ordering up in size means the sleeves are too long.  The cut of the jacket has a lot to do with the fit too. This one is tailored for curves and since the sleeves roll up i ordered the next size up.  It fits great.  I love the pin striped lining (the sleeves are fully lined).  The sleeves can be rolled up or down since the cuffs are not tacked and I appreciate that.  I like that this blazers has two full pockets also.  I hate to buy a jacket and find the pockets are fake. I need the pockets.  The jacket looks and and feels great.  It's made from a polyester, rayon, spandex blend so it as a little stretch to conform to your body.  I purchased my blazer at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

Such a cool thermos.  I love the white graphic design on the black, it looks sharp.  This this double walled vacuum insulated thermos looks like a soda can but it's a thermos.  It can be used for both food and drinks, hot and cold. Don't put carbonated drinks in it though because it creates pressure and can cause it to leak.  We use it mostly for coffee, hot tea, cocoa, and soup.  It's 12 ounces so it's perfect for these items.  It will keep your contents hot for about 6 hours.  Cold contents will keep cold up to 12 hours.  It came with an extra straw so when the one you are using wears out it is easily interchanged.  Which brings me to another point, with some foods you may want to remove the straw (seriously do you really want yogurt in your straw?).  This thermos fit in our cup holders and did not leak or spill.  It's easy to clean with hot soapy water or dishwasher.  Don't use bleach or anything abrasive that will scratch up the shiny steel or pretty paint job.  I purchased my thermos at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These sheets feel amazing.  I slept like a baby in them. I got the California king size sheets in black.  Taking them out of the package, they were soft before I even washed them.  After I washed them before using them they were even softer.  The color did not fade when I washed them.  They stayed a really dark black color.  These are really nice sheets.  I have bought a lot of sheets trying to find the perfect ones for my bed.  I have many sheet sets that claim they are California king size that are clearly not because they are ill fitting.  I have some that claim to be deep pockets that are a struggle to get on the mattress.  These are properly sized for my bed, they were California king and deep pocket.  They fit perfectly.  The fitted sheet didn't ride up and off the mattress while sleeping and moving around the bed.  They felt soft and silky and luxurious and cozy.  I'm just thrilled with them and plan to purchase more.  I want to mention that I received the wrong size to began with but the seller paid the shipping to have them returned to them and immediately sent me the correct size.  I purchased my sheets at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

3:54 MinsI am obsessed with essential oil diffusers and essential oils.  I have asthma and allergies and I have been dealing with a respiratory illness for months so I run my diffusers literally 24 hours a day to breathe.  My goal is to have a diffuser(s) in every room of the house.  I already have them in his office at work and it's been a hit there too.  He comes home with questions from co-workers for me about the diffuser and essentials oils and their use.  This diffuser is a nice one.  It's great quality.  It put out a good deal of mist.  It runs about 4 hours and the blue color light is so soothing and beautiful.  This one doesn't have a mist option to run it intermittently.  This is fine with me because I run my on constant mode at home. My boyfriend runs the one he has in his office on intermittent mode because it will last for 8 hours and he doesn't have to think about it and refill it during the day especially since he may not have a moment to do it. He sets it up at the end of each work day so all he has to do is turn it on in the morning and forget about it.  So it's just a matter of preference.  This diffuser does have lighting options. You press the power button once to turn on the diffuser with light, once more to turn off light and mist continues, once more to turn off completely.  This one is also electric and I like that the power cord unplugs from the diffuser.  It makes it easier to transfer and clean.  To clean use a q-tip to wipe the sensor and the mist path and spout.  I purchased my diffuser at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

4:06 MinsI love having a hands free automatic soap dispenser for my kitchen sink.  When I am working with poultry and other raw meats I want to touch as little surfaces as possible to prevent cross contamination or the transfer bacteria.  This is a sanitary option.  The dispenser is easy to operate.  It takes 4 AA batteries, not included.  There is a cap on top that you turn counter-clockwise and fill with your favorite soap, lotion, shampoo, etc.  Press and hold the power button (on top) down for 3 seconds to turn on.  Hold your hand under the dispenser and the motion sensor will activate dispensing the liquid.  It will dispense for 1.5 seconds, if you want more soap at a time, press the power button a second time to dispense 2 seconds, a third time to dispense 2.5 second, and a fourth time to change back to 1.5 seconds.  It's recommended not to immerse in water or use in direct contact, so if you use it in the shower I would set it on the side where the shower curtain could shield it.  You don't want water to get into the battery compartment.  I put the batteries in wrong to begin with so I had to flip it upside down to change the batteries after I had fill it with soap.  Because of this I found out that the soap does NOT leak out when you have to change the batteries.  Also it says not to fill it more than 90 percent full, I guess you need a little air space inside.  I noticed that the soap expanded after using it a couple times. so it appeared to be 100 percent full.  I purchased my dispenser at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

3:47 MinsI so needed this shiatsu massage pillow.  Most "shiatsu massage" gadgets I have tried have been a real let down.  Either they are not very powerful or they just don't hit the spot.  This pillow is fantastic.  The massage nodes are on a v-spring and really wrap around your muscles.  And powerful? The nodes really work your muscles deeply and intensely. I was actually sore a couple of days after using it.  It worked some knots and tension out of muscles that I didn't realize were that tight before using the pillow.  I carry a lot of tension in my back and neck and don't realize it sometimes how extreme I do so unless my boyfriend touches my neck or back and comments on it.  And the few times I've had a deep tissue massage the therapists always comment on it.  I use this pillow starting at the bottom of my back and work up to my neck and by then I am so relaxed.  I also used it on my legs and arms.  This pillow really is multi-functional with the designed allowing you to use it on many different and varied parts of your body.  And the heat option is awesome, I like to use it with heat the best.  When you press the power button once the nodes will operate with heat, press a second time to turn off the heat, and hold it down for 3 seconds and it will turn off.  When activated the pillow will massage for 20 minutes (the recommended limit per section of your body) then turn off. This is also a safety mechanism in case you forget to turn it off.  The nodes are covered by a soft mesh like material and by a button flap of the same red leatherette of the pillow.  Leave the flap down, covering the mesh and nodes for a less intense massage, lift it to expose the mesh covered node for a stronger more intense experience.  I would recommend the first time to leave the flap down if you are not used to it unless you want to be sore like I was after my first use.  When not using for massage you can turn it around so the cushion side is facing you and use it as a lumbar support cushion or to look pretty on your couch, chair, or in your car.  It comes with an electrical plug and a car charger plug in.  Please heed health warnings and don't use if you have a pacemaker, if you are diabetic, at risk for clots, have phlebitis, thrombosis, or any circulatory problem.  And don't use on any part of your body that has plates, screws, or any type of reconstructive surgery.  I can't use it on my left leg because of reconstruction of my knee, and all the screws.  If your not sure if you can use it ask your doctor.  I purchased my pillow at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These kitty cat ears are adorable.  I ordered them for Halloween options but they are so cute you can wear them anywhere. I see them worn everywhere all the time, it's the fashion.  They are a lot of fun and everyone likes them even animals.  I had a friends dog that is mesmerized by them.  He seems to think I'm an animal too when I have them on.  LOL.  The headband is very flexible and comfortable and the ears are constructed out of bendable wire  with the band and ears covered with a soft sheer black shimmery lace.  If the ears get bent, they are easily reshaped.  The ears are about two inches tall and since they are bendable you can form them into any shape you want.  I purchased my cat ears at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These are great for taking your lunch to work or school, packing snacks, or freezing meals.  There are 8 inches long, 6 inches wide, and 2 inches deep.  There are 2 compartments, the large holds up to 2 cups (16 ounces) and the smaller compartment holds up to 1 cup (8 ounces).  If you portion control your food, meal prep containers are the way to go.  I have the 3 compartment containers too.  The two compartment containers feel a little sturdier and not as bendy because of it only having two sections (more sections  more bendy).  Because of the design and color these look a lot like take out containers but they are a thicker more durable plastic than disposable one time use containers.  These you can use over and over for some time before needing to replace.  The plastic is BPA free and is safe for the microwave, dishwasher, and freezer. And the lids seal with no leakage so far.  We use them for ready-made healthy snacks to grab and go, and for pre made meals.  I like to cook in the slow cooker, make large pots of pasta, stuffed peppers, meals that are hard to make for just the two of you.  This way I can make up meals from the leftovers and freeze to take to lunch or for dinner when I dont have time or feel like cooking.  I purchased my set at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These jeans are fabulous!  I love the sparkly bling "V O" on the band on the back.  I love the crystal trim on the pockets and the chain and leather braiding on the pockets and the white stitching detail..  I read all the reviews and recommendations for sizing and the seller's recommendations and size chart.  These are junior sizes and Asian sizes on top of that so they are going to run small.  I wear an 8-10 at the moment so taking everything into consideration I ordered the 13 and they fit like a glove.  So don't be vain and insist on getting the size you usually wear, or you will end up with cute jeans you can't wear.  It's all just a number, what's important is that you feel good in them and like the way you look (beautiful).  These jeans are skinny jeans and the cut and design of these really accentuate your butt.  They are pretty sexy looking.  I've worn them with just a tank or t-shirt and I've worn them with boots.  I went to an animal park and wore them with boots and a top and jeans jacket and they looked awesome. I had good range of movement in them.  I was able to bend and squat petting baby animals.  They were very comfortable all day which included a three hour ride back home.  I purchased my jeans at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I love this halter babydoll nightie.  It is so sexy and seductive.  I love the sheer slinky fabric of the skirt.  It is soft and feels wonderful and sensual against your skin.  The skirt is stretchy, flowy,  and airy.  The bodice is a sheer lace that is stretchy and soft and has some ribbon embellishments.  The lingerie is well constructed of quality materials and is very flattering to the female figure.  The top ties behind your neck like a halter and which always looks great on large busted women.  I wear size medium or size 8 to 10 in pants at the moment and a medium or large in a top depending on the style. Button up tops can be a real problem. It's hard to find one that fits without pins to keep it from gaping in the breast area. I am 34DD sometimes 34DDD and when buying lingerie, it is difficult to find something sexy that fits through the chest and that is not too big everywhere else.
