I don't add any sweetener to it at all. It says that you can sweeten it however you want and it will still work, but personally adding sugar to a weight loss drink seems counter productive. It really doesn't need it though and I have drank it hot, warm, room temperature, and cold. Personally, I like it warm the best.The other part of this tea that I actually think works (since it is hard to tell something like this most of the time), is the immune system support. Both of my kids have developed a cold while I have been drinking this tea. It's the full chest cough and icky running nose kind. I haven't had any of it except a slight runny nose which is my normal for winter and not a cold. You might think, "You must have a better immune system than them right now, but my husband literally got up this morning to tell me that he is fighting what they have and losing. I interpret that to mean that the tea is actually helping me to not get sick. A great bonus to the weight loss element.

Dot&Dot Travel Accessories has something that every parent needs. As your kids grow, their car seats are turned to forward facing and long before you can reason with them, they learn to kick the back of your seat. Besides being annoying and sometimes painful, it's messy. Picture this scenario. It's winter and snowing. Your child has been walking through the snow to get into your vehicle. While you make every effort not to track a bunch of snow into your vehicle, inevitably some will get stuck to their shoes and melt. In my experience this causes a nice muddy streak on the back of the seat as they kick and wipe their dirty shoes on it. In some vehicles, this isn't too big of a problem to clean, but it is all dependent on the type of interior you have. The kind that are made of their weird fuzzy material are almost impossible to get all the dirt out. My pleather seats in my truck can be cleaned, but I can't get everything out of all the little lines in the interior.The protector came in this little plastic zipper bag that can be used for something else when not holding the cover. I intend to put diapers in it to store in my truck.Now I used to have this Eddie Bauer seat back cover that was made to hold stuff like diapers and wipes. I put it in my truck and the thing could not be tightened enough to 1) protect the seat or 2) hold anything without dumping it. When Dot&Dot approved me to review their Car Seat Back Protector/Cover, I was thrilled to see if my truck was just incompatible with this type of thing or if that expensive Eddie Bauer cover was really worthless. I am happy to report that the Dot&Dot Car Seat Back Protector/Cover fits in the truck amazingly! The top clips around the head rest and tightens a lot so you can keep it in place.The bottom has an elastic strap on one side and not elastic on the other side. So you stretch it around the base of the seat and it can slide between the cushions. it holds tightly and the protector doesn't move.I have given this protector a full week before deciding how I feel about it. We haven't have any snow, but we had some rain. Not a lot of bad weather to create messy shoes. I can say though that the cover has helped not feel the sting of kicks as much and it has protected my seat wonderfully. A HUGE thank you to Dot&Dot.
This is a Christmas present so it hasn't been played with yet, but it looks perfect for what my son wants.
My four year old loves this game but the ads are a serious problem. I actually would pay for the game if it came without the ads.

In Ashes of War you get glimpse at a relationship between two gods that had been torn apart and "forgotten" for over 1500 years. Ashlynn, daughter of Artemis, discovers that the father she has never known and whom her mother will not talk about is actually alive on Earth. He was cast of from Olympus for reasons unknown and her mother told that he was dead. Well...really she was told that he was no longer "with them" which Artemis interpreted as him being dead. The virgin goddess never attempted to look for Evangelos because she didn't think that her father, Zeus, would lie to her. Zeus simple mislead her and now she must decide if she wants to have Evan (instead of Evangelos) back in her immortal life. He was the only man that she loved and the only one to ever touch her. She gave up her virginity to him and conceived Ashlynn. He never knew that she was pregnant because he was cast out of Olympus before Artemis could tell him of the pregnancy.This novella is a short story giving you more detail about the gods in Lia Davis's universe. While it is part of the Sons of War series, it doesn't actually involve the dragon shape shifters all that much. It focuses on Artemis and Evan rekindling their relationship and trying to get Evan's godhood re-established. Zeus feels bad about sending Evan away and had hoped that Artemis would get over her love for him. He was wrong. Over 1500 years later, he is finally ready to admit that he was wrong (in his own way) and give Artemis the blessing on her relationship that she never knew she wanted. I loved how their relationship unfolds and thoroughly enjoyed the little bit of back plot given for the Sons of War series.

Book two in the Sons of War series is just as exciting as the first book. This was another book that I read in less than a day because I just couldn't put it down. Ash (her preferred nickname instead of Ashlynn) is a goddess. She really isn't crazy about being reminded of this, but both of her parents were gods and she was born on Olympus which makes her a full goddess even if she is just a minor goddess of the hunt. Her mother is Artemis and her father it turns out was a god sentenced to an immortal life among mortals. His godhood was stripped from him for unknown reasons. Ash has been living among mortals for a long time though as she spies on the demigods and dragons for the gods' purposes. Her current assignment is to watch Ty, a dragon son of Ares, to determine if he is guilty of killing another Goddess (or two). Upon seeing him, she is immediately drawn to him. Apparently gods, goddesses, and demigods are immediately drawn to their soul mates. She has been trying her hardest to stay out of Ty's life, but it has come to a point where she must get answers directly from him in order to prove his innocence. This is her mission and if she must seduce him or even die in while trying, so be it. She just has to find a way to break down Ty's walls in order to get him to trust her. She must discover the reason behind his deep hatred of all women and try not to completely fall in love with him in the process.I loved this book, much like the first one. The most upsetting part about it is that there's only one more book in the series for me to read before I have to move on to another series or author. I love the mix of Greek mythology and the dragon shapeshifters. The character development i wonderful. Even though things happen over a short period of time, you really get the feeling that time doesn't matter in their immortal lives. A week to them feels like a day or even a month. It feels like it is possible to fall in love with someone without saying, "I haven't known them long enough." This is a problem I find in a lot of books, that the love couldn't have happened that fast, but I don't feel that way about this story. A fantastic read for those that love romance, Greek myth, and dragons.

Greek mythos and Dragon shape shifters together in one book. Sign me up! This is a refreshing twist on mythology for me with enough of what I actually know combined with something new an exciting. Gwen is a demigod which in this story means that she has the blood of the gods in her but she was not born on Olympus. Being born on earth makes her a mortal and subject to the rules the Gods have placed on them. Gwen knows that she is Aphrodite's grand daughter, but after traumatic events that resulted in her parents' deaths via a scary black dragon, she does not accept that part of herself. She has the gift of persuasion, but she has locked it down for years. Unfortunately, a winged man keeps appearing where ever she goes causing her to move across the country to remain in hiding. Her fear of dragons comes to life when she meets the sons of War (Ares), the legendary dragon warriors. Her body betrays her by being drawn to Markus. She fears him and at the same time wants nothing more than to be with him. How can these warring emotions be reconciled? How will Markus deal with his growing attraction to Gwen when he is forbidden from mating with the demigods? How will he protect her from the dragon, his brother, who is hunting her down to use in a war against the Gods?I loved this book. There are some typos and if I hadn't been so into the story, I might have marked them for the author simply because I think it had to do with the conversion to MOBI. Don't quote me on that though. It was exciting, sexy, and entertaining. I read it in one day when I had planned to read it over the course of a week. I just had to know what would happen next. I am actually going to read the second book next because I am so excited about the series.

I was gifted a copy of this book.This is a cute story with unique computer generated graphics. I don't mean computer generated as in clipart, but rather C.L. Murphy had to have painstakingly created these images on the computer. They are super cute. They story is tells about how Lobo and his raven friend Roxy find a blue-footed booby bird named Bobbie and help him to find his way home. Home just happens to be on another island in the Galapagos. They make some other friends along the way and even discover that sometimes facing their fears is necessary. I enjoyed the story. The only issue I had was that I kind of felt like I was missing a page where there were introductions with Bobbie in the beginning of the story. I had it on PDF, so I don't really think a page was missing, but I felt like there was a little jump in the story. My son didn't seem to notice this though so it could just be because I read more extensive books typically.

This is a fantastically cute book! I absolutely love the art and the rhyming story. My four-year old son loves construction trucks. He has to point them out everywhere we go. His Nana has borrowed countless books from the library for him about these types of vehicles. I knew when I saw it that it would be a big hit. I personally loved the rhyming and how wonderful the descriptions of what each vehicle does was simplistically put for a child to understand. Yet the vocabulary is something that encourages kids to ask questions and learn. The song is very cute too.My son enjoyed the book. One picture on my blog has the story upside down, but he quickly righted it. He showed me the different trucks and identified the ones he already knew. He has a few books that we have read several times which taught him what some of the trucks do. He laughed at me when I sang the song and told me to just read him the story. Being that he just started preschool and they read a book every day, I think he just wanted me to do what his teacher has done so far. This is definitely a great book for your little lover of cars and working vehicles.

Heed the warning in the description of this book. If you do not like to read about topics like rape, suicide, adultery, abuse, etc., this book is not for you. Alana has been through more than any girl should have in just shy of a decade. She developed faster than the other girls her age which caused her to be ridiculed for being more grown up than the others her age. Unfortunately, she caught the eyes of adult men as early as eleven years old. None acted on their desires until her father took advantage of her. She was so young that she didn't know it was wrong. This became a trend in her life. She was called derogatory names that really don't apply to a rape victim, but the other kids in school didn't know the difference. How any other them learned the truth, we will never know.Alana makes friends with Jack and Dave who have some serious problems of their own. They are the outcasts at school, but their misfortunes bring them together. Their closeness also causes them not to move forward with their lives. They latch onto each other in an unhealthy way where they dwell on their problems. Except for Dave really. He has found a way to move forward, but his love for Alana remains. It's just a question of whether that love is a healthy kind or not and whether Alana can learn to accept it for what it is. These are all issues that Alana must deal with in therapy. She finally has a therapist she likes and is making progress.The book alternates each chapter between what happened in her past and what is currently happening. It is a book about healing and that it can be a long, miserable road. However, I found this book rather depressing. Of course it doesn't help that I was reading it when dealing with my husband's grandfather's death. Much like how Jack, Dave, and Alana being around each other causes them not to move past their problems, my depressing family death caused this book to be even more upsetting to me. This concept is why I am not crazy about things like group therapy. I think hearing about other people's problems can make you feel better if their problems are worse than yours, but it can have the opposite affect if yours are worse than theirs. I think this topic was covered in this story in a subliminal way. It's well written, but not my thing.

I was gifted a copy of this book.Emily Warren has been through a great ordeal but doesn't want to tell anyone about it. Her sister Suzette knows that there is one person whom Emily might reveal her secret to. Bill has been a friend of the family since Emily was six, but somewhere in her teenage years, she fell deeply in love with him. She never confessed it to anyone because she never felt good enough for him even though he was from a poor broken family and she from a famous actor/actress married couple. She never acted on her feelings and instead went off to college to pursue her dream of becoming a doctor. It was when she finally completed school that she nearly had the unspeakable happen to her. Under the guise of being sick, Emily is sent to Bill's house to try to discover the source of his "migraines", but really her sister sent her there to see if bill could get her to tell him what actually happened to her to cause her to lock herself in her childhood bedroom and not to eat. As a doctor, everyone knew that she knew better, so something traumatic must have happened.I really liked how Regina Puckett had the characters interact in order to reveal the big secret and pretty much how Emily's entire family reacted to it. Many women that suffer any kind of abuse are not believed, but Emily's family immediately believes her and supports her. The character development is great. Things don't happen too fast or slow, but you do still have those moments where you want to scream at them for not just speaking their minds. Of course, that's human nature. The love story is endearing. I found it very entertaining and am interested in reading the rest of the series. By the way, you can read these stories out of order since this is number three in the series. I don't feel like I learned too much about Emily's family to have ruined the other stories.
We love this game. My 4 year old can't get enough of it.

I was gifted a copy of this book.I was immediately entertained by this book. The story is pretty short and to the point. You are introduced to a few immortals at first who are bantering about the "equipment" of the other immortals. It is quite funny. I honestly am not sure where they are though. The entire story teller about other realms but I don't know if they are based on any specific mythology. It doesn't impact the base story, but I am actually curious if it was real myth or author created. The importance is only when Samuel is sucked from his realm into Ella's realm, which I believe is on Earth. You see, Ella is a witch and she created a potion to summon her perfect guy for her for Valentine's day. She didn't expect an actual angel. Their relationship develops and Samuel gets annoyed being picked second in Ella's life by her zombie pet. You read that right. She has a zombie she is taking care of and trying to cute from his zombie curse.It was really entertaining and I really want to read more by this author. Fast and easy to follow no matter how many interruptions I have from my kids. I highly recommend this book.

Finally, I have a matching set of crochet hooks rather than the ragtag bunch I've made do with for years. I received these for review and really like them. They are easy to hold and use, and the soft handles really help. Another reviewer mentioned that they are short, but I consider that a plus because they are easier to carry around. I prefer to crochet small items and had no problems with them.The case holds the hooks securely, but it's a little bit flashy for my taste. I would have preferred a canvas case or some kind of fabric roll case, but for the price it's nice that it comes with one.

I love these cups. I've tried both these and the more narrow 'champagne' ones, but I prefer the size of these. I don't use them for wine; I mostly just use them for ice water throughout the day. I prefer plastic glasses because I drop things easily, and these are nice and shatterproof. They also don't tip over easily. Although they are very thin, they're quite strong. I really like the thumb indentation.These are easily washable, but they do scratch. I get a lot of uses out of one glass, but eventually I recycle them due to scratches. The only thing I don't like is that the top rim can be a little rough, but it's not as bad as some other plastic cups I've tried. I think the price is very reasonable.

These look really nice with our butcherblock countertop. I especially like the size of the largest one, but it's nice to have three options. They can be used on either side. They are a good thickness and feel sturdy, but are very lightweight. I like that the edges are rounded. Bamboo is great because it's a sustainable resource and it doesn't splinter. I received these for review but will definitely keep using them in the kitchen.

I received this tea as a sample to use with a glass teapot from Tea Beyond. The flowering tea compares very well to other flowering teas I've had. It's always fun to watch the flower unfold as it brews. I always have flowering tea on January first; as I watch the flower bloom, I think about all my hopes for the new year. The tea is drinkable, but not as good as regular tea.Of the non-blooming teas, I loved the jasmin best. The earl grey was pretty good, but I didn't care for the caramel at all. That's the nature of samplers though, and it's still fun to try all the different kinds. I think this would make a nice gift for someone who wants to try new teas, especially if they've never had flowering tea before. Note that these are loose teas, so you will need a tea infuser or a teapot with one built in.

This teapot is very cute and also quite functional. It makes about two or three cups of tea. There is a glass insert that you can use with loose tea, though a tea bag would work as well. The strainer insert has very thin slots and did a nice job of filtering tea. If you want to make flowering tea as shown in the photo, you don't need to use the insert. Tea Beyond also sells a flowering tea that works very well with this teapot.I will say it's fragile, since it's small and made of glass. I have a sturdier teapot for everyday use, but I think this one is perfect for special days, and it looks very decorative on its own.

Reading some of the reviews makes me wonder if we're thinking of the same product. Yes, it adds a touch of softness to the bed, but it won't be cloudlike unless you have a good mattress to start with. I bought it to use temporarily on an old mattress that I'm about to replace. It makes it bearable, but I still feel every coil in the mattress. Imagine putting a nice fluffy duvet on your bed and sleeping on top of it  that's exactly what this is like.It does seem well made, and it stays put on the mattress without sliding around. I chose this pad in particular because I wanted one that would not add much height to my bed. I expect a foam topper would be much more comfortable. This has no resiliency and flattens completely when you lie on it.As for washing it, I don't. I put it under a mattress protector and it stays clean. I air it out now and then, and it looks as pristine as the day it arrived.

As of this writing, Apple doesnt make a dock for the iPhone 6 plus. After a few weeks of fishing around for the cord that constantly fell behind my bedside table, I grudgingly I bought this one. I wasnt enthusiastic  Id envisioned something lower and more discreet. The other options were either more expensive, or else very cheap plastic.In person though, I love this stand. Its very easy to dock and undock the phone, it works perfectly with the Apple cable, and now that Im used to it, I love that it raises the phone up off the table surface. It makes it easier to see when my phones alarm wakes me up in the morning.It does take some assembly, which caught me off guard when the box arrived. Its in more pieces than youd think possible for such a little stand. For that reason, I dont recommend it as a gift, unless youre prepared to help the recipient put it together. The advantage is that it comes with three connector options that fit different types of iPhone cases. The #2 connector works well with my medium-thickness Sonix case.I was thankful for the reviewers that mentioned the possibility of getting a counterfeit product. I ordered from Twelve South Direct shop here on Amazon and had no issues.

I like that these measuring cups have the markings engraved for both metric and imperial measurements. The stainless steel is strong and sturdy; I am confident that these will last a long time. I normally use a cute set of plastic measuring cups, but I was enthusiastic about trying these out for review. They definitely have a heavier, more professional feel. The long handles are perfect for scooping ingredients.I do wish the handles were joined in a more seamless way, because they are a little hard to clean. Also, I wonder how long the green padding on the handle will last compared to the steel. Overall though, its a very nice set.

I have the case with a different pattern than the ones shown, and now Im tempted to buy more. There are two layers of protection, a soft silicone piece the fits easily over the iPhone, and a hardshell outer layer that snaps over it.The inner layer has a small lip to protect it when you lay the phone face down. It covers the side buttons but they are still easy to press. My case has a pale liner and it does tend to get dirty easily if Im not careful. In retrospect, choosing a case with a black liner would be more practical.The outer layer seems pretty tough; Im not worried about bending. It has a rough texture on the sides that make it easier to grip. I was worried that the case would bulk up my phone and make it harder to hold, but its actually much easier.

This was one of my favorite snacks when I lived in Japan for a few years. Don't be thrown off by the 'salad' flavor; these are not healthy and do not in any way resemble salad. The 'bits of carrots and parsley' are tiny specks you can't taste. These are really just salty stick-shaped potato chips. I highly recommend them if you like the more widely available Calbee Snapea Crisps.The price on Amazon is double or triple the cost in Japan; be aware you're only getting one small container of potato sticks. Due to the odd shape of the container and cheap international shipping, often they arrive dented.

I believe the pdf of this book is now offered free on the author's website.I read this because it's on Josh Kaufman's reading list of the 99 best business books, which is supposedly kept up to date - but this book has me wondering.It's interesting to learn how businesses changed as they began using the internet, especially before social media like Facebook and Twitter existed. However, this book is very much outdated. I looked up many of the businesses highlighted as positive examples, and most are either gone or have websites that look like they haven't been updated since this came out a decade ago. This isn't one of those books with timeless wisdom you can apply to modern situations. Some core information is still valid, but most of it comes from other books, which are extensively quoted.This book would probably appeal most to seniors who want inspiration for starting their own businesses after retirement. However, it doesn't give a full picture of what's available and what works best now. This isn't a bad book to start with, but definitely read other books and don't let it be your only guide.

I thought I'd love this candle based on the description of amber, sandalwood and vanilla. Unfortunately, it has an underlying perfumey scent that I don't like. The fragrance is strong when you're smelling the unlit candle up close, but it doesn't fill the room when lit.The wick is actually made of wood and makes a gentle crackling sound, which is good for people who might forget about the lit candle. However, it does make a lot of smoke when you blow it out. The flame is bigger than I expected, and I trimmed it despite the directions saying not to. It's a soy candle and burns very slowly; the listed burn time of 50-60 hours is probably accurate. It takes a long time for the wax to pool all the way to the edges of the square holder.The glass container looks cheap, because the amber color is sprayed onto a regular clear container, and the metal logo is put on as a sticker. I was hoping it would be actual amber-colored glass so that I could reuse it, but the bottom is clear.The candle is made in the USA, which would have been more of a selling point to me than the pretentious story about experiencing `the same sense of privilege once left for only a select few.'

First, this candle does not smell like you think it will when you hear the name 'cannabis'. That could be a plus or minus depending on your perspective. It's a warm chypre, maybe veering a little towards masculine. I'm not sure how to describe the scent, but the website describes it as 'top notes of fresh lemon and orange, middle notes of fig and pepper, with a sophisticated base of oakmoss, sandlewood and amber-patchouli'. I mainly smelled oakmoss with a bit of sandlewood.This candle burns cleaner than most other candles I've tried. They say it's a blend of beeswax, soy wax and vegetable wax. The whole contents of the votive turn to liquid when it burns. I was a little concerned about the thin glass, but it's definitely heatproof. The candle has a great throw and made the room smell wonderful.

I have this speaker in purple; the color in the photo is a little brighter than it is in real life. I think it looks much better in person, and I love that they make this in so many color variations. It has a soft, almost rubberized feel. I also appreciate that it comes with a pouch for travel.The sound quality is ok for the price. Not audiophile quality by any means, but it works well for the podcasts I listen to and the volume is good. Im a little surprised by some of the reviews that rave about the great sound quality; we may have different standards. Or it may work better for bass-heavy pop music than the opera and symphonies I tried it with. Still, its decent enough for an inexpensive travel option.This is very similar to the more expensive Boomtune Macaron, which I also have. In comparison, the Xboom is slightly larger, but both use the same twist mechanism for expansion. The Macaron is more attractive because it doesnt have branding across the top. However, the Xboom has some features that make it much more useful, such as volume control and an attached audio jack.

I'll start with the obvious and explicable: this is a large, hefty book. The cover has embossed glossy parts; there's no dust jacket. The pages are a matte cream paper with a texture; it's a little thin, so frequently the content on the reverse page shows through like a shadow. I would have preferred thicker paper, but the coloured pencil illustrations are clear and vibrant.The endpapers are vivid yellow and there's a pocket at the end with the Decodex, a booklet with a brief essay from Serafini translated into several languages. It explains a little of the Codex's background, and reveals the muse who may have inspired it. I was worried that any (readable) text would either squelch the mystery or come across as pretentious, but the Decodex is charming.There are complaints about a large white sticker on the back. Warm it with your breath and peel it gently away, breathing heavily on it again if it gets stuck. The warm moisture of your breath should soften the glue enough for safe removal. I can't absolutely guarantee this method, but it worked for me. Go slowly!As for the content... if you are considering buying this expensive volume, you probably already know what you're in for. This is an encyclopedia from an imaginary realm, and depicts plants, machines, people, animals and all kinds of things that ought to make no sense whatsoever, and yet somehow do. The squiggly writing is not meant to be decipherable.The Codex is whimsical without being cutesy. There are diagrams of organs, skeletons and dismembered nudes, assorted bizarre creatures and a two-page spread devoted to showing a human couple having sex while morphing into an alligator. I personally don't find any of this disturbing, but if Hieronymus Bosch is too much for you, then you won't like this either.This book inspires a kind of fascination. I look through it slowly, curious and engaged, wordlessly piecing together meanings that fall away as soon as I turn the page. It will delight people who enjoy ambiguity and creating their own interpretations. It will displease people who like to get to the bottom of meanings and are bored by things they don't understand.If you think the Codex is your cup of tea, buy it right now, even if it's backordered. It's been years since this book sold for under $100, and I would expect this edition to sell out like every other.

I really wanted to love this needle threader, because it's so pretty. It comes on a lanyard and the design looks just like the picture. It works a little differently from most threaders I've used: you put the thread in a notch, and it gets caught by a little hook that you slide upwards through the eye of your needle.The problem is, the tiny notched piece is made of thin metal that easily bends. And although it's very thin, it doesn't fit into the smallest needle eyes at all. It's ok for occasional use, but isn't a tool to rely upon.

I thought this would be a funny stocking stuffer for a family member who is enthusiastic about Obamacare. I couldnt tell from the description, but this is actually a deck of cards that you can use for regular card games. Consequently, the backs are all the same, and the reverse has cartoons and tidbits of information along with the card values. Each card is unique; the illustrations and info do not repeat. The cards feel pretty sturdy and well made.Those who oppose Obamacare will not appreciate the one-sided positivity, but then they wouldnt buy this anyway. I learnt a few new things, for example that screening for cervical cancer will be free for women over 30.Im removing one star for the typography. The layout is a bit dense and the text could use more leading. The content could be edited to fit on the cards more easily. However, I still think its a fun item and recommend it.

I bought this elephant to be used as a stool in the bathroom, but it's so cute that I'm considering using it elsewhere as a small table. It's better than the photo because it looks great from any angle. I'm a little bit timid about sitting on something that seems like it could break, but it held up fine when I tried it out. Compared to the more expensive Jonathan Adler menagerie animals I have, this has a less consistent finish; it's glossy in some places and less so in others. However, it's still a fantastic piece, and quite a bargain.

In the intro, Crilley says he did his best to make this 'a real how-to-draw-manga' book, meaning an emphasis on conveying narrative rather than just drawing manga-style characters as art. There are sections that explain his process start to  finish, planning a panel, composition, sequencing, inking, page layout and more. I especially liked the section on using point of view to convey narrative purpose.The bulk of the book focuses on drawing characters, both male and female. Some of the basics do overlap with volume I, like basic proportions of the body/face. However this book includes variations such as a worm's eye view, sitting, a standing kiss and foreshortened views. The harder poses are a good continuation as a level-up from volume I, but the instructions are clear enough that I think beginners could follow them if they take their time to get it right.I follow the author's Youtube channel and I've noticed that his style has evolved a bit since the first book was written. Lately he seems to be doing more traditionally realistic drawings, many of which are quite impressive. However, this book is more rooted in the manga style. I've read some criticisms of the first book that say it's not authentically Japanese enough, but personally I like that he portrays people of different ethnicities and ages, which I haven't seen as much in the Japanese books I have.Both volumes of Mastering Manga are good, but if you can only get one, consider what you want to learn. This book would be a better choice if you want to learn more about putting together a full story, whereas the first book had more examples of variations for details such as hands or eyes. Each book does stand on its own, so get both if you can.

My terrible cooking is legendary. Someone I knew at university taught me how to make toast for the first time, but it was years before I realized 'broil' wasn't just a variant spelling of 'boil'. I once invited my best friend over to dinner; she asked if I were cooking the meal myself, and I admitted we'd be getting takeout. She brightly responded, 'in that case, I'll come!'Over the years, I've found a few little things I can make, but when I saw this book, I knew it was meant for me. It's a lovely cookbook, spiral bound so that it will lay flat, but with a hard cover for durability. The instructions are clear and each dish is shown full size in color. The tone is friendly and each recipe has a 'Don't Panic' note, such as 'Using an electric mixer may put you off, but it's only about as complicated as using a blow dryer.' There's a part at the beginning that explains kitchen tools and how to set things up, along with photos showing how techniques like chopping garlic and removing the pit from an avocado. The back has a glossary, a guide to in-season produce, a meat temperature chart, storage guidelines, measurement equivalents and a couple of pages for notes. Also, some pages have a little icon that you can use with a smartphone to view videos; it isn't necessary, but it's a nice touch.In the 24 hours I've had this book, I've tried two recipes. The Shepherd's French Toast (page 57) was absolutely delicious! I've always loved French toast but didn't think it was something I could manage myself. The book does assume you have things like multiple cookware items, but I managed to make the french toast one piece at a time in my only saucepan, and it came out fine. I know I'll be making this recipe a lot! I also tried the marinara sauce on page 133, which was also very good. I did find it a little spicy and might not use as much red pepper next time. I made both dishes with ingredients I happened to have; there was nothing obscure. The instructions are short enough that I could read through once and remember them while cooking.There are sections for chicken, meat and fish, but there are enough other dishes to make the book useful for vegetarians. Nearly all dishes outside the meat sections are vegetarian, which includes most of the book. Even the ones with meat could be adapted. (For example, I want to try the Tuna & Apple Pita Pizza without the tuna.) However, there are a lot of recipes with eggs, milk or cheese, so vegans may not find enough recipes to justify the purchase.

I can tell that Erica Domesk is a very creative person who is inspired by many materials that most of us might overlook. Her projects have a lot of flair and personality. My favorites were the party decorations: fringe streamers, raffia-wrapped bottles, glassware decorated with paint and nail polish... there are some festive ideas. From the title, I would have expected a big focus on entertaining, but it's really just a sprinkling of party projects throughout the book. This is a shame, because Domesk's particular talent of turning everyday items into a fun decoration is perfectly suited to casual entertaining.Too many projects are things that most people would not want to own, let alone invest time and money to make. For example,  there's a cocktail ring made from an outdoor plumbing valve handle, and earrings made out of safety pins. Other projects would be charming for kids' costumes, like a plastic pencil box made into an evening clutch and a poncho made from a fleece blanket. In fact, I would love to see Domesek release a book of Halloween costumes for children; sadly, the accessories and jewelry in this book are already halfway there. I can envision a fabulously artsy person carrying off some of these looks, but if you're the type to rock Sharpie-embellished clothes, you probably don't need a book to tell you how.The home decor projects are a little better; I'm going to try the faux mercury glass technique, though I found better examples on Pinterest and more detailed instructions on Youtube. There's a moroccan mirror made from faux tin tile that's really pretty clever, but again it seems more like a flimsy party decoration than permanent decor. The low points are framed art of the word `love' scrawled in neon cord, and sticker dots used to decorate a table. Yes, neon sticker dots, the kind you get at an office supply store to tag items at a yardsale.The book itself is nicely hardbound and beautifully designed. The photo instructions are clear, and there are plenty of them. The book is light on text, which is fine - the pictures and videos give plenty of instructions. Yes, videos! You can get extra instruction if you have a smartphone that can read the codes included on several pages. I did have to download a special app to read the code, but it was easy to use. I think this is a great idea, and it's the first craft book I have with this feature.Still, this is the kind of book that gives DIY a bad reputation, the glue-this-to-that type projects that scream "I made it myself". A lot of projects assume you already have things like tshirts, tote bags, pillow covers or even a chandelier lying around waiting to be made over. If you don't, these projects will get expensive fast, especially since some include pricier supplies like peacock feather trim or Swarovski chain. This book might have some appeal to tweens, but most crafters expect a little more quality out of the items they make.

I love this bento box and use it nearly every day. I have the purple box and the colours are true to what's shown in the photo. My favourite thing about it is that it doesn't become stained from food like so many other containers do. At first, I wasn't sure if the parts would hold together well, since they don't lock together. However, yesterday I accidentally dropped the whole thing on the hard kitchen floor, and only one tiny drop of fresh spaghetti sauce escaped the bottom container.I used to live in Japan and have owned lots of different bento boxes. I thought I preferred the kind that has an inner seal and handles that clamp down. I would still use that type for soup, but this style is much easier to clean. I haven't noticed a difference in freshness between food stored in this type and the other. This also holds more food than most of the Japanese ones. For me, it easily holds two meals, depending on what's in it.I took advantage of the mail-in offer for a free extra strap and received it in the mail about a week later. I haven't had a need to use it yet though. The only negative I can think of is that the plastic utensils fit a little loosely in the middle section, but it's not a big deal. I've noticed some comments saying that it can deform if you put it in the dishwasher or microwave; I haven't tried either, so it's not been an issue.

I thought this was just a spice blend, but it's basically a spicier substitute for parmesan cheese. Here are the ingredients: parmesan cheese (pasteurized skim cow's milk, cheese culture, salt, enzyme), garlic salt, spices, sesame seed.I've tried this on pasta and with scrambled eggs, and it's very flavorful. It definitely enhances dishes and makes up for my meagre cooking skills.Unfortunately, nutritional information is not on the packaging; you have to email them for it. It's not even on their website!Also, as of this writing, all ten of the 5-star reviews are from people who mainly only review Leo's Amazing products.Update: I emailed for the nutritional info and received it within 24 hours:Nutrition FactsServing Size 2 tsp (5 g)Per Serving% Daily Value*Calories 20Calories from Fat 14Total Fat 1.5g  2%Saturated Fat 1.0g  5%Cholesterol 4mg  1%Sodium 250mg  10%Carbohydrates 0.0g  0%Dietary Fiber 0.0g  0%Sugars 0.0gProtein 2.0gVitamin A 0% * Vitamin C 0%Calcium 6% * Iron 0%

'Much of our food comes from living, sentient plants' which 'many scientists... have proved are able to read your thoughts.'If you read that and thought, 'wow, what I always suspected is true!' then buy this book, because it's filled to the brim with equally insightful revelations. Otherwise, save your money and skip this one.

I have two milia over one eye and I read that this cream could help with that. There are other options, but this seemed the most gentle. After four weeks of regular use, I can't tell any difference in the milia at all. That aside, I still wasn't impressed with this product. The smell is so unpleasant that I dread using it; it smells just like Vick's vap-o-rub. I agree with the reviewer who said it makes eyes sting and water, but that only lasts a few seconds. It does feel somewhat moisturizing, but I haven't noticed any difference with fine lines or any kind of change or improvement with my eyes at all.It's not terrible eye cream, but I am sure there must be equally effective products that do not cost as much or smell as dreadful.

This is a bag you either love or are bewildered by, but I think if you like it online, you'll like it in person. It's a great medium size, and the handles are soft and sturdy. It has both a zipper and a magnetic flap closure. The inside has a couple of open pockets and one zippered pocket, and there's a zippered pocket on the back. The striped part is canvas.It looks adorable, but the quality is mediocre. The zippers work smoothly, the metal spikes are solidly attached and the tassels on the front have real bamboo beads. However, my bag had a few loose threads, and the zipper stitching is already pulling away on one side. The lining feels cheap, and there is no extra lining behind the grommets, so it's not waterproof at all. The bottom doesn't have metal feet, and the pleather seems delicate. The tassels look especially fake, since you can see the white vinyl backing. I still think this bag is very cute, but I don't think it's worth even half the retail value. I got mine at a steep discount, but would have been disappointed if I'd paid more.

Tea, fig & tobacco? Hardly! This candle smells like a Christmas tree. Which isn't bad, but I wouldn't have purchased it in May had I known. I questioned the name 'gifted', wondering if it's a holiday scent, but there was nothing in the description to indicate it.I was expecting a warm, grassy scent and instead got this bright evergreen fragrance. As a candle, it's heavily scented and burns well. As perfume, it has staying power. However, I can't imagine anybody, male or female, wanting to smell like a spruce!Update: This candle does not burn cleanly at all. I use scented candles on a daily basis, but this one gave me a headache. Candles in tins are my favourites, and I loved the idea of using this as a wearable fragrance. I also appreciate that it's cruelty free. But I also have to say, as someone who buys many candles from a variety of makers, this is probably the worst candle I've ever bought, from the scent to the smoke to the headaches. I'm the sort of person who uses products all the way up and hates to throw things away partially unused, but this one's going in the bin.

I love the Skyn Iceland cleansing cloths and thought this would be very refreshing. I have dry skin and hoped this would help with the dry heat indoors in winter.The fragrance is a little too intense for me. Its not unpleasant, but its a heavy, artificial scent. The sprayer is a somewhat hard to press, and the mist comes out stronger than Id like. Ive used it daily for a couple of weeks now and havent noticed any change in my skin.

Pisces is one of my favourite Little Dals  I wish there were a big version. Her face is particularly pretty and her eyes are purple to match her hair. She comes in a pretty plastic box that makes a wonderful gift presentation, but getting the doll out can be time-consuming.Her bikini top is made of two filagree metal circles strung on ribbon, and her tail closes in the back with velcro. She's jointed at the shoulders, hips and neck. Her wig is glued on and she has a metal headpiece. If you have Petit Blythes, she can share their clothes.These dolls definitely are not suitable for young children, as they have very tiny parts.

This Byul is much prettier in person. Its skintone looks washed out in the photos; in real life it's darker and has reddish undertones. The doll has a nice wig that can be unbraided. The natural faceup and simple hairstyle make this a versatile doll if you'd like to redress it. It looks cute in traditional or modern clothes. The doll is fully articulated and poses well. Moving a lever on the back of the head will make the eyes move from side to side - they don't close.The clothing looks like the photo and is very detailed. It's worth noting that part of the doll's outfit uses real fur, probably rabbit fur. However, it's possible to remove the fur part and display the doll in her cotton dress and the cape-like piece that fits over the shoulders. The clogs (?!) fall off her feet easily, but might stay on better if she were wearing socks. She comes with an ornate orange plastic stand and a collector's card, in an attractive box.This is a collector's doll meant for adults, and is not durable enough to withstand rough play. It has a lot of tiny parts and one of the arms on mine falls off from time to time. It might be ok for a child who will mainly keep it on a shelf as decoration, but what's the fun of that?

This toy, or at least most of it's parts, will be in my home for years to come! The toy seems primarily designed for bath time fun, with holes in the shapes to allow water to run through, as well as decorative holes in the bottom of the green bowl to allow water to escape. The brown nose on the center face squeaks when you press it, but I'm not sure if this feature would work in the tub if it were wet. My kiddo isn't quite old enough to be taking full tub baths yet, so we play with this in the living room or sometimes when we go on playdates.Another awesome use for this toy would be sand castle additions. The little shapes are open on one side which would make perfect little sand stuffers for the beach. Would be great to toss in the toy tote for the beach day.This toy is well made, easy to handle, even for the littlest of littles, and will be around to take abuse for years.

We love this coffee & buy the kilo when we can as it is the cheapest we can find it (even with shipping from Amazon) per ounce. The 454 variety of Kicking Horse, in particular, is our go-to and we use it in both our French press and our espresso machine with delish results. Coffee preference varies so much by individual so I'm sure there will be plenty of folks that don't enjoy this, but this is the coffee we love and get every time we're able to. We try the other varieties in the medium and dark roast by Kicking Horse and like them as well, but try to get the 454 when we can.

These gorgeous blue simulated sapphire studs are a great addition to my jewelry box. While my office wear is generally business casual, every once in awhile we have a formal business meeting or get together that I need to dress up a bit for. These will be my go-to's for such occasions. They would also work well for any other formal or semi-formal event you might have to attend, but I could also see these glamming up some awesome jeans, t-shirt, & heels combo.The only thing I'm not terribly fond of is how heavy these are for their size. The sides do stick up a bit, maybe 1/8" or so, and while this side detailing is beautiful, I feel it pointlessly adds to the overall weight of the stud resulting in it sagging on the ear a bit. I think if the post were higher set on the earring it might counter this, but they are a bit droopy for my taste.

My husband and I sat down to play this and had a pretty good time of it. We come from different game preferences; He is a fan of the written series and generally enjoys strategy games, and I have never read or watched the series and am rather terrible at strategy games. He also has a background in strategy card games while I do not. I found the game to be a little more confusing than he did, but I think this just has to do with him being more adept at interpreting several rules per phase of each turn while it is harder for me to keep track of so much at one time.The gameplay is not fast-paced, but with some practice the games will get quicker. Learning the rules and cards and abilities will help with this and the only way to do this is to just play the game.While I know nothing of the story line or lore, my husband does and says it follows the books pretty well. Even with my lack of knowledge, the game is still very enjoyable and I don't feel like I'm missing something or not 'getting it'.A few things I didn't like about the game - I hear the first edition of this same game is not compatible with this edition. All the cards that were published before for the game are now obsolete. This is a pretty huge drawback for me and I would hate to have to keep sinking the same start up capital over and over again into a game that I enjoyed because the makers chose to do this. Allowing the cards to be used across editions of the same game seems like a better way to keep players returning for more rather than forcing them to purchase all new cards.Another thing I do not enjoy about the game is the complexity without there being too much strategy involved. From the couple of playthroughs that we did, it seemed like the game encourages you to really duke it out between two players, but there isn't much reward for me. Again, this isn't my type of game to begin with, so it could be something I just don't enjoy and others do.Overall, I would recommend this to people who have regular game nights with their family and friends, and who have a couple people handy that have some sort of background in strategy card games to help out along the way with rules and such. I look forward to keeping this in our rotation for our game nights and really hope future editions will be compatible!

Giving this four stars because sometimes my baby just refuses to eat this, but as we all know that doesn't really mean anything when you're trying to feed a baby.I tried some of this myself - without the breastmilk - and it tastes pretty bland. There is an apple flavor there but it's not overly sweet or fake tasting. The cereal itself was a bit gritty and coarse, but I literally ate some dry powder off the spoon, so not the best judge there. I would assume if it sat in some liquid for a while, hot or cold, that it would soften up quite a bit.As with any other cereal you feed to babies, this will get hard and lumpy if not stirred well and enough liquid is added. We don't follow the directions whatsoever on this package and just kind of eyeball it and make a gruel with the powder when we want to spoon feed her and just put some directly into a small bottle for a thick milk / super thin cereal bottle at night with a nipple that we cut a slit in the end of.Baby will sometimes eat this, sometimes not. I like that the ingredients are recognizable and that I think it tastes pretty okay, too. We're not huge cereal feeders and usually only do it for a comfort measure for her (after a bath, before bed, etc.), but when we do give it to her, it's nice to know she's getting good quality food. We stay away from super processed foods, so we try to keep her away from them too.

While I think the glare-free, halo-free, shadow-free adjectives are a little absurd to describe the light output of a lamp, I do really like the desk lamp. It has two light settings that are selected by holding down the power button for one second. The power button itself is a touch-sensitive button, so there isn't any mechanical feedback to it, i.e. you don't feel it click on or off. I like the silence of it, honestly, as silly as that sounds.While I do wish the head swiveled back and forth, the up and down movement of it seems to be adequate for lighting my desk. I like the USB charger that is on the side and the little cubby is nice for holding small gadgets or your phone while they charge from the port.The design itself is okay and I do feel that the plastic is a bit cheap looking for the price point this lamp is at, but that doesn't take away from the lamp in any way.The light output is sufficient for my desk and would also be great for a bedside table, but I wouldn't try to use it for much more than that. This is great for task lighting at my desk, but I wouldn't want to depend solely on this for long hours if I needed lighting for a specific need like crafting or small detail work on something.

I am familiar with De'Longhi products from an acquaintance who for many years had an older model cappuccino machine from that company. I knew the quality and durability of their products, so I was excited to get this in and started up!From doorstep to cappuccino in hand was about 10 to 15 minutes, so set up time is short and directions are super easy to follow even for someone who has never made drinks with this type of machine before.After setup, which is basically giving things a bit of a wash (my preferences, this is not included in the directions for setup) and then running a full tank of water through the machine, you're ready to go.The machine is lightweight and takes up as much counter space as a regular drip coffee pot would, so there is minimal space investment with this machine. I did find the filter holder to be hard to turn once it's seated in the boiler outlet, and because of the light weight of the machine - even with the water tank full - I had to press my hand against the side to brace the machine while I attached it. Most probably won't have this issue, but I'm not the strongest in my upper body.The milk steamer worked great with our soy and we sprinkled a bit of cinnamon on top for a nice treat. Te Get Started book that comes in the box includes the different drinks you can make such as cappuccino, cafe latte, Americano, etc.In addition to regular ground espresso, the machine will also take espresso pods if you prefer to deal with the grounds that way making cleanup easier. There are some descaling instructions in the owner's manual, but first time espresso machine owners should really take some time to get to know the machine and the different areas that should be cleaned after each use to keep the machine in top form.

This is supremely robust accounting software that is perfect for small to mid-sized business that are seriously keeping track of their own accounting, with or without the assistance of a CPA.I have a small business that I run with my sister and my husband and this software makes keeping all of us on the same page a breeze - especially because my sister is located in a different state. I love that you can seamlessly export to Excel much of the data - this makes storage and sending info to others really easy for us.The main draw to this software is the breadth of service that is offered here. Shipping automation, task management, cost estimates and comparisons, and tons of other features are available for use. There is even features that let you forecast your options in pricing and purchasing and training. I love that we can do everything from here - payroll, bank account watching, business forecasting, and tons more.Installation was straightforward and typical of any software. A few steps and we were ready to go without having to install too much extra stuff on the computer.There is a HUGE drawback to this software. The price vs. life span of the software is not that great. While our business will be able to continue to use most features of the software in the future without the support and other features that will be disabled when the Sage service is up, all those extras are nice and losing them really sucks, for lack of a better word. I suppose I could continue to fork over the ridiculous price they want to allow me to keep these services, but it just isn't worth it after I've dropped such a pretty penny on the software.The software is truly amazing for what it is and I really hope that when our year is up, the bill won't be all that bad and we'll be able to keep it for a while, but as it's looking it doesn't seem to be the case.Despite the time limit on some of the features, I would still recommend this to anyone who has the capital to invest in good accounting software. It's pretty easy to use, despite the complexity and I feel there is a pretty good bang for your buck with it.

Essie is a leading brand in nail color and is also a 3-free polish, meaning no dibutyl phthalate, toluene, or formaldehyde in the mix. This particular shade I got, Coat Couture, is a beautiful purple gray color that has a shimmer of teal / green / blue in it.Because the polish is matte, the shimmer is much more subtle than what you would find in a high gloss finish, but the effect is amazing. I love wearing this color on it's own or mixing it in with a regular polish, creating a single stripe on each nail or doing just the tip in the gloss to create a more interesting look.The color is perfect for fall, but I can see wearing it year round without any issues. The color goes on well and covers great. One coat would work, but two makes this really stand out and last a good bit. Chip free for about two and a half days on my fingers (this is saying something as I'm currently an at-home mom who is constantly doing something with my hands) before I needed a couple touch ups. Left the polish on for around a week before I broke down and took it off for another color.

We use this dice expansion with Adventure Time Fluxx Game and it works perfectly with the game. Adds a bit of extra fun to the mix and changes it up just enough to keep the same ol' game a bit less stale.We play the Fluxx Games, Cards Against Humanity, and others of that type before longer role playing games or board games to get the crowd warmed up, so to speak. It gets people out of their shell a little more and if all the players don't know each other, it gives a chance for more interaction. Great for parties too!

I found this wash from a sample packet I was given in a gift bag from my birthing center. This wash has a light citrus scent that does not linger after the bath like many other baby products do. This is one of the main reasons I am drawn to it. Another reason is the natural ingredients and limited ingredient list the product has.Tear free for our three month old and doesn't dry her skin out.

One day my baby loves these pacifiers and the next she hates them. I'm taking a star off because she does tend to favor the NUK Farm Animals Pacifier we got for her, but who's to say that won't change in the future.We mostly use these for a bait-and-switch when she wants to keep nursing after she's asleep or will wake up if we try to put her down. We'll give her the bottle initially, then switch over to the pacifier to get her to sleep and then set her down. It works most of the time.

This is a very cute book that is suitable as individual bedtime stories or for a sitdown reading of the whole thing. We read the book to our infant, but anticipate this being a book she will also read on her own in the coming years.I like that the stories give something to think about and discuss between parent and child. No prior knowledge of Buddhism is needed for these to be great stories for children.

Charmin Ultra Soft is one of my picks when I'm shopping for toilet paper. I rotate through a few different brands and types depending on the price and Charmin is one of my main go-to brands. I enjoy the combination of durability and low lint - something that seems hard to get in the more plush toilet papers. While this isn't super-top-of-the-line toilet paper, this gets the job done without feeling like you're trying to save money in all the wrong places.I know the price can vary, but this is the cheapest I can find this toilet paper in my area by a good bit. Also, being able to get it in bulk is a convenience for me.

We are primarily a cloth diapering family, but when I do use disposables I use the Pampers Swaddlers. These diapers are the Swaddlers Sensitive and just like the regular Swaddlers, these do a wonderful job when we need them. Mostly, I use disposables when I use a carrier to avoid compression leaks with the cloth diapers and when we're going for longer car rides and I don't want to pull over every couple hours to change her diaper. These do a great job.The sensitive branding isn't too much of a step up to warrant the price difference, in my opinion, but we've never really had problems with extra sensitive skin, either. I can't say it won't help a babe with extra sensitive skin, but we just were not able to tell a difference. The diaper is softer on the outside and the tabs are white instead of yellow. Other than that, we can't see much of a difference. The scent is the same as the regular Swaddlers, as well. There is added aloe according to the packaging.These hold well for our child and we don't have too many blowouts. I can't say that a blowout is the mark of a bad diaper, it just happens.

My cats have been eating Wellness Core food for several years now and the assurance of a grain free diet along with the amazing coat it gives them is well worth the bit of extra cost.After having my dearly beloved Manx cat diagnosed with diabetes and our vet explaining to us the negative side effects that feeding grains to pets can have (increased blood sugar from the carbohydrate conversion to sugars) we switched all our pets to grain free and never went back. A nice side effect of the switch has been the increased glossiness of their coat. I have a smaller, all black cat that is almost ten now and his coat is gorgeous with this food.The cats, who are notoriously picky eaters, took to this with no issues.

This is my go-to dry shampoo and I use it almost every day.So why four stars instead of five? I'm still searching for the perfect dry shampoo, that's why. I'll list my two main complaints with this, and all other dry shampoos I've tried after going over the awesomeness first.I love the effectiveness of the product, firstly. I need to either shampoo my hair or do something to mask the greasy look after about 24 hours post-washing. This dry shampoo is great at doing that for me. Shake it up pretty good and spray on my roots in a few areas, let it sit while I brush my teeth, then use my fingers to give myself a mini scalp massage to work in the product.Another great use is for this product is texturizing. If you want to give your hair a bit more of a lived-in look when you've just washed it, spray a bit of this on the ends and work it through with a wide toothed comb.The two things I don't like about the product is the strong smell, which after trying a few flavors (scents?) of this product I found the Original is my favorite and the lightest scented, in my book. I also don't like the velocity of the spray that comes out. It tends to mess up my hair, but holding it farther out only applies product where I don't want it. I'm going for a worn-in look or just trying to touch up yesterday's look, not going for the wind tunnel look. It's not so bad, though, but wish it was a little more chill on those fronts.

As with all other Presonus devices, this recording device has all the small details covered to deliver a truly world-class product. Some find that the limit of two inputs is limiting, but I never find myself playing more than one instrument at a time and wanting to record it. If I had a group to record, I'd probably do it in a different format for better quality, or just use an ambient mic.Beyond the two inputs little details like control clicks when you turn the knobs and the awesome software that is included with this recording device is really great.I had a little bit of issues when using this for the first time. The software is set to pic up the Mic by default so until I found this setting, I wasn't able to record properly. Also, the playback is through the output by default, so to hear it through the computer, you'll need to change that as well.The software, Studio One, is really great with extra samples and lets you clean things up nicely.

Sometimes the little things make a big difference in life; a new lip color or lotion can really give you a boost. I was really excited to try this leave-on Dead Sea mud cream to give myself a bit of extra pampering every once in a while.After using the lotion a few times, I've found that I prefer to use it when I bathe so that I can wash it off. The smell is way too strong for me and the product becomes oily after applying, so rinsing it off is my preference.Advantages:- Does a wonderful job of giving me super soft feet.- Thick cream that melts with your body's natural heat.- Can use and remove, and still get good results.Disadvantages:- The overpowering scent was too much for me and a big reason I didn't care for this foot cream as much as I wished I would.- As your body heat melts the oils in the cream, the product gets oily and did not quickly absorb. This would be perfect under some socks for the evening, but I don't like walking around in socks and I don't like oily feet for more than a couple minutes.- There are no ingredients listed on the bottle. For what it's worth, the product I received could have been without it's outer packaging because I am a Vine reviewer, but it still struck me as odd.After the second use, I washed it off with a damp rag because of the smell and have since just used it when I'm taking a bath so I can enjoy the sft feet  without the lingering scent or oil.

There is a good amount of gaming that takes place in my household and I was very excited to try this racing wheel. I wish that I could give a 3.5 star review; the set is exceptional, but super expensive and a slight pain to get working on Windows 7 x64.Fresh out of the box my first thoughts were that this product feels well made, it is hefty and the hand stitched leather on the steering wheel feels excellent. The pedal base has a pop out pad of spikes to keep it from moving on carpet, which I found to work quite well without it tearing up the carpet at all. It mounts easily and securely to my desk with two clamps that screw into place.Some of the only issues I had installing the device was when I installed the Logitech Gaming Software package from the official website, and after successful installation, Windows 7 informed me it was an unsigned driver then disabled the device.  Heading back to the Logitech website I noticed under the details tab that Windows 7 users need to install a certain Windows Update, which fixed my unsigned driver issue.The force feedback on the wheel is quite strong, and I have it turned down a bit from the default levels. The Logitech software allows full configuration of buttons as well as sensitivity levels for the wheel and pedals.This really takes games to the next level and I highly recommend it for the serious game lover.

Got this for the spouse - he's around 6' and 170lbs or so - in the large size. It fits him nicely and isn't too snug. He probably could have gotten a medium, but he prefers a roomier fit in all of his clothing.Despite the light weight of the robe, it is very warm but still highly breathable thanks to the silk composition. The fabric weave is a charmeuse, meaning that the outside has a sheen while the inside is more dull. It's very similar to the lining on men's jackets and the like.There are a few features that I really like about this robe.First is the belt. It is sturdily sewn into place in the middle back which helps prevent missing belts altogether. On my spouse's other silk robe, he has shoved his belt into one pocket to keep from losing it which, over the last ten years, has resulted in a permanently wrinkled belt that looks a bit scuzzy when he wears it. Sewing the belt into place only makes sense and it's a small touch that does wonders for the garment as a whole.The next feature I really like are the offset pockets. Pockets on robes are almost useless, but they almost always seem to be in an odd spot, like the front and center of your thighs rather than more along the side of the leg. These pockets are set off to the side a little more than usual for robes and the top is even on a bias so you can get your hands in and out with ease and little to no stress from the pockets pulling on the main fabric of the robe.My only complaint with this product is the packaging. I've seen others mention the same thing, but the packaging on a robe that costs this much should really be thought out a bit more. Mine came in a flimsy plastic sleeve with the robe folded around a standard cardboard square. Granted, I wasn't expecting much more, but I was just so surprised they couldn't find classy packaging to match the classiness of the robe. First impressions are very important for consumers.

Whenever I make purchases for my kitchen, in particular, my cook and bakeware, I try to make sure the product I get will last me for a good long while. I will never, ever understand the person that will re-buy a crappy pot or pan every five years. If you would have spent the money on a nicer product in the first place, the original would have lasted through several of the typical re-purchase cycles.That being said, this KitchenAid cast iron casserole dish is certainly a piece you will be able to hand down to your children. The manufacturers know this is a lifetime piece and even offer a lifetime warranty along with their product. In addition to this being microwave and freezer safe, you can also put this guy in the dishwasher, and use it on either the stovetop or in the oven. (ETA: This is NOT microwave safe - it is toaster oven safe, however, but not microwave! Thanks for pointing this out!)The dimensions given in the info boxes for the product include the handles, so the cooking area is about 9"x9". I've used this pan almost a dozen times since receiving it. A few of the dishes we've done so far include shepherd's pie, which starts on the stovetop before finishing in the oven, brownies (the handy 9"x9" size...), cornbread that stuck a little bit, potato gratin, and baked ziti.All our food has tasted fine and the flavors have not transferred from one dish to another. The nonstick interior really is nonstick for the most part. One of the issues I struggled with on my traditional cast iron ovenware is how badly thing stuck, even if I had properly seasoned the pan (or thought I had). Other than a little bit of cornbread that stuck in one of the corners, my batch came out just fine elsewhere.Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this casserole dish as a good investment piece. There are brands out there you could easily pay two or three times this much for the exact same quality as you will receive with this casserole. I look forward to using this for years to come.

We are a primarily cloth-diapering family, but still having disposables on hand, I feel, is a must. Not only are these diapers getting us through those first weeks of adjusting to a newborn, but they also give our friends and family members that drop in to visit an opportunity to care for the child without hassling with our cloth diapers if they aren't comfortable with them.Another reason I keep disposables on hand is because many daycares or drop-in child care that is provided at the gym or church will not take a child with cloth diapers. Some family members or babysitters are not comfortable with the idea of changing a cloth diaper, and sometimes I just don't want my cloth diaper to possibly be damaged if they use them improperly.In any case, these diapers are fitting wonderfully, a couple of leaks around the legs, but nothing too serious. I don't really dig the Disney prints, but it seems near impossible to find major brand diapers without some sort of branding on them.

This socket wrench set makes a great starter set or addition to any toolbox. We have been hodge-podging together a toolbox of various, basic purchases over the last ten years or so, and these were a much welcomed addition.Advantages:- Set comes in a box that is peg-board compatible.- Easy to maintain and clean- Lifetime warranty gets me every time- One handed operation with the quick release button on the back of the wrench that allows you to change the socket being used with only one hand instead of twoDisadvantages:- The foam that comes inside the case to keep things from rattling around too much is pretty thin and isn't attached to the box at all. This will probably end up being replaced with a cloth at some point.This is an excellent set overall and for the price range, it is hard to beat the quality. I look forward to many years of use out of this wrench set.

After having a cat become diabetic around 6 years ago, we switched all our cat food and treats to grain-free formulas, with Wellness taking the majority of our loyalty. It's easy to find the brand in most of the major grocery stores and the chain pet stores.The Trufood line of the Wellness brand in particular has a very wide range of vegetables and supplements that have been added in to help provide a more complete food. I do not find that the step-up in quality is that significant over the current food that I use - the Wellness canned wet food & Natural Balance dry food - to warrant such an increase in price per pound. This is the only reason I'm taking off two stars. I just wish that for this price jump, there would be more of a benefit or fewer fillers and supplements than what is offered.My cats eat this and really like it, something I was concerned about as they tend to be hesitant to any changes in their diet. Their coat is still looking great and they haven't had any extra stinky breath issues since starting this food - all issues that I keep an eye out for when we change things up.

Neither of my cats - one that has been raised indoors his whole life and the other an outdoor-turned-indoor cat - would touch more than a few kernels of this at a time. The first time we set it out, one cat ate several bites but then puked it up and the other just sniffed and ignored it.We can put a couple of these down as 'treats' for them, but they just won't eat it like normal food. The quality is excellent, as with the entire Wellness Core line, but my cats just won't eat this.

This simple and classic design in rose toned gold is is offset with a matte black ribbon that wraps around the center of the strap and surrounds the faceplate of this Kate Spade New York analog wrist watch. Pops of bright pink are found on the second hand and on the logo in the 12-o'clock position.The Skyline series of watches give a more modern feel to a very classic design with the pop of color that accompanies the classic appearance. I really like the black color the most out of the series as it has the most versatile function for my wardrobe.I am in love with this watch - the rose gold is perfect for both the office or going out at night and it has a such a classic design that it goes with literally anything I wear. Besides working out, if I am going out of the house I am grabbing this guy off my dresser without fail.The width of the watch is perfect, even for someone with small wrists. It doesn't get lost in your overall appearance (I've had a few compliments on it now) but isn't so big or bold that it creates a statement piece. I did have two links removed from the watch to fit my wrist circumference better.

This AIO is a great starter for both newborns and new parents - or those parents new to cloth diapering. The diaper is designed to be very similar to a modern disposable diaper and I think this is very important for those just starting out with cloth diapers. The inside is very soft with a flip-out insert that is sewn into the diaper along the front side of the diaper. The back side of the insert has a pocket designed to hold an extra layer of absorbent material if you need that for a heavy wetter or an overnight diaper.I found that adding a flour sack towel, or even half of one, is a bit much for this diaper in terms of bulk and causes it not to fit the best in the world around legs, but this is different for each child.The umbilical cord area is not permanent - which is excellent for keeping the diaper in use for longer stretches of time - and is just a one-snap fold down area in the front center of the diaper. There are also rise adjusting snaps on each leg that can be used for those kiddos with the skinny thighs. I do wish that the flaps that fold around from the back and secure to the front came with more than just one snap for securing the diaper to provide for a bit more stability, but the diaper functions perfectly fine without it - just a personal preference.The design is super cute and vibrant, and is easily used with boy or girl clothing. The blue seemed to be lighter in color than the site pictures it, but not drastically so.

I tend to put my hair through the heat trials - I blow dry and flatten my hair back to back some mornings and if I'm not doing that, I have a curling wand that I use on the highest setting. While I do use a good quality heat protectant spray before I use any heat, it only does so much. I still have to moisturize and make sure my shampoo isn't too drying or I'll end up with frizzy, lifeless hair.This smoothing conditioner is great at doing what it is designed for. A little bit goes a very long way with this conditioner and the product really coats your hair to provide lasting results throughout the day. I can blow dry after using this product and if I take my time with a large round brush, I can even get away without flat ironing the ends of my hair.
