The smell is a bit on the sweet / fruity side for me and it does tend to linger all day, but it is not overpowering or nauseating.

This diaper has some serious marketing with it - they really lead people to believe, as evidenced by some of the other reviews here, that they are chemical free, contain only natural ingredients, or something else of the like.While they are made with substantially less 'stuff' than many other leading diapers out there, they still contain several types of plastic and it's all over the areas that are next to baby's skin. Polyester, polypropylene, polyethylene, and a few other chemicals are all used next to the skin in this diaper whereas most of the plant-derived ingredients are found in the absorbent layers and material that covers the outside of the diaper.Advantages:- The diapers work at holding in major bathroom happenings. Things are kept where they should be the majority of the time.- White pigment is the only coloring agent in the diaper and plant-based materials have been used in this diaper where other companies use plastic fillers. This cuts down on time spent decomposing in landfills and the footprint of creating the diapers.- Less expensive than many other eco-friendly diapers on the market.Disadvantages:- The velcro area for attaching the diaper to itself is rather small and if you have a kiddo that likes to tug at their diaper if it's not covered, this might not hold up very well for you.- The marketing campaign behind these diapers does tend to make folks believe that these are either fully cotton diapers or 100% natural.I'm taking two stars away for a couple of reasons - one star gone for the marketing campaign behind these. Yes, they are made with friendlier materials for the earth, but the amount of folks that seem to think these are chemical free or a fully cotton diaper is a bit disheartening. I'm not sure to hold this against the company or the folks that assume this. The other star is gone for the lack of staying power on the velcro attachments.

REVIEW OF THEATRICAL RELEASE BLURAY (SEE BELOW FOR REVIEW OF EXTENDED EDITION):This BluRay contains the 137 minute theatrical release of the film, plus the usual Bonus materials including an interview with the film's executive producer Rafaella de Laurentiis and a collection of deleted scenes.  The overall quality of the video is only "fair". I was disappointed to see that the transfer was made from a print of the film that was not in pristine condition. Specifically, it looks like they at least tried to clean up scratches, dirt, and smudges on the film before it was scanned, but the color saturation, luminance values, and contrast are inconsistant, being poor in many scenes, and better in others. It's as if pieces from many different prints of the film, that were not all stored in the same conditions, were cut and spliced back together. Many of the scenes have a faded, almost "muddy" look to them. Audio quality was also less than ideal in some scenes.  By way of comparison, I have BluRays of other films from the 1970's and 1980's, "Blazing Saddles" being a good example, that are MUCH better in image quality, even though Blazing Saddles was made 10 years before Dune. One thing to note is that the deleted scenes shown in the bonus videos are in far worse condition than the main movie: they're heavily scratched, faded, and showing tons of dirt specks and holes in the film emulsion, so it's obvious that at least some effort was made to repair the physical damage in the film print transfer for the main movie; it's just not as crisp, clean and bright as some other 30 to 40 year old films I've seen on DVD's or BluRays.Actual resolution of the film image isn't very impressive, and frankly this BluRay is not significantly better than a DVD, at least in my opinion.  On the other hand, the $11 purchase price is only a couple of bucks more than a DVD, so I guess it's reasonable, and you do get 5 or 6 bonus videos that you wouldn't get with a DVD.WARNING - Spoilers in the next couple of paragraphs.As for the movie itself, if you have never seen it, I STRONGLY urge you to read Frank Herbert's novel FIRST. The story is very abstract, and even though there are frequent voice-overs that give the viewer some insight into what the characters are thinking, I think you will get much more enjoyment out of this film if you read the novels first, or at least shortly after watching the movie. Remarkably, director David Lynch stuck very close to the actual novel, even lifting crucial lines of dialog right out of the book in many scenes. Some of the actors are far too old for their characters, especially Kyle McLachlan (Paul Atreides) and Sting (Feyd-Rautha Harkonnen), who are only 16~18 years old in the novel. But overall, most of the cast were good "fits" for their characters, especially Jose Ferrer as the Emperor, Virginia Madsen as Irulan, Jurgen Prochnow as Duke Leto, and Freddie Jones as Thufir Hawat. The only characterizations that I think were overdone were the Baron Vladimir Harkonnen and Glossu "The Beast" Rabban. In many of Frank and Brian Herbert's novels set in the Dune universe, the Baron is a central character, and while he is undoubtedly corrupt, vindictive, scheming, vicious, and evil, he is not portrayed in the novels as an outright psychopath as he is in this movie. The same goes for Rabban, who is also portrayed as a raving lunatic and depraved psychotic in the movie, and doesn't come off that way in the novels.Unfortunately, 137 minutes isn't very much time in which to try and tell a story as complex as this, and the movie as shown in theaters (and in this BluRay), contains only a little more than half of the footage actually shot. Some crucial scenes are not in this film, or were shortened drastically, including Paul and Jessica's entry into Stilgar's tribe, and Paul's duel with Jamis, Again, a read of the novel is essential to get maximum appreciation for this film.  There is an Extended version of Dune, with almost an hour of extra footage, that may tell the story better for some viewers, but the extra footage is mostly in the first half of the movie, which leaves many scenes after the Harkonnen attack still uncovered.To younger viewers who grew up with films like Star Wars Episodes 1-3, the special effects in Dune will seem laughably crude, especially the sandworms and 'thopters, but remember that in 1984, sophisticated CGI was still in it's infancy, and it was not yet possible to marry CGI and live action in a totally seamless way, so Dune used animatronic models, like Jabba the Hutt in "Return of the Jedi". The difference being that Jabba was only a little larger than a human, whereas Dune had to try and portray sandworms that could be 450 meters long and 80 meters wide, with people riding on them, moving through sand in a believable way, and on a very limited budget. The Wikipedia article on this film mentions that the "bean counters" in charge of financing at the studio placed severe budgetary restrictions on the producers, and this is most visible in the special effects. Other areas of production, like costumes and set design/decoration, are surprisingly lavish. The very first scene in the film, where the Padishah Emperor is threatened by the Spacing Guild in the person of Edric, the Navigator, is extraordinary. One would think that the costume and set design budget for the entire film was expended on this one scene. The dress worn by Princess Irulan (portrayed by Virginia Madsen), is stunningly beautiful, and the costumes worn by other persons in this scene are almost as good, even though many of them are only passing through the room and are only on screen for two or three seconds.Summary: Dune (and I include all 6 novels of the series) was Frank Herbert's "magnum opus", This film by David Lynch was the first major attempt to translate the story into a movie, and while it was not very successful at the box office, it's well worth watching for Dune fans. It is especially gratifying to see how well the cast and crew tried to keep to the essentials of the novel, considering how often other Sci-Fi novels get horribly mangled in their movie versions (Heinlein's "Starship Troopers" being a prime example). For the $11 price, and a few more cents for a bag of microwave popcorn to eat while watching it, it's well worth adding to your collection, despite the less-than-ideal, sometimes faded and muddy quality of the film-to-digital transfer.  I gave this BluRay only 4 stars instead of 5 because of the mediocre film transfer quality; the lower rating was not because the movie itself was less than what I expected.REVIEW OF EXTENDED EDITION DVD:Amazon won't allow me to post this review of the Extended Edition separately; for some reason they have lumped the reviews of the Theatrical Release and the Extended Edition separately, which is a shame because they are practically different movies. The total run time of the Extended Edition is 177 minutes, 40 minutes longer than the Theatrical version. What do you actually get in that 40 minutes? (WARNING, SPOILERS)1. A 10 minute long Prologue, that replaces Princess Irulan's opening monologue from the Theatrical version. This prologue isn't even video footage from the film, it's a sequence of paintings and drawings, kind of like a storyboard, that gives a brief introduction to Frank Herbert's Dune Universe, including the primary story elements and the main characters. They start the Prologue with the Time of Titans (~6000 CE), and the Butlerian Jihad (~10,000 CE) (although they don't use those exact names), then discuss the formation of the Bene Gesserit, Spacing Guild, CHOAM, and the Landsraad. All of this Prologue material is wasted on anyone who has read the book, although it may be helpful to other viewers who know nothing of the story. I found this prologue to be somewhat jarring; it didn't feel, look, or sound right. The voice-over narration for the Prologue was done by a male actor who I don't think was part of the original cast. I would have had a better opinion of the prologue if the narration had been done by Virginia Madsen, speaking as Princess Irulan. That would at least have been consistant with the opening monologue of the Theatrical release, and with the chapter openings in the Novel, many of which are taken from the various histories written by Irulan. NOTE: The Prologue has a continuity error: The narrator states the year as 10,192, whereas Irulan's opening monologue in the Theatrical version states that it is 10,191 (which is consistant with the dating of Yueh's death at the opening of Chapter 5 in the novel).The remaining 30 minutes of extra material in the Extended edition is additional film footage, some of which consists of brief extensions to scenes that are also in the Theatrical version, and other clips which were "deleted scenes", and therefore will be new to viewers who have only seen the Theatrical version. Much of the new material is concentrated in the first half of the film, which may give an "unbalanced" feeling to the Extended edition for some viewers. The actor who did the narration for the Prologue also does some voice-over during other scenes in the movie, this supposedly was done to "explain" the story and make it easier for viewers who had not read the novel to understand and place in context what was going on. I found this extra narration to be distracting, and wish it could be turned off, or at least that it had been done by Virginia Madsen (as Irulan).The image and sound quality of this DVD is okay. It actually looks better than the BluRay of the Theatrical release in some respects, probably because the higher resolution of the BluRay emphasizes the flaws, color fading, and other problems in the film-to-digital transfer (see above).Is this DVD worth the price? That depends on a couple of factors. If you don't already own any version of Dune, this DVD is double-sided: it will give you BOTH the Theatrical and Extended versions on the one disc, plus several videos of Bonus material.  If you can find a used one in good condition for under $15, it's definitely worth it. However, if you already own the Theatrical version, either on a DVD or BluRay, then it's a harder choice. That 10 minute Prologue is practically worthless to anyone who already knows the story, so you are really only getting 30 minutes of extra movie footage. The Amazon price for this Extended Edition DVD is $46 (new), which is outrageous considering the BluRay of the Theatrical version is only $11. If you can find a Used copy for under $15, including shipping, it may be worth it if you are a dedicated Dune fan and just HAVE to have that 30 minutes of extra movie footage. I paid $15, including S&H, and my copy was in near-new condition, so I feel like I got my money's worth.One question that occasionally comes up is the rumored 4 hour version of Dune. Rafaella de Laurentiis talks about this in an interview on one of the bonus videos. Apparently the sum total of the principal photography that was completed includes a bit more than 4 hours of film footage. But just because that footage exists, doesn't mean that anyone will ever bundle it all together into a "super-extended" version of the movie, at least Ms. de Laurentiis doesn't think it will ever happen. So, go make some popcorn and enjoy the movie as it exists. And again, to really get the full appreciation of this film, you really should read the novel if you haven't already.

This is a typical cat brush - the models with the backward facing wire bristles all work pretty much the same way. I like the plastic handle, which feels like it has a light rubberized coating to help you grip it. The rounded edges make it a little safer to use on a squirmy cat than the rectangular models with pointed corners on the brush head.  My cat likes being brushed with this brush, and it does a good job of gathering up the loose hair.  Clearing the brush of the hair is easy: just start lifting the wad of hair along the back edge of the brush and with a combined lifting/pulling motion, the whole wad of hair will pull off. Recommended for short hair cats.  I don't have a long-hair breed cat to try the brush on, but maybe another reviewer does.

The bristles on the brush are just what I hoped for: neither too stiff or not stiff enough. If the handle was 6" longer it would be perfect. I shopped around for an all-plastic bath brush with a longer handle but could not find anything, so this model was a compromise. I suppose I could use a piece of PVC pipe to extend the handle.  For the price it's okay.  The ridges on the handle help you keep a grip on it when your hands are soapy.

It seems like there are at least a million choices in tablet computers nowadays, so it's becoming very difficult to figure out which are the best values.  First off, you have to figure out what features and functions you want the tablet to have, then prioritize your list. AFAIK, all tablets can play music and video clips, and they all have WiFi so that you can browse the Internet and do email, and there are more apps than you can even comprehend. All tablets can serve as e-book readers, although some are optimized for this function, like the Kindle. There are even several choices in operating systems: various flavors of Android OS, Apple's IOS, Windows Mobile, and probably others. I am most familiar with Android v2 (Gingerbread), having owned a 4" Samsung Galaxy MP3 player for several years, that came with this OS (I still have it and it still works fine, but the screen is too small for comfortable ebook reading, which is why I decided to upgrade to a tablet). I am happy enough with Android, and the available apps on Google Play Store, do I decided to narrow my shopping list to Android tablets.I looked at all of the available devices on Amazon, which range in price from $100 to $600, and screen size from 7" to 10". The very cheapest ones turned out to be no-name Chinese knockoffs of questionable quality and stability, with lots of problems reported by owners, so I eliminated those from consideration. Likewise, I decided to limit my budget to $350, so that cut off the big 10" models with ultra-high-resolution screens. I also noticed that the 10" models were double the weight of the 7" and 8" models, and I wanted something that would be comfortable to hold for extended periods of reading.Next, I started researching models for which user-replaceable batteries are available, a feature that's important to me, as I hate dumping electronic gadgets in the trash just because the battery is worn out and can't be easily replaced.  This search quickly narrowed the choices down: I found only a couple of manufacturers for which replacement batteries are available. One of these is Samsung, and the others were all brands that I had already eliminated from consideration for other reasons. I was disappointed to not find a battery replacement for the ASUS MeMo Pad seies; these were high on my list, due to having a much higher screen resolution at the same price point as most other brands, including the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3.After extended research, I finally had narrowed the choices down to one of the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 models, and based on weight, size, memory, and price, the 8" model for $269 looked like it was the best value for me. I purchased the tablet and a MoKo case [http://www.amazon.com/MoKo-Samsung-Galaxy-Tab-Case/dp/B00CSMYBFS/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1395853862&sr=8-5&keywords=samsung+galaxy+tab+3+8%22+case], and so far after a couple of months I am very happy with the purchase.This tablet has Android v4.2 Jelly Bean as the operating system, which is similar to the older v2 Gingerbread on my MP3 player, except for one major - and extremely annoying - difference: Mass Storage Mode has been removed, and I have not found ANY way to re-enable it or add it back in as an app. Mass Storage Mode allows you to plug the Android device into your desktop or laptop PC with a USB cable, and easily transfer files back and forth between the PC and the device's internal or MicroSD card storage in Windows Explorer. Mass Storage Mode basically turns your device into an "SD Card Reader", just like you might use to download images from your digital camera's SD card. You can use various file management tools, like WinMerge, in Mass Storage Mode to compare (synchronize) files on the PC's hard disk to files on the Android device.Well, when I first plugged this tablet into my desktop machine, which runs XP-32/SP3, the only access I could get was "digital camera mode", which limits you to downloading JPEG photos, and only from the DCIM folder on the tablet. After many hours of research on the Internet, and downloading several supposed "fixes" for the problem (most of which did not work, including Samsung KIES, surprisingly), I finally found the following solution, that enables the MTP Protocol on Windows XP: 1. Install Windows Media Player Version 11. 2. Install Microsoft User Mode Driver Framework for XP. These two packages finally got MTP mode working on my PC, so I could see the files and folders on the tablet, but MTP is basically crippled from the get-go. You can not use file management tools like WinMerge with it, so it's not really a substitute for Mass Storage Mode.  All of the above problems I experienced are supposedly taken care of in Windows 7 and 8 with built-in MTP drivers, but I have no PC running either of those OS's to test this tablet on. And MTP is still a lousy downgrade from Mass Storage Mode.So, other than the unexpected lack of Mass Storage Mode in Android Jelly Bean, what else do I have to say about the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8"?  Overall, I like it! So far, I have two primary uses for it: 1. As an ebook reader, and 2. as a GPS navigator in my car. I have also used it as an alarm clock, as an MP3 player, as an Internet browser and email tool, as a game platform for playing chess, Angry Birds, and Freecell Solitaire, as a remote controller with a Canon 6D camera, and as a night-sky Astronomy tool with the SkEYE App (this app is really cool, if you live somewhere where it's dark enough to really see the night sky).1. As an ebook reader: the 1280x800 screen is adequate. Obviously, it won't be quite as sharp as the 1920x1200 screen on the ASUS MeMo Pad tablet, but it's not bad. The color rendition for looking at photos or videos is okay, if not brilliant, and the widely adjustable screen brightness can handle almost any environment except full outdoor sunlight. There's no way to make the screen contrast high enough to use this tablet as an e-reader outdoors in full sunlight. In any less challenging conditions, the screen is good. I use the built-in Adobe Reader with my PDF format ebooks, and re-flow the text. The tablet can also read TXT ebooks with the built-in Polaris Office app.2. As a GPS Navigator, this 8" tablet can give some serious competition to a Garmin Nuvi. It is GLONASS enabled, which gives it better capability to maintain position lock in urban areas where you might be surrounded by high buildings, or in deep canyons (think Utah, Arizona, or any mountainous region). I use the MapFactor Navigator app with free Open Street Maps, and it works well (some stability problems, and occasionally obviously wrong turn directions, but this is a problem with the software and the map, and is not the Tablet's fault).  There are several other car navigation and GPS apps on Google Play, I just happen to like this one because the process of downloading and installing bulk map updates is easy and automatic. The big 8" screen on the Samsung Tablet makes it VERY nice as a car navigator, compared to the much smaller screen on most cell phones, Nuvi, and TomTom type devices.Battery life for non-processor intensive tasks, like looking at still photos or reading ebooks, seems to be at least 8 hours.  High-power apps like playing videos, or any app that needs the GPS chipset or the WiFi or Blue Tooth radios, will run the battery down much faster. Browsing the Internet - which means using WiFi, obviously - will use up the battery in about 3~4 hours, same for using any GPS app, so be sure to turn off the WiFi, Blue Tooth, and GPS when not actually needed.  The included charger will pump up an almost dead battery to 100% in about 4 hours, and a 50% battery in less than 2 hours, assuming the device is powered off. When actively running as a GPS Navigator, the power draw appears to be as much as 2 amps, maybe even a little more, as my ANKER USB 12 volt, 1.5 amp car charger can't quite keep up, and the tablet battery very slowly goes down, rather than charging back up, until I shut down the GPS app.Speakers: As a music player, the built in speakers on this tablet are better than the ones on my old Samsung MP3 player, but not nearly as good as the speakers on some IPad tablets. You get what you pay for, and to be able to sell this talet for only $269, Samsung obviously had to save costs somewhere, and the barely-adequate speakers are one of the cost-savers, I guess. If you really want to listen to music or watch videos, you will have to plug in an external speaker or headphones.  The speakers are good enough, and actually quite clear, for the voice prompting of a GPS Navigation app, or whatever sound you set up for the Alarm clock app, they're just not quite good enough for real music listening.Controls: The power on/off button on my copy of the tablet is actually hard to work. I usually have to press it with the edge of a coin, or something else hard and small. Maybe this is a deliberate design, so that it's not easy to power the device on or off with an accidental button press when you didn't intend to? The volume control and the "home" button are both easy and don't require excessive force.Built-in apps and widgets: There are a bunch of these, only a few of which I think I will ever use. The Polaris Office, Adobe Reader, Alarm Clock,  Memo Pad, Email, Google Play Store, Music Player, SPlanner (a calendar app), and the Camera app are all ones I've used. For a general purpose Internet browser, I installed Firefox, and for a calculator, I installed Droid48, an HP-48 Emulator. I also installed The Hacker's Keyboard, which is VERY nice, and gives you most of the functionality of a the QWERTY keyboard that you use with your regular computer, including arrow keys, and a Delete key in addition to the Backspace key. The only downside of this keyboard is that it's a little larger than the default Samsung keyboard, so it takes up more screen space, leaving you less to see what you are typing.Size, weight, and Form Factor: The Samsung 8" weighs in at around 0.8 lb, about half the weight of the 10" ASUS MemoPad and  Samsung tablets. It is too large to fit in a shirt pocket, but might fit in the side or back pockets of some blue jeans. It should easily fit in most any purse, fanny pack, backpack, briefcase, or coat pocket.Screen touch: The screen feels nice and smooth, like gorilla glass (I'm not sure if it actually is gorilla glass or not), The usual swiping, tapping and pinching motions all work as you would expect - with bare fingers, but not wearing gloves or mittens - and the screen is easy to clean with a damp cloth.Cameras: The 5mp rear camera is okay, for if you ever really need to take a snapshot and don't have a real camera available, but there is no flash so it only works in daylight, or brightly lit indoor areas. The lens can focus on subjects as close as a 3", so it's got some macro capability, and there is a 4x zoom function. I am not sure if this is an Optical or Digital zoom. Unfortunately, this camera app appears to be hard-coded to use a very heavy level of JPEG compression, and I have not been able to find a setting to change it. The files average 560kB, whereas 5 megapixel photos with "light" JPEG compression should be around 4 mB. This heavy level of compression means that photos with large areas of clear color, like sky, will show a lot of JPEG compression artifacts. The front facing 1 mp camera is very low quality.SUMMARY: A nice general purpose Android tablet computer with a medium-size screen. A good choice for someone who wants maximum functionality, but doesn't want the extra weight, higher price, and larger physical size of a 10" model.UPDATE JULY 29, 2014: If your Galaxy Tab 3 8.0 came with Android v4.2.2 (Jelly Bean), I recommend that you stay on this version and do NOT accept the automatic update to Android v 4.4.2 (KitKat) that Samsung is pushing out.  KITKAT WILL CAUSE YOU MANY PROBLEMS, especially with Apps that store data on the external SD card.  Google made a significant change in KitKat that imposes a new layer of permissions on how Apps are allowed to access storage. For me, the worst effect was that as soon as I rebooted after installing KitKat, all of my GPS and Navigation apps stopped working, as they all store their maps off-line on the external SD card. I had to uninstall three apps, than download and re-install them, then download and re-install several gigabytes of map tiles. A MAJOR irritation that left me with no functional Navigation software for several days.  As far as I can tell, KitKat offers no noticeable improvements in the tablet's user interface, so from the User's point of view, it offers no benefit and will actually cause problems for you. Stay away - once you install Kit Kat, EVERYTHING on your external SD card is at risk: music, videos, documents, game stats, maps, etc. It's not that KitKat will actually erase these files, but the extra layer of "permissions" that it imposes on the external SD card will effectively render these files invisible to the apps they are associated with; to fix the problem, you will probably have to re-install the app from scratch, and may have to re-load it's data files from backup to reconstitute the association. Maybe not with music and photos, but that's what I had to do to get my Navigation apps working again.UPDATE August 5, 2014.  After months of frustration at not having Mass Storage Mode, I finally couldn't stand the thought of doing any more file transfers with MTP, and decided to Root the tablet and try out a Custom ROM that promised to give me Mass Storage Mode.  The first step, gaining Root access, was relatively simple: I had to install ROM Manager, SuperSU, TWRP Recovery, and a Root exploit I downloaded from the XDA Developers website. WARNING: The Root Exploit and TWRP packages have to be versions compiled specifically for your exact model device! Attempting to install any other version could "brick" your device.  So far, so good. After a little stumbling around and a couple of false starts, the installs were done, TWRP, SuperSU, and ROM Manager were running, and the Root Checker app said I had full Root access. So the next step was to download CyanogenMod.  Uh,Oh! This Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8.0 (model SM-T310) Tablet isn't directly supported by the "official" CyanogenMod!  But I found a link to "unofficial" builds of CyanogenMod, done by volunteers for less popular devices. After a couple of hours of searching, I had located 4 different Custom ROM's that claimed to be for the Samsung SM-T310 8" tablet. Also, at this point, I made a TWRP Full backup of the device. And I will be eternally grateful that I did, because NONE of the four Custom ROMS that I had downloaded would boot the tablet: all four caused unbreakable boot loops. After spending an entire weekend in ever increasing desperation, figuring that I had "bricked" my $279 tablet, I managed to revert the tablet back to the previous (stock Samsung) operating system from TWRP Restore. Of course I lost all the apps and had to re-install them, but my personal data was all safe on the external SD card so I didn't lose any of that.  Lessons learned: (1) Tablet computers have a lot of proprietary hardware in them unique to each brand - you MUST be sure that the Custom ROM you are installing was created and tested by Android-savvy techs, who actually know what they are doing, specifically for your model. (2) If your device isn't officially supported by CyanogenMod, it might be for a very good reason: that the Gurus at CyanogenMod simply could not find or create a Kernal that would work with your hardware. (3) Boot Loops are VERY common in tablets, especially Sumsung models, and I was very fortunate to have been able to recover from mine - many owners have irreparably bricked Samsung tablets while trying out Custom ROM's and Recovery programs, and had to junk them.  (4) After going through all of the above, I STILL don't have Mass Storage mode, and might never get it unless someone comes up with a build of CyanogenMod specifically for my tablet.UPDATE: July 16, 2015.  The Tablet has continued to function perfectly. I use it several hours every week, mostly as an e-book reader, car navigation device, and for general note-taking and listening to music. The battery is holding up well, and I expect to get at least a couple more years of service out of it. I also found a work-around (actually a Registry setting) that over-rides the stupid block that Google put on Android v4.4.2 that restricts  you from directly editing files on the external SD card. The URL for this fix is at: [http://trendblog.net/fix-kitkat-sd-card-write-restriction/]. NOTE: You have to have Root access to your tablet to make this Registry change.Also, after nearly a year of waiting to see if an official build of CyanogenMod would come out for this tablet, it appears that there will be none. I have been anxiously awaiting this, as CyanogenMod is supposed to re-enable Mass Storage Mode, which Google and Samsung have removed from the "official" versions of Android after Gingerbread. I tried one of the "unofficial" CyanogenMod builds and it put the tablet into an infinite boot-loop, nearly bricking it. Thankfully I had made a TWRP backup of the original Samsung operating system, so I was able to break the boot loop, but CyanogenMod appears to be a no-go, at least for the time being.UPDATE: November 20, 2015. I think the battery is starting to wear out and lose charge capacity. It still powers the tablet for several hours when just reading an E-book, but if the WiFi and/or GPS services are switched on, the battery will drop from 100% to 30% in less than two hours, which indicates that the battery has lost maybe half it's charge capacity from when it was new. Other than that, everything else is still working well. At one point I was thinking of replacing the battery, but Samsung has a couple of newer 8" tablets with WXGA screens (2560 x 1600 pixels) that only cost $320 and have much better performance thanks to a quad-core processor, and that have "official" builds of CyanogenMod available.

This small-footprint laser printer is amazingly fast. Warm up time is a few seconds, so it's a little slower "out of the gate" than an inkjet, but once it starts printing, it's much faster than most inkjets. Of course, this is a monochrome printer, so it's most useful for printing text documents (it might also be able to print greyscale graphics and photos, although I have not tested it that way for image quality). It comes with a "starter" toner cartridge, so I don't expect to get more than maybe 500 prints before it needs a replacement cartridge, but reconditioned Canon 125 cartridges aren't very expensive, around $25 for a 2-pack.Set up is pretty easy, but involves several steps: When you unpack the machine, there is a large instruction sheet with graphics showing what to do: all of the orange plastic thingys inside the machine are shipping restraints that protect the mechanism from vibration and impact, and also seal the toner powder in the cartridge from leaking - all of these orange widgets need to be removed. There are at least 6 of these, be sure to follow the instruction sheet carefully and make sure you have removed all of them before powering the machine up.This printer does not come with a USB cable, so be sure you have one already, or purchase one-they are not expensive. This is the standard USB printer cable, with the little square connector on the printer end, and the usual flat USB-A connector on the computer end. Also, when you are first unpacking the machine, you will be removing the toner cartridge in order to pull off the toner sealing tape: pay close attention to how the toner cartridge is oriented so you can install it back the way it's supposed to go.The printer comes with a CD of Windows drivers which need to be installed, and installation - in Windows XP - was easy and intuitive. Other reviewers have reported that drivers for the Macintosh OS are NOT included on the CD, and have to be downloaded from Canon's website. Some Mac owners have reported difficulties with installing the Mac version of the drivers; check other reviews for detailed instructions.I was pleased to see that the Windows drivers are quite small, in terms of how much "footprint" they take up on your computer. There is no bloated software program on the CD, like some inkjet printers come with, other than the drivers, so this printer would be a good choice for use with a laptop that has a small hard drive.Main reasons to buy a laser printer instead of an inkjet:1. If you are a person who only makes a few prints per month, a laser printer is a much better choice than an inkjet. The toner powder in a laser printer will not dry out and clog like the liquid ink in an inkjet printer that is only used occasionally. Toner may "cake" after a long period of disuse, or in very humid environments; if your prints start looking streaky or there are gaps, try removing the toner cartridge and shaking it GENTLY to fluff up and redistribute the toner powder. WARNING: Toner may leak when you do this, and it's messy to clean up, so do this outdoors somewhere, or over a sink or trash can, where any leakage won't be an issue.2. Toner cartridges cost about 1/3 as much per page printed as black ink for an inkjet, and that's assuming you manage to actually use up all of the ink before it dries out and clogs, something I have never managed to do, since I rarely print more than 2 or 3 pages per month.3. If you are printing primarily text documents, then a laser is definitely a better choice. When you do want to print photos, send them to a place like Walmart or Costco - their photo printing services are not very expensive, and you will get MUCH better quality images, on really nice, heavy photo paper, than you can get from a small home-use inkjet. Also, the prints you get from a photo store will last longer since the ink is archival quality and the colors won't shift or fade, at least not as fast as ink from a home printer.NOTE: because laser printers use an electrically heated fuser to "melt" the toner powder onto the page, this printer will use more electricity than an inkjet, but considering how much more you pay for inkjet cartridges, I believe that the laser printer is still less expensive per page. Just be sure to power it off when not in use.Printing quality: Looks pretty good, at least good enough for home use. I think the dots-per-inch specification is not quite as high on this machine as what you get with big Office laser printers, but this little Canon costs thousands of dollars less, so what do you expect? I printed some income tax forms yesterday that had lots of very small 6-point type font, and it was perfectly readable, although not quite as smooth around the curved characters as the same forms printed by the government on a color offset press.NOTES ON TONER REFILLING: I found a webpage with a very detailed, very high quality HD video showing step-by-step instructions and a demonstration of how to recondition, clean, and refill the Canon 125 toner cartridge used by this printer. If you intend to purchase toner refill kits and refill the cartridge yourself, this video is a must-see. The URL is: [...]. Also, the Canon 125 toner cartridge uses one of those memory chips that count pages or toner level, so be sure the refill kit you buy includes a new chip.WARNING: The toner cartridge in the video was empty and clean, which yours will not be when you go to refill it. Toner powder is EXTREMELY MESSY, and it will get all over everything. Cover your work surface with newspaper or something to catch spillage and do NOT tilt or tip the cartridge like the technician does in the video. He was doing that so the camera could focus on everything, but if you tilt the cartridge with toner in it after the seals and wipers have been removed, it will spill!Also, please keep in mind that the light-sensitive drum in the toner cartridge, as well as the rollers, wiper blades, gears, and bearings, are all subject to mechanical wear and tear in normal useage, and you should not expect to be able to keep refilling a toner cartridge indefinitely-at some point, these parts will wear out and fail, or the drum will get scratched (which will result in big black streaks on every print), at which point the cartridge is done for. However, the low purchase price for the printer and the relatively inexpensive toner cartridges still make this little machine a pretty good value for a home or small business user. If any Amazon vendor is still selling this machine for less than $60 (I paid $55 for mine), I don't see how you could go wrong. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

This small-footprint laser printer is amazingly fast. Warm up time is a few seconds, so it's a little slower "out of the gate" than an inkjet, but once it starts printing, it's much faster than most inkjets. Of course, this is a monochrome printer, so it's most useful for printing text documents (it might also be able to print greyscale graphics and photos, although I have not tested it that way for image quality). It comes with a "starter" toner cartridge, so I don't expect to get more than maybe 500 prints before it needs a replacement cartridge, but reconditioned Canon 125 cartridges aren't very expensive, around $25 for a 2-pack.Set up is pretty easy, but involves several steps: When you unpack the machine, there is a large instruction sheet with graphics showing what to do: all of the orange plastic thingys inside the machine are shipping restraints that protect the mechanism from vibration and impact, and also seal the toner powder in the cartridge from leaking - all of these orange widgets need to be removed. There are at least 6 of these, be sure to follow the instruction sheet carefully and make sure you have removed all of them before powering the machine up.This printer does not come with a USB cable, so be sure you have one already, or purchase one-they are not expensive. This is the standard USB printer cable, with the little square connector on the printer end, and the usual flat USB-A connector on the computer end. Also, when you are first unpacking the machine, you will be removing the toner cartridge in order to pull off the toner sealing tape: pay close attention to how the toner cartridge is oriented so you can install it back the way it's supposed to go.The printer comes with a CD of drivers which need to be installed. I was pleased to see that these drivers are quite small, in terms of how much "footprint" they take up on your computer. There is no bloated software program on the CD, like some inkjet printers come with, other than the drivers, so this printer would be a good choice for use with a laptop that has a small hard drive.Main reasons to buy a laser printer instead of an inkjet:1. If you are a person who only makes a few prints per month, a laser printer is a much better choice than an inkjet. The toner powder in a laser printer will not dry out and clog like the liquid ink in an inkjet printer that is only used occasionally.2. Toner cartridges cost about 1/3 as much per page printed as black ink for an inkjet, and that's assuming you manage to actually use up all of the ink before it dries out and clogs, something I have never managed to do, since I rarely print more than 2 or 3 pages per month.3. If you are printing primarily text documents, then a laser is definitely a better choice.  When you do want to print photos, send them to a place like Walmart or Costco - their photo printing services are not very expensive, and you will get MUCH better quality images, on really nice, heavy photo paper, than you can get from a small home-use inkjet. Also, the prints you get from a photo store will last longer since the ink is archival quality and the colors won't shift or fade, at least not as fast as ink from a home printer.NOTE: because laser printers use an electrically heated fuser to "melt" the toner powder onto the page, this printer will use more electricity than an inkjet, but considering how much more you pay for inkjet cartridges, I believe that the laser printer is still less expensive per page.  Just be sure to power it off when not in use.Printing quality: Looks pretty good, at least good enough for home use. I think the dots-per-inch specification is not as high on this machine as what you get with big Office printers, but this little Canon costs thousands of dollars less, so what do you expect?  I printed some income tax forms yesterday that had lots of very small 6-point type font, and it was perfectly readable, although not quite as smooth around the curved characters as the same forms printed by the government on a color offset press.If any Amazon vendor is still selling this machine for less than $60 (I paid $55 for mine), I don't see how you could go wrong. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

I won't wade into the war currently being waged between Tolkien "purists" and Peter Jackson loyalists over the changes Jackson made to Bilbo's story as told in this film adaptation. At least not very deeply. Suffice it to say that these changes are many, and some of them are HUGE departures from the original story that were hard for me to swallow the first time I saw this movie in a cinema.  However, I have to say that much of the extra footage in this Extended edition is crucial, and I wish it had been included in the theatrical version. If you are wondering if the $10 extra for this Extended edition is worth it, I would answer that as an unqualified "yes". If you have never seen this film, and your purchase of this BluRay will be your first viewing of it, let me just say that Martin Freeman does a very good job of portraying a younger Bilbo Baggins; he doesn't look like Ian Holm did as Bilbo in LOTR, but I think he projects the spirit and attitudes of Tolkien's Bilbo very nicely. If you can accept that this film was made to: 1. make oodles of money for the producers, and 2. appeal to and entertain as wide an audience as possible, and if you keep it in mind that 80 years have passed since J.R.R Tolkiien wrote the original story, hopefully you can keep an open mind about Peter Jackson's handling of the plot lines and story and just enjoy it as an entertainment.You might want to consider that the additions in this film flesh out some characters, like Radagast and Saruman, that were barely mentioned in Tolkien's novel of The Hobbit, and that other changes add links to tie The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings together more seamlessly. Whether or not these changes were TOO drastic is up to you to judge, personally, I appreciate the extra element of pure storytelling pleasure I got from most of Jackson's additions.I also want to note that Ian McKellan (Gandalf), Cate Blanchett (Galadriel), Hugo Weaving (Elrond), Andy Serkis (Smeagol/Gollum), and Christopher Lee (Saruman),  all reprise their LOTR characters wonderfully, and the fact that this movie actually takes you inside the White Council (which the novel just barely mentions), is great, and I'm glad that Peter Jackson provided time for it in the screenplay. Without the White Council scene, Cate Blanchett and Christopher Lee would not have had parts in this film, and their characters are fun to watch.  So throw some popcorn in the microwave and get settled in your most comfortable chair - this is a long movie (2 hours 50 minutes) and you won't want to pause it, at least not on the first viewing. Enjoy!

This MoKo case for the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 and Note series tablets is a bare-bones folding cover. It is made from PVC embossed in a faux-leather pattern, and is available in lots of colors.  Structurally, the rim of the MoKo case is a hard plastic molding into which you snap corners of the tablet. The fit is very precise and the tablet is held securely enough that you should not have to worry about it popping out and falling to the floor. The "lid" of the cover is held closed by a couple of small magnets. The automatic sleep/wake function works exactly as desribed: the screen shuts off as you close the cover, and wakes up to the lock screen when you open it again. I wonder how this is accomplished? Maybe the front camera "sees" the lid open and close?The inside of the lid is coated with some kind of fuzzy material that I suppose was intended to simulate micro-fiber cloth and protect the screen against scratches; I assume this is the same material as the flocking on an air mattress, since PVC is what both products are made of.  The fit and finish of the MoKo case is excellent: all the connection ports have cut-outs that are very accurately sized and positioned, and there is even a small opening for the miniscule microphone hole that the Tab 3 has.I have a couple of reservations about this product's long-term durability and service life:1. As far as I can tell, the "hinges" that allow you to fold the lid into a makeshift support stand for the tablet, as shown in the Amazon product photo, are made of PVC (polyvinyl chloride), same as the case cover, and my experience with this material, in applications where it is required to flex, is that it tears along the crease line after not very many cycles of folding and bending. With this in mind, I suggest that you avoid frequent folding the MoKo cover into the stand configuration, at least until the durability of the hinges can be proven some way.2. There isn't any actual padding or shock-absorbing material in the areas of the case that are the most critical to protect the computer from impact damage; i.e. the corners and the screen. This product is not an Otterbox case by any stretch of the imagination, and if you buy one, I wouldn't go around assuming that it will provide much more than a minimal level of drop and impact protection for your tablet. It also has no water resistance at all, being completely open around the edges, so you still have to put your tablet in a waterproof bag or box if you have to carry it outdoors in wet weather.  I know from experience that digital devices like cell phones can go crazy if even a tiny bit of rain water gets into the headphone jack or USB port.Ergonomics: I was hoping that this cover would make it a little more comfortable to hold the tablet for reading, but unfortunately, in some ways the cover is actually more uncomfortable than trying to keep a grip on Samsung's famously slippery plastic with the tablet "naked". The trouble is that the top cover isn't detachable, so it's always going to be there, flopping around loose and upsetting the "balance" of the tablet while you are holding it, unless you bend it 180 and fold it against the bottom cover.  And if you recall from my comment in the last paragraph, I don't think the hinges will last very long if you bend them a lot.I am thinking that I might try attaching a couple of elastic strips across the back of the case to slip my hands through for when I want to hold the tablet for reading. These will let me relax my fingers so I don't have to "grip" the tablet very hard. I used a Trimble TSC2 Data Collector for several years that had a heavy duty elastic strap across the hand grip that made it a lot easier to hold the device, especially when you might not have a convenient place around the job site to set it down, and end up with it in your hand for three or four hours at a time. With that strap, you could extend your fingers at any time to work out cramps and the data collector wouldn't fall.For the time being, I am giving this product only three stars, because my impression of it is that it isn't much better than average in build quality, and may not even be worth the $15 I paid.  If it lasts a full year without the hinges cracking, I will upgrade my rating to four stars.SUMMARY: A low price cover - IMO it is misleading to call this product a "case" - that gives minimal screen protection for a Samsung Galaxy tablet, but no water resistance for inclement weather, no storage pockets for extra MicroSD cards, only a little drop/impact protection for either the screen or the corners, and only a little ergonomic improvement for hand holding your tablet. It's only a little less slippery than the bare Samsung plastic, and there's nothing really for your fingers to grab on to. I guess it's better than nothing, and is possibly worth the $15 retail price, but it falls far short of an Otterbox case for protecting a delicate electronic device that costs $300~$600. The ability to fold it into stand for the tablet, and the automatic wake/sleep function both work as advertised, but I have a feeling that frequently folding the hinges in the top lid will cause it to fail fairly quickly.UPDATE: March 25, 2014.  I have upgraded my rating from 3 stars to 4 stars, something I rarely do. The MoKo case has turned out to be more durable than I thought it would be, with no signs of cracking or failure at the folding joints after 6 weeks of use, and it does make the tablet much easier to hold. I especially like the auto-sleep function, which is a feature one would not get with a gel-skin.UPDATE: July 15, 2015. I have upgraded my rating to the full 5 stars. This MoKo Case has surpassed my expectations in every way. It is still in perfect condition, despite my almost daily use of the tablet, with so signs of cracking at the folding hinges. I would buy another one if and when I buy a newer Samsung tablet.

These ice cube trays are somewhat larger than the blue Sterilte ones that are also sold on Amazon and retail stores like WalMart, so you get maybe 10~15% more ice per freeze cycle. The ice cubes pop right out with a light twist of the tray, and there is less sticking and need to pound the tray on your kitchen counter, than with the blue Sterilite trays, which I also own a few of.  They seem durable and since you don't have to twist the tray very hard to pop the cubes out, they should last quite a long time before failure.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

This cable was purchased to allow a Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 to access files on USB thumb drives, and it works perfectly.  My Galaxy Tab is running Android Jelly Bean 4.2, and it connected immediately to the 4 gb Kingston thumb drive that I plugged into it. I was able to see the drive and all folder/files content in the built-in "My Files" App on the tablet, with no special tweaks or drivers at all.  I have not yet tried it with an external HDD, as I don't have one formatted as FAT-32 (Android does not support NTFS drives), but I would assume it would work. The cable end connectors fit just right: not too loose or too tight, so the quality appears to be at least average. RECOMMENDED for anyone owning an Android tablet who wants to be able to use it with USB storage devices.

As a long-time author in both the traditional and indie fields, I've been watching the publishing landscape like a hawk. It's clear that the old models are no longer feasible for most authors (including me) but what is the new model that will create lasting and ongoing income? Jim Kukral's book delves into that very question. Fortunately, he has some answers.Traditionally, the ability for an author to get a book into the hands of readers has been controlled by industry gatekeepers (traditional publishing companies). Today, digital publishing has smashed that barrier. However, the question Jim's book raises is:  Can an author succeed by first going directly to her true fans?  This theory was tested on this book's release in a "go direct" campaign, before moving onto the Amazon platform. (I purchased the book as a Go Direct buyer) The key, as you might suspect, depends on how "true" your true fans really are.I love the way Jim's thinking about the future of publishing and about how a very old system of art patronage is being brought into today's publishing world. This book has really forced me to think outside the box and explore for myself ways to leverage the people who are my true fans.If you write - whether you ever go direct or not - take the time to read this book. I'm sure you'll come away with as many ideas as I did.

Although I've written many books, I'm always looking for new ways to increase my productivity. Tim gave me several of those in this book. Because I'm not a fan of outsourcing, I felt that I needed to discover a better work flow as I write several books on the craft of writing, which can take quite a bit of time. I thought Tim's approach was ingenious, one I hadn't previously considered.  Kudos for doing an outstanding job!.

There are many reasons I love this book but I want to concentrate on two of them:1.  I'm a non-fiction author who has been struggling with writing fiction. This book has helped immensely because it is filled with examples of what's right and what's wrong in a way that other books on the craft do not.2.  I'm terrible at editing my own work. That said, I've learned so much from this book about better use of adjectives, improving dialogue, and revising the scenes that just don't flow.I think this is the first book on the craft of fiction I've read that's written by someone who knows not only the writing side by the editing side. This is an invaluable tool for me and one of the best in my arsenal.

If you like conspiracy theories, 007, scifi, and strong female leads you'll definitely enjoy this first novel by Roger Woodbury. Not being a novelist myself (I stick to non-fiction), I'm in awe of those who tackle the world of fiction and this is no exception. There aren't enough books out there with great female leads (read: strong, bold, unpredictable), which made this story doubly interesting.

Loved this book. I'm working on a ghostwriting project involving Greece so this guidebook was truly helpful. It gave me a thumbnail of a lot of places, events and beliefs that was incredibly useful in my work.

This was my first read of one of J.F. Penn's fiction books and I can't wait to read more. Her ability to seamlessly blend history and action is extraordinary. Add to that her skill at transporting the reader to a distant time and place and you have a wonderful journey awaiting you.

I had previously purchased Wendy Owen's book on arthritis so was interested to read this one about fibromyalgia. Although it's not something I suffer from, my oldest friend does - and has for years. I know that one of my friend's most frustrating issues was in simply trying to get a diagnosis, as many of her health care providers didn't really think fibromyalgia was a "real" disease. I was hoping that by reading this book I could at least offer up some alternative suggestions.Fortunately, this book had several.I think the two most important things I learned was how debilitating fibromyalgia can be in terms of sleep. I know my friend complains about never getting good sleep because pain wakes her up.I loved the idea of the sleep diary because I do think it will help identify patterns like how sleep is impacted by stress or certain foods or napping, etc. I also think the chapter on a fibromyalgia diet was excellent, along with the alternative supplements that can benefit people who suffer from this disease.Just like the author's book on arthritis, this one is well-researched and well-written.

I have the iPhone 5S and am really cautious about using non-Apple products. But after reading all of the many reviews of this cable, I purchased it to use in my office, keeping the native cable at home. The AYL Apple Certified MFI Lightning to USB Cable is incredibly sturdy - far more than the original cable that came with my phone. In addition, it charges perfectly - I've never had any kind of charging glitch at all.My favorite feature is the length (6 feet).  I have no idea why Apple makes their cables so short - it's really a pain when I want to keep my phone on my desk and plug into my computer's USB port.  The original cable is so short I have to take the phone off my desk and put it down on top of the drive.  Now, with this AYL cable, I no longer have to contend with that problem.

Whenever I"m traveling to a new place I always try to pick up an insider's guide as I know I'll get the best view of a city from someone who knows it well. That's one of the reasons I really l liked The Montreal Plateau - it gave me the opportunity to see the city through the eyes of a local. Like the author, I always go looking for a great cup of coffee when in a new city, and the books description of Le Fouvrac put it at the top of my go-to list.It was also so cool to read about Le Plateau's bike-friendly and walk-friendly attitudes. Just wish more places within large cities were more like this.The author begins by mapping out the boundaries of Le Plateau as it sits within Montreal, then gives readers an overview of the language, culture and spirit of the area. Clearly more French than English, this neighborhood retains a charm that makes it (as the author says) more an experience than a venue.To be honest, prior to reading this book I hadn't really thought about going to Montreal, but Le Plateau is now enticing me to go north!

I've been interested in meditation for years - and in fact used to meditate daily. Then, like most good habits, it went by the wayside. I'm not trying to get back into the groove and meditate daily. That's because I know from experience how valuable meditation is for me.I found the chapter on External Distractions especially helpful as I'm one of those "ooh, look at the butterfly" people. It takes almost nothing to pull my mind elsewhere. Like the author, I too used to go to sleep while trying to meditate. That's one of the reasons I loved this chapter - it gives several suggestions for using "controlled distractions" to still meditate without dozing off. You can tell that the author has experienced all of the challenges of being a consistent meditator - I could absolutely relate to worrying about my breathing being so inconsistent!If you want to get started in meditation, OR get back into it, I can highly recommend this book.

The author suggests a quite non-traditional method for learning English - - and that's by having fun.From watching movies to music videos, documentaries and YouTube, non-English speakers can actually have some fun (and learn interesting things) but just immersing themselves into activities that are driven by English as the preferred language.I thought one of the most creative (and fun) methods was singing via karaoke! I think it takes a lot of courage to get up in front of other people and sing regardless of the language - - but singing in a language that's not your own must be doubly challenging.  But, fun.  I also liked the "slang game" idea, which really tests players in learning not only English but English slang.A very good read if you want to learn English - I'm positive readers will find at least a half-dozen techniques that work for them.

From Pinterest basics to strategies for pinning podcasts, videos and images, Pinterest for Business covers it all.As a Pinterest early-adopter, I was immediately hooked on the idea of curating great images in a single location. But, unlike basic photo sharing sites (Instagram, Flickr) Pinterest gives users the ability to curate favorite recipes, vacation spots and DIY projects; additionally, the service went far beyond to give businesses a place to interact with customers via contests, follows and comments. It's the business side of Pinterest that this book covers in detail.Pinterest for Business truly is a Master Guide to using pin boards for any profession. Not only can big brands tout their merchandise, small service providers can pull in potential customers via images around the water cooler, great testimonials, and podcast or video interviews with employees. Pinterest really does level the playing field.Although you'll find information for beginning pinners, there's absolute gold in the chapters of creating a Pinterest strategy, staying on brand, picking the best categories and board names, and integrating Pinterest with your website.  As a full-time author, I've danced around with Pinterest, trying to find the best way to get my books out into cyberspace (and beyond) . . . after reading this book I now have a solid blueprint from which to proceed.A fabulous resource - a must-have on your marketing bookshelf.I received a pre-publication Advanced Proof of this book for review purposes. (But I would have bought it anyway)

I just finished reading the author's book, Travel to Enlightenment, and wanted to know more about his thoughts and experiences around relationships. This book is a compilation of articles originally published in his newsletter - which I just signed up to receive. My own experience with relationships runs from the sublime to the soul-eating, so wanted to read what the author had to say about creating a truly good relationship. Like all manifestation it begins with clarity; what do I want in a relationship? Great question. The first article in the book goes into great depth about a woman who created a "want list" re: a relationship and learned the importance of being ultra-clear about the type of person she wanted.The second story is about having a clear intention - something I've experienced in my own life time and again. I don't want to give away the story, but suffice it to say that if your intent is of a negative outcome, a negative outcome you'll receive!If you're interested in creating a wonderful relationship (or a wonderful life) - I highly recommend reading this book. It enlightens readers through real stories demonstrating the power we all have within.

I've been on a spiritual path most of my adult life and love reading what other people have experienced and learned along the way. This book was no disappointment. Whether you travel across the globe or simply walk outside your door, you have the opportunity to be fully present in your own life. While the author had the opportunity to be present in many exotic locales (Tibet, Beijing, Hong Kong), he also recognizes that being present in your own life doesn't require world travel, but it does require being awake.In addition to the chapters on travel and enlightenment, I really enjoyed reading about the many synchronicities the author experienced. Again, even recognizing that a synchronicity is happening requires being awake vs. walking through your life in a haze. Lastly, I loved reading about practicing psychometry in Tibet. This was a synchronicity for ME as one of the characters in a book I'm writing is a psychometrist!A good read; if you're not sure about the whole "spiritual" or "enlightenment" thing pick up this book - I think you'll find a bit of synchronicity of your own!

I've read all of the books in the Jeff Resnick series - and this one was my least favorite. Although the mystery itself was interesting and kept me guessing, the book just didn't grab me like the others in the series did. Still, I love Jeff and Richard and Brenda - just wanted this book to keep me a bit more interested.

As a fulltime author myself, I'm always in the market to read books about the writing world, including self-publishing. I thought this book had a lot of helpful information that would be particularly helpful to those fairly new to indie publishing. While the author inspires new writers to persevere, she's also practical about the nuts and bolts of the business, from marketing (a must!) to connecting with readers, to the various sites that an indie can get started (Smashwords, Goodreads, etc). A good resource, highly recommended.

I had absolutely no idea that "just folks" could get celebrity endorsements of their products. And, I also had no idea that getting contact info for star was so easy. This books details the ins and outs of getting celebrity endorsements, including a guy on fiverr who can ferret out contact info, as well as several websites where you can search for star addresses or social media presence. Once you find someone you want to contact, the books tells you how to go about contacting them, including what to include in your request and how to word your letter or tweet. An excellent resource - am just amazed that this world exists.

I can't stand clutter, so decluttering isn't an issue for me. But it is for my cousin. In fact, I can hardly stand to visit her because there's "stuff" sitting on every surface. I thought I'd give her this book as a gift! In skimming through the contents (just in case I could pick up a tip or two) - I totally agree that clutter that's hidden is still clutter and it works on our subconscious mind just as if the junk was sitting out in the open. I also agree with the "T" part of the ACT System - Treat Daily! One thing I do need help with is processing bills as they come in and not when I have a 4-inch stack in front of me. So there! I guess I do have a clutter issue.  The book looks great - and I can't wait to see what my cuz thinks of it.

I've long been a believer in the power of acupressure - and remember several years ago helping someone with elbow pain by working on pressure points on the ear. This book is all about using pressure points to give yourself (or someone else) a facelift. The instructions are clearly written and easy-to-follow. I thought the illustrations were really easy to see - for me, the pinpoints on each place made it simple to follow along with the massage and pressure. A good resource for anyone, male or female, any age.

I have to admit, the whole gluten-free thing has always mystified me. One of my good friends was diagnosed with celiac disease and went gluten-free. Talking to her, it seemed to me that avoiding gluten might be a good thing for those of us who don't have celiac. Reading this book just confirmed my prior beliefs, probably because I also now think I'm gluten intolerant. As someone who has always had gut issues, it was good to learn more about gluten and its impact on our systems - particularly our guts.  Good info here - I learned far more than I anticipated.I also want to say a word about the recipes. For some reason I thought that gluten-free foods were bland and tasteless, but after going through the recipes I can see how wrong I was. Butternut Squash Risotto, Lentil Sheperd's Pie, Raspberry and Banana Ice Cream - now THOSE are foods I can't wait to try!If you have celiac or think you might be gluten intolerant I highly recommend picking up a copy of this book.

As a long-time reader of the western genre, I've recently had the pleasure of discovering the books written by L.J. Martin. Mojave Showdown was my latest read - and among my most favorite. The story is about Ned Cody's relentless search for his pals in the Mojave and as the book's description said, it really is reminiscent of Louis L'Amour classics. What I enjoyed more than anything - aside from the story itself - was the author's ability to transport me to a time and a place through great dialogue and believable physical descriptions.I was captivated from the very beginning and could easily picture the wind in the gap, the raven cawing and Mangas Saragosa blending in with the shadows of mesquite. Because I spend a lot of time in the Southwest, I'm familiar with the scenery and can honestly say that Martin captures it incredibly well.  I also want to mention how well his dialogue suits the time and place as does descriptions such as "his head caved in like a watermelon kicked with a pointed boot" !  Classic.

I am a sucker for unsolved cases and never missed an episode of Cold Case on TV. Loved the thought of being able to go back in time - sometimes decades - and work on an unsolved case. If you have the same taste in unsolved crimes, this book is for you. Starting with Jack the Ripper, the book chronicles chilling unsolved murders, among them Adam Walsh, JonBenet Ramsey and the Hall-Mills Murder. Each case includes background, details of the crime and suspects, as well as the aftermath.For those of us who are ardent viewers of the CSI and cold case brand of television, this is one of those books you definitely want to add to your virtual crime library.

This is a really cute read about a little boy who let the monsters out of the closet - only because he believed they truly existed. What happens next is chaos in the neighbhood! Not to give away the ending of the story, but I thought this would be a really good gift for a small child who was afraid of monsters or what was in the closet or under the bed. Good job.

I was looking for a guidebook to learn the basics of Scrivener and this book did the trick. I have really struggled with Scrivener - partly because it wasn't intuitive (at least not for me) and partly because I hadn't seen a "getting started" type of guide to walk me through the settings.  This book detailed all of Scrivener's features, from folders to panes and various view modes - all the stuff a newbie to Scrivener needs.  Good job.

I write for a living, so am always looking for books to help me with time management and book marketing - this book has both. With today's availability of multi-platforms for authors it takes a tremendous amount of time to consistently get your book out onto the platforms and then market, do more research, write more books, promote your books. It's never-ending.  This book has some easy-to-follow guidelines for getting and staying organized. Also - there's a tremendous amount of links to free resources - many of which I'd never seen before, although I've been around the marketing block a few thousand times! Good stuff here, authors!

I was a little perplexed at the negative comments about this book as I found the contents really helpful. I get so tired of cookbooks that have recipes for eight people - I don't want to cook for 8 and then freeze 6 or 7 portions. That's the real draw for me in buying a cookbook that I can actually use just for me.Someone's review commented about how there were too many veggie recipes - but I'm so happy there are! I especially loved the one for a sweet potato as I almost never see anything about these that don't use brown sugar and butter. Happy to see, instead, broccoli and yogurt. I also thought the peach dessert was especially yummy.Good reference and one I'll use often.

I found this title fascinating because the author focused on a trait that I think everyone who goes onto the Internet shares: We love to be distracted. Whether by cat videos or funny picture - no matter what our original intention we seem to go down 100 other paths. This book shows marketers how to use the Law of Distraction to attract visitors to your web page, your services, or your products.This book covers just about everything you need to know about creating marketing videos, from free resources to ways to easily share what you've created - including a free resource to do this for you.

My sister-in-law and one of my good friends suffer from RA, so I wanted to pick up this book to learn more about it - and to see if there were things I could suggest to them. First, I'm always more open to suggestions when they come from someone who has "been there and done that".  Secondly, the author doesn't suggest any magic bullets, but rather a well-thought out and sensible approach. For example, I found the section of the auto-immune section really interesting, particularly when talking about food. I am in total agreement about the quality of today's food and was interested to read the author's take on this as well as her thoughts about detoxifying the system. Interestingly, many of the foods mentioned are the same suggested for people with cardiac disease.I discovered so many things (thank you for the info on systemic enzymes) that I think are good for my own (non-RA) issues. I highly recommend this book.

Like many people, I'm a sucker for a good time travel novel. This was no exception. I thought the characters were well-developed, the dialogue believable, and the journey back in time to Wales fascinating. (That will teach you to buy an amulet!). Although the target audience are teen readers, I thought the plot interesting enough for most adults who like this kind of book (like me).

If you've ever read my reviews you'll see that I'm a huge fan of the slow cooker. In fact, I use the slow cooker more than any other kitchen appliance other than my blender (I'm a morning green smoothie fan).  Like the other single recipe books by this author, the directions are easy-to-follow and the photographs are outstanding. I've never made French Onion Soup before because I kind of thought that it would be more complicated. However, using the ingredients suggested, I can throw this together in a few minutes. Again, I really appreciate the photographs - they always give me a good sense of whether what I'm doing is what the dish is supposed to look like!

The CARMEN legend gets a Spaghetti Western makeover in Director Luigi Bazzoni's 'MAN, PRIDE. AND VENGEANCE' aka 'L'UOMO, L'OROLOGIO. LA VENDETTA'- `1967.  Fresh from his hit Director Sergio Corbucci's 'DJANGO'-1966, actor Franco Nero plays the tragic soldier infatuated with the gypsy prostitute Carmen played by cult actress Tina Aumont.  Along for the ride is actor Klaus Kinski as her sleazy outlaw husband and a small cameo by Franco Ressel.  With a nice flamenco guitar score by Carlo Rusticelli and beautiful photography by the Director's brother Camillo Bazzoni. it never achieves the epic status that it deserves.  The Western action takes second place to the love triangle and tragedies that Carmen puts the soldier through as she slowly destroys his life but its slow in coming.  The archivists at Blue Underground have found the original negative and the transfer is flawless in HD 1080p with a 2.35 aspect ratio which looks like it was made yesterday.  You can enjoy the English dubbed version or the original Italian track with English, Spanish. or French sub titles.  Extras include an audio commentary with 2 journalists Henry Parke and C. Courtney Joyner which I have not heard , a great interview with actor Franco Nero and cameraman Vittorio Storaro in Italian with English sub titles.  Nero has great stories on the shoot plus his take on coming to America , Italian and International trailers and a poster and stills gallery.  Director Bazzoni would direct Franco Nero again in the excellent Giallo 'THE FIFTH CORD' aka ' GIORNATA NERA PER L'ARIETE'-1971 but this Western only starts cooking at its climax with a brutal fist fight between Kinski and Nero.  It's worth it just for that.

Although the Giallo genre was peppered throughout the sixties with works by Directors Mario Bava and Umberto Lenzi among others, it wasn't until Director Dario Argento's 'THE BIRD WITH THE CRYSTAL PLUMMAGE' aka 'L'UCCELLO DELLE PIUME DI CRISTALLO-1970that the genre kick started into over drive causing other countries to get on the band wagon.  Here we have a British production Director Sydney Hayers's  'IN THE DEVIL'S GARDEN ' aka 'SATAN'S PLAYTHING'-1971 which is a cut above (no pun intended) some of the releases of that year.  Boasting the lead actress from Argento's opus, Suzy Kendall , it emerges as a routine thriller involving school girls being sliced and diced and the usual suspects of teachers are paraded in front of the viewer.  Actor Frank Finlay is wasted as the prefect of police and one of the main victims who survives is played by an incredibly young Lesley Anne Downe.  Director Hayers who gave us such classics as 'CIRCUS OF HORRORS'-1960 and the wonderfully atmospheric  'BURN,WITCH, BURN' aka 'THE NIGHT OF THE EAGLE'-1961 seems off his mark this time around.  The film emerges as a routine thriller resembling the West German Edgar Wallace films and the climax where the killer is trapped is the films only highlight utilizing the cinematography by Ken Hodges beautifully.  VCI entertainment releases the film in a nice ,crisp 1.85 transfer with Dolby digital sound with trailers to other VCI releases its only extras.

The archivists at Vinegar Syndrome known mainly for reviving vintage X-rated films from the Seventies and Eighties have dusted off two rare Horror titles  for fan completists.  First up is 'CRYPT OF THE LIVING DEAD' aka 'YOUNG HANNAH , QUEEN OF THE VAMPIRES' aka' LA TUMBA DE LA ISLA MALDITA'-1973, a Euro/US production with an interesting history.  Started and shot in Turkey with a Spanish film crew directed by Julio Salvador, it was completed in the US by Actor/Director Ray Danton using L.A. locations and retaining some of the actors with extra sequences.  When a noted archaelogist turns up mysteriously dead on the reclusive 'Vampire' island, his son decides to investigate and becomes embroiled with a beautiful 700 year old Vampire queen overseeing a blood cult.  Resembling Vampire 70's cult classics such  as Director Bob Kelljan's 'COUNT YORGA, VAMPIRE' -1970 and Director John Hayes's 'GRAVE OF THE VAMPIRE'-1971, it boasts a mixed bag of wonderful atmospherics trapped under slipshod film making.
