The detective, David Wolf, is a fascinating character, so this book packs a double whammy.  An interesting mystery, good characterization, plenty of intrigue and adventure, too.  You are as interested in the detective's problems as you are in the mystery he is working on.  I compliment Jeff Carson on an excellent book.  Highly recommend it.
A good adventure mystery with interesting characters and inter-relationships. I enjoyed it.  If you like mysteries in historical settings, you will most likely enjoy this one.  Recommended.
An interesting mystery.  A relatively dark story.  A good read, with interesting characters.  There's nothing average about this book.  I recommend it.

This books was really interesting.  The author has done a lot of research on his subject.  His description of the area and people comes alive.  He tells the story as eye witnesses described their experiences.  The author did not sensationalize.  He didn't exaggerate the eye witness accounts.  Whatever conclusion you come to after reading this book, you will find it thought-provoking.  I enjoyed it.  I recommend it.
I am very pleased with these gloves.  They fit well and are flexible and comfortable to use.  I would recommend them.

Got this for my dog - 100 pounds of active dog -- We have had the ball for a few months now, and the ball is still in one piece.  It's also doing much better in the weather than any other soccer ball we have bought him, even other Wilson balls.  So I think this is a very good deal -

An excellent mystery -- not quite as cozy as the title would lead you to expect.  This mystery is a fascinating psychological study of people in a dog park.  Surprising.  Perceptive.  I highly recommend it.

To fully enjoy the use of this camera,  YOU NEED TO READ THE MANUALS, BOTH OF THEM.  YOU NEED TO DOWNLOAD THE ADVANCED MANUAL AND READ IT.  This camera has amazing capabilities.  The zoom capabilities without reverting to the use of the digital zoom are awe-inspiring.  The Intelligent Zoom is better than a digital zoom, and it extends the zoom capabilities to more than the 60x figure.  I have used both.  The intelligent zoom will give you a photo with fewer megapixels, but the distortion common to digital zooming is missing.  Since you're starting with 16.1 mp, you can well afford to reduce the mp for the purpose of getting a long shot, but you don't even have to do that if you use the zoom attachment you can purchase with the adapter.I also have the adapter for the zoom attachment and the close-up attachment.  I was using a FZ100, and the same accessories work.  For the record,  you can use the regular zoom AND the intelligent zoom with the telephoto attachment which allows you to get magnificent zoom capabilities without using a digital zoom.This camera also has good wide angle capabilities as well - at least as wide as I ever want.  It doesn't do fisheye.It has macrofocusing down to 1 mm AND macro zoom focusing, which is delightful and will enlarge the subject.  And I have the close-up attachment as well, although so far the macro zoom has produced pictures I'm happy with, so I haven't used it.  .It has many different focusing choices.  You need to see what they are and see which one works for you.  The flexible focus is my favorite.  Uses a bit more battery, but it is faster continuous focus than the one labeled continuous focus.  This is why you have to read the directions.  There is also manual focus.  And standard focus.They have skimped on not making the vewing screen moveable to different angles.  If you want to take a time exposure, you mght want to use the timed shutter release to avoid camera movement, since there is no input for an external shutter button.  And yes, those things would have been nice, BUT I couldn't afford the camera if they hadn't kept the price down.  This is a hobby of mine, not a profession.This is one whopper of a camera for the price.  I think they economized in the right places and spent the money on the best kind of image stabilization that you can get - a necessity if you are going to use such a zoom.I have set my camera to limit the shutter speeds (found in the camera menu settings) so that it can't automatically go to too slow a speed.  Panasonic recommends a tripod -- and it's very true that a good tripod helps - but ninety nine percent of the time, when I want a photo, I either don't have my tripod with me, or it's not set up -- so I am handholding shots that should be on a tripod -- because the deer will leave -- or the birds or small animals are active -- I'm often taking a walk, and I use the zoom to photograph wild flowers I can't get close to without getting into poison ivy or some such thing.My advice for handheld shots is to use the shutter speed limit, so the shutter speed can't go too slow on you.  I often use shutter priority, risking the shot being too dark, but there is also an option in the setup stuff. Often, even if a picture is too dark, you can improve it with software.The camera also had editing capabilities, but I use Corel's software on my PC.I take LOTS OF PHOTOS.  If you think you can't hand hold the camera, snap as many photos as you can, and try.  Hold your breath and get your elbows close to your sides -- really - it steadies you -- or find something to lean on, if possible, and do your best.  Sometimes it doesn't work, but often if I take a lot of photos, at least a couple of them will be sharp, because I snapped the picture at just the right moment.The beauty of digital photography is that you don't have to pay for your flops.  You can just delete them, and keep the good ones.This is not a professional photographer's camera, although I would bet that pros would have one whopper of a good time with it.  But I don't have the money to buy a pro's camera, nor do I have the ability to carry the camera equipment I used to -- nor do I have the money to spare for excessive film and processing.SO I am as happy as a hog in a mud waller with this camera.  It take good pictures.  As with any camera, you need to get used to this particular one.  I have a particular combination of metering and exposure that I usually use -- you could vary your choices to suit yourself, BUT YOU WON'T DO THAT IF YOU DON'T DOWNLOAD THE ADVANCED MANUAL AND READ IT.I went to the trouble to print out the manual, because I studied it in odd places in order to cover the information.  It is convenient to have it on your computer, too, but I wanted a print out.  I printed it one section at a time.This is a wonderful camera for the money.  If I could afford the setup the National Geographic photographers use, I wouldn't be able to carry it anyway.  This camera is a great deal of fun, and if you will take the time to master the vast number of choices you have available, you will surely enjoy it.I highly recommend it.

This is a good adventure mystery.  It deals with the real sleaze of the use of kids by pornographers.  It makes the horrible nature of the industry clear without being overly graphic, which makes it a good and thought-provoking read.  It certainly would encourage awareness of a serious problem in the context of fiction you don't want to put down.  That awareness should encourage people to make kids and young people aware of the dangers around them.It's a good mystery, interesting characters, and an adventure.  But the subject makes it a serious read as well.

I am using this on my digital with a built-in zoom.  I use UV filters to protect the lens - had never used a UV/IR filter before, and I was a bit concerned about its effect when I realized it has slight color reflections in light.  However, it is working very well.  It certainly hasn't degraded my photos, and I would say it's probably improved them.  It's a high quality filter.  I recommend it.

Interesting characters, a good plot, a good mystery -- the description of cancer treatments and side effects was well handled.  Marty Singer is a retired police detective with a health problem.  I've read two of the Marty Singer books now, and I've liked them both. Well worth a read.  Not for kids.
This works very well for me.  A good but reasonable level of magnification, easily held relatively near the small print I'm reading.  I am very pleased with this magnifier.  I recommend it.
Genuine Energizer batteries at a reasonable price.  A good deal.  I recommend them.  There are cheaper deals, but these which are supplied by amazon are actually Energizer.

I am a woman with a wide foot, and I buy the men's insoles.  They can be trimmed if they are too wide for a particular pair of shoes, fit most of my wide wide shoes well, and don't leave bare spots in the insole area when I have inserted them.They are comfortable, and I am a repeat customer.  This is how I extend the life of my shoes.  Highly recommended.

This book is a real cliff hanger of a thriller --  It certainly kept me on the edge of my seat.  It is also a warning about complacency about the dangers facing out country.  It is a paean to our beloved and blessed freedoms.  A good job.  Well written.  A wild adventure.  A good read.

One of the best surprises I have had.  When I started reading, I thought it might turn out to be a hackneyed story -- I found myself instead becoming interested in the characters and involved in the story.  It didn't take me long to wish I didn't have to put it aside for chores.  It is a fascinating and a thought provoking book.  I highly recommend the book to readers.  I congratulate the author for a superb job well done.

An oldie that was surprisingly absorbing.  Characters were interesting.  The murder was a good puzzle.  I honestly can't explain exactly why I found it so interesting.  It drops you back into a different historical period.  I think it's because I cared about the characters.  I definitely recommend this book.

A good light mystery - a good puzzle - I enjoyed the book.  The main character is the one who fills the dead woman's shoes by taking over her detective business with absolutely no training and solving her first mystery.  Not overly realistic.  I thoroughly enjoyed escaping from the real world for a while.  I'd read more of Kaye C. Hill's writing.

Get some small measuring spoons so you can measure this stuff easily.  I use it for iced tea and cooking.  This is a real money saver, has very good flavor, and it doesn't take up much space.  I'm very happy with this product.

This is a wonderful book with some specific recipes, but more important, it's a trip down memory lane for some of us.  I loved the reminiscences.  I was fascinated by some of the descriptions of how some remedies actually worked.  Some of them are truly odd -- and I think there MUST be an explanation for the success of the remedy, even though I don't know what it is.  I really loved this book, and I highly recommend it to anybody who wants to know more about old home remedies and how they work.  Some of the stories gave me a good laugh --  Highly recommend this book.

This soap gets a new name every once in a while.  I look for Phisodern Unscented Bar and usually it comes up on a search.  It's an excellent product.It is antibacterial and mild enough for me to use which says a lot -- I have extremely sensitive skin and I am allergic to even the mildest scents.  My doctor told me about Phisoderm Unscented Bar soap years ago - I cannot use Phisoderm's liquid soaps due to allergies.  This unscented bar product is the one that works for me.Highly recommended -- reasonably long-lasting bars -- I shop for the best prices.  This can be a hard-to-find product.  Thanks to amazon for carrying it consistently.

These are a good, basic, soothing eyedrop which can safely be used as a soothing eyewash, if you get irritants in your eye -- and it's just easy soothing stuff -- I am often allergic to eye drops, but these are pretty non-threatening, and they work.Check out the active and inactive ingredients.  Bausch & Lomb has been selling this formula for years under different names.  I know of at least three name changes and new style boxes over the years.  That can make these hard to find if your favorite eye drops seem to disappear.This is not a new gimmick formula - It's an old standby in new dress -- and sooner or later they will change the box again - so make sure you know what's in the one you like, and then you can find it over years.Highly recommend this eyedrop.  A good product.

A good mystery, good characterization, just a good yarn all the way around.  I highly recommend this book to mystery lovers.  It's a cop story - and a good one, both about the system and the individual.  Well written.

This is a book everyone should read.  The previous review did not take into consideration how many people have been hurt by so-called "psychic healing".  There are real dangers that are discussed in this book.I personally read books that I don't always agree with -- I can often learn from people who have ideas I haven't considered.  So if you are dealing with psychic healing in any way, reading only a few pages and then trashing the book is certainly not being tolerant or open minded.  People are entitled to disagree with you, just as they are entitled to disagree with me -- and considering the ideas of people who disagree with you is NOT a negative.  It is a way we sharpen our minds.I am a Christian who believes the Bible to be the Word of God in written form.  It is an act of love to tell someone the truth about problems in an area in which they may encounter great difficulties.I give this book 5 stars and I highly recommend it.

Myrtle Clover mysteries are just plain fun.  The mystery in this one is well handled.  Her son isn't really enough of a ghoul to want to put his mother in a rest home for no reason -- he's much nicer than that.  He's also a policeman.  Her sidekick is a neat character.  I read to relax.  If you're looking for serious literature, this isn't it, but this is a fun read.  Highly recommend it.

These shakes are an excellent way to get a quick dose of good nutrition and protein.  The chocolate is rich and satisfying.  I also love the vanilla.  We keep these in the refrigerator -- It's a quick and tasty way to take the edge of the desire to snack.  A good product which helps me to control weight.  You don't have to be diabetic to enjoy these and benefit from their use.

These shakes are just a good way to get a quick dose of good nutrition and protein.  You don't have to be diabetic to appreciate them.  We keep them in the refrigerator at my house.  Both flavors are good.  The chocolate is rich.  I personally love the vanilla.  Highly recommend this product.  A good way to hold off the munchies when you are dieting.

These cough drops really work.  Help to break up phlegm in your throat, and actually seem to CURE a sore throat, not just anaesthetize it.  I have used these cough drops for years now.  Used to pass them around the church choir on a regular basis during wintertime rehearsals.I honestly think these cough drops do something to help you get over a cold and a sore throat.  They certainly add to comfort.  They also are excellent for soothing a throat irritation caused by an allergy.  I once felt as if I was choking when I got into an area of town where I was allergic to something, and I grabbed a Ricola cough drop and got immediate relief.Highly recommend this product.

An amazing improvement over other systems.  These lancets really ARE pain free, at least for me.  I purchased a Freestyle light meter, and I didn't intend to buy lancets, since I had some from an earlier system.  Two tests with these lancets, and I ordered a box.  They really make a difference.

My cat was lame from the time she was a kitten, and in her later years we gave her Cosequin for Cats.  I was amazed to see her start jumping up to places she had never jumped to before.  I wish we had known sooner how much this would help her.  She is a finicky little lady, and she turned her nose up at an alternate product, refusing even to touch the food we put it on, BUT she LOVES Cosequin.  A good deal all around.  I highly recommend this product.

A wild adventure with some fascinating characters and some surprising plot twists.  The added emotional kick of the main character looking for his missing father creates a real feeling of empathy with the young man.  This does not detract from the fact that it's a spy story in any way.  The fact that the whole adventure is wildly improbably only adds to the fun.  The hypothesis is modern in a historical framework.  This book is fun.  I highly recommend it.

I am always a little put off by authors who portray their characters as walking sex bombs, but looking past that part of the book, I did really get interested in this mystery, and since I read a variety of books by authors with different attitudes toward life, I don't often disqualify books based on that issue.This is a good mystery/adventure.  I was intrigued by the characters and the role playing vampire game for a setting.  I'm not really into vampires either, but this made a good backdrop for the tale.I read mysteries for entertainment.  This one certainly provided that.  I recommend it.

It took me a little bit to decide if I liked this one.  As I got into the story, I really became interested. The characters and situation are interesting.  The setting is well described.  The mystery is a good one, and the tension is well managed.  Highly recommend this one for a good mystery and adventure, too.

A very good read.  Interesting characters.  A small town mystery which becomes very absorbing.  The more I read, the more interested I became.  I suspect it presents an idyllic idea of cross-border relations with the Mexican police, but the possibility exists that personal contacts as described might make a major difference.I really enjoyed this book.  A good mystery.  I cared about the characters.  Highly recommend.
The author is one of the grand old men of Biblical theology.  This is a book well worth reading.  Highly recommended.

I am able to see George Washington's faith expressed in his own words.  Skip the introductions.  Read Washington's prayer diary, and you will see that he was a Bible believing Christian who trusted Jesus Christ as his Lord and Saviour.  He was NOT a deist.  He was a believing Christian.  Don't just stop at the beginning.  Read the whole diary.Our society's educational and other media has chosen to MISREPRESENT the actual beliefs of our founding fathers.  That is intellectually dishonest.  I was pleased to hear what Washington thought in Washington's own words -- the intro is written by somebody else, obviously.I was also fascinated by the fact that George Washington as a high level Mason was a believing Christian, and he apparently saw no clash between the two.  I think that Masonry is often a reflection of the beliefs of the men who participate in it.  It is, as far as I understand, an organization which welcomes men of differing opinions who choose to behave responsibly.  A man should believe in a Creator God to be a Mason, but Masonry is a fellowship of Christians, Jews, and others.I know a great many people consider Masonry to be incompatible with Biblical Christianity.  I see that George Washington had a different opinion.  And there is no doubt at all about the depth and Biblical nature of his Christian faith.  Many of the references in his prayer diary are references to the Bible's teachings.  You do need to be familiar with the Bible to realize that.I have found this book to be an excellent piece of primary source material.  I highly recommend it.  You don't have to become a Bible believing Christian to acknowledge the fact that George Washington was one and to respect his faith.  I am a Bible believing Christian.  You don't have to be one to be intellectually honest about historical facts.

They are slightly snug even in the larger size I bought -- However, it helped to poke each of the fingers to get the liner properly placed in the fingers.  Then they go on pretty well, and they seem warm.  I haven't had them very long.  They seem like pretty good gloves -- They look as well sewn as the more expensive pair I have -- The material looks just as good and sturdy.  I can't afford to pay luxury prices for warm gloves, and that's why I decided to try these.  All said, I think they're a pretty good deal.  I recommend them.

This is my basic tea for making iced tea.  I combine 8 Twinings green tea bags with 2 Bigelow Mint Medley.  Make a pan of hot tea with about 1 quart of water.  Put 2 quarts of cold water in a pitcher, sweeten with bulk sucralose (cheaper to use than Splenda) to taste, add your quart of concentrated tea -- Makes 3 quarts of delicious  mint flavored iced tea.  Serve over ice, obviously.  Enjoy.Highly recommend -- oh -- when I brew green tea, I bring the water to a rapid boil, let the water stop bubbling, and drop my tea bags into the water.  Green tea needs this slightly more gentle method to retain good flavor, in my opinion.
A good read.  An exciting story.  And it gives you a great deal to think about as you read.  This book is both a good adventure and thought provoking.  Highly recommend.

This volume of the Patton Papers provides real insight into the character and training of Gen George S Patton.  It's a fascinating window into the span of history preceding WW 2 from the perspective of an interesting observer.  I highly recommend this book.  The information included is extensive.
This is an extensive volume -- a feast of information about a fascinating person.  It also provides a clear perspective on the historical period it covers.  Highly recommend this.

The replacement pads give you one plain and one carbon embedded pad for each change.  This is working very well to keep my 5 gallon aquarium clean.  I have tried three other filters -- This one is actually keeping the water in very good shape.  My betta is in excellent health with fewer water changes.  I think this is due to my using Azoo's own filters.  The carbon impregnated pad is very effective at removing impurities.When I change the filter media, I change both the plain and the carbon pad, AND I add API's Quick Start, Stress Coat, and Stress-Zyme -- all three just as if I were starting a new setup.  This puts the startup bacteria into the filter, adds extra bacteria which do clean up, and protects my fish as I am normally adding fresh water at that point -- sometimes due to water change, sometimes due to evaporation.I am also very happy with the Azoo filter that these pads are used in.  The adjustable water flow is good for my betta.I am very pleased with the results of using this product.  My fish is healthier, and maintenance is easier.

I really like this printer.  Print quality is excellent.  As for paper jams, which people have been complaining about, HP paper works very well with only an occasional instance of printer pulling two pages at once -- something every printer I have ever owned has done.  I learned quickly NOT to mix different types of papers.  That does cause a problem.  Thumbing your paper before you load it does help.There is a place to choose your paper type.  It is important that you do this.  One choice is HP paper -- There is also a choice for OTHER printer paper.  I think it's wise to make the correct paper selection so as to avoid problems with paper feed.  I have had very few problems.  This printer is doing its paper feed as well as any.Print quality is excellent.  I am VERY happy with this machine.  The fact that it isn't wasting colored ink every time it prints just black is a real blessing.Highly recommend this product.  DO select the proper paper type.

Love this tea iced, and I especially like the case of it -- saves money and it also has 4 teabags in each packet so you don't have to unwrap so many individual teabags.  I make a 3 qt pitcher -- 8 teabags in roughly a quart of boiling water -- sweeten with Splenda -- add two more quarts of cold water.  Makes a delicious pitcher of iced tea.  Enjoy!

I find this man's books fascinating.  He was writing in the 1800's, and it is incredible what perceptiveness he shows on the subject of prophecy.  He has simply taken his Bible seriously, refused to over-allegorize it, and he has missed some of the errors in prophecy that were made back then, because they were not looking at today's current political alignment in the Middle East.  A lot of prophecy students back then completely missed the fact that Israel would actually return to the Land and become a nation again, because before 1948, it just seemed so incredible.  I have read a couple of Pember's books now, and I highly recommend his writings.  He is a careful thinker, and even though you may not always agree with every one of his conclusions, you will have to admire his clarity and careful analysis.  A very good read.

Fits the keyboard well.  Just sits on it, but it's very secure.  Doesn't alter the touch of the keyboard, and, in fact, it actually stops your fingers from slipping around so much -- a slight change, and I think a good one.  I would certainly recommend this product.  It will protect the keyboard well, and the notebook closes with no problems.  It doesn't leave any impressions on the screen either.  I'm very pleased with this thing.A CHANGE IN REVIEW -- I would love this keyboard protector, IF THE LABELS DIDN'T COME OFF THE KEYS.  I don't use hand lotions or anything that should cause the letters to vanish, but that's what's happening.  I'm going to look for a different brand for that reason.

A good and absorbing mystery and adventure.  The plot is complex and a good puzzle.  The characters are well defined and interesting.  The background with the hawks adds special interest.  I enjoyed this book.  Compliments to the author.  Hightly recommend it.

Helped my cat who is older and was lame.  She was never a jumper, even when she was a kitten, yet recently she jumped up on my bed without using her steps.  I was surprised.  She no longer limps.  You have to give this to them for a while.  It's not a 3 day cure,but it certainly works.

This is a good product.  It works on my eye irritation.  I can NOT use the generic "equivalents".  They burn and irritate my eyes.  I don't know what the difference is, but this is one time when buying the brand name is the best option.  It works well, doesn't irritate my eyes, and is worth the money, because buying the brand name, I use less since it works.

This is our household bath and sink soap.  NOT just for facial cleansing.  I am allergic to most soap products.  I am NOT allergic to this.  It's gentle, gets you clean, and doesn't irritate.  Also, it's a good value for the money.  Highly recommend this product.

I have a cat who really needs hairball control products.  This works very well.  It doesn't use mineral oil, which will take the fat soluble vitamins out of a cat's body if used too much.  My cat has been living on this food since we got her from a shelter over 15 years ago.  She's in remarkably good health for her age, and the vet said "Whatever you're doing, keep it up."  This is her food.  She can't eat the dry stuff -- no teeth.  This is a good product.

This product does really help maintain joint health, and it has helped me with back problems.  Twinlab maintains excellent quality.  You do need to take this for a period of time.  It's not a 3 day cure.  It's a nutrient.  It was recommended to me by someone who credited this for helping to heal serious knee problems.  Even my cat gets glucosamine and chondroitin - except a brand for cats that manages small doses.  She was injured when she was a kitten.  She was never a jumper.  The vet recommended feline glucosamine and chondroitin, and she jumped up on my bed the other day without using her stairs.  She is an older cat, so this is exceptional.  Wish we had given it to her sooner. She no longer limps.I have been taking this stuff for years now, and I am doing very well -- and I'm no spring chicken.  This stuff works.

I have had a remarkable experience with HP's service, and I am impressed.  They are TERRIFIC.  My machine arrived with a defective dvd drive.  I registered the machine before I realized this, which I now realize was a good thing.  HP's service is exemplary.  They promptly shipped me the replacement drive.  It is now installed, and  the machine is running very well.  I could have returned the machine for them to replace it, but I knew I could get this done, and it saved time. I am so pleased with my purchase and the service I received that I recommended HP to a family member who purchased one of their other machines.For the price this machine is exceptional.  I am not into games or graphics, so I can't comment on how it would perform in that category.  The USB3 ports are fast.  The machine has a comfortable keyboard and a good screen.Windows 8 hides things.  I have been told that their next update or upgrade (not sure which) will put the start menu back.  You have to poke around to find things.  Try right clicking in different places.  Menus change with small changes in the cursor location.  I uninstalled a lot of the stuff that was unnecessary and which was offers to buy stuff.  Windows 8 is not a bad program EXCEPT that it's hard to FIND things at first.  If you are determined, you can learn this program reasonably quickly, but I have been doing computers since Dos 3.11 before Windows was ever invented, so I do have a bit of an edge.  The aps page isn't bad, but I move to the regular desktop which is where I normally work from.  However, if you want to go back and forth from that to the aps page, it's easy to do and very helpful in many situations.Also in Windows 8, the right hand pop out menu changes depending on where you are, and from the aps page, if you move your cursor to the right to open the right pop out, then click on "tiles," you can tell it to open a bigger list of aps, and you can find a lot of the programs that do machine maintenance, etc.  However, if you are a beginner, be a little careful with those.  Also, you can find stuff in the programs directory from the file manager.HP HAS DONE SOMETHING WONDERFUL.  If you are a keyboard user and do a lot of typing, it is VERY handy that the touchpad can be turned  off with two light taps on a little indentation in the upper left corner of the touchpad.  Can be turned back on the same way, so you don't have to worry about what you are typing suddenly changing size or taking off into the wild blue yonder.  VERY handy.  Kudos to HP.The Windows 8 email program is horrible.  It seems to work well until you go to forward something, and then it gets messy.  As best I can figure out, you have to select what you want to forward, and that is like pouring molasses in January.  Then it doesn't always work.  When I tried to move something into a special folder, which should work, the machine froze.  If the email is open, and it seems to be open ALL the time, then I got an error message when I restarted the machine that windows couldn't access something.  That wasn't helpful, since the message disappeared so quickly I couldn't read it.  Without that email program set up, I don't get an error message.  Without the email program, the machine is working great.My suggestion is to delete all your email accounts, if you have set any up.  Use your email provider's web site, or, if you want to do your email on your machine, get a different program.  There are two reasons for this:  1. security  and 2. the program is lousy.About security, the very first thing I do when I turn on my machine is update my Norton's Internet Security.  If you have set up an account using the Windows 8 email program, you machine is online before you can get a security update, and you are not as fully protected as you should be if email comes in, as it almost surely will.I have already said the program drove me nuts, because it didn't work well.  I am perfectly happy working on the web site for my email, and that also avoids downloading a lot of spam and risking hostile files or viruses getting to your machine.  If you do use a machine based email system, I highly recommend Norton's security programs.  They have stopped bad emails from getting to my older machine, where I was using machine based email.  Obviously you have to do your own thinking about phishing emails, but Norton will stop hostile files and viruses fast.I hope this review helps people deciding whether or not to buy this machine.  It is an excellent machine for normal activities.  For running high end graphics, you need something bigger -- and more expensive -- but this machine is faster and does more than older desktops, and I like it a lot.If you have a problem, contact HP support.  They have a regular specified routine they go through, and if you will bear with them,they will help you as fast as they can.  Have a little patience, and they WILL solve your difficulties.  They certainly have done a wonderful job for me.  And it's not their fault you are frantic because you machine is pitching a hissy fit.Hope this review is helpful.

I like detective stories - don't care if they're hard boiled detective or not -- BUT SOME detective stories just turn into guys showing off potty mouths.  THIS DETECTIVE novel was a good read -- Ths mystery is good, the adventure is good, the characters are interesting, and the suspense is well paced.  I enjoyed this book, liked her main character, would be happy to look for her books again.  The author did a great job. She handled the historical setting well.  This was light entertainment, yet her characters have depth and their problems aren't shallow.  It's a tough dame mystery, and the attraction is a well done story.  Highly recommended.

This book has it all: adventure, conspiracy, travel, and archaeology.  The hero made me think of Indiana Jones, but he's a college prof with a bad knee, not superman.  The descriptions were wonderful.  The characters were unique and well developed.  The adventure was superb.  If you liked Dan Brown's adventures, you'll enjoy this wild ride, except it's not hostile to any church.It's a good story, what I call a fun read -- and it's got clear cut good guys and bad guys.  Refreshing.

A good mystery, good character development.  It deals with the issue of racism - and more.  It's not just a book about racism.  It deals with all sorts of personality and personal issues and prejudices.Too much comment will spoil it for other readers.  I did thoroughly enjoy the reading of this book.  I'm impressed with the talent of Parrish.  I highly recommend this book, and I'd like to compliment the authors.  A good read, and a job well done.

We have religious freedom in our country, and every man is entitled to his own religious views.  However, quoting the Bible OUT OF CONTEXT is essentially misrepresenting the actual message of this fascinating and historical document.  You are perfectly free to accept or reject the message of the Bible, but, at least, be accurate about what that message IS.This book quotes the Bible, BUT, in so doing, it misrepresents the Bible's teaching about the second coming of the Messiah.  If you read this book, and if this book stimulates your curiosity about the end times and the second coming of the Messiah, don't accept this false picture of these events.  The first time the Messiah came, He came as a carpenter and rabbi.  The second time He comes, He won't be hard to identify at all.Try reading Zechariah chapters 12-14, especially chap 14, in the Old Testament for an idea of what it will be like when the Messiah returns -- When He touches down on the Mount of Olives the Mount will split in two.  Not an inconspicuous event.  Maybe if your interest in piqued by the genuine article, you'll find Biblical prophecy an interesting subject to investigate.In Matthew 24, the Messiah Himself warns against searching for false Messiahs in the deserts and secret chambers, and He Himself says that His second coming will be like lightning shining from east to west --Portraying the returned Messiah as a drunken musician, who is totally confused about his own identity and who, oddly enough, spends time in the desert, is not an accurate presentation of what the Bible predicts.Matthew 24:23-27 King James VersionThen if any man shall say unto you, Lo, here is Christ, or there; believe it not. For there shall arise false Christs, and false prophets, and shall shew great signs and wonders; insomuch that, if it were possible, they shall deceive the very elect. Behold, I have told you before. Wherefore if they shall say unto you, Behold, he is in the desert; go not forth: behold, he is in the secret chambers; believe it not. For as the lightning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.I've used the King James Version in my quotation, because this version is obviously in the public domain.

A good mystery.  The author is knowledgeable about art -- the old masters, those who copy the old masters, and forgeries -- The characters are interesting -- the book gets better as it goes along, and I didn't want to put it down.  I was NOT fascinated with the fancy license plates - the book is a lot better than that gimmick indicated.  Good characterization, a good adventure, a good puzzle -- Well done.  I recommend this book.

This turned out to be a good book.  It's an interesting mystery and has an exciting ending.  It's what I call a "light mystery" - one I read for relaxation and entertainment -- I enjoyed it.  It's a good puzzle.  Enjoy.

This is a beautifully constructed book.  Even the cheapest edition is amazingly flexible and a delight to handle.  HOWEVER:1. I was extremely disappointed in the print.  It could be much darker and more distinct.  Don't say they couldn't do that because the paper is so light in weight.  I have a Cambridge Cameo KJV which is even smaller than the Clarion and which has very thin paper which has DARKER PRINT of a comparable size and which is easy to read.It's possible that part of the problem is the line spacing.  Not sure -- but this is nowhere near as easy to read as the Bibles printed the old fashioned way, meaning not computer printing.They did NOT make the mistake of having the ink run out in the printing process, so the printing job is well handled in that respect and was carefully monitored.2. I was disappointed to discover that they have left out some of the references which were included in their older Bibles.  They had room.  Just left the refs out.  It's not a matter of whether it's side or center column reference.  They had ONE COLUMN to use, and they didn't use it.  I like a reference Bible with a complete set of refs, especially for this price.  For example, in the Cambridge Cameo KJV which I have, there is a reference at 1 Thessalonians 5:18.  There is no reference for that verse in the Clarion edition.  An unnecessary deletion.3. The other disappointment was in the information in the combined concordance and encyclopedia type information in the back of the Bible.  I was startled to read that the Apostle Peter did NOT write either of the two books attributed to him by name in the Bible itself.  The commentator believes that the books were written by some guy who claimed to be the apostle Peter at a date when Peter would have been dead.  If this were so, then the writer of these two Bible books would have lied about who he is and would have LIED ABOUT BEING AN EYE WITNESS TO HIS MAJESTY as he claimed in 2 Peter.If the writers of sacred scripture are liars about who they are, what they saw, and when they lived, WHY should we believe anything else they say?  In my humble opinion, the Bible is God's word, and Jesus, who said "I am the way, the truth, and the life," is NOT going to sponsor lies -- nor is the Holy Spirit going to inspire lies.I was well aware that Cambridge notes and encyclopedia entries often lean toward liberal interpretations, but this was egregious.I think it's important for Bible believing Christians to know BEFORE they buy this Bible that the notes in the back are not consistent with belief in the truth of the Scriptures.  NOW, that said, if you aren't going to rely on the notes, if you do enjoy the kind of type and the paragraph format -- then you would be purchasing an exquisitely crafted edition of the King James Version of the Bible.Superior construction of the volume.  However, the print is not up to the standard they could have achieved simply by dint of using more ink, and the notes in back are not consistent with conservative theology.Those are the reasons I have only given it three stars.  I hope this information is helpful.  I rarely do negative reviews, but it seemed to me that purchasers of a book that is this expensive might appreciate this information.  If, knowing this, you choose to purchase the volume, at least you won't be surprised in a negative way.

This was one very good book.  Fast moving, well paced, intriguing mystery, adventure, and a romantic angle, too.  I didn't put this down until I had finished it.  Highly recommended.  Compliments to the authors.

The first 25% of this book was a bit of a bore. There was a lot of unnecessary description and not enough action. And through it all I was distracted by the inconsistent voice of out narrator Mayme. The tragedy during which our two main characters lost their families and were then drawn together was a chaotically powerful part of the story. I was drawn in when Mayme and Katie were gettig to know one another. But the last 30% of the book seemed redundant and the conflict was not really resolved. I enjoyed the story overall but don't feel compelled to read bfurther in the series.

Tales From the Crib is your typical romantic comedy in terms of the plot line...no surprises or twist endings. But Coburn filled the story with a slew of quirky and memorable characters that will have you laughing out loud. As a new mom, I was drawn in to download this book because of the cover art; I figured it would be a comedic take on new parenthood. But other than the couple of La Leche meetings she attends, the story is less about Lucy's parenting and more about the other relationships in her life.

I've read some terrible memoirs before....those that include endless pages of useless details or are poorly written. And some memoir writers aren't very good at telling their story...as though they are qualified to pen a book merely because they lived through an era of great importance. This book is not one of those memoirs and Carolyn Maull McKinstry is not one of those writers. While the World Watched is well-written, tells a compelling story ripped from the pages of our not-too-distant history, and includes just enough historical data to make that story come alive. I highly recommend this book.

There's nothing really though-provoking about this book. It doesn't really teach any life lessons or make you reconsider your views on the world as you know it. But it IS chock full of quirky characters and zany situations. So much so that you'll laugh out loud.The story is narrated by Jane, a 30-something HR professional who is (not so) secretly stalking one of her neighbors, taking care of her 20+ year old goldfish Sparky, and dodging calls from her prying mother Pat1 (not to be confused with her dad, Pat2). Along the way we meet her hopelessly romantic brother and his ditzy but well-meaning fiance, a chain-smoking co-worker, a promiscuous friend, a latin lover, a couple of gay best friends, and a TV newscaster (among others).Pros: The narration is executed in such a way that it's like having lunch with an old friend. The dialogue is down-to-earth and believable, even if the plot developments aren't always. The characters are all unique and fairly well-developed, considering just how many characters there are.Cons: There weren't any major plot developments so while the characters and situations were fun, the story overall got a bit stale near the end. I'd have left happier if the book had been about 25% shorter.

The premise of the book is pretty straightforward.... Four 50-something women reconnect at a class reunion, reminisce about the past and take a hard look at their futures. Their bond was formed back in grade school simply because they are all named Linda (and consequently all opt to go by their middle names) and life has taken them in four very different directions. Yet they pick up as though they hadn't spent any time apart at all. And apparently no one--kids, spouses, fellow classmates--knew they were even friends. Odd...The characters were trite, the dialogue was completely unrealistic, and the plot chugged along at a snail's pace. I'm not a fan and won't be reading any more in the series...or any of the author's other "about 200" books!

Having recently (3 1/2 months ago) given birth to our first child, I thought this book would be a fun read and give me a glimpse into what my hubby went through during my pregnancy. And based on the handful of other customer reviews, it was sure to be funny, too...bonus!The book is a series of diary entries penned by our narrator, Graham. His audience, he assumes, are the aliens who will someday find his diary (?). Graham talks candidly about his fears and excitement as his girlfriend progresses through the months leading up to his fatherhood. The story has the potential to be funny. It has the potential to be poignant. It was neither.I think the humor was just lost on me because I'm not British and, clearly, the author is. (Perhaps some of the "funny" was "lost in translation"...?) That aside, very little of the content was believable. I find it hard to believe that any 29-year-old man is as ill-equipped and aloof as Graham seems to be. He came across as flaky and, sadly, unlikable. So much so that in my mind, it was Russell Brand's voice narrating the story. (Have I mentioned that I can't stand Russell Brand?) I digress. Needless to say, I don't feel compelled to read the author's next installment about the first three months of fatherhood.

I don't pre-make bottles, which means there's no refrigeration or warming required. And when we're on the go with our daughter, these dispensers are perfect to throw in the diaper bag. We can still make her bottle immediately before she's ready to eat it AND we don't have to cart the whole can of formula along with us.We also use them when bringing our daughter to daycare or any other time someone will be watching her for us. That way we know it's measured correctly and again there's no carting a whole can of formula around.I've tried other formula dispensers and hate how you can't ever seem to get all of the formula out. That's not an issue with these, though. The covers come in 2 pieces: a lid and a cap. To fill the dispenser, you remove the lid (which leaves the entire top of the cup open). To empty the dispenser, you remove the small cap (which opens a hole in the lid). The lids are curved on the inside, creating almost a funnel shape which allows you to get all the formula out easily. And since the opening covered by the cap is small, it keeps you from spilling the formula while trying to empty it into your bottle.The only negative thing I can say is that I wish they were slightly larger. The packaging says they are big enough to hold enough formula to make an 8-ounce bottle but they're not. I can fit 3 scoops of formula (enough for a 6-ounce bottle) but can't imagine where you'd squeeze another whole scoop. Still, I'd recommend them in a heartbeat!CORRECTION ADDED 11/19/13: We have since started using these formula dispensers for our 8-ounce bottles and the formula does, in fact, fit! After adding the third scoop, I tap the container on the counter a few times to allow the formula to settle a bit. And then I'm able to get the fourth scoop in. The size is absolutely perfect!

Haven't we all had a job that left us saying this? Specifically one in retail or working with the public? I know I have.Our narrator (whose name, interestingly, we never learn) seems to have done just that. He's one of the managers at Village Books, an independent bookstore facing its doom as a bigbox corporation prepares to buy them out. Along the way, we meet an eclectic mix of employees a la Empire Records.The only (somewhat) negative comment I can possibly make about this book is that the plot is nothing special. You won't find any suspenseful twists. It doesn't raise any social, moral, or any other kind of question. But it at least flows. And ultimately, the plot doesn't matter because the dialogue (including that between the narrator and reader, thanks to the first person narration) is often hilarious and constantly witty. Be prepared to laugh.

My brother-in-law just got his first bachelor pad and selected a shower curtain that has sheet music printed on it. I thought these hooks would be the perfect addition to his bathroom so I purchased them as a gift. They look great and he loves them. :)

I'd venture to say that billions of people--past and present--have kept journals or diaries. And I'd even venture to say that many of them were written during a time of great historical importance, as this one was. However, just because a journal was written during (and/or about) an important historical period does not mean that it warrants publishing.Two words I'd use to describe the story as presented are disjointed and unengaging. I was completely bored when the author listed off her relatives; I would have preferred to hear about only those relatives that we'd learn more about during the story like her parents, grandmother, and brother. There are random "editor's notes" sprinkled throughout the narrative that are a complete distraction from the story (and often unnecessary, as they simply restate what the author has already said). And the writing itself is only about as good as can be expected from an amateur teen girl.The Holocaust was a terrible period in our world's history. And the atrocities committed by the Nazis during that time are downright repulsive. I fully understand the importance of making that history known so I'm not trying to diminish the subject matter in any way. I'm sure these journals are a treasured family heirloom. But to publish them...? If this family's intention was simply to share Nonna's story, perhaps a family member should have used her diaries to create a more cohesive book *about* the contents of the journals.

This story is both riveting and nauseating...and I loved it! It's got all the elements that Picoult fans have come to expect; a controversial premise, a legal/moral question, and immaculate character development. The book does include a graphic account of the Holocaust which is not for the faint of heart. But it makes the story that more powerful. My advice: read in short spurts to allow yourself time to process the story. I had a feeling of almost despair through much of this book which speaks volumes about the quality of Picoult's work. Don't miss this one!!

I downloaded this book after reading the synopsis because it sounded like an entertaining read. What I found, though, was that the author tried to pack too much plot into too short of a novel. The result was a lot of "half-baked" ideas that seemed slapped together. To top it off, I found the dialogue and interaction between the protagonist and her love interest to be very artificial; I couldn't picture any two adults actually having any of those conversations or exchanges.

When I want to kick back and enjoy a book that is well-written but doesn't require a ton of thinking, I turn to Stephanie Bond. Her books are zany, light-hearted, and fun. And Party Crashers was no exception. She has a knack for delivering readers a solid plot full of memorable and likable characters. Kudos on another fun read!

...I would certainly try another book by this author. A troubled marriage, a tragic loss, and a widow trying to pick up the pieces; the story had all the makings of a solid dramatic novel. But then unexplained things began happening and the main character begins to think she's losing her mind. Several other reviewers commented that the story was predictable but I have to disagree. I had no idea what was going on and even after the big reveal near the end, it still didn't make sense of all the odd occurrences along the way. I liked the themes in the story. I liked Howzell's writing style. And I felt that she did a good job of painting a portrait of grief. But the "mystery" in the story came across as a bit to far-fetched (even fantastical) for my taste.One other thing bothered me about this book. The author made it a point on several occasions throughout the story to bring up the fact that Nicole (the main character) is black. I thought it was an odd choice because each time she interjected it, it stuck out like a sore thumb. Her race had nothing to do with the story or the emotions behind it. She could have been black, white, or purple for all I cared. I just didn't understand why the author kept mentioning it.

This story drew me in from the first few pages. From the get-go, readers have a clear understanding that Christmas is important and Malone continues that theme throughout the book by highlighting family milestones and events in relation to Christmas time. The story follows the characters over the course of about 40 years and the readers get to see them grow and evolve.About halfway through the book, I started to get annoyed with the style. Malone lost me with all his "recapping." Since we only checked in with the characters at Christmas (and often with years in between chapters), he was left listing off all the events the reader missed in between chapters. It left me feeling disconnected from the story and the people it was about.But I kept going. And by the end, I was weeping--thank goodness I finished the book at home where only my husband and dogs could see/hear my tears! When the book ended, I was confused at my reaction. If I wasn't feeling engaged by the style of the book, then how could I have such a strong emotional reaction to the end? What could the author have done differently to keep me engaged throughout the book--not just at the beginning and end?I think the book would have been more effective for me if the chapters were not set with Christmas day as the "present" every time. Yes, Christmas was an integral part of the story. But I think the same would have been true regardless of what date each chapter was told from. Getting to see some of the big events that we missed between chapters--rather than just reading a brief recap of what had happened since the last Christmas--would have kept me more engaged throughout the book. But I'm probably just being nit-picky.I'm giving this book 4 stars overall because it got me to cry. So clearly the author did something right, in my opinion. It was a beautiful story full of well-developed and (mostly) likeable characters. And I'd recommend it to anyone who likes epics.

I scooped this book up immediately after finishing Perry's book "Playing for Keeps" (which I really liked). Based on my first read by her, I was expecting this one to be much the same; an entertaining "romantic comedy" storyline with likable characters. Unfortunately, the book just didn't deliver.The main characters were not especially likeable (or believable) and several of the plot developments had me scratching my head wondering on what planet this would actually happen. The supporting characters were one-dimensional and cliche. And Perry failed to create the chemistry between the protagonist and her love interest that I had loved so much in her last book. (Ditto for the chemistry between the characters involved in the secondary romance that develops partway through the book.)Based on this book alone, I would have rated it one star. But I gave it two stars because I see now that it's book three of a 4-book series. And I can't help but wonder if I'd have more of an attachment to the characters and their back story if I'd read the first two books. However, I was so underwhelmed by this one that I wouldn't dream of spending any amount of time reading the others in the series.

I felt like the author tried to explore too many plot lines at the same time. And unfortunately, the end result was a too-dramatic-to-believe novel full of one-dimensional characters that I never really got to connect with. While most of the story is told from Christine's perspective, a few chapters are told from the viewpoint of other characters, including Uncle Harry and Christie's boyfriend Connor (whose voices were almost indiscernible from each other!). The story would have been more effective if some of the sub-plots were eliminated to allow the characters time to process the various layers of drama thrown their way. Overall, it seemed half-baked to me, which was a huge disappointment, especially when it came to Christine's budding romance; I found myself not anticipating or caring if they got together at all.

If you're looking for plot twists and an ending that leaves you thinking, "Whoa, I did NOT see THAT coming!" then this one is not for you. It's a formulaic romantic comedy; you can see the ending coming from a mile away. But, still, I found it to be an entertaining story with a host of quirky and likable characters. The chemistry between the protagonist (Gracie) and her best friend Pete is fun. I'd describe their romances as "unexpectedly steamy."

This was a fun, light read that featured not one but TWO murder mysteries plus a healthy dose of innocent romance. This was my second Stephanie Bond book and overall, I like her style. Her books are perfect when you want to unwind, be entertained, and not have to think too hard. My one complaint about this book is that readers are introduced to a fairly large cast of characters and I, for one, had a hard time keeping everyone straight. The three sisters at the heart of the story, for example, were very unique characters but it took me about half the book begin to remember which name went with which character. I'm not sure how the author could have improved on that, though, because the large cast created more intrigue when it came to the whodunit side of the story.

Based on the title, I was expecting a book about cloth diapering and maybe some yummy home-made baby food recipes. I got something completely different. Instead, the authors talked about "elimination communication" (letting your baby go diaper-less from even before his or her first birthday), "baby-led weaning" (from what I can gather, the concept that you should go directly from breast milk to solid foods), and "co-sleeping" (allowing your child to share a bed with you until he or she makes the decision to sleep alone). Overall I found most of what the authors said to be a bit too new-agey and unconventional for my taste. But perhaps I was biased by the section on breastfeeding.I am at the end of my first trimester during my first pregnancy and the concept of breastfeeding is creepy to me. I hoped that this book would discuss the pros and cons and open my mind to giving it a try. Discuss, it did...roughly 20% of the book was dedicated to lauding the benefits of breast milk. But open my mind, it did not. After much soul-searching and considering the "facts" (which seemed like anything but at some points), I have concluded that it's not for me. But my personal preference doesn't change that the authors were throwing around some absurd-sounding information to woo readers to their side. My personal favorite was around location 1735 when the authors said, and I quote, "Breastfeeding mothers, due to hormones, are most in tune with their babies. Compared to bottle feeders, they tend to move babies to safer positions, including on their back, away from pillows. Breastfeeding mothers are also more likely to position themselves in ways that prevent overlaying." I was offended by the implication that by bottle feeding, I am risking smothering my child in his or her sleep. Seriously?!All of the authors' arguments were along the same lines--very one-sided and seemingly not based in fact. The book did not cite any sources but rather listed a bunch of articles and books at the end. I'd love to know just where they got some of their "facts" from.The best piece of advice I found in this book was "...forget everything you've heard, everything you've read, and everything anyone has told you if it doesn't resonate with you" (Location 2646). And, unfortunately for these authors, that means I'll be forgetting about 98% of their book.

**SPOILER ALERT**I usually try to not include spoilers in my reviews but I can't talk about this book without addressing my dissatisfaction with the ending (and the build-up to the ending).I really liked Tekla in the beginning. She came across as ambitious, responsible, and mature. But my opinion of her changed pretty quickly when she took a job tutoring two entitled teens, Xander and Gemma. At first, the job seemed completely in character for her; she needed extra money to take care of added financial responsibilities related to her school, room, and board. But when she started the job, she realized that the kids didn't want help with their homework--they wanted her to do it all for them. And their parents and Tekla's boss from the tutoring agency supported that opinion. She whined to herself about how wrong it was, yet she continued to do it anyway.Next thing you know, her job is taking up far more of her time than she expected, thanks to Xander and Gemma's absent parents, and suddenly Tekla is shirking her responsibilities on Law Review as well as in her own studies. So what does she do? She lets her would-be boyfriend Markus--the "good guy" she's not interested in dating--do her work for her. After finishing the semester strong (thanks to Markus), she lands a coveted internship where she is asked to write opinions for a judge--again, hired to do all the work for someone else. It's a depressing premise that in "the real world" it's necessary to sell yourself out just to pay rent.There was a bit of a love triangle involved in the book. Tekla didn't seem to want anything more than friendship from Markus yet fawned over Julian, the personal assistant to Xander and Gemma's famous photographer mother. Julian is the stock "bad boy" whose sole job in the story it is to show Tekla that she really wants the good guy. Julian completely embodies all the ideals Tekla claims to be morally opposed to--selling oneself out for a paycheck. And by all rights, Tekla is "supposed to" end up with Markus in the end, based on the standard love triangle formula. But the author leaves it completely open-ended in the last chapter, referring only to a "boyfriend" but not his name.The author has created some very quirky and memorable characters, each with a strong and distinct voice. I would have liked to have seen more of a conclusion at the end. Based on several other reviews, though, it seems that this novel is perhaps the first of a series...? If so, I'm glad to know that readers may get more of a conclusion to this story. But even so, I'm not sure I'll be picking up book 2.

If you can get past the fact that the plot line is absurd, it's an entertaining and light read. It begins with a widow winning the lottery and offering her two 30-something commitment-phobic children $8 million each if they produce grandchildren for her within a year. The two immediately kick into high gear trying to conceive or adopt before the deadline. The story is funny at times but always on the far-fetched side. The ending is a bit predictable once you've reached about the halfway point. But overall, it's a fun read.

It really is a shame that E.L. James' trilogy is linked to this novella. I read the original "Fifty Shades of Gray" and loved it. And after reading the stellar reviews of "Fifty Shades of Silver Hair and Socks" I figured I'd be in for a laugh-out-loud treat. I figured wrong.This book had all of the elements that readers were so appalled by when E.L. James wrote them--including explicit sex scenes and an "untraditional" relationship. Which I'm perfectly okay with, by the way. However, this story also lacked all the good attributes that made the original "Fifty Shades" so popular with its readers. The character development was about as good as it's going to get in a not-quite-60-minute read. Which means I didn't get to know the characters enough to really care what happened with them. The plot was completely lacking and the pacing of the story didn't adequately build any sort of tension or mystery.On the up side, I did chuckle out loud once during the story when I read the ground rules. But it was hardly worth the read.

This was the first Stephanie Bond book added to my library and certainly won't be the last. It was the perfect blend of suspense--kept me guessing until the end!--and romance--boy, was I rooting for Butler!Bond did a great job of painting three very distinct, very memorable characters in Beatrix, Natalie, and Ruby, which was important because the story was told from all three perspectives. The plot moved right along and I wasn't bored at any point.I'm giving this book 4.5 stars simply because the conclusion to the murder mystery was a little lackluster, in my opinion. Other than that, it's an enjoyable, light, even zany read. But take it for what it is. It's not a police procedural--don't expect a very realistic investigation of the murder. It's not a bodice-ripper--don't expect a gushy lovey dovey "romance novel." Come expecting to be entertained and you won't be disappointed.

Sometimes you just don't want to muddle through a book that makes you think. This book is perfect for those times. The characters were cliche, the dialogue was contrived, and the plot was so predictable that I could have easily read the first three chapters and written the rest of the storyline myself. I gave this book two stars because I appreciate a love story. But when you have a character-driven story, it's disappointing when the characters don't speak and behave in a realistic way. Thumbs down.

The book description mentioned the idea of "doing one kind thing for another person every day" and promised that the results were "sometimes funny, sometimes heartbreaking, and often brilliantly surprising." I found this story to be none of the above. The protagonist was one-dimensional and downright aggravating through most of the book, the plot was extremely predictable, and the story overall was a bore. This one was a miss for me.

Three very different narrators, each with a strong voice and memorable story....Song of the Orange Moons is a coming-of-age tale of two young girls who befriend the old widow next door. The imagery presented by the author and the emotions the story conjures up in readers will leave a lasting impression. It's not an action-packed book so if you're looking for a plot-driven novel, this one's not for you.

The main character drives to Canada to buy bubble bath in the middle of the night then decides to stay for a "30 day vacation from her life." The premise sounded absurd so I was expecting hilarity to ensue. But the humor just never came. Mara/Jane was selfish and completely unlikeable. Her husband Dan was clueless and needy. And the cast of characters we meet in Canada were neither entertaining nor memorable.

I completely agree with the other reviewers who have said that "My Temporary Life" was like two books in one. The first half was a heart warming coming of age story. I loved it! And then the author randomly jumps into the future of our main character's life and introduces us to his extremely unlikeable girlfriend. And the heart warming story deteriorates into a cheesy Lifetime movie with a predictable ending. I fail to see any connection between the first half of the book and the second half of the book. And I actually think the two halves were geared at totally different audiences. I give the first half of the book 5 stars. But my overall rating is only 2.5 because the author lost me entirely on the last half.

The fact that this book was poorly edited was a huge distraction to me...spelling, grammar, and punctuation mistakes abound and there were MANY instances of random words in italics for no apparent reason. The concept behind the story was a good one. But the dialogue was extremely forced and completely unrealistic through most of the story. And with a book like this where the dialogue IS the action, it's important to be able to get lost in the conversations.

The storyline started off strong in Part 1 when a car accident changes the lives of two families forever. I liked the prmise right away and was drawn in by the well-developed characters. Part 2 lulled me in to the languid love story turned love triangle...the light, airy romance was a good follow-up to the emotionally charged opening. After that, though, the sparkle of the novel wore off for me. Major events and conflicts were brushed over or rushed through and I felt the ending came too abruptly. I am giving this book 3 stars because the author really had a knack for witty dialogue and character development. An enjoyable read overall.

I love it! It offers me the ability to control my iPod using the steering wheel mounted radio controls. And it was about half the price compared to what my local Hyundai dealer wanted for the same product.

I wasn't wowed by the first book of this duo--Leaving Paradise. But, still, I read the sequel in the hopes that there was a happier ending in store for Maggie and Caleb. I was not disappointed in that regard. However, there was nothing really surprising about this read...no twists or turns or unexpected conflict. I'm at least glad I know the conclusion of the story.

I loved the idea of this book...Caleb and Maggie were dynamic characters who displayed a lot of very relatable emotions. Their relationships with their families seemed believable, though a little overly-dramatic at times. The thing I found distracting was the layer Elkeles added by including scenes at school. The relationships between Maggie and Caleb and thier friends--current and/or former--came across as unlikely and at times outlandish. The story could have been more effective if the author spent more time developing the handful of main characters (and their interactions with one another) than pulling in a motley crew of supporting characters. I also felt that much of the dialogue was forced and not very true-to-life. Finally, several of the "twists" were predictable by about 30% into the book. Still, I think I'll probably read the sequel in the hopes of getting the happy ending that Maggie and Caleb both deserve.

This light read packed a big punch! The author took on so many themes and emotions central to 20-somethings growing up and growing into the people they were meant to be. And while several of the plot lines and twists were trite, It was an enjoyable read. Though, I think younger readers--I'm 28--would likely enjoy the book more than I did.One topic I saw several other reviewers mention was the author's use of "episodes;" most seem to find the book choppy as a result of the brief scenes. I felt very much the same as I began reading but I quickly realized that the vingettes were effective in conveying a mood. Today's world is fast-paced and hectic...especially for young adults who are still searching for themselves and their places in life. The brief "episodes" reminded me of that throughout the book. I'm not sure if that was intentional on the author's part, but well done.

I'm not sure who this author's target audience is....the subject matter and language were "adult" in several of the stories yet the storytelling itself came across as juvenile. Take this for what it is--a light and entertaining read. If you're looking to be scared, look elsewhere.

I'm glad I didn't read the reviews before the book....I, like several other reviewers, was caught off guard by the religious overtones of the book. But by the time I realized I was reading Christian fiction, I was already hooked on the story. Had I known in advance, I likely would have passed over this book...and missed out on a great read! I loved the way the author wove the historical and present-day stories together. I loved the cast of characters she created--flaws and all. And I respected the way she presented all points of view surrounding this rare condition that is so personal to her. Had this book been a secular one, it would have earned 5 stars from me without a doubt....Christian fiction just isn't my cup of tea.

An inspiring and beautiful story of hope and love....  I respect that this is a Christian fiction novel but all the talk of God was very repetitive. I have taken away one star for that reason as I think the story would have been better with less of it. I have also taken away one star for the believability of the ending. I had a hard time seeing how Molly/Isabelle, for example, felt such an immediate and strong connection to siblings she never really knew. Overall the story was great and I was glad the siblings were reunited. I just wish the ending weren't wrapped up into such a cutesy little package.

From what I can tell from the half of this collection I read, Rivenbark is trying to be funny. Unfortunately it only came across to me as self-indulgant. Maybe the author should try her hand at stand up comedy instead. She'd probably be hilarious on a stage...I just don't want to read her act.
Just captivating....I found it incredibly easy to get wrapped up in this story and I fell in love with Jacob immediately. I look forward to more from Gruen.

I have no idea what so many people saw in this book. The basic storyline was good....single mom faces terminal cancer and her and her loved ones prepare for the end of her life. But the random tangents the author goes off on make the finished product seem disjointed and "slapped together." For example, the odd paranormal connection between the main character and her daughter is never explained and not fully developed. The characters are largely flat, the dialogue is completely unnatural, and many of the events (including the "rituals") are unbelievable to the point that they are downright laughable. I, too, lost my mom to cancer at a young age and I can't fathom moving on by meeting a new crush at her services! And despite the "Beach Book Festival" award, the only thing "beachy" about this novel is that it takes place near the beach. Overall, this story was an emotional journey that lost its luster after the first dozen or so pages.

This was my first Emily Sue Harvey novel and I am pretty sure it will be my last. I had no connection at all to the main character or any of the supporting characters. And I found no point to the story. So Sadie grows up one summer under the watch of her cold-hearted grandparents. So what? I have rated this two stars only because I liked the way the author phrased things. She'd make a beautiful poet but I'm not inclined to read another of her novels.

I bought this book when it had nothing but 5 star review. As I began reading, I was pretty bored, though....even considered throwing in the towel at about 30%. But I kept thinking back to all those 5 star reviews, certain that if I just stick it out it'll all be worth it in the end. At around 45% I FINALLY started to get into the story. And by the end, I was teary with emotion. I had a hard time connecting with any of the characters but  really appreciated the themes central to the story....survival in the face of turmoil, the importance of family, and knowing when to admit you're wrong.

I picked up this book immediately after reading the first two books in the Lake Shore Chronicles. This one, though, will be the end of the line for me. I truly love Wiggs' characterization--she has yet to create a character I didn't connect with. But the plot line is getting old. The Lake Shore Chronicles all seem to be about rekindling an old flame or finally getting 'the one that got away.' The story of Avalon has reached a point where I am feeling like if I've read one, I've read them all. I don't plan to read the rest of this series.

Having just finished "Summer at Willow Lake" (and falling in love with the Olivia/Connor romance) I dove right into "The Winter Lodge," which I heard was book 2. Wiggs has created an ecclectic and largely likeable cast of characters in the quaint town of Avalon and combines just the right amounts of drama, romance, and mystery to keep me reading. There are 8 books in the series and from what I've seen thus far, you don't necessarily have to read the first book/s for the other/s to make sense.
What a quaint little story! The plot was predictable at times but it was such a relaxing, enjoyable read that it didn't even matter. I loved the chemistry between Olivia and Connor!

For such a short novel, this book took me forever to wade through because it felt like the story wasn't going anywhere. After pages and pages of slow-moving plot, it concluded abruptly in a flurry of nonsensical explanations that left me just as confused as the characters. Perhaps the most baffling part is how this book managed to earn 4- or 5-star reviews from all its reviewers before me....

I think (I HOPE) that Aunt Lydia's character was meant to be absurd. So thinking about her in that light, she was wonderful and truly the (only) saving grace of this novel. Other than the wackiness that ensued whenever Aunt Lydia entered a scene, there was nothing good about this story.The conflicts presented (abuse, oppression, sickness, alcoholism, etc) were handled in a very elementary way; the solutions offered up by the auther were all very predictable and didn't really leave me anticipating finding out how the book would end.Despite the fact that the story was predictable, I had a hard time finding anything believable in the book. I thought much of the dialogue was forced. I just could not picture anyone actually talking as these characters did...especially the women when they were discussing their abuse and/or marital problems. Same goes for the events in the book. For example, while psychic nights were hilarious to me, I couldn't see them happening in real life.Finally, the characters were unrelatable for me, personally. I didn't really connect with the women--almost all of whom are (or had been) abused. I found the women as a whole to be weak, which I think was exactly opposite what the author intended. And I didn't really care for the men who all fell into one of two categories--abuser or savior of women.The ONLY reason this book eked a second star out of me was because of the comedic relief sprinkled (sparingly) throughout.

The story was far more bizarre than anything I have in my library so maybe I am biased when I say that it was lousy. I'd like to think there is some underlying metaphor going on but if so...I completely missed it.

The storyline was a little like "Eat. Pray. Love." meets "PS, I Love You" then geared toward the young adult crowd. It's a story of self-discovery, first love, and moving on after losing someone important.
