This review is not against this particular brand as Solgar is consistently higher in quality. This review is a warning about taking 400 IU every day. Fat soluble vitamins are stored for several days (mostly in the liver) unlike water soluble vitamins. Large doses overload our storage space and gets stored in places that lead to stress or internal damage of organs and the nervous system. If you buy this high dose please consider not taking it two days per week (ex Tue and Saturday). Please read the following scientific data (not my personal opinion).Johns Hopkins Medicine:==> "Our study results do not support the use of high-dose vitamin E supplements.  If people are taking a multivitamin, they should make sure it contains no more than a low dose of vitamin E," said study lead author and internist Edgar R. Miller III, M.D., Ph.D., associate professor of medicine at The Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine.  "A lot of people take vitamins because they believe it will benefit their health in the long term and prolong life.  But our study shows that use of high-dose vitamin E supplements certainly did not prolong life, but was associated with a higher risk of death.""Vitamin E capsules, used as supplements, typically contain 400 IU to 800 IU.  The study results indicated that these high-dose supplements were associated with a higher risk of death."  <===Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDAs) for Vitamin E (Alpha-Tocopherol)0-6 months*(6 IU) 4 mg7-12 months*(7.5 IU) 5 mg1-3 years(9 IU) 6 mg4-8 years old(10.4 IU) 7 mg9-13 years old(16.4 IU) 11 mg14+ years old(22.4 IU) 15 mg(My opinion and some science) Solgar is a good brand. I caustion people against taking high doses of Vitamins E, A, D, and K because they are all FAT SOLUBLE vitamins (please research "Fat-Soluble Vitamins").Quick Facts...- Small amounts of vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin E and vitamin K are needed to maintain good health.- The body does not need these vitamins every day because it stores them in the liver and adipose (fat) tissue when not used.- Megadoses of vitamins A, D, E or K can be toxic and lead to health problems.- Fat soluble vitamins are stored (mostly) in the liver for use later when needed (like a camel).Many studies show issues such as organ damage, nerve damage, and increased mortality rates among people who regularly supplement 400 IUs or more of Vitamin E.This is a good brand because you do want "mixed E" but just not in high daily doses. Pleasae do a quick search on the term "full spectrum vitamin E". This Solgar product contains 4 out of the 8 derivatives of vitamin E (which is great). I think for the cost that is a great buy. Full spectrum E costs much more yet the benefits of having all 8 derivatives vs 4, if any, are still being researched. If you buy this dosasge try to skip it two days per week. Can be consecutive days or seperate days. This gives your liver time to release a little of its stores.I take 100 iu of E with my lunch five, six, or seven days per week. There are also 30 iu in my multivitamin which I do take every day (I only take a half dose of my multi each day). The average adult requires 30 (or 33) IUs per day (minimum). If you have a semi-healthy diet you are already getting some vitamin e in your food. Mega dosage of some vitamins and especially minerals can kill you slowly over time. Nerve damage and/or organ damage and/or heart failure can occur as well. But the autopsy will list cause of death as natural unless they have a reason to suspect fould play and look more closely at the cause of death.So don't feel the need to overdose on Vitamin E. You may cause more harm than good when you do. Don't follow the crowd. Follow the science. 100 -200 IU is more than enough for anyone. even though 100 - 200 IUs per day is still pretty high it did not show to cause premature death. 400 IUs or more did (according to science not according to my opinion). One 100 to 200 IU per day  of "mixed E"(or just four times per week) is honestly all you really need to reap the benefits unless you have been diagnosed with a medical condition that requires more. On the days you skip a dose the E stored in your fatty tissue will be realeased to cover your body's needs. This can be done over several days. So missing a day or two will make zero difference to your body regarding fat soluble vitamins.Some of the foods you eat also contain naturally occuring vitamin E. So please consider all of your sources and add them up to get a feel of how much E you are actually consuming daily and/or weekly. Too much E is not the same as too much C. Your body can tolerate and expell too much C. The damage being caused is such a slow process people don't realize it is happening.I am not trying to make anyone paranoid. You need Vitamin E. Short term gains from mega dosing (if any) are not worth the long term damage to your liver and nerves. However we are free to make our own decisions. I hope this review helps others to make an informed decision.Save some money. Save some time. Possibly extend your life by NOT taking more than 200 IUs per day. Don't just take my word. Search the web for "vitamin E dosage" or "Vitamin E side effects". Vitamin C is one of the suppliments that appears to cause no harm at high doses. All vitamins are not like vitamin C.SIDE NOTE: I encourage you to research "Side effects" of ANY substance you intend to purchase before you buy it (ex: vitamin e side effects).RECOMMEND PURCHASE OF VITAMIN E 100 IU or 200 IU OR BUY THIS PRODUCT AND SKIP A DOSE TWO OR THREE DAYS PER WEEK. I just purchased the Solgar 100 IU dose of "mixed E".

According to WebMD "Don't use royal jelly if you have asthma or allergies. It could cause some serious reactions, even death." I was astonished when I read this because I do have asthma. I foolishly ordered this product before doing the proper research. I just received the order yesterday. Fortunately I grew curious about "Royal Jelly" and decided to research it the day before my order arrived.I don't know if I would have any adverse side effects from the contents of this product but I am 100% appalled by the complete lack of warnings that are on the product page! If you sell a product for good reasons you should feel obligated to provide information or a link to information regarding potential hazards for some people.I don't view this as a conspiracy to sell goods. I do view this as negligence and reckless endangerment although I am certain the manufacturer has nothing but good intentions.WARN PEOPLE OF POTENTIAL HAZARDS WHEN YOU SELL TO THE PUBLIC!!! Do this and I will have no problem changing my rating (if that matters to anyone).I am going to contact a States Attorney General's Office about this issue IN GENERAL, not just about this product, because I am convinced that this is not an isolated incident. Once again I do not think the manufacturer is trying to hide anything or is being malicious for profit. At times the obvious can be easily overlooked such as warning people to allow them to make an informed decision. This is, in my professional view, a matter of Public Safety.A warning will prompt consumers to ensure the product is safe for them to use BEFORE they use it vs playing Russian Roulette. If someone does suffer adverse effects from this product the manufacturer is better protected from being sued out of business so it is also in their best interest to inform people of possible side effects.

I am currently 203 lbs and now would like to reach 198 lbs which is very doable thanks to this product without drastically adjusting my mostly healthy lifestyle.Once I achieve 198 lbs I will cycle off this product with the assumption that I will regain 2 or 3 pounds a couple of weeks after I fully stop taking this product.UPDATE (10/08/13) - Stopped using this product 2/3rds through second bottle (couple of months ago). Bottomed out at 201lbs. Additional use did not effect any change so I discontinued use. I am still amazed by this product for getting me down to 201. I regained 1 of the 10 pounds that I lost and that was it. I later started taking Creatine to increase my weight lifting. A known side effect of Creatine is weight gain due to water retention in the muscles. I went back up to 210 (but waist remained slimmer). When I cycled off Creatine my weight dropped down to 205 (not 202). The extra weight is muscle. I eat very healthy but I'm not a health extremists.TIPS -HIGHLY RECOMMEND not going through continuous bottles of this product.  If you can't resist doing so take at least two weeks off between bottles. If you lose 15 pounds and gain back 5 that is still great! I had a two bottle limit. If you take a short break your wallet, stomach, liver, and kidneys (to name a few) will thank you.EAT MORE FIBER - ex: High Fiber Oat Bran Cereal. I add cinnamon, honey, and flaxseed meal to my cereal - Baked sweet potato (I eat half of one) - dark green romaine lettuce - fiber one cereal -so forth. Look for enjoyable ways to increase your fiber intake. Honey, cinamon and high fiber foods often taste well together. Coconut oil goes well with fiber too. Personal tastes of course.PROTEIN POWDER - Buy a good quality protein powder. Drink 20 - 25mg with water first thing in the morning. Protein builds muscle. Muscle burns fat. Give your body the tools to naturally burn fat for you. If you are a little active your body needs .5mg (or so) per pound. So if you weigh 150lbs, your body needs 75mg per day. Quality powdered protein is a great way to help meet your protein needs without the unwanted calories.COMPLEX CARB POWDER - Excessive protein without carbs impacts your PH. Your muscle and bone tissue then release calcium to balance your PH. Average carb-to-proytein ratio is 2:1. 2 grams of complex carbs for every 1 gram of protein. The complex carbs I use are not the weight gainer products. They are listed near the top of this review.WALKS - short daily 15 minute good pace walk does wonders (on days you don't exercise).WATER - I don't drink soda or juice (I actually love water). Try to cut down on beer, juice, and soda as much as possible. I drink wine once every other week or so.CARBS ARE NOT EVIL - Excessive simple carbs are bad - complex carbs are good (not in excess) - people consume thousands of simple carbs and gain weight. Then extremists label carbs as evil. Excessive ANYTHING is bad for you. Excessive exercise damages joints yet no one calls exercise evil. Complex carbs digest slowly and is your body's fuel source.FADS ARE EVIL (well at least bad for you) - Each decade a different food or food type is labeled as deadly by some group of people and to be avoided at all cost. Ignore ALL extreme views and fads when it pertains to what you eat. Generally those who initiate these extreme views are either out to make a buck or feel an overwhelming desire to act like they know something without doing the proper research. I live by the monthly 80/20 rule. Up to 80% healthy food and exercise coupled with 20% of whatever I feel like enjoying. Please note I really enjoy the 80% too but the 20% is solely based on what will put the biggest smile on my face. It may happen to be something that is healthy or it may be chocolate ice cream. It just depends on my heart's desire during those moments that make up 20% of my monthly intake. The other 80% (or so) of eating I am more focused on health and pleasure vs only pleasure.ENJOY!!!
