Prior to using this vase for real flowers I loved this vase.  The colors were rich and vibrant, and the design was beautiful.  I have NO idea why the glass of this vase turned "milky" after having some water and flowers in it.  It's a vase - this should not happen.  What's worse is that the person who told me about this vase had the same thing happen to her after she put water and flowers in it.  She had previously had some decorative branches in it and had no problems.  Now both of us have vases that make us look like we don't care for the things we own.I recall reading a review from another design of vase also made by Amia where this was mentioned.  I thought it must be an isolated incident.  It's not...This is a VERY expensive vase to have this happen to.  I can't understand why this would happen.  A vase is supposed to hold flowers and water after all, isn't it?  I think Amia makes nice suncatchers and jewelry boxes, but stay away from their vases unless you never intend to put real flowers and water in it.

This flag has nice vivid colors and is a great one to display for St. Patrick's Day and as we get into spring. It's charming and doesn't look "kiddie" as some flags do. I use garden flags as an inexpensive way to change my seasonal look in the bathroom. This was a great purchase for that purpose. Toland makes several great flags that I proudly display in my home.

I am a left leg amputee so I don't stand in the shower and use this on the shower curtain rod which is what this was primarily intended for. But when I read that it worked on curved bars that are 1" in diameter I immediately measured my Moen 16" curved grab bar with shelf and sure enough it was 1". I ordered 2 of them and they hook on the curved grab bar with shelf like a charm. These hold my mesh bath pouf and other shower accessories that have a cord on them. As other reviewers have noted, this probably isn't the best choice for things like a washcloth. If there's a loop on your bath accessory it should work out just fine.IMPORTANT NOTE: This will only work with the Moen curved grab bar with shelf or other "lighter" grab bars made by Moen that are 1" in diameter and support up to 250#. Moen makes heavy-duty grab bars that support up to 500#, but these are 1.5" in diameter and will not work with this product. I see no reason it wouldn't work with other brands if grab bars so long as the are no larger than 1" in diameter.

Overall, this product is very helpful and works well. I recently had shoulder surgery and these have been very helpful for turning on/off a wide variety of appliances in my bedroom. The biggest downside I've discovered is that the rounded shape of the product prevents me from plugging in anything except a plug for something like a lamp or small fan below it. Even the very small USB adapter to charge my iPhone won't fit below one of these plugs. That is poor design to maximize use of an outlet. In the two months of relatively light use some of the writing is coming off of the remote. It's not a complicated remote so it's not that big of a deal, but I'm only handling this remote a couple of times each day.If the shape was more space efficient I would definitely given this five stars.

I am torn as far as how I like or dislike these votive flameless candles. On the plus side, the candles are slender so they fit even in narrow votive holders. They also have a good, strong light to them. The light goes all throughout the candle too. The batteries are easily replaced and are readily available. On the downside, these seem to flicker almost nonstop and it is not a subtle flicker either. I purchased these votives to place in clear votive holders that are in a decorative base. The "candlelight" doesn't even seem realistic at all in this setup. It seems to be more like Christmas tree lights that blink - really. However, when I put one of these in a metal-like votive holder it seemed to be more realistic. So if your aim is to use this in a clear or lightly frosted votive holder you may be disappointed. However, in a somewhat patterned or metal-like/medium to dark colored holder these may work out just fine. This is one of those products that depending on your needs it could be just okay or it could be outstanding. In my case these are working out okay at best. I will continue to look for this type of candle, but with a much more subtle flicker. Once I find flameless votive that is a better fit I will likely give these away as gifts in an individual colored/metal-like votive holder.

What I love the most about this garden flag is that it doesn't have that typical garden flag look. This actually looks like a painting that you would expect to see in a frame. The colors are beautiful and rich. I purchased this is an inexpensive way to seasonally change the look in my second bathroom. Toland actually makes several garden flags that have the "painting" feel to them rather than a typical garden flag feel. This would make a fine and affordable gift that I think almost anyone would enjoy having in their home or garden/yard. Highly recommended!

I am an above knee amputee of 26 years who recently had rotator cuff surgery and currently have my arm in a very immobilizing sling. Since I have to take potent pain medication to aid in my recovery I don't necessarily want to be transferring myself too many times in and out of my wheelchair during the night if I need to use "the facilities." Missing my left leg and having extremely limited use of my left arm at this time creates a significant safety concern. So I borrowed a commode from a family member to keep in my bedroom and purchased these liners based on reviews here on Amazon. These were easily the most expensive liners I saw at the time, but they are the "gold standard" in liner bags as far as I'm concerned. Like many people, I'm somewhat hesitant to believe everything I read in the reviews, but all of the reviews I read were dead on accurate. I lined the bottom of my commode bucket with a product commonly known as "shop towels on a roll" to absorb any moisture that might leak through the bag. That was over three weeks ago and I have yet to need to change those "shop towels." I have not had one leak at all. I keep a 2 gallon bucket with a lid next to the commode and can fit about five of these in there before needing to empty it. They do not smell one bit. The most I do for odor control is a quick spritz of Lysol.I also read a review from someone who stated they use this in their RV. I own a travel trailer and could easily see where these would come in very handy, especially during long road trips when emptying the black tank may not be so easy to do.Highly recommended and worth every single penny.

This is an inexpensive way to display garden flags in a different way. It certainly is nothing fancy, but is functional. However, the stopper does not firmly fit on the dowel and it would only take a very, very light breeze for the stopper to come off of the dowel, thus allowing your flag to fall to the ground. My recommendation would be to either use this only in areas where there would be no breeze, such as an enclosed patio or even in your home, or to permanently put a flag on it and superglue the dowel into the stopper. Used in the ways I've recommended would make this a four or five star product.

I've worn Keens for 10 years, but new versions of the Keen Newport pinched my little toe no matter what I did so I tried this style after the Keen Whisper left me without any real arch support, not to mention how narrow they are.The recommendation on the Amazon page (and the Keen home page) for the Venice was to buy a half size larger.  I wear 8.5, so I ordered the 9 - they were like water skis.  So then I sent them back and got 8.5 - better, but the arch support didn't line up that great and for this money they need to fit perfect.  I decided I'd try one more time and got the 8 - SO glad I did.With regard to the shoe itself, I like that the footbed isn't like the Keen of old where there was a leather topper on that which retained smells no matter what you did.  These easily wash up and look great each time.  I wash them with Sport Suds, though I imagine any detergent will do.Since purchasing these in Petrol/Twilight I've purchased 3 other colors - all within a 2 month period.  They are the only footwear I've worn all summer.  Perfect for walking, cycling and other activities, yet they look cute with a cotton dress-down capri pant or jean skirt too.  I get comments all the time like, "Where'd you get those?  They look SO comfortable."  When they ask how much they cost I sometimes get comments like, "You paid WHAT for those?" But for quality footwear you have to be willing to pay more.  That's the way it goes with quality.  If these are as hearty as my first pair of Keens they will easily last me 4-5 years - small price to pay for quality and comfort if you ask me.  No sense in penny wise, pound foolish.I'm an amputee (left above knee amputee, with prosthesis) and I need to protect the only foot I have left.  I am willing to pay good money for footwear so long as they are quality, supportive items and these certainly have been.  I can easily work all day in them, then go grocery shopping, and for a walk without once saying, "man, time to get these off!"  As an amputee I am SO picky about footwear, so any shoe getting my endorsement I feel is a winner.  Your experiences may vary, but it's certainly worth a try in my opinion.So again, just because the product write-up recommends a half size larger that it doesn't necessarily mean it will work for you - half size smaller is what I personally needed.  When Amazon is the retailer they almost always provide free returns on footwear within 30 days so if you don't know your size for this exact sandal I suggest you use Amazon as the retailer on here, at least until you know what size really works for you.  Some colors that Amazon sells are not directly through them, so be aware that you may have to pay return shipping if they don't work.
A great find for use in my very small travel trailer where space is limited. Stays on the cabinet nicely and is at the ready. Bronze finish looks rich on oak cabinets. Highly recommended!

I went back and forth wondering whether to get this clutch/cross body purse or a "regular" Broncos purse.  I'm SO glad I went with this one since the new NFL stadium regulations indicate that ALL bags must be clear and no larger than 12x12x6.  Many things that used to be allowed in no longer will be, but this shouldn't be a problem since you can also have a clutch that's about the size of the palm of your hand (which this is).  It will easily hold a small point and shoot camera, cell phone and some money.  The backside, which is clear, doesn't do much for me and is supposed to be there for easy access phone use, but my iPhone 5 doesn't fit well in there - I keep it under the front blue flap with the Broncos logo instead.Can't wait to use it at a Denver game this year along with the NFL Clear Ultimate Carryall Bag.  A cute, useful accessory that I feel is pretty reasonably priced (vs. what you'd pay on the team's website).

I wasn't necessarily seeking a watch with this level of function on it - I just wanted a fairly solid watch to wear when I'm camping or doing other outdoor activities and don't want to worry about being rough.  It wasn't too hard to set, but don't toss those directions out - you'll need them in the future, esp. if you want to use more of the functions. I haven't tried the other functions given that my intended use is for a no-nonsense, inexpensive yet solid outdoor watch that doesn't require batteries.  When I first received it and set it up I had it charging in pretty direct light for about 3 hours.  When I woke up the next morning there were no numbers/characters on it at all - I was bummed thinking that I bought junk.  I turned my bedside light on and within a few moments the watch was displaying the correct time.  About once a week I make sure it gets several hours of solid sunlight to keep it fully charged.  It's worked flawlessly since then.  I often wake with the numbers not showing and this seems to be a power saving kind of mode - again, within moments of even dim light the numbers appear.The only things I'm not thrilled about, but can easily live with, are that it's kind of big for a women's watch and the wrist band could be a bit more comfortable.  Recommended.I purchased on Amazon from a retailer other than Amazon who offered it with free shipping so I didn't have to make a $25 order for free shipping.  It arrived within 3 days.  I liked that option since there are times I just don't have anything I want/need to take advantage of super saver shipping.

I am a dyed-in-the-wool Denver Broncos fan and had purchased a Broncos product here and this came up as a recommendation.  What a fabulous value at what I paid (a Jackson and a Lincoln).  It's got a nice wide seat that is pretty well reinforced in the seat area.  A "solid", but not overly "solid" person could safely use this chair (says 300, but I wouldn't go much above 250 to be on the safe side and to maximize chair life - and definitely do not "plop" into it).  It has nice little extras such as the cup holder, side pocket for small items and the insulated cooler sleeve on the left arm.  It won't hold a 6 pack, but it would easily hold 2-3 beverages with a small blue ice freezer block in it to keep it really cold.  Overpacking it would cause too much stress on the zipper and it's not meant to hold enough for a 3 hour game - stock back up at halftime.  Don't count on that cooler sleeve to be as good as a "real" cooler for an entire day of cold storage, but for a few hours with that ice block your beverages or small food items it's a great item.  It fits back into the storage bag easily and the bag even lets others know what team you pull for.This is a chair that you'll want to make sure someone keeps an eye on if you have to step away for a little bit - count on it to be gone if you leave it unwatched since it's that nice of a product.  Perfect guest seating for a "fan cave" that can fold up to be out of the way and go with you wherever you'd like.I like it so much I might even buy one for a Giants fan I know - may the best Manning win!

I have an iPhone 5 and an iPod Touch 5 (I know it seems redundant, but different products for different needs).  I chose the orange case for the iPod Touch and think it's a great case for protection against scratches and minor drops.  I would NOT recommend this product for a "tween" or teen, for someone who is clumsy or somewhat careless - get an Otter Box for those folks.  But for those of us who are slipping the device into a purse or bag and just want a little protection for the screen and/or for an occasional drop it is fine.  I like that it's offered in a variety of colors.  I actually am about to order one for my iPhone - I ordered a similar case for my iPhone and the phone slipped out the same day and gratefully only a small corner of the phone had a little ding in it that didn't damage the phone itself.  Though it's a pretty snug fit at first I know my iPhone will NOT slip out of this and the much thinner iPod Touch hasn't budged a bit in this case.  Having a variety of colors means I'll grab the right device and the magnetic closure works well.  I've ordered many an iPod/iPhone case since these devices came out and I truly, truly like this brand the best.

This book is written for the ultra novice regarding RV's/travel trailers.  It is NOT for someone who has already purchased one and wants to learn a little more about how the unit works.  This guides the reader through the different types of units available, sometimes to the point of inane obvious comments.There is a small section that was somewhat beneficial in explaining the workings of the unit itself which is what I was aiming for.  That being said, I have an app for my iPod Touch (RV Ref) that I got for a whopping dollar that explains things far more extensively.The campground listing is sparce, outdated and really not useful.The information found in this book can be obtained by talking to other RV owners, picking up an RV magazine somewhere, looking up things on the internet and by purchasing a few apps related to RV's - some are even free.Not the worst book around, but even for me as a first time unit owner it was written on a far too elementary level.  It's outdated and better resources at reduced prices or even free are available nowadays.  Try those first.

Expecting a Bose-level of sound?  Keep looking.  But if you're looking for a small little speaker to enjoy on a day trip, camping trip or next to the pool this is a great little product for the price.  I like how the 3.5mm cord is built right into the unit and am even more pleased that this operates off of 2 AAA batteries.  I like to use rechargeable standard sized batteries rather than an internal battery that has to be plugged in and charged up.  Once these batteries die down you can just replace them with a spare set of AAA rechargeables rather than wait hours for it to charge up.  If I'm camping there's often no place to plug things in to charge up - use of standard sized batteries addresses this issue and rechargeables keep it more environmentally friendly.I played "Don't Come Around Here No More" by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers on my Sony 5.1 surround sound home theater system and then on this.  Obviously the Sony blew it out of the water and I was able to hear little background tones in the song much better.  However, if I was at a state park having a picnic for the day I'd be very pleased with listening to my music on this.I wish it had a FM tuner on it though, but I'm not going to knock down the star rating over this.  For the insanely low price I paid I'm pleased and think this would be a nice gift for a "tween" or someone who is on the go a lot and enjoys their music, but isn't a critical audiophile.  I may even pick up a second one just to have on hand for myself.  The vendor I used via Amazon had quick delivery.  Very satisfied.

For the price this isn't necessarily a bad case.  It's no Otter Box by any means, but as a responsible adult who won't let children even hold the device it would be fine for my overall needs.  That being said, I won't be using it.Pros:1.  Reasonably priced - worth a shot at this price point, but once you get it you may find it looks pretty chintzy.2.  Reasonable protection for the careful user - along with a good screen protector will probably be fine for most adults.  I wouldn't trust it for clumsy adults, clumsy teens or anyone in the "tweens" or younger category - if you're considering for those users I'd definitely spend more for the Otter Box.3.  The covers for the lightning charger and earbud jacks are nice and will keep those areas free of debris.4.  Stand holds nicely horizontally which is nice for watching your own videos, YouTube, etc.5.  Was able to use the power and volume buttons easily.Cons:1.  Stand is not very secure at all when vertical and this is the mode I want it in the most for signaling to my Bluetooth speaker.  When I have a playlist on and want to go to a different song or playlist I end up holding the unit.  Given the sensitive touch needed on the Touch I shouldn't have to do that.  After looking the case over quite a bit I'm not sure why they couldn't have made this a little bit wider - I don't think it would have impacted its performance - it probably would have markedly improved it.  This is my biggest gripe about the product.2.  Stand seems pretty fragile and was not easy to loosen from the main part of the case.  I was sure I would end up breaking it, but once I got one side loosened a bit I used my library card to gently slide around the rest of it for fear I'd put too much pressure on it with my own hands.  I have not secured it entirely back into the slot and leave it loose - I know it will break very quickly if I don't.3.  Rather cheap looking.  No one will say "where'd you get the neat Otter Box with a stand like that?"4.  The silicone doesn't feel like it has a good grip in my hands.  Not awful, but not as secure feeling as my Amazon Basics 4th Generation Touch skin was.I don't regret giving this case a try given the inexpensive price.  It's not a horrible product, just not the right product for me - it might be the ideal solution for others though.  The next person I know who gets a 5th Generation Touch will probably be offered it free of charge.  I think as more people purchase the 5th Generation Touch there will be better cases with more secure stands.  I'm actually happier with an inexpensive orange skin I purchased and a small folding stand I purchased when I bought my 4th Generation Touch that allows me to have the Touch in vertical or horizontal mode.  I was hoping this one product would take care of both needs, but for me it didn't - your results may be very positive, but mine are neutral at best.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:  JANUARY 2013I ordered this at the same time I ordered the new iPod Touch and installed it as I pulled the fake screen off of the iPod itself so I didn't even have to use the enclosed screen cloth.  It went on easily enough and I had no bubble problems.  But the screen is just so grainy looking.  I'm not a professional photographer, but have some of my very good professional-level published pictures I uploaded from my computer on the iPod.  This screen protector just doesn't do those photos any justice because it's grainy.I was showing the new Touch to my sister and her first words within seconds were "why is this so grainy?  Your pictures really don't pop out like they did on the other one."  I have no doubt that this will keep the screen from being scratched by the careful user and it seems durable - as such I don't think it's a bad product necessarily, but I'm not as pleased with it as I was with Armor Shield for my 4th Generation iPod Touch.  I had to use the cloth once in a while for fingerprints, but I'd rather do that and have my pictures come through the way they should.  The 5th generation is supposed to have the retina display, but you'd never know it with this (in my opinion anyway).If your primary use is to get some of your e mails, play a game here and there and other things that don't really make a huge difference in appearance then this is probably a good product for you.  For those using the iPod to have their photo collection on, watching video, etc., I'd suggest a clear screen protector instead.  No regrets in trying it - it's all about how the product fits your needs and this one just doesn't fit mine.UPDATED REVIEW:  MAY 2013 (original review gave 3 stars, now upgrading to 5 stars)I had been meaning to update this a little sooner.  After I wrote my review I was contacted by the company who offered to replace the matte finish with the clear finish - I received it very quickly and am very impressed with the company's commitment to customer service.  The clear finish shows fingerprints more than the matte finish, but also allows your pictures to really "pop" out more with the retina display.  The kit comes wtih a cleaning cloth anyway so it really isn't a big deal.  A quick swipe against a soft cotton T-shirt cleans up the screen nicely too.My overall recommendation:  If your primary use for the iPod Touch is to use some apps, access the internet, general "messing" around with, etc., then I'd probably recommend the matte finish since it is good about concealing fingerprints.  If you use your iPod Touch for showing photos then I'd recommend the clear finish - your pictures will come through much more nicely.  Both products are quality, as is the manufacturer.  The difference is in what your primary device use is for.

When I ordered my new iPod Touch 5th Generation I also ordered the Ionic SLIM FLEX Case for The New iPod Touch New HTC Droid DNA (Blue) since I wanted a skin for the device for a nice grip and it seemed to get overall good reviews.  I didn't like it at all since it was still rather rigid and just didn't fit the device nicely.  It also didn't feel nice with the textured sides.Though several people gave this Evecase a less than ideal review, I decided to try it and am glad I did.  It's the closest thing I've found to the AmazonBasics Silicone Case with Tread for iPod touch 4th Gen (Black), but not quite there.  It most assuredly isn't nearly as rigid as the Ionic Slim Flex case, but just needs a bit more substance to it like the Amazon Basics case for the 4th generation model had.  I'm hoping that an Amazon Basics 5th Generation Touch skin will be available soon.The cutouts lined up nicely and I have a small external speaker that plugs directly into the headphone jack - no cord, just the speaker and jack.  The other case didn't allow this speaker to fit, but this one does.  I've had no problems using the power button or volume buttons at all.  I like the standout orange color against the black of the Touch too - looks sharp.This is certainly no Otter Box by any means and if you're seeking something to provide breakage protection this is NOT the product for you.  But if you're looking for an easy to slip on/slip off silicone skin that provides a pretty decent grip at a good price then this is worth the price.  It was also delivered VERY quickly - within 4 business days from California to Central New York.

While this case isn't inflexible, it's not as flexible as I wanted it to be.  It's a bit on the rigid side and I don't find the ridges on the side of it to be comfortable at all.  The cut out for the camera is fine, as are the ones for power and volume.  That being said, I realize that the 5th Generation Touch is pretty new and there aren't as many reasonably priced skins out there yet such as the one made for the prior version by Amazon Basics which I find to be very comfortable.  I'm hoping that Amazon will be making one for this model very soon.  On the upside, the blue is a nice shade and it looks sharp against my black iPod, but I'm more about the function of it than the fashion of it.  For now it'll do...

Obviously, the primary intended use of this product is to cover foods in odd shaped containers without lids or when a lid has been lost or damaged.  I use them for this purpose, but the way I like to best use them is to keep dust out of things that I may not use all the time, such as my  OXO Good Grips 3-Piece Stainless-Steel Mixing Bowl Set or on my Crock Pot SCR450-PT 4-1/2-Quart Slow Cooker, Black Demask Pattern.  This keeps my kitchenware ready to go without having to wash them out first because they've been sitting around for a bit - doesn't take long at all for dust to build up.  I use the large ones with the red band for these things.  The medium size (green bands) will cover most 2 serving sized dishes and has also worked well as a cover for Progressive International Collapsible Mini Colander.  I'm rather disappointed that there's only one small size (blue band) though since I've thought of several ways to use these.  I purchase them at the big national chain store with the smiley face logo for a fraction of this cost.

I was a bit hesitant on how sturdy the overall form of this tub would be given that it collapses - I was pleasantly surprised.  The plastic top and bottom are extremely sturdy and the grey collapsible section is strong as well.  I've been using it to soak and hand wash more delicate items.  I fill it to just below the top of the grey section at the sink and then carry it to a corner out of the way for a while.  There is no shifting to the solid plastic whatsoever as I carry it and it never feels as if it's going to give out.  In fact, I think it's equally as solid as a traditional dishpan and certainly more handy.  I will primarily use this at my apartment, but own a travel trailer - it will be great to be able to use it in the same manner and then be able to compact it for saving space.  At my apartment I typically leave it expanded since I feel that any product manufactured in such a manner will last longer if not continually stressed by expanding and collapsing.

These pieces aren't as solid as I had hoped them to be.  They aren't of horrible quality and my main reason for purchase was to have a set of microwave items for my travel trailer.  If I were going to be using this on a regular basis in my home I don't think I'd be too happy.  But I think for my specific purpose it will be fine.  I bought a few other Starmaid pieces too and am equally as neutral on those - they'll work OK for occasional needs while on the road - good enough.I had hoped to be more impressed by the set so I could get some pieces to use in my home - not going to happen with Starmaid microwave pieces.  Too bad since they have reasonable prices, but now I think I'm realizing why...

I've only owned this for 30 minutes and I already know I'm selling it back to Amazon since I'd pretty much lose money by sending it back for a refund.  Recycled recipes, way too big, just not what I was looking for, but bought it based on all of these 5 star reviews.  I'm glad it's worked out for those people, but for me it's not a good fit at all.  Anyone with any degree of food creativity can come up with similar recipes.  I suppose the best way to go is eat more whole foods since they fill you up better anyway and eat less processed foods.  This one is loaded with processed things.  Thanks, but no thanks.Lesson learned for myself:  If I desire to purchase a cookbook online make sure I've thumbed through a friend's copy first or go to a Barnes and Noble and look through it there.  Amazon's prices are almost always better, but not if you're spending it on something that ends up being a dud for you.  Personally, I have my grandmother's old, old cookbook from the 1930's and 1940's - while lard isn't something we use as a main ingredient these days, at least the recipes are real and can be updated on your own for current cooking practices.All this book did hungry-wise for me is make me hunger for my money back.

I own the full blown hardcover version of this book that also contains the garden center items and find it to be one of the most useful items I own.  So when my nephew started an electrician's training course at his high school I thought this would be a great item for him.  It is great from a reference point of view, but from a user-friendly point it really isn't.  The book is small and the print tends to start to go a lot toward the inner crease/binding, making the book something you have to almost flex back in order to read comfortably.  It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that in time doing that repeatedly will cause pages to fall out.  It might be good for a quick reference once in a very great while, but if you think you might reference this pretty regularly I'd recommend the larger book so it will last.  I wish my larger book didn't have the garden center part since I really don't need that, but that seems to be the only way to get a durable copy of this book and is worth having the extra pages and size for that reason alone.  I've purchased 2 "very good" rated copies of the full version here on Amazon for literally less than a footlong sub each at Subway.

...but it's worth every penny for my athletic clothing.  When I received this I didn't think 40 loads were contained inside.  The small scoop inside really does do the job and is more than adequate for my athletic wear washing needs, you may need 2 scoops at times depending on your needs.  I have deliveries from Amazon made to work and a colleague scoffed at the idea of paying what I did for this product.  I figured it out to be a little less than $.50/load.  Considering the price all of us pay for Under Armour, REI and other athletic wear I find that to be an incredibly small price to pay to get residual odors out, keep them from coming back and extending the life of my clothing.  I wasn't thrilled with the product after my first load since there still seemed to be some leftover unpleasant scents, but ran the load a second time and was amazed with the results.I know there are several other similar brands of detergent out there and this was the one I chose based upon reviews of other Amazon users.  Thoroughly and completely pleased and I probably won't try another brand unless I hit one heck of a low price.

My title pretty much says it all.  I don't like putting my refrigerated pizza directly on the rack of my oven because there have been some instances where cheese has dripped on the bottom of the oven and that's not the easiest to clean up.  This allows the pizza to cook nicely and get a relatively crispy bottom without the mess.  This won't work for the larger pizzas that you can purchase in the refrigerated section, but great for a 12" pizza for 2-3 people.  It cleans with ease, but as with most bakeware a good towel drying is needed to prevent rust from eventually forming.  I just let it sit in my dish rack for about 30 minutes and get any excess water droplets when I wipe it down.The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars is because I think there are other pans that have aeration holes that are a bit larger which makes it crispier.  That being said, I have almost all Good Cook bakeware in my home with a couple of Oneida pieces.  I am very pleased with nearly every piece in the Good Cook bakeware product line and is the reason I chose to go with what I felt would be a pretty safe bet.  No regrets.  I'd love to see them come out with a pan for a 16" pizza too.

My Mom had her knee replaced recently and this was the same exact cold pack that the rehab facility used.  It conforms very nicely to any part of the body and is nice and big.  She loved it and I looked it up online while she went to PT one day using my iPod Touch Amazon app at the rehab facility.  The price is very reasonable (from the vendor I used anyway) and it was delivered to my Mom in less than 4 days.  She loved it so much she wanted a second one.Update:  October 2012 - My Mom still uses these daily and are holding up well.  However, vendor price has increased substantially since I purchased it, so I'm glad I bought these when I did.

I have the good fortune of living only minutes away from Sherrill, NY, the home of Oneida Limited.  I found the Good Cook loaf pans, all three sizes, at the factory store and bought a 5x3 pan since I had recently found a recipe for a single loaf that size and wanted to try it in my GE Countertop Oven.  The pan performed beautifully with a light coating of non-stick spray.  The bread cooked evenly and with a beautiful golden crust and literally slid out of the pan.  It wasn't long before I was back at the factory store and purchasing the other two sizes of loaf pans along with pretty much every other piece of bakeware imagineable that they had which I'd find useful.  Using my Good Cook pieces makes me want to bake and cook a little more knowing how well they perform and clean up.Though they could sustain some light and deliberately thoughtful use from metal utensils, the product line will clearly last longer if non-stick utensils are used with them.  I don't know how these perform in a dishwasher, but they hand wash beautifully.  I use a sponge that has a "grittier" side that is safe for non-stick cookware and bakeware to help remove any residual non-stick spray.  Hand drying after use is recommended to prevent rust from eventually starting to form.  The non-stick surface is an anondized type, not the older style that often peeled off.I've been impressed with all of the pieces of the Good Cook metal bakeware I've used thus far.  It was great to replace my heavy and harder to store glass pieces I had with these lighter, quality pieces.  The only items of Good Cook bakeware that I'd steer away from are the larger cookie sheets.  The smallest one is good and firm, but the larger cookie sheets tended to have a little shifting to them when I twisted them at the ends.

This is probably the largest spoon rest I've ever seen.  I couldn't believe the size when I opened it up.  Every conceivable utensil will be able to fit easily on this, in many instances 2 or even 3.  It's lightweight and nothing fancy, but it's a quality product at a good price.  I'm an apartment dweller, but have a full size stove/oven so it fits on top of the stove nicely.  Other apartment dwellers with efficiency size stoves/ovens may not be able to do the same safely.Update:  Found this at a Dollar Tree store recently for the obvious price.  Picked up a couple more - still not a bad deal on here though.

Overall, I like this product.  It's simple and slim to store.  I love to travel and usually stay at places such as Extended Stay that have a kitchen.  The downsides to these kinds of places is that they often are missing some pieces such as a colander so being able to take this along without really taking up any space is great.  Can easily hold pasta for 2 people (if using portion control sizes and not mammoth servings).  I'm also a die-hard tent camper and like it for my camp kitchen bag too.  It's a bit small for me for everyday use in my home, but for travel or camping it's great.

I own this brand of onion keeper and I absolutely love it.  I live near Oneida Ltd. in Central New York so I bought mine there at the factory store rather than on Amazon.  A friend saw it and liked it so I thought I'd see if Amazon had it and send a link to her so she could get one of her own.  Never in a million years would I have thought that this product would keep my red onion as fresh as it has for as long as it has (going on just over a week now).  My refrigerator has no evidence of any sort of onion smell.  I also have the green pepper keeper and that works equally as well.  There's also a garlic keeper and tomato by this company - I don't use either of those for their intended purpose, but look great sitting on the ledge area of my stovetop (with a little non-skid shelf paper to keep them in place).  These make wonderful gifts and everyone I've given one to thinks they are one of the most practical and decorative kitchen items they've seen in years - they're right!  Highly, highly recommended.

I am NOT an earbud person at all - until now.  Well, I still don't think I'm an earbud person, but am more than willing to use this particular product.  I have 4 iPod/Shuffle products and never once used any of the earbuds Apple provides with them.  Just looking at them my ears feel uncomfortable and as such I've always used headphones of some sort.  Since I now have a small rechargable earphone jack speaker (Macally Portable Stereo Speaker with Lithium Battery Silver TurboTune) that fills most of my listening needs I thought I would try out these earbuds after reading multiple good reviews of them.  I travel a lot so I wanted something that would take up the smallest amount of room and not have cord all over the place.  This product provides nice sound, is pretty comfortable for the price and they have extra pads for the earbuds.  All in all, a good purchase for me - the product adequately fills my need.Downsides:  As another reviewer mentioned the cord on this is a bit short even at its fullest extension.  This can be a bit problematic if I'm carrying my iPod since my arm can't relax comfortably at my side.  I'm not a tall person - I'm 5'7", so I am knocking it from a 5/5 to 4/5 for this.  Also, I'd think twice before I purchased this for someone who would be using them constantly since the wires are very delicate.  I realize they have to be delicate in order to wrap around the center chamber and to be so compact.  For someone like me who is using them a handful of times each month it will be fine.  I know not to pull quickly and to treat it gently.  I'm not sure the average teenager would be so cautious, however.Overall I'd recommend it to someone with those caveats in mind.  For the price I'm very pleased.  I purchased this at a site other than Amazon only because it's on backorder here and I needed it before they would arrive.  Once back in stock I may purchase a backup unless I can find something within a reasonable price range that has a longer cord and a cord that is a little less delicate.

...the first one I received from Amazon had a product defect right out of the gate.  It arrives in compacted shape and as I was extending it I noticed the upper portion of the silicone green sides separated from the clear acrylic upper portion and I had to contact Amazon to return.  They promptly replaced the item and paid for my return postage for the defective one.  Because of this problem I'm reluctant to compact it unless I really need to.  I feel the less this product is messed around with the better.  When I travel to my vacation home I'll want to have this along and will compact it then, but otherwise I'll leave it in extended form.  I'm pleased with it as a produce keeper - the 2 qt. truly held 2 qts. of strawberries and seems to extend the life by a couple of days.  I like being able to rinse and store in the same container.  I myself have not had the problems with the bottom cover as others here have mentioned.I'm not sure I would purchase this same container again unless I saw it at a killer price.  I'd most likely seek to purchase the non-collapsible type instead based on the problem I had since I'm not really collapsing it anyway.

When I bought my Amazon Basics silicone case for my Touch it came with a pretty decent screen protector, but the fingerprints were just awful.  Awful to the point that I had to keep the lint-free cloth close by for regular use several times a day.  When I read that this was the "creme de le creme" of screen protectors I thought "what makes this so much better?"  Well, now I know.  The fingerprint marks I can readily see are so minimal that I don't constantly need to use a lint-free cloth to clean it up - maybe just once or twice a week vs. several times a day with the one I had been using.  I had one small air bubble that was luckily in the black area on the lower right of the Touch that didn't seem to be going away, but as many others wrote it eventually did (I helped it along a little).  Had it remained, however, I still would give this 5 stars for the clear, minimal fingerprint finish I have.The Youtube video was very helpful and highly recommended prior to application.  The instructions I saw were for an iPad, but are pretty much the same for this particular product.  Seeing the step by step tutorial is helpful.  The small piece of shield for over the button at the bottom seems rather inane to me and I didn't use it.I am so impressed with this product that I have no reservations about purchasing more in the future for other products.  I don't think my 4G iPod Touch is going to need a new one - I think it would take a lot to destroy this.  Highly recommended, esp. if kids are regularly handling the item.

I bought this to use with my iPod Touch for when I travel to have a better speaker than what comes on the Touch.  I wanted it to be slim, easy to use and no-fuss.  I wasn't looking for it to give me the same kind of sound experience I get from my Bose system - just something a little less "tinny" than what the Touch plays through its speaker.  I don't necessarily think this makes the Touch sound level louder as much as it seems to create a fuller sound which, to me anyway, makes it seem louder.  As another reviewer wrote if you have this playing in a relatively quiet household you'll hear it a couple of rooms away nice and clearly.  For a couple of people playing cards while camping it will be perfect, but to entertain a room full of chatting guests it won't give you that level of volume.  It charged pretty quickly and the sound integrity only seems to fade as it's running out of juice.  For my needs it will be absolutely perfect and it's the only one I've seen in such a small size.  I use a 4.3" 2-sided GPS case HDCSXL: Extra Large Hard Shell Case For Garmin, TomTom, Mio GPS with 4.3" Screen to hold EVERYTHING I need for my Touch, including charger, an extra case with cover, cables, stylus, etc. and this slides in there just perfectly so everything I need is right in one location.  In fact, I couldn't seem to find another speaker in this size range and thought I'd take a chance that it would both fit in the case AND produce the sound I'm looking for.  Mission accomplished!

This case is nothing fancy and I don't need the case for my iPod Touch to be anything other than a comfortable way to hold and secure my iPod Touch.  I have a case with a cover for when I just want to put the Touch into my purse, but other than that I keep my Touch and all related accessories, including an Apple USB charger, in a hard-sided 2 section GPS case HDCSXL: Extra Large Hard Shell Case For Garmin, TomTom, Mio GPS with 4.3" Screen.  Since it's in this protective case I don't need a case with a cover for the most part and wanted something more comfortable than a pseudo-leather case to hold onto.  The Amazon Basics case is just right for this purpose.  It's got a nice secure feel in my hand and the ability to easily access sync cord slot and the earphone jack too.  The power button and side volume buttons are covered by the case, but are easy to notice on the case and work just fine through the silicone.  It also comes with a very nice screen protector and application "squeege" along with a small cleaning cloth.  Simple product, great price, highly recommended.

My main reason for purchasing this was for the ability to keep it connected to my iPod Touch since I need to use a stylus for effective typing.  I cannot for the life of me understand how no one has yet to make a case for an iPod Touch that includes a simple, secure slot to hold a stylus.  There are enough styli on the market (literally page after page on Amazon) so why hasn't anyone made the simple case with cover and stylus holder?Anyway, when I got this I thought it would be OK enough until I found something that secured a stylus better.  It's still a little too short when fully extended but certainly is useable enough to type out a quick message so I was satisfied enough with my small investment for the time being.  One day I got thinking that this item cost really next to nothing so the plastic used to go in the headphone jack probably isn't of the highest grade plastic and what happens if it breaks off into the jack.  I stopped using it altogether after I thought about that for just a moment and I would encourage you to do the exact same thing.  I ended up giving it to my nephew with the warning that he may want to think twice as to whether or not he wants to put this in the jack.However, if it's a compact stylus you're considering I'd give it about 3 stars.  Nothing horrible, nothing spectacular, useable enough.

My travel is for personal purposes only so I don't need any kind of device that has programs such as MS Office or any specialty computer program.  I just need something compact for travel since I simply want to be able to check my bank statements/ensure direct deposit went in, send and receive messages, access the internet to look up local attractions, maps and local travel guides, checking the weather, maybe a Kindle download here and there, things like that.  I didn't want anything too involved or expensive (like the iPad) since I don't go on vacation to be connected all the time, but want now and then access to look things up or keep entertained if I'm waiting for something.  This device does all these things, but has so much more to it than that.  I'm pretty brand loyal to Apple, but wouldn't hesitate to bring up any problems I encounter.  So far I've had no problems with apps running awkwardly, crashing or any other things other people seem to be noting when looking at app reviews.  Many things are available offline once downloaded, such as travel guides or specific maps, which is great for someone like myself who is envious at times of people with smartphones and their ability to look things up on a whim (but I know I don't want a smartphone and the additional charges since it's not important for me to be THAT connected).  So many places have wi-fi availability that I really don't have any problems finding a place to use it.Favorite Apps:-ShopShop (free, shopping list maker with ability to have multiple lists with a simple layout and it remembers your items for future list making)-iHandy Level (free)-Weather Channel Max ($3.99, but I like the moving radar feature - free version is good though)-Pandora (free, and it will upload whatever you have on a Pandora account you already have)-Betty Crocker cookbook (free, and it's a full version)-Better Homes and Gardens cookbook (free for full version, $.99 to get a specialty add on with more recipes like slow cooker)-Discount Calculator (free, determine final price of a percentage off item)-Vocabology (free, daily new word and urban slang phrase)-National Geographic National Park Guide (free, able to add one specific park in depth information for free but would have to pay small amount for others)-Photo Collage (free, numerous layouts and ability to adjust collage frame size, can use pictures you upload from your computer or ones you take on the iTouch camera)-Gas Buddy (free)-Coleman Lantern (free, select from about a dozen different lantern models to turn it into a flashlight)-Zip code reference (free)-Hobby Lobby (free, coupon via the app vs. printing off of computer)-PBS (free, can watch a multitude of full length programs for free)Most major banks, credit card/financial companies and major retailers have a free app.  This is also reassuring to have while on vacation to ensure my automatic payments indeed went through successfully.  With all of the apps I ended up downloading I think I paid no more than $10.  If you're willing to put up with some ads many of the free versions will do just fine.I like that I can load my own pictures since I like to have some pictures with me of my travels to show others easily.  There are many free collage programs you can choose from to even make a collage and send it via e mail.  It's a neat feature for taking a few vacation pics on the iPod Touch itself and sending to family and friends.  It's not nearly as nice as the pictures I take with my DSLR camera, but in many instances has taken some nice shots I'm proud to send along.  I can load the DSLR shots onto this later if I want the really good shot available for viewing.I've played with the FaceTime a little bit with my niece and nephew for the novelty of it all.  I imagine teenagers would find that more fun than a 41 year old, but it is a neat feature.  If I didn't live near them I probably would find it more useful.I have a 2 GB shuffle with ability to use playlists for my music, but I added on a compilation mix of the 3 major types of music I like to listen to on the Touch just to have available if I'm using it while out and about.  When I go camping at the National Parks I can conserve my battery on the Touch by using the shuffle for music and the Touch for reference needs.The size of the iPod Touch is both a curse and a blessing at the same time.  Along the curse side I wish it was more along the size of a 4x6 picture which would be slightly smaller than the Kindle Fire, but a little bigger than it currently is.  Its ability to be taken anywhere easily (vs. something even like the iPad) makes it a blessing.  I've heard rumors here and there from family, friends and some internet articles that Apple is looking to come out with something that could be considered an "iPad mini" or "iPod Touch max" in the near future too.  I would certainly jump on that opportunity in an instant and is ultimately the device I'm seeking to have.My only regret about this purchase is that I didn't order the 32 GB.  I thought about it briefly, but figured that I'd only be loading on a few things.  Wrong - once I got this in my hands and realized all the things I could easily do with it I wished I had ordered the 32 GB.  Had it come in a 16 GB version that would have been a no-brainer purchase.  That being said, I can always temporarily take off some apps I'm not using as much, take some pictures off, put shorter playlists on and things like that to conserve space yet ultimately still have everything available.  I know this version of the iPod Touch has been out for about a year now so Apple's close to being due for a new version and I will then order one with a larger memory and hopefully it will be the rumored mid size version several of us have been hearing about.

I remember when I got my Nikon D50 SLR 6 years ago that a 1 GB card was about $70.  I choke thinking how cheap they are these days in comparison and come in class 10, but all technology comes down in price.  Since they are so inexpensive these days I find myself transferring my images onto my laptop and external HD and then keeping the card as my "digital negative" in a SD card case as a final backup, esp. for trips such as Alaska, Hawaii and other more expensive trips that I'm not likely to take again.  There's no way I could do that back when cards were so expensive - I'd be broke with all the traveling I do.  Since I use the card this way I don't want an 8 GB or higher SD card - for me anyway that becomes too much storage and I'd rather keep it short and sweet so 1 card equals 1 trip.  4GB is a lot of images even on the highest resolution setting.  It may not be all that much for those using it for videos, but according to my newest point and shoot that does 1080 HD recording it gives between about 25-30 minutes which is still pretty respectable.  I don't use the video function so it's not a concern for me, but I think that amount of time would be more than enough if I ever did want to record something.I like Amazon's frustration free packaging as well.  A welcomed change to having to fight with packaging.

I live in a place that's been around for many decades now.  Of course the best places physically for me to use my resistance bands for a workout happen to be the same doors that have sizeable enough gaps between the bottom of the door and the floor that the anchor that comes with my tube set is as about as handy as a doorknob on a tree.  The door anchor that came with my set of exercise bands was no more than a marble sewn into the nylon webbing.  This anchor, as evidenced in the photo, has a nice, large anchoring surface that not only anchors it better but doesn't rub into the door.  It also has a very nice soft piece of material where the resistance bands go which will no doubt increase the life of your bands.  It's a well made product and wish my set came with something more along this line, but this accessory isn't very expensive and is well worth it.  Kudos!

This will be a great product for me to use to warm up my 3 person tent before going to sleep (turning it off prior to sleeping of course), but it wasn't all that helpful for tailgating.  I didn't expect it to produce that much heat, but even holding my hands pretty close to it I didn't feel too much heat.  If I had purchased it exclusively for tailgating I would have been disappointed, but knew that I'd use it to warm up my tent and am confident it will be ideal for that situation given my tent is not a large one.  If you're considering it for either tailgating or for use in a larger tent then consider the next size up like I now kind of wished I had...

I received this style lanyard in orange as a gift.  The webbing itself is nice, but it has velcro at the neck which is not secure.  On top of it not being secure it also doesn't overlap with the velcro making it look quite odd and scratches the neck.  I had a relative remove the velcro, overlap the ends and sew them securely in place.  Now I'll feel comfortable wearing my expensive game ticket on it whereas before there's no way I'd risk wearing it for fear of it coming off too easily and the discomfort of having the velcro scratching my neck.  It looks nice and sharp, but the individual that designed this particular lanyard should go back to the drawing board or should probably get out of design altogether - it doesn't take a whole lot of common sense to make an effective, secure lanyard.I'm also not sure why this doesn't come with a ticket holder - I had to buy that separately.  Had this item been made more securely and came with the ticket holder I'd easily bump it up to a 4/5.

I use this primarily in my home with my laptop when in my living room.  I purchased a second power cord for my laptop since the one in my home office (primary use location) is entwined with numerous other cords and I don't always want to run it off of the battery.  I didn't want a large surge protector power strip in my living room where I use the laptop, but recognized the need for surge protection and this product certainly meets this need.  There are 2 outlets in this plug and has phone line and ethernet line inputs as well for complete protection.  It offers a $75,000 guarantee for devices properly connected to it and has indicator lights so you can ensure that the unit is properly functioning.  When plugged into the bottom outlet on the wall the upper outlet is completely available for use with this unit.  The travel benefits of this device are obvious and this will easily slip into a laptop bag.

My Dad was a tradesman and when he passed away last year I "inherited" one of his Makita drill sets that also included 2 batteries, speed charger and a flashlight as well.  Though there were several drill bits in there as well as flathead and Phillips head driver bits I wanted a more complete set and saw these during Amazon's holiday season "lightning sale" at a great price.  I read the reviews and even though the reviews weren't so great, I figured for my needs the set will work and it does.  I use them every now and then vs. my Dad who would have used these 4-5x/week and in far more heavy duty projects than I'll ever have.  If you need to drill a simple hole or want to drive a screw in quickly it's fine, but for detail and heavy duty work I'm reasonably sure that my Dad would have hated them.I think a lot of product satisfaction depends on how the item fits your needs - for my occasional, light duty work this set is adequate.  Though not in the building trades myself, I spent 40 years of my life helping a perfectionistic tradesman with numerous projects and based on those experiences I am fairly confident when I say that tradesmen would not likely be satisfied with this set.  Evaluate your needs and purchase accordingly.

I've done SLR photography for years now and admittedly use the "auto" setting too much despite having the knowledge base to be more creative with exposure/aperture/shutter settings.  I've been wanting to make the most out of my cameras and wanted to get a good solid education with exposure without having to take a class.  After much searching here on Amazon I found this book to get great reviews and I now know why.  The book is written in such a way that if you have a good knowledge base it isn't insulting, yet if you are new to SLR photography it isn't written so technically that you can't get a grasp for what it's saying.  That's definitely a difficult balance to reach and this book has successfully reached it.  I also like that this book doesn't cater solely to the SLR user, though that's the user who will definitely gain the most knowledge.  I enjoyed the book so much that I'm considering other titles in the series as well.I recently took a trip to Niagara Falls and after reading much of the book noticed that my night photos were greatly improved versus other night photos I've taken in the past using the night photo setting on the camera.  By gaining a better understanding of the delicate balance between aperture and shutter settings explained in this book, along with use of a tripod and remote, I now have some beautiful shots to add to my personal portfolio that a pre-programmed setting would never allow me to achieve.

SD cards have come down drastically in price - I remember paying nearly $80 in 2006 for a high end 1 GB card.  Since I can get a 2 GB card for about $6-7 now I've decided to not erase them once I've transferred the images to my computer, external HD, etc.  I've essentially made the SD card the equivalent of the film negative so I have my back up images.  As such, this is a great product for my needs since I just label the SD card and put it in one of the slots and only remove it if absolutely necessary.  The slots are quite snug around the card which is great for card security/non-slippage, but if you think you'll be taking the cards in and out of the slots frequently the plastic sheet may eventually tear.  There are 2 slots that hold larger memory cards OR it would hold the traditional SD card size with a case that is essentially the same size as the SD card without a lot of excess around it - those are the slots I'd use if I would be taking the card in and out of the slot often.  The case is plain but effective, could slip into virtually any little space in a camera bag, zips nicely and the zipper pull could have a carabiner put through it if desired.  A nice organizer for the small price and a nice little gift for a digital photographer who's hard to buy for.

This game is nice for its ability to be played as a single player (for 2, 3 and 5 players) or as teams (for 4 and 6 players).  It's a fun game that anyone over the age of about 8 could enjoy.  Maybe it's just me, but it took longer than usual to figure out the rules for the game and during our trial run game we had to reference the rule sheet nearly every turn and all of us playing are well-educated, smart, common sense oriented people.  For the second actual play round we had to reference the rules here and there, but from there it went relatively smooth and those of us playing all said it was a nice change from Uno.  It's a fairly quick play game and though the rules state that you have to reach exactly 1000 miles to win, you could make it different by having a win achieved by the first person/team reaching 1000 miles without having to be exact, "drive" a higher number of miles or through the highest score at the end of whatever amount of rounds you choose.  Make sure you have adequate room in front of you to have areas to place up to 6 different cards - works fine at a kitchen table or card table, but probably wouldn't work very well using a small side table or TV table.  I also own a card tray available through Amazon that works well with this game - 2 Deck Rotating-Revolving Card Tray.In a nutshell, each player has 6 cards at all times during the game and always draws a card on their turn.  You need a Go card to get started, need to hope you don't have hazards (flat tire, repairs) imposed on you by other players and if you do hope that you obtain the necessary card to overcome the hazard quickly (you'll also need to have a Go card to proceed), need to hope that other players don't impose a speed limit (meaning you can't use point cards that are over 50) and score the exact 1000 miles (if playing by customary rules).  There are nice reminder cards to reference throughout the game, but keep the rule sheet handy until you've played this a number of times and really have the hang of it.

I've wanted a card holder for Uno, Mille Bornes and other card games involving a draw and discard pile.  Thankfully I wasn't looking specifically for a rotating/revolving card holder because this holder simply doesn't do it.  I knew this was likely by reading reviews before I purchased it.  If you consider having to press down on the holder firmly to rotate it then sure it rotates, but it really should spin relatively smoothly without much effort.  Other reviewers noted that if there were too many cards on one side that it leaned, but I haven't found that to be a problem as of yet.  The clear acrylic is strong and this item would have to take one heck of a whack in order to crack.Again, I was simply looking for a card holder for draw/discard so I think it works well, but if you need it to rotate/revolve I think you'll be disappointed.
And everyone else who believes in the divine power of God. I could not recommend this book more highly.

These are genius. Now, I don't believe for two seconds that someone could not bust through one of these if they wanted to, and that is certainly not the purpose we were looking at when we bought them. We have a two and half year old Grandson and did not want him getting out of the house to go outside and "play" without our knowledge once he learned to work the doorknobs and open the doors on his own. This is a great concept because you can just leave the key in the top and if someone needs to get in from the outside all they need do is to turn the key from the outside and the chain falls away, you just reattach it when you come in. It was well worth the extra ten bucks to know he cannot get out on his own! I ordered this for my daughters home as well.

Great Quality Leather!!! And I love the orange color, it is just what I wanted, I can easily see it no matter where it is. The reason I'm giving it three stars instead of five? I'd have been happy to have given it five except for two reasons. This wonderful wallet is RFID, also an important thing to have in a wallet full of credit cards, BUT...while it has tons of slots for the cards, they tend to fall through the slots of the top two down into the pocket and below the first card! So you have three slots side by side on three of four panels, but the cards in upper slots disappear because there is not an actual pocket for each card, just slits cut into the leather, half the time I think my cards are "missing" and have to go digging to see if they are actually there. That is not a good thing to have to do every time you open your wallet and it is very annoying! The other problem is that the piece of leather that is meant to clasp the wallet closed is far too short once you fill all those slots with cards. The wallet is now thick with all those cards and it is a test to get the wallet clasped. I have every slot filled and you can forget putting any money in this wallet if you plan on getting it closed. So you must either NOT fill all the slots, you'd probably lose six slots to be able to carry cash. Not really a big deal for me as I never carry cash, but if you do? It will be an issue. They either need to eliminate six slots and make one panel strictly for bills, which in my opinion would ruin the wallet because there are already two pockets you can use for cash and/or receipts OR make the dang leather piece longer to wrap around the the wallet. Someone did not actually FILL this wallet with plastic cards and cash after designing it to see if it would WORK properly, what a shame. Other than that it is a beautiful wallet.

Just what my husband wanted! He always complained that his iPhone did not stay charged long enough, this did the trick perfectly and did not add too much size to the phone for his pocket, it did make it thicker, but not enough to bother him at all. I've decided to get one for myself! Great price too!

Decent size, looks like an address book, has sufficient pages and is large enough to write in appropriate information, in the note section you can include account numbers and phone numbers as well. It is well made and if you remember to put the passwords in pencil you will make life easier for yourself as we all know you have to change those passwords from time to time.

I bought the pink and they are not quite as pink as the picture, more of a light pink, but very beautiful. Nice weight silk, beautifully made, surprisingly not as slippery as I thought they would be. They get a little warm on your face, but not too much so, not enough to make you sweat anyway. I really like them, and while pricey for two, considering I paid $100 each for my down feather pillows and another $35 for the allergy pillow protectors, it was worth the investment...these are the most expensive things I've ever put under my head! I'll be back for the red ones!

I love these! They are pricey and I've not washed them to see how they hold up yet, but they are nice on my also pricey down pillows. I thought the terry would make my silk pillow cases a bit lumpy, but it is indiscernible underneath them. They are a good weight and well made. I'm happy with my purchase.

There is just no way that books of such volume can be portrayed correctly on the screen, they highlighted the sex and grave details missing much of the story, and to top that off? Eight episodes and you have to wait months for more? Ridicules! I paid $14 a month for Starz in order to watch this ONE show $168 a year, the channel has nothing else I wanted to see; movies I've already seen. I could have bought the stupid DVD for $22 at Wallyworld!! Which is what I will do to see the rest...if there is a "rest" to see. I think it was well done, but still maintain you cannot get the whole story from this...the books are better, and even those need major editing of all her "going nowhere" parts due to the way she writes.
This one is my favorite!

I opened these and compared them to the one that came on my platinum Sonicare and I was going to return them, they felt too soft. Then I saw the price of the actual Sonicare heads by Philips...which I thought these were. I decided to try one. And I was very pleasantly surprised that I liked them! They were just right and even if I had to replace them once a week they were a bargain! So I'm keeping them! I think they will be just fine. I replace my toothbrush once a month or if I get sick then as soon as I am well. I think these are a great value for the money.

Excellent cover!!! Matched our room perfect and is upholstery quality fabric. They also called to make sure the measurements were correct and that I ordered the right size, which was nice actually! Fits well, does the job, I have tennis elbow and it gives me good support when my elbow is bothering me. I bought a large and I really could have used and XL I think. I think it runs a little small. My arm is 13" 3" above my elbow if that helps you decide on size. :D

I love this thing!! It's perfect! Okay, okay, you all said that your tablets slide on it. And they will!!! BUT if you use your noggin a little  you can come up with a solution! You can use picture bumpers (little rubber nubs that keep pictures from sliding on the walls and being crooked) on each side (that is what I'm doing) or you can use shelf liner cut to size and use double sided tape to put it on, that would keep it from moving. There are a lot of fixes for the sliding issue. And maybe they will eventually put something behind it to keep if from sliding. But for now you can come up with something because this is a really cool and useful item. I love that you can adjust it to any angle. On a table or your lap it is perfect! I was tempted to buy another but forgot I bought one of those tablet pillows too, which I also love for using in bed.

Best price on amazon for this type glove. I was concerned with the size because of all the reviews but bought them anyway because all the others were 30 bucks and I wasn't paying that for them. I wear a size 7 glove which is a large in ladies gloves, I wear a size 9 shoe and I'm 5'8"....you may wonder why I told you that? Well, hands are relative to feet and height. My hand is just under 3 1/2 inches wide at its widest and these fit me perfect. Many people said they fit big and that worried me. SO IF you are short with little feet, these will probably fit you big. They will stretch and I would expect them to fit a glove size 8... and 9, which is huge for a woman, but pretty standard for a man. They will be big if you wear small or medium gloves.

I had read Mr. Moody's book ages ago, and his book was fascinating to me and actually sent me on my journey to find out what is really Out There. I tried on a pair of these at DKNY and I was so impressed by the comfort of them!! I came home and ordered three pair from amazon. I am a true size 9 and technically I have a wide foot at 4", but I didn't order a wide or anything, they are plenty wide and comfy and that is why I say you could add the insert, there is room for it. I have tons of trouble with my right foot, plantar faciitis and so I really cannot say if they are comfortable all day since I cannot walk all day or wear a shoe all day...or even stand all day! But I do know that these are the most comfortable shoes I've ever worn. That said, they are not the most attractive shoe around, they (to me and my husband) look like Old People shoes, which is funny because we have become Old People!!! Maybe it's actually a young person's shoe! Who knows, but we kind of make fun of them and my husband has a similar style of shoe made by Propet that is also a slip on.

If I could give it no stars? I would. Perhaps she could funny in real life, I don't know, but she is not funny in this book, she only thinks she is. I found her to be rude and disrespectful. She seems to have a major chip on her shoulder about her Father, her family, her upbringing and her former religion. She took things out of context on a regular basis, made them out to be something they were not, and out right lied at times. She seems to have a warped sense of things. Having been around Mormons all my life, and having many, many relatives who are Mormon, I was looking for some insights into those who have left the church. I found a book making fun of Mormons in a really bad and disrespectful way. I felt sorry for her in so many ways because she could only see things from this warped point of view and chose to tell things out of context in a warped and mean manner. She deliberately chose words that twisted the truth about the things that Mormons do and hold sacred. There is nothing strange or untoward that happens in Temples. I am of the same age she is and she flat out exaggerated everything she could to make them look bad! She's outrageous. Like anyone who chooses to talk bad of someone else or something else, they twist the truth to get people to believe their version things. That is precisely what she did here. I wouldn't get Life Coaching from this bizarre woman for all the money in the world. I wouldn't trust her and I sure won't read any of her other books. My husband read her Finding your North Star or something like that, a book I picked up somewhere, and he wanted to read this one. He began telling me strange things, and because he is not Mormon I thought I better have a go at it. In the first three chapters she was so utterly un-likeable I could barely continue. I gathered in the next few chapters that what she thought was humor in the previous few chapters, only came off as showing her in a very unfavorable light. She has a very poor sense of humor, indeed. Perhaps in person she does not come off as so scathing, but none the less she is manipulative and full of exaggeration that I found no respect for her....at all. Trash.

In todays world anyone who can write and post it on amazon is an "Author", that does not mean that those who can write, write properly. The grammar is atrocious, and the punctuation is horrendous; the spelling was correct and it was quite clear that a spell checker had done that for her. The organization was poor at best. Amazon has created a place where one cannot possibly know what they are getting when they purchase a "book" unless they purchase a hard bound copy that has properly been done by a publishing house. This "book" was clearly not proofread, edited or done in proper order. Frankly I am tired of buying books that cause me to cringe because they are written by freelance writers with poor English skills. I have begun "returning" them immediately upon the first error I come across in order to retrieve my hard earned dollars and spare myself from the embarrassment I feel for these so called writers. That said, she has some quite good stories and I did like her as a person. There was a great deal of personal information in this book, some that an editor would have had her remove for her safety and the safety of her family, particularly her mother. I learned more about her and her family than I did Spirit. She seems to be a lovely person, but she is certainly not an "Author".
I really found this to be tedious and repetitive.

Interesting...HILARIOUS at times..strange...weird. But Interesting indeed! Period perfect, loved the art. This man just cracked me up the entire time...its not supposed to be a comedy but it certainly comes out that way in my opinion.

I can completely understand the deep, primal appeal of a long, singlehanded sailing voyage. Bernard Moitessier's The Long Way is a beautiful rapture of the deep. He was winning the first round-the-world-nonstop sailing race, but instead of heading north to claim his prize, he sailed around again, all the way to Tahiti, without ever stopping.This is something else. This is rowing across an ocean to prove that you can row across an ocean. Now that it's been done, someone will no doubt row frontwards across an ocean, and then someone will do it in a birchbark canoe, and then with no paddle, and so on. All of those ways are very short on pleasure.So you are guaranteed to meet a very odd person in here. She's a global warming and ocean-ecological-disaster nut much like myself, but she is also a strangely uninformed one: when she meets a sunfish doing what sunfish do (lie on their sides and flap their flippers in the air, literally sunbathing), she assumes it's some horrible pollution-mutant.But hey: she dumped her bog-standard life-with-hubby-n-kids to go find her adventure, and obviously loves doing what she does, and there is genuine adventure in here. I enjoyed the book.

By page 114, I could already comfortably explain Hawking radiation: the seeming paradox that absolutely nothing can get out of a black hole, yet it radiates vast amounts of energy. (Hint: think of particle/antiparticle quantum foam popping into normally-temporary existence right ON the event horizon.) Where does that energy come from? Literally nowhere.Still here? Good: now I know who I'm talking to. This is a brilliantly clear history of 20th Century physics, astronomy, and cosmology. The characters come to life: before his killjoy editors got to him, one of Stephen Hawking's papers included "Suppose you have a little race of gnomes..." At one point, astronomers could rank themselves depending on whether Allan Sandage had at some point stopped talking to them. Described at length are several cases of mentors guiding students in the best Platonic fashion. Also, interestingly described at length is the fall and rise of the mighty Allan Sandage, who was thought of as being out of date until more modern yardsticks stunningly verified his thirty years of meticulous, lonely work.I only have a good brain, a year of college math (which I'm dreadful at) and physics, and a lifelong fascination with astronomy/cosmology going for me, but I submit that any intelligent, interested person would like this book and may be inspired by it. It is an adult dose, and I'm savouring it. By page 300, I already understood symmetry, broken symmetry, the whole enormous fuss about the Higgs boson (yes, it IS that big a deal: until we created one in the CERN accelerator, they had been entirely missing from the universe since the first trillionth of a second), the concept of a supercooled Higgs field, and finally what inflation is and why it had to happen.
