Though very interested, I thought I could never understand any of those concepts and even dismissed them as mumbo-jumbo: Overbye makes them plain as ... well, he makes them understandable.Overbye doesn't get into string theory very deeply, probably because it was very new in 1991, so I'll end with a question: Can anyone recommend a book that covers the last 20+ years?

I was able to compare this apron against my everyday favourite. The cotton canvas is heavier (which I prefer) and it is cut about 10% larger, which I also like. The only thing stopping it from becoming my new favourite is that the pockets are smallish and at an uncomfortable height. I wear aprons for hours on end, and it's nice to be able to drop my hands naturally into the pockets. Which is a pity. I know exactly how cotton reacts to extreme heat, whereas the blend used in my favourite is less predictable.If you are not inclined to put your hands in apron pockets, this apron is about perfect.

I got this from the library on a whim, not expecting much, given the spectacularly well-coiffed and turned-out author.But so happens the lady really knows and loves her subject, and the book is exactly what it says it is: authentic Japanese cuisine that uses few ingredients and needs few instructions to prepare.Which doesn't imply it's all easy-peasy. The kara-age chicken needs to first be fried at 340F until almost done, then singed at 370F to finish. My first experience quickly taught me that those specific temperatures are important, and are difficult to maintain (do NOT trust the dials on electric deep-fryers: these days I just hover over the stove, monitoring the oil temperature in the pot). I thought to eliminate the first fry by pan-roasting the chicken beforehand, but turns out the batter needs all that time in the oil to cook properly.But my first, messy attempt got eaten almost as quickly as my second. And as I already had hot oil, and we had harvested-today local corn on hand, I also tossed in her kaki-age corn and shrimp fritters, without the shrimp, which means I was basically deep-frying corn and flour: those are so utterly addictive that they evaporated on their way to the table.For a Scotsman, I've made an astonishing amount of tofu, but then so has Ms. Arimoto. Tofu is tasteless, you think? Try using her recipe, but substituting edamame (frozen is perfect) instead of dried soybeans. The result is BRIGHT green, tasty in a very subtle way, and likely to get you lucky if you ever bring a vegan home for dinner.A recommendation for a next book? Japanese Soul Cooking. A sorta Japanese-gets-funky-n-messy cookbook, including several horrific-looking dishes (like Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki) that look distinctly ... Scottish.
I like how this tool can diagnose its own connection. It also has good range.

Excellent quick iced tea that's ready in seconds. Nice also that it's unsweetened, because the alternative always seems to be too sweet. Slightly expensive for what you get, but the convenience is great.

I ordered this book because the excellent Making Artisan Pasta mysteriously skips soba entirely. Now I know why.I am an experienced pasta-maker, and thought that the problem with buckwheat flour - the complete lack of gluten, contributing to a rather brittle texture - could be solved by throwing technology and pure gluten at it.That does work, vastly simplifying the process, but the resulting noodles, while excellent, are just buckwheat noodles, not soba. There is an entire other world in here to discover, encapsulated in the mysterious phrase: "mixing of the water into the flour in such a way as to allow the buckwheat to develop its own viscosity."I'm a scientist, don't like mysteries, and hate doing things because "that's just how it's done." I will eventually understand the chemistry behind what is going on there, and where the viscosity is coming from, but in the meantime I'm learning the traditional way, and maybe in a couple of years I'll be making passable soba, at which point I'll treat myself to the coolest kitchen knife ever, just the thing to have on hand when the zombies attack.

So this is a movie starring David Duchovny and John Neville, with FIFTEEN MALE supporting actors and Blythe Danner? I'm not even remotely a feminist, but a product description like this makes feminist paranoia a little more believable. So they couldn't get Gillian Anderson to play herself in the movie? Then why is she on the cover? And who is the guy who plays her? I'd love to meet him, because he has one real healthy rack, for a guy.

If you think you know all the problems and possible fixes for the state of food in the world today, you need this book as much as I did. Mr. Barber picks one subject after another and dives in very deep. Take wheat, the largest world crop. One of its problems is that it is an annual, needing planting anew each year, right? Wrong. Wheat has been bred to be an annual, but it can also be a perennial. Perhaps the most staggering diagram in the book is the side-by-side comparison of the roots of perennial and annual wheat. The perennial roots are 3-4 times deeper and wider: that diagram alone COMPLETELY explains the "Grapes of Wrath" Dust Bowl.Then he moves on to foie gras, which provokes an automatic "Boo! Hiss!" from all animal-sensitive people, right? Wrong again. He describes a goose farmer ( who is quite likely clinically insane, but all the more delightful for that) who simply allows his geese to force-feed themselves. When the first cold-snap appears (which triggers gorging to prepare for migration), he lets his beloved geese into a field of their favourite food and they make foie gras voluntarily, while he lies on the ground among them, snapping photographs and laughing.Then Barber explains how chicken farming sadly became The Chicken Industry (Mrs Perdue, with too many chickens but enough feed), and how corn took over half a billion acres, yet tastes like nothing. And then he dives into the ocean, in depth of course.Two months later, I finally finish the book, is how much digesting it needs. At the end, he cycles back to wheat: how varied the flavours could be ("as different as heritage tomatoes") but how they somehow all got squished in the drive for commodity-uniformity. The problem here, he suggests, is that even most artisan bakers and cooking-nuts like myself LIKE uniformity, you betcha ... and yet Kitchenaid grain mills  are inexpensive, and I could almost walk to Skagit Valley WA, which is currently all a-ferment with custom wheats.Dan Barber has a possibly-unrealistic view of our ever-more-overpopulated sustainable future, but aren't they all? His sounds more tasty than most.

I dove right in the deep end: making pasta using only a bowl, rolling-pin, and knife. (Why? Because I recently had everything I own stolen.) Ms. Green's instructions worked perfectly, and I had a blast doing it. I'll post images shortly.Now that I have an Atlas pasta roller again, I'm all over these recipes like a cheap suit. No more store-bought wonton wrappers for me! The flavoured pastas are brilliant, and the utterly-gorgeous laminated parsley sheets are a show-stopper. I adjust amounts of semolina vs. Caputo "00" flour to give exactly the texture I want. Hand-formed udon in miso soup is ... ambrosial.More about the laminated parsley: It took me four 1/4 lb balls and about 20 minutes total to nail it (see user photos). The main thing is to completely trim the stalks off, or the sheets will tear. It's fun to experiment doing the laminating while still a couple thickness away from what you want: the leaves become enormous and abstract. Next time: edible flowers.Four stars only because her recipes constantly refer to other recipes, which is usually just inconvenient, but can be disastrous. Making spinach pasta? After blending the spinach with the eggs, you're told to follow the rest of the directions for red pepper pasta, but THOSE tell you to reduce the liquid on the stovetop. When the liquid started rising rather than reducing, my brain kicked in and I realized I was making a nice-looking spinach souffle. And yet the book had given me the confidence to just throw in another egg and make (excellent) spinach souffle pasta dough.

I read this brilliant cookbook cover-to-cover as soon as I got it. He has lots of stories to tell and he introduces several obviously-beloved associates along the way, but those asides are always there to introduce and explain the recipes. Most people will likely find the recipes far too detailed, but for obsessive cooks like me the level of detail is exactly right.I dove right into the northern-style herbal sausage recipe. Yes, it's long and (very) involved, but the only hard part is finding the ingredients. I managed to score every one except the coriander roots (strangely unavailable in the Pacific NW). The toughest to find is probably the kaffir limes, but I have my own tree.The resulting sausage has me seriously considering dedicating the rest of my life to making and selling it. I'd sell it at farmers' markets, each one wrapped in its recipe, completely unworried that people would then start making their own.I have every David Thompson Thai cookbook, and they're uniformly excellent, but also strangely passionless. This book inspires passion. Maybe tomorrow I'll fall in love with and dedicate my life to making (say) his Vietnamese wings. That's the kind of cookbook this is.

To install the driver, the installation instructions tell you to insert the CD and navigate to the folder that has the same name as the model number, which is SI-7200ND.But the CD has NO SUCH FOLDER. I installed the driver from the folder with the name closest to this model number; no dice.The company has no website to download drivers from.I then went to google and started to type "drivers for Etekci..." whereupon google AUTO-COMPLETED "drivers for Etekcity SI-7200ND." Google only auto-completes search items that are very common, so I quickly lost patience with the damn thing. I've taught computer science at college level; I know how to get things working, but spend an hour or more installing a $20 adapter? It is going back, just like the last one. Candidate #3 arriving shortly, sigh...

Yes, you have to get used to it, which takes just a little learning, but that only takes a few minutes of playing around. I keep it for personal use and keep simpler timers for guests, but personal use is exactly where it shines.I have short-term memory problems, so there are several events that I need to time every day. Tea-brewing (9 minutes, over and over) is typical, so it's nice that each timer remembers what it is set at. (Hair-dying was another regular one, but I recently realized I was starting to look ridiculous... )I could properly be described as an obsessive cook, and often load this timer up with three different things to keep track of. I sometimes have to write notes to myself to remember what each timer is timing, but I successfully muddle by.I always thought I just tolerated its quirks, but when mine broke (after 7 years of heavy use), I immediately ordered another.What's not to like? The toggle-switch for clock-mode, which gets inadvertently pushed far too often. And who needs yet one more digital clock? I solve that one by slicing off the button (mine has rubber buttons) with a razor.

(OK: I dearly love cats, and always save some lovely big flakes of what is basically fishy catnip.)It's wonderful to have this much bonito on hand. When I run into an insane dashi recipe that calls for 7 oz of flakes, 24 square inches of konbu, and half a gallon of water, I can follow it all the way to miso soup Heaven. First time I made it, I had smoked salmon and chanterelle mushrooms all ready to jump in, but instead stopped at tofu (from Tacoma Tofu: gorgeous and very fresh here in WA) and green onions: anything else would have been overkill. The quality here is excellent. A little bonito-dust doesn't bother me; if I want to be fussy, I just run it through the strainer twice.The only outstanding question is: why on Earth is a SCOTSMAN writing this review? Miso soup with TOFU?!? No sheep-guts, suet, or deep-fried pizza (no, I didn't make that last one up) in sight anywhere?

Nobody would now name, and nobody would now buy, a book titled "The Best of Asian Cooking." As if it could all be lumped into one slim volume! The only reason I'm reading it is because I'm house-sitting for a friend, and she has it.Which, it turns out, isn't a surprise. She spent several years eating her way around SE Asia, while setting up tea supplies. This guy did exactly the same (except for the tea-part). Just last night I got a hankering for miso soup with tofu (Go figure: I'm Scottish!) and I followed his ridiculous recipe (7 oz of bonito flakes for 4 pints of wateri!?!) for dashi. It was harder to follow his "2 squares of konbu (seaweed)" so I just winged the amount, but the result was transcendental. I had chanterelle mushrooms and smoked salmon all ready to jump in, but ended up adding only sliced green onions, and also ended up in soup-heaven.(There are two massive Asian supermarkets close to here. They both sell endless varieties of "dashi-mix," NONE of which contain actual bonito flakes. Luckily, Central Market was also nearby. It's the Seattle-area food-cathedral where everything (including bonito flakes and the deathly-cute Asian assistant who found them for me) is utterly edible.)I've only made the one recipe, but the dashi was so marvellous that I read all the way through the book. There are dozens of excellent, well-informed recipes for now-popular dishes like Tom Yung Goong here. He was brave enough to include then-impossible-but-now-doable ingredients like shrimp paste and kaffir lime leaves. He includes an accurate recipe for beef rendang (my current passion) but falls down at the end when he says: "Continue to cook until the liquid has been almost completely reduced" without mentioning that this should properly take several hours: rendang is beer-party food: settle in, crack a few, and give an occasional stir.I've got perhaps 100 Asian cookbooks, but the reason I'm going to steal this one (hey: I'm taking care of her dying dog, and her goats and ducks and cats, while she goes gallivanting..,) is the dozens of recipes I'm unfamiliar with. I'd heard of winter melon soup, but had no idea it could be done this way, as the stunning  centerpiece of a genuine feast (and advanced pumpkin-carving skills would help greatly, here :-)In short, the book title is fairly accurate. If you ever got lucky enough to snag yourself a copy, I'd recommend you do.

This thing is fun, very comfortable, eliminates the need for a coaster, but is not terribly effective at keeping drinks cold, dammit.It's designed for tall-neck bottles, but it also works well on stubby bottles, by squeezing the sides together while zipping up, and then folding the neck down slightly.But then I got scientific, and measured what difference it makes. I took two beer bottles with water cooled to 40F, wrapped one while leaving the other one uncovered (the room temperature was 70F) and measured every five minutes with a probe thermometer. In short, after 45 min, there was only 3F (52 vs 55) difference between them.The beer FEELS colder when drinking from a wrapped bottle, because your hand is grasping something warm, so the cold beer is a surprise. I'll keep using it, but will look around for something more effective.

All of you silly Colonials entirely miss the point of these pans: they are designed to make proper British PORK PIES! (Any pie that doesn't start out with something that once went "oink" is NOT a pie; it's a tart. Oh, and the pastry requires actual LARD.)For making pork pies, these are bloody marvellous: easy to form, easy to fill, utterly-easy to release (wax paper recommended on the sides and bottom; simple greasing doesn't work), and they bake up right proud.They get docked a star because the coating doesn't exactly wear an eternity ring, and the hinges will flake their coating and give out with heavy usage, which mine are seeing. Order yourself at least three sets, because pork shoulders only come in Large, and "too many pork pies" is about as inconceivable a phrase as "too much bacon" or "too many cheerleaders squeezed into this elevator with me..."
The instructions are (pointlessly: there's plenty of room in the box) too small to read, so when the installation ran into problems, there was nothing I could do to fix it.

Felicity Cloake has laughable knife-skills, an endearing little speech impediment that likely makes her unintelligible to most Americans, and is short on knowledge on several important cooking techniques. But she has a real way with finding the perfect recipe. Not familiar with her "Perfect" format? She makes several recipes taken from various top-of-their-game chefs, describes the strengths and weaknesses of each one in detail, and then melds them all into her idea of perfection.Her ideas are damn good, but if you disagree with any decision she makes, you can simply reverse it by substituting some road she didn't travel. The other recipes are described in enough detail that each recipe can easily fan out into a dozen distinctly different ones.But if you still pay attention to American health warnings about food ("Margarine is good for you! Butter is bad!") then you should know that's she's ... authentic. Her Perfect Cornish Pasties call for lard in the pastry. You might think to bravely substitute butter, but the pastry recipe ALSO calls for butter, so just suck it in and buy some (preferably fresh) lard, OK? Your mouth and your guests will thank you, giving you time to make your own separate peace with your bathroom scale.

I thought this might be wonderful, since it stars Dustin Hoffman and Mike NIchols before they made "The Graduate," but it's a very slight piece of work indeed, more of a study piece than something meant for entertainment or enlightenment.

PROS:Has silent mode with VERY vigourous buzzer.Has Lock mode that disables all buttons except for the stop one.Pleasant alarm that switches off after a minute.Strong magnet.Can be completely figured out without reading the manual.CONS:Impossible to read the buttons.Will reliably fall over even if you just look at it.No backlight.3 timing buttons: hour, minute, second. (Why is this a negative? Read on.)Has clock mode, which just complicates things: does anyone REALLY need yet one more digital clock?An outfit calling itself American Innovative should at least try to innovate, no? Like instead of setting time by 1 hour, 1 minute and 1 second increments, why not realize that 80% of kitchen timing tasks are for less than an hour, so having a TEN minute button instead of an hour button would reduce button-pushing by about 90%. A backlight that turned on whenever it was picked up would also be a nice innovation. (Oxo Good Grips people: are you listening?)Nonetheless, I like this little thing. I have short-term memory problems, so I use timers constantly. Having a silent buzzer that DOES get my attention, and a lock-mode that allows me to put it in my pocket, is really nice. (The vibrator is so strong that it is guaranteed to shorten battery life, though.)Why could it not have been designed with a stable base? No reason whatsoever.

This lovely dated movie holds the answer to one of the most enduring Beatles mysteries, to wit: Just how many holes does it take to fill the Albert Hall? John Lennon, who wrote the song, mumbled about something vaguely remembered from a newspaper, but this movie imbeds a better answer.(Evidence offered: Richard Lester, the director, had just directed "A Hard Day's Night" and would next direct "Help!")The film is a fun, slight piece of nonsense unless you're into that Rita Tushingham square-jaw 'n square hair 'n square stare look (sigh...) But it also involves two studs who compete on how many women they can bed. To settle the bet, they invite all their conquests to the Albert Hall.HENCE: "Now they know how many holes it takes to fill the Albert Hall."QED(Source: It's my bleedin' idea.)

Pacific WWII naval history fascinates me, and I'll happily put up with merely adequate writing as long as it is clear and accurate.I only got halfway through this book before ditching it out of irritation. The description of the USS Tang's torpedoing is just flatly confusing: it describes the stern sinking to the bottom at three different points in the timeline.But that was just the final straw. By that point I was already irritated by the poor quality of the writing. Typical: "He wondered if he would survive. He would soon find out." Well, obviously he survived to tell someone his thoughts, or Kershaw is making stuff up. Sometimes it seems he uses this tiresome, amateurish foreshadowing technique every few paragraphs.Interested in the story? Amazon has at least two more books that cover it. First is The Bravest Man, which tells the expanded story of the career of Richard O'Kane (the Tang's commander), and then for a much drier, more technical take on the story, why not read O'Kane's own book on the topic? Clear the Bridge! gets very good reviews. Some of the reviewers complain that he rarely describes the emotions the men were undergoing? Having had my fill of US sports coverage ("How were you were feeling..."), I consider that an even stronger recommendation.

I ordered this for "a friend," but she and I had a falling-out before she told me what she thought of it (but NOT before she told me what she thought of me). So I tried using it myself to get some idea of its effectiveness.I don't wear makeup, so I tried it on a gummed-up old carburettor I was rebuilding. A couple of towelettes easily removed fifty years of thick, stinky varnish that once upon a time was gasoline.Which simply makes me wonder, once again, what exactly it IS that women put on their faces, and why?

I was looking forward to perhaps getting some helpful metrics to calibrate my exercise program, but the problem is that this - as purchased - is purely a pedometer, not an "activity monitor," and I bike for exercise instead of walking.I tried adjusting the settings, but never got any useable or trustworthy numbers out of it, so I put it aside and went back to calculating calories using the Strava biking app on my stupidphone.

Nowadays, even highly-regarded cookware store staff have no idea what a larding needle is (and usually look kind of grossed-out when I explain), so I understand I'm preaching to a very small choir indeed.Which is a shame: modern, bred-for-leanness meat needs a larding needle much more than meat used to. This one works very well, with a couple caveats: I find it's better to pre-drill the larding holes by pushing the bare needle through a couple of times, twisting as you go. Then, after cutting your larding strips (all I've used so far are strips of pastured pork belly fat, but the results are wonderful), stick them in the freezer for just a few minutes before pulling them through the meat. I've had very few breakages.But I'm starting to think that this could be used for more than just lacing fat through meat; how about lacing salmon-belly fat through a lean fillet of the same fish? Lacing bacon strips through a hard-boiled egg just for giggles?

This is a brilliant product that contributes to making incandescent pizza, but if you are serious about making pizza, then you'd likely use it on something like a wood-stoked kettle grill, heating it to 900F before sliding the pizza in. When the pizza is done, you need to peel it off of the Lodge immediately, so what are the handles for? They just get in the way.Cast iron absorbs much more heat, and transfers it much more rapidly, than stone, so your pizzas are going to cook faster, which is the same as saying they will be better. I was suspicious of the pre-seasoning, but it works very well: I've now made a dozen pizzas on it, and the seasoning just gets better each time.One comment about sizing: I started out using this on an 18" kettle grill, but it is too big for that-sized grill. The handles don't even fit under the lid, and not enough airflow gets up to the top, requiring the pizzas to be finished under the broiler. It's perfect with a 22.5" grill, but I'm still thinking of sawing off the pointless handles.

The day I got this was the day I finished teaching myself how to make excellent pizza. I'd already learned to use Italian 00 flour and a wood-stoked kettle grill with a KettlePizza insert (which easily tops 900 F but is truly scary) and a Lodge cast iron pizza "stone", but I was using a standard rolling pin to finish shaping the pizza, making the results just too uniform.It takes no more than a few minutes using this to get it completely figured out: perfect shaping with a nice fat roll on the edge of the crust. What happens next is up to you. I thought I'd be making all sorts of exotic pies, but I've become a Margherita-purist, using exactly eight ingredients including salt, yeast, and water.(Confession: I then tried making my own mozzarella. I nailed it on only the second try, but I had some very fancy sous-vide equipment to help me. I recommend you instead just buy really good mozzarella.)

This is the movie I turned to today, because I was feeling utterly sad about recent events in my life, and despondent about the human species in general.I've watched it 3-4 times before, so I knew exactly what to cue up today. A beautiful, inspiring, reassuring film.

I've been trying, and succeeding, to tame this beast for the last two weeks.I'm using an 18" grill and a Lodge cast iron pizza "stone" that is simply too big for it, restricting the airflow to the top and requiring that the pizzas get properly finished under the broiler.But it's easy to crank it to 900F or more (confirmed with an infra-red thermometer), and the 6-minute pizzas already coming out of it are stratospheric, easily the best my roommates and I have ever had. By far our favourite is an utterly-plain Margherita, made with exactly eight ingredients: Italian 00 flour, water, yeast, olive oil, tomatoes, basil, mozzarella, salt. Excellent Parmesan is always on hand, but it simply does not need it: it might be the perfect food.(I added a few ingredients, like lipase and goat rennet, when I tried, and finally succeeded, to make my own mozzarella from raw milk. The results were spectacular on my second try, but to get it right I had to invoke a Rube Goldberg sous-vide setup with 1 degree temperature control. Honestly not recommended, though the result was much better than even Italian bufalo mozzarella, which is, after all, old by the time it gets here.)The KettlePizza is far too expensive for what it is: a simple band of stainless steel, with two handles and a hole in the front, but order the damn thing, and crank it up: it will immediately scare the crap out of you. A hair-net is highly recommended, but you will then have one fun summer.

I was looking for an alternative to that dreadful Scott Kelby book for my 16 year-old. He'll update the review when he's finished the book, but my impressions of it are excellent. Yes, there are lots of photos, but unlike the Kelby book, they're only as large as they need to be and are mostly to the point being made in the text. The babbling brook sequence showing the effect of varying shutter times? Each of the six photos is worth a thousand words.I really like the writing style, clear, relaxed, and unfussy.

I have 10 TB of storage in my desktop, but I got this to share music and movies with my mixed-race (PC and Mac) roommates. I fully expected the software to be balky and the documentation pathetic, so I wasn't disappointed. (My four-star rating ignores those two issues, since they are very much par for the course.)It took me a couple hours to get it up and running, and quite some time to load it up over Wi-Fi, but since then there have been no real issues.

So far, all I've used this on is stainless-steel cookware, but the results have been excellent. It quickly removed old, persistent stains on the inside and outside of the pots.I suspect it leaves a residue, so I made sure to thoroughly wash the pots after polishing them.

This 60+ ex-hippy loves this video. I bought it about two weeks ago and have watched it perhaps 6 times already. Eminem is as brilliant and intense as usual, but the for-real high point is the long Dre/Snoop recitation of "G Thang," leaving the audience to fill in some of the shout-outs, like the one I used for the title, above.The only mystery is why was Ice Cube even there? Or was he really there? I didn't know his work at all, and still don't know it. But It's still a solid gold concert.

I'd love to be able to write a proper review for this book, because the recipes (especially the fast chicken stock recipe) look marvellous. I'm an experienced cook, so I appreciate many of the ideas discussed here.Unfortunately, we lost the cord for our Chinese-made electric pressure cooker, which is a shame because I loved trying to figure out what the numbers and dials meant. My roommate is currently in Beijing and is bringing back a new cord, at which point I will post an actual review about the book. The only reason I'm writing this one is because I'm required to do so within 30 days. I apologize for that.

[Upgrade to 5 stars: I've been working with the book for a few weeks, and get more impressed as time goes by. It's quickly answered every question I've had, and the results have stunned this sous vide rookie and his rapidly-fattening roomies. But I had been using it purely as a numbers reference, and only recently looked at the author's developed recipes: they are excellent, uncompromising recipes. Three that jump out at me are the Jamaican pork chops, the pastrami, and the very first fish recipe, the Moroccan snapper. That's the recipe I stole to make a 6-hour halibut rendang, the best thing I've ever made.]This completely-unpretentious little book is excellent at explaining the ins and outs of sous vide and also as an extensive and quick reference book.Just last night I wanted time/temp for lamb chops. Keller's (enormous, showy) sous vide book (only he knows why he titled it "Under Pressure") only has one lamb recipe, (140F for 35 min) for a saddle. This little book has 12, plus a two-page discussion about cooking lamb, PLUS a reference page listing time/temp for sixteen different lamb cuts, each to two or three doneness levels.I read the discussion and quickly selected 132F for two hours. The result was astonishing (all the more so because I used a crock-pot hooked up to a PID controller, because the splashing-water noise from my Braun Thermomix has a ... diuretic effect). Since I was brining them, then cold-smoking them, then marinading them in tandoori paste before cooking them, I added a rack of lamb to the recipe, hoping there'd be leftovers: there were none.Two nights before, I needed numbers for that halibut: this book gives 4-5 doneness levels for 38 fish/seafood species, though of course the numbers don't vary very much between species.The author makes the excellent point that far from being complicated, sous vide brings incredible simplicity to cooking, completely separating prep from cooking, and greatly loosening up timing. With the lamb taking care of itself, I had plenty of time to make a simple pineapple curry side-dish, and raita. I could just as easily have sealed the lamb up and held it for 24-48 hours before cooking. Last night I made his Jamaican pork chops (at 136F, not his 131F). My roomies didn't come home, so I seared mine, died, and went to heaven. Thing is: my roomies can die and go to heaven any time in the next 5-6 days, on 45 min notice: 40 min at 136F, then stripe-sear one side and blast the other with a torch. Or I can freeze them for several months, and they're still less than an hour from the same meal. Life is good.

My title about says it all. Step on them and they won't dent is how sturdy they are. My pass-fail test for measures is: can you smoothly run the back of a knife across them (to get an exact measure)? With these you can. Their greatest feature is that they are CLEARLY marked with their sizes: no glasses or peering necessary.I'm a big fan of good-quality measures, but I don't love these. I don't get the flare on the lip of each one. I'd also prefer them to be elongated-lozenge-shaped, because these are frequently too wide to fit in jarmouths.They're a welcome addition to my kitchen, because yet another set is never too many, but I also don't understand why the (too short, in my opinion) handles are so thick: it just makes them unstackable.

I got this because I love the Guardian's "How to Make the Perfect..." column by Felicity Cloake (even though she has NO knife skills whatsoever).It's odd for me to be writing a review, because this is the food I grew up with, yet is no longer mine (well, except for pork pies!). These days my mouth lives in SE Asia.But just tonight my roommates unexpectedly expected dinner, and I discovered I had every last ingredient for his chicken soup in veloute sauce, including a pastured chicken and homemade double stock.(Take normal, excellent chicken soup, add a stick of butter made into a roux with a little flour. Restauranteurs call it "monter au beurre." It's blatant cheating, but no complaint has yet been registered.)My roommates swooned clean away, declaring it the best chicken soup ever served. I'd made plenty; got little, which was fine, because it was not exactly my cup of tea. But I got interested in the book, and discovered that the man indeed knows his stuff, using really clean and efficient technique. I'll update when I make something else, but there is plenty in here to rekindle and warm the cockles of my heart for the food I used to love.

I got this to see if long strips of these lights (a single controller can handle 26' of lights) might work as battery-saving ambient lights for the VW Camper I'm rebuilding.The answer is: gosh yes! right now I'm running them off a big deep-cycle battery that is hooked up to a 4W solar trickle-charger. I've left them on all night for the last week, and the trickle-charger seems to be holding its own.Installation is easy. (If you're doing a permanent install, I recommend potting all the connectors in silicone). I was concerned about the amount of light, wanting to use these to at least read by: no concerns there: put six strips side-by-side above the kitchen cutting board, and you've got operating-room brightness (which is exactly what you need, given that the cutting board IS an operating room featuring your hands). A single strip is easy to read by. Thrown in for free is the multicolour capabilities. It's a shame that the controller only allows you to choose between 15 colours and white: the LEDs themselves are likely capable of many more, but it's really nice to be able to see clearly, and also do mood or nightlight lighting.I believe these are built to an international standard, allowing you to mix and match manufacturers. And I'm SURE someone makes a plugin controller that syncs them to the music that's playing (Deadheads pay attention).Dislikes?* If the remote dies, so goes the lights: there is no other way to control them.* Restricted colour choices (ridiculous complaint, given the price)* A slight roughness to the response. Switch colours, and it might flash brightly in another colour.* The remote is primitive: to brighten or darken, holding down the button does nothing: you have to press it repeatedly.* But I dislike that I'm even bitching, given how useful and how much fun these are.

Very few common recipes call for pastry flour: even Cook's Illustrated(CI) avoids mentioning it, probably thinking it too specialized for their customer base.They shouldn't. I used this flour to make CI pastry. The proportions were slightly off, but that was quickly fixed. Really easy and slack to work, and baked up gorgeously. My only complaint is why the tiny packages? I can use up 24 oz just playing away in my kitchen on an afternoon...

I didn't order this because I instantly recognized it as just a collection of the tags that come with Bradley briquettes. I've seen perhaps twenty different recipes on them, and they're fairly decent, but the font size is too small to cook from.If you want a Bradley recipe (and there are some really excellent ones) just print one out from the Bradley website. I suspect they only publish this as a convenience to their customers, but to me it's not convenient.

This is a series of lectures, not an audiobook. The difference becomes obvious very quickly, as the lecturer is thinking what to say as he goes along. This means that he speaks slowly and ramblingly, throwing in many emphases, long pauses, repeating himself, and adding conversational white noise like "and so on and so on."There is nothing wrong with the actual arguments, and of his choice of main battles (Artemisium, Salamis, Trafalgar, Tsushima, Jutland, Midway...) the only one that looks out of place is Jutland, because it changed nothing. His summation of Midway is succinct and to the point: at 10:22 am, the Japanese Navy controlled the Pacific; six minutes later, they didn't, and the change was brought about by less than a hundred American men, mostly by sacrificing their lives for the cause.But then he closes the book with an analysis of Leyte Gulf, which is a fascinating battle and a personal favourite, but it was hardly a pivotal moment in history and doesn't really belong here.So approach this one with some caution, and give it a listen first to see how you respond to the overall delivery. I found it rather annoying, and he further didn't endear this Scot by interchangeably using "Britain" and "England" as if they were the same thing.

[Update: For its first real job I had it grate multiple layers of pecorino romano onto a lasagna I was building. In this job it really excelled, quickly and accurately snowing layers of cheese onto the lasagna and not onto the counter. The photo, above, shows it in process. Each layer took less than a minute to grate and distribute: impressive.]This is an impressive-looking design, and with the rubberized handle and end-cap both bonded directly to the blade, looks very durable. The only really relevant question to ask of a new grater is: "Is it as good as a Microplane?" With that in mind, I compared at a variety of tasks against five different Microplanes. It's an unfair test, since I selected the best of five Microplanes at each task, but keep reading.You can see the results in the images, above. The first one shows the Cuisipro lined up beside its competiton. I first tested cheese grating, choosing fresh, soft Pecorino Romano and a stone-hard old piece of Parmesan. The Cuisipro was slightly better, and quite a bit faster, than the two best Microplanes.Next was zesting. My favourite Microplane for this job came out on top, being easier to calibrate exactly how much zest is coming off and how close to the white pith I was getting, but the Cuisipro, while it was harder to to control exactly how deep it was going, was ferociously fast, zesting at twice the pace. A little practice with it and it could be a fine, fast zester.Next, chocolate. I chose a difficult one: 70% cacao. When chocolate-grating, aesthetics comes to bear.My favourite Microplane for this job - the Large Shaver -produced much more attractive, large chocolate curls, especially after warming the chocolate to 85 F in a water bath, but the Cuisipro was once again effective and very fast.When comparing build and durability, all the graters in my test were equal, but notice that I only have Professional Microplane models. The standard-issue Microplanes (in other words: the ones that cost the same as the Cuisipro) are all made with easily-breakable transparent plastic frames. Given that the natural way to get grated material off of them is to bang them against the edge of the bowl you're mixing in, their lives will be short, which makes this new Cuisipro an excellent choice.

Having delighted in  Charcuterie by the same authors, I waited eagerly for this book's release, received it just hours ago, and have read about half of it already.The first long, non-introductory chapter is entirely about butchering a hog, which is entirely appropriate here; they even give the economic breakdown of buying a whole or half hog, but of course you can approach the process more timidly if you prefer.But I'm more of a "damn the torpedos" type, so I turned to the prosciutto chapter ... and stopped short: the short preamble is great, but the following recipe is two pages long. It certainly touches all the basic bases - breed, diet, butchering, draining, packing, weighing, larding on the strutto, hanging - but a chapter that opens with: "This is the most demanding cut to cure..." should, honestly, go into more detail than that. For instance, the chapter ends with: "Depending on the conditions of your drying chamber, you may be able to leave it there for up to two years. The danger in letting it dry too long, though, is that it can be come [sic] dry, leathery, and tough." Which conditons are most desirable for prosciutto? How about best temperature/humidity? There is a long, excellent chapter on general curing, but before I invest a year or two making a prosciutto, I want a more detailed treatment of its specific requirements.[Update: Somebody wrote, then deleted, a comment about the above. I think what he had to say was informative, so I'm pasting it here, verbatim.==============I really am not trying to bust your chops, but I feel that the book gives as much detail on curing prosciutto as is possible, without going into esoteric meat science-speak."The Environment: Creating a Place to Dry Cure Meat" [p. 76] gives very straightforward instructions for how to dry any salumi. Professionals hang their hams in the same chamber as their salamis, and so can we. As someone who has screwed up MANY a prosciutto, I can attest to the fact that they are indeed the most demanding cut to cure. They are so demanding not because there is a highly specific set of actions and environmental factors that are difficult to execute, but because they are massive, convoluted things, and there IS NO foolproof way to make them perfectly.==============I hope he is wrong, but I suspect he is right. In the meantime I'm perfectly willing to delve into "esoteric meat-science-speak" if it will lead to more reliable results.]The other, less-daunting preparations seem to get the detail they need, though: the two pancetta recipes are simplicity themselves (to the point where I'm already calling around looking for a pastured pork belly), and the many salami recipes all seem within reach.But the above gripes are minor: like Charcuterie before it, this is a cookbook, not a recipe book. In order to properly make some of these recipes, the whole subject needs to be studied in depth, and this book seems an excellent starting point.

With Costco here in Seattle currently selling twitchy-fresh Alaskan Sockeye fillets for $9/lb and whole fish for $5/lb, this Scotsman decided he needed a long filleting knife. At the knife shop, the best one I was shown was this Global, but I couldn't bring myself to spend that much, and I dislike the Global handles, especially when wet as would happen while filleting.So instead, for chump change I got this excellent knife with a far superior handle. A short detour to Youtube for salmon filleting videos (recommended: the hilariously-unhygienic one that has chickens wandering all over the filleting table) and I was in production, with the freezer and the stockpot quickly filling up. I figure that with the Global's extra flexibility, I could get about 5% more meat off the bones, but none of it is going to waste, so I don't mind. A shorter knife wouldn't work nearly as well.Next up: the same store is selling whole NZ lamb for $3/lb...(Note: Every decent cookbook I've ever read says salmon carcasses make dreadful fumet. That's simply not true: salmon fumet is an excellent base for robust dishes like a Malaysian rendang made with unsubtle fish like mackerel or blues.)

I'm also 45 years late in writing a review of this book. I read it when I was ~15, haven't read it since, but the many lessons it taught me are still fresh in my mind, like Asimov's deconstruction and explanation of all the components of paradimethylaminobenzaldehyde (still remembered intact, no spell-checker needed), of which I'll just give one: The "amino" comes from ammonia, which got its name from the ancient god Ammon. Camel dung was used to heat his temples in winter, and the priests noticed a white crystalline substance collecting in the rafters, hence ammonia.He goes on to masterfully explain each other component of the name, but not without also mentioning that the name itself scans in quadratic pentameter, which means that it can be sung to the tune of "The Irish Washerwoman". He probably made up the tale of quietly singing it while standing by the desk of an Irish receptionist, whereupon she gasped and exclaimed: "Oh! You know it in the original Gaelic!" but that amount of license is richly deserved by Asimov the writer.I believe he wrote more books than anyone else, ever. I went off his dry, unpeopled science-fiction before I reached 20, and am now a technical and science writer myself, but I'm not worthy to polish the boots of this man, who can truly explain anything to anyone, amusingly. Pick up any of his (100+) non-fiction books, and you will have pure gold in your hands.Why am I reviewing it now? Earlier today I told my roommate everything I remember about the paradimethylaminobenzaldehyde essay, and immediately she ordered me to find the book, which took all of five minutes.

I love jigsaw puzzles like this one: made from an interesting photograph (as opposed to those dreadful Kinkaide things or pointlessly-difficult "photographs" of 101 Dalmations), and with not too much monochromatic sky to slog through.The photograph has enough well-defined separate areas (the boat, the house-roof, the windmill) that multiple people can work away on their own favourite sections.Packaging is good, and the pieces usually fit together unambiguously, but sometimes it is possible to connect wrong pieces together in ways that seem plausible, which gums up progress until you eventually figure out the error.This being a 1000-piece puzzle, you're well-advised to first put down a roll-up puzzle-saver like this one, or risk losing your dining table for a couple of days.

This game reminded me of those annoying Publishers Clearing House competitions, forcing you to invest lots of time in finding pointless stickers in odd places, and pasting them in other odd places.We never did finish setting it up because we ran out of time. It sat out for a week or so, then got tidied away. It's unlikely we'll ever take it out again.

I've been trying to finish this book for the last two months, but still haven't reached page 100. This despite being personally very interested in finding relief for chronic pain.Parks writes well, but instead of writing a medical book about a problem and the finding of a solution for it, we get a long-winded, very personal account of his overall quest. After I post this I'll be interested to read some of the other reviews, though.

Here are the numbers and the other information that I wish some of the other reviewers had written up.I just took delivery, immediately set it up to test it (of which the only non-trivial thing was loosening and rotating the hose clamps so I could align it correctly).Without it, the standard Bradley internal temp with the heating element off is 60 F above ambient (my test was done on a 70 F day, and internal temp was 130 F).With it attached, and the heat exchange tube stretched out to the proper 36" (the product pic is very misleading, making it look like the heat exchanger is too short to be effective: I'll try to post a more representative one), the smoker-internal temp is 15 F above ambient, which qualifies as impressive. When I tested, the ambient was 60 F and the smoker temp was 75 F. I was just running a test, but I was making smoke while doing it so I stuck some cheese and a stick of butter in. The butter did not melt, but the cheeses sweated, confirming that 75 F is too high for cold smoking. That can be simply solved by the inventive use of ice, thank goodness, because I'm in the Pacific Northwest and right now it is HIGH salmon season, with Copper River Sockeye and Chinook ten bucks a pound for almost-still-twitching fillets. (I did a later test when the wind was gently blowing, and that made for a remarkable difference: internal temp was only 5F above ambient.)Yes, the heat exchange duct (very similar to a clothes dryer exhaust duct) is incredibly fragile and will look cosmetically horrible before long, but it does need to be fragile up to a point. You'll receive an education about heat exchange and temperature gradients by just running your hand along it. The rest of the components are durable quality, with even a magnetic-latch door for the water bowl.This paragraph for people who are using the digital Auber Bradley controller. All you need is a longer power cord between the Auber and the smoke generator, so that the remote temperature sensors can still go inside the smoker. Or just order replacement sensors from Auber: you'll need them eventually anyway, and they come with extra-long wires.If you skipped the last paragraph, you need to consider getting an Auber Bradley controller (auberins.com). It turns this, or any electric smoker, into an incredibly versatile, precise machine. You don't yet have your Bradley, and are wondering about whether to splash the extra for the digital model? Forget it: save the extra money and put it towards the Auber. Granted it's a pain to program, but really worth the effort. If you make beer, or cheese, it can also control some of those essential processes. And if you like to cook, and have a standard slow cooker, plug it into the Auber and you instantly have an excellent sous-vide machine.I've got the whole setup on the back porch right now, but this IS the rainy Pacific Northwest, and I'm installing a woodstove in my man-cave, so I'm getting thoughts about tapping the smoker into the chimney. That would be some radical man-cave indeed to invite some foodie date downstairs to examine...

I got this detergent so I can wash the comforter on a weekly basis. The washing instructions on the comforter say warm on gentle cycle only, so I could not get rid of the dust mites that require a hot cycle. Now I can wash my sheets and comforter together, instead of doing separate loads.The detergent comes with a measuring scoop. That is the red top you see in the picture on Amazon. The scoop is tiny (maybe 2 tablespoons?), so you may want to use it instead of eyeballing the dosage what I usually do with regular detergent. You need 3/4 scoop for a regular top loading washing machine. The instructions say it is compatible with the high efficiency front loaders which I have. Good thing is that it uses even less detergent. It only needs half a scoop for the front loader. Because the scoop is so tiny and half of the detergent sticks to it when I measure it, I put the cup in the detergent compartment as my washer fills up with water.With a regular washing machine, you will get 30 medium loads out of a bottle. With a front loading washer, you will get 45 loads which turns out to be about fifty cents per load.Update: it may be good for allergens but it does not clean as well as regular detergent. I still use the hot wash with regular detergent for the whites once I see some stains.

The color of Spanish Copper is exactly like that of a used penny, not the brand new shiny one but one that has been around for many years and is dark brown. I like the dark brown color but I can see that people expect something with more yellow in it. The tube is 0.5 ounce and the instructions say that it covers 20 sqft! I have not put that statement to the test yet.Rub 'n Buff is a wax rub on compound and not a paint. It seems that most people use it for decorative items like picture frames and ornaments that are not touched afterwards. I called customer service and asked whether there is a way to make the finish durable. I was told that a coat of water based utherane will do that. Since Rub 'n Buff has solvents in it, you can't use the oil based polyutherane. I have used the product on cabinet pulls with three coats of Minwax satin polycrylic. Both the Rub 'n Buff and polycrylic were very easy to apply. Hopefully this will give me a moderately durable finish for several years. Putting this on the front door knob that gets even more use will probably be too much.I also tried to pu the Rub 'n Buff on a bright copper colored chandelier. The fixture had several sections of square metal which did not work with the product. It rubs on fine but when you buff, it comes right off at the square edges. You can't just put another layer on top of it like paint since it has a solvent in it and the previous layer does not dry as a hard layer. I probably spray paint the chandelier black or brown first, to mask this issue but that would be too much work.

I wanted to buy some shoes that are as comfortable as sneakers but don't look like the typical sneaker. These Sketchers have a casual boat shoe type of look and are super lightweight. I wear a 6.5 and ordered the 6.5 and the sizing was right on. I bought the sand colored one with the contrasting orange trim. The shoes come with set of both sand colored and orange laces. The looks did not disappoint.The shoes are pretty comfortable. No breaking in required and my feet did not get blisters when wearing them without socks, even on the first day when I got them. My feet just got very hot. The support is so-so. After a couple of hours in these shoes, I can feel my feet. They don't have the same support as my running shoes. However, if you are used to wearing flats, these are probably more comfortable and they are a dream if you are used to heels. Unlike most sneakers, these shoes do not have any mesh on the uppers. I definitely notice the difference and my feet can get quite toasty in these shoes when the temperature heats up.Update: I have had these shoes in the stone color for half a year now. They got quite dirty and looked for instructions on how to clean them but could not find any. I don't think they would survive the washing machine, so I tried it by hand. I first sprayed some Shout on it. After that I rubbed liquid detergent on it. I rubbed it with my hand, a sponge and brush and then rinsed it. Before I put it to air-dry outside, I stuffed some paper towels in the toe area to shape the shoe. They came out almost like new with about 20 min of work.

0:57 MinsSince Home Depot switched to the junky Diablo sanding discs, I started buying these discs on Amazon. Mirka does not disappoint me. The 60 grit gives a fast and heavy removal but leaves a smooth surface. The pad sticks very well to the sander. Unlike cheap pads, the Mirka pads don't get clogged with paint quickly. The price is very reasonable when you get the 50 pack. The per disc price goes up dramatically for the smaller quantity packs.

0:31 MinsI have two old houses that are about 100 years old. They have a dark stain on tons of woodwork which I think is shellac based or covered. Doing a stain match is just about impossible, but I tried this stuff and it was a 100% match. Where the stain is worn, I just wipe it on with a cloth and rub it in. On the bare wood, just one coat was enough. I have had horrible experience with blotching on pine, especially with darker stains. This stuff had ZERO problems. The stain is poly-based, which gives it a durable finish. Although the finish is listed as satin, I find a real satin poly a bit shinier. So if you want a little more sheen to your stain, give it a poly satin topcoat.I have also used it on bare wood with paint splatters or painted wood (yes, white latex paint). No problem either, it may just need an extra coat or two. Until you end up with the last coat, it all looks bad, so keep on going. I have used it on a veneer door from the 60's. No prep required, just wipe it on three times for full coverage. I used a foam brush for the door and a cloth to wipe it on bare wood. The application is very forgiving. Sure, you need to go with the grain of the wood but you can't see the brush marks like if you were to used regular paint. And if I had to paint that door, it would required some sanding of the finish, oil paint to prevent bleeding and two topcoats.The movie shows the application on the trim of an old window. In case you can't see the end result well, check out one of my pics in the photo gallery.

0:14 MinsThis pinwheel is cute and durable. My toddler was running around with it and beating it, trying to make it spin. We now put it in the yard where she looks at it in amazement that it spins on its own. The pinwheel needs virtually no wind to spin. The video shows it spinning but I could not feel any breeze at all.

I love the facial wipes. No messing with cloth and I don't like to use diaper wipes on kiddo's face. I also use them as diaper wipes when I am on the go, since it is smaller than a diaper wipe package.Amazon is way overpriced on this. For about half the price, you can get them online at Walmart ($8 for four).

I have sanded many houses. Nothing takes thick coats of paint of like the Makita GV5010 5-Inch Disc Sander with this type of grit disc. It is superfast and very effective. I have stripped entire houses down from multiple layers of alligatored cracked paint to bare wood with these Makita discs. I don't think you can even get this type of coarse grit in a belt or sheet sander. The discs last for a long time and the grit doesn't easily get clogged with paint. I used to buy the Makita discs at Home Depot but they stopped carrying it and switched to a junk brand Diablo, so had to switch to Amazon. The price is not even that much more than the junk Diablo. Made by Makita for the Makita tool, can't go wrong with these.

I bought this as a potty training book. Initially, I was disappointed because there is no mention of potties, going to the bathroom or anything like that. The book starts with mom throwing a diaper in the trash. From there on, you see a little girl who shows off her huge collection of very cute panties. It shows that big girls like her, mom, grandma and aunts but no babies or alligators can wear panties. So why five stars if it is not about potty training? My little girl likes it so much (and she has 50+ books), that she is happy to sit on the potty while we go through the book. The story is long enough that she can do her business in time and short enough that we can finish the book. Bonus is that this is a board book. We also have a book that shows the whole story of a girl going through the potty training experience. My girl does not care for that book and it is way too long, so this book works great for us.

The exercise ball is of very good quality. I use it for exercise and also bounce on it with my little one when she needs to relax a bit. It has an insanely high rating of supporting 600 lbs, so I don't feel like it will pop under me any time soon. Once it is inflated, I found that it stays quite firm and I don't have to pump it up continuously unlike a cheaper ball that I had before.The pump is not that great. I am not in terrible shape but I had to pump it over the course of an hour while taking breaks in between. It took several hundred pumps of air to inflate this thing. Between pumping sessions, I would have to put the plug in and I could only take the plug out with plyers. However, I understand that a very nice pump would have made the ball way more expensive, so it is ok since I have not used the pump for several months now.I give the ball five solid stars but ding it is one star for the crappy pump.

A "hip" guide to The First State, that is not a bad primer for newbies relocating East of the Mason-Dixon Line.  I bought this for business associates who are relocating to our state with an eye toward giving a quick and accessible overview.  The book serves this purpose fairly well.  The only drawback, judging from my needs, is that it focuses somewhat on the trendy, which means the book may not match up well with a broad audience or stay in-date as "hip" changes.  But not a bad introduction.

Not bad a bad overview of the First State.I bought this because I am looking for a Delaware primer I can give to members of our trade association who relocate here from other states.  This basic book gives a quick overview of Delaware.  It serves its purpose as an accessible, if thin, introduction to what makes Delaware, Delaware.

The Oregon Trail resembles any number of Bill Bryson books in its organization and approach to the story.  Rinker Buck tells of America's mid-1800's mass overland emigration as he recounts his modern day wagon crossing of the Oregon Trail.Buck is an older man looking for something in his life and burdened, perhaps, by the shadow of his father.  Dad had taken young Rinker and his siblings on a New Jersey to Gettysburg mule-pulled wagon trip in the 1950s.  The trip imprinted Rinker (as well as earning a story in Life Magazine).  As a man in his 60's looking for a reckoning with his past and present as well as a change, the idea of doing Dad's trip writ large - over the 2,000 mile Oregon Trail - grew in appeal to where it became an obsession he could not rid.$25,000 later, he and his brother Nick set off from Missouri in a three-mule powered wagon pointed toward Oregon and a recreation of the overland route west taken by an estimated 400,000 Americans in settling what was then the far coast.  Bryson-like, Buck gives a fascinating of history of the trail - including what went into a functioning wagon, the breeding, propagation and unique suitability of mules, and a sampling of the people who endured the 2000 mile trek west (often walking next to the wagon if they were women or children).  Alternate chapters recount his own encounter with the trail - remarkably preserved down to wagon ruts in some places, asphalted over in others and with occasional detours required by dams, interstate highways and fence lines.Rinker and Nick become good at what they do - grinding out the miles in often hostile conditions, handling a mule team with needs as well as distinct personalities, and dealing with their own quirks as well as the ghost of their Dad (who weighs heavily upon Rinker, but apparently not Nick).  Rinker becomes an Oregon Trailer - not just in action, but also spirit.  His connection with and research of the original emigrants and trail history gives him an emotional bind to his effort.  This bind helps him understand his father and become accepting of the man who raised him, but who's presence in his life raised discord for the younger man.It's a well-written and engaging book.  The author doesn't have Bryson's wit, but it is gently humorous in its own way (as well as occassionally sarcastic a la early Bryson) and tells a good story - be it history or current.  The only clinkers were about five dropped-in comments equating Fox News watchers and Tea Party folks with dunderheads.  A minor annoyance and discordant with an otherwise smooth narrative, but not a major distraction.Enjoyable as history and as a modern adventure.

Functional, sleekly designed and with a quality cap, these bottles deliver what they promise.  They'll hold water that won't pick up any bottle taste due to the glass.  The sleeves provide modest breakage protection (these are still glass, however) with a loop that aids in carrying the bottle.  In a nutshell, they work as advertised.I do want to note that I was offered these by the seller in return for writing a review.

I liked the wealth of trail information in this book, "....The Complete Hiking Guide."Not having been in RMNP in years, and planning bigger hikes with my seventeen-year-old this time around, I wanted a comprehensive book that would provide information on the breadth of hikes available in the Park.  This book served the purpose.It is fairly well organized with reasonable maps and nice trail descriptions (borne of the author's personal experiences).  I did agree with a couple of the other reviewers who pointed out that non-peak hikes aren't graded and that the author uses the Yosemite point system to rate peak hikes - which might be too technical for those not familiar with this rating scheme.  Also, the author puts basic hike descriptors (elevation gain, for example) in the back of the book in the Appendix instead of with each hike.  This doesn't make sense to me as it requires flipping back and forth to get a full sense of the hike.Still, this book provides a wealth of useful information and I found to be a helpful planning guide.

Nicely produced, high quality map with excellent detail.This Nat Geo map is very well done and serves as an excellent planning and get-to-the-trailhead guide for hikers in Rocky Mountain National Park.  Not only is the map detailed and easily readable, the paper stock is tear and stain resistant, meaning this can be taken into the field.That I did not do.  Its detail means it is fairly large.  I couldn't see myself folding and unfolding this map, particularly in a wind, on the trail.  I got smaller one page route maps from the Nat Park Service and the internet after I had honed in on the trails I wanted to take for day hikes.  I did not do any overnights.  I do imagine this would be nice to have on a back-country overnight trek when one has planning time before and after the day's movement or during breaks.Having said that, this is a very high quality map and served its purpose well for me as  planning tool and general terrain reference.

This is an excellent book for easy day hikes as the title suggests.  Particularly a nice guide for families with young children, as many of these hikes are accessible and easy but still offer great views in the park.Each hike is introduced with a chart giving summary data about the hike.  Directions on how to get there, a route description and very well done maps complete the information.The size of the book as well as the quality of the drawn maps make this a very good take-along guide when one is actually in the park.

A National Park junkie, I have become a junkie of books with titles like "Death in Wherever National Park" (Grand Canyon, Yellowstone, Big Bend).  Partly out of morbid fascination, but also because many of these types of books give interesting accounts of back-country adventure and rescue stories.  They also provide excellent advice and warnings of what not to do in rugged terrain.I ordered this book and sent a copy to my seventeen year old son when we started planning a trip to Rocky Mountain National Park this summer.  Longs Peak, the only 14-er in RMNP, drew his attention.  Also mine after I read up on the hike and saw it required not only great distance (fifteen miles), but also climbing abilities in addition to hiking skills.  Possessing neither climbing experience, nor unsure of my fifty-plus year old ability to do a fifteen mile strenuous hike in rough terrain, Chapter 2 of this book persuaded us both that Longs Peak was beyond our current skill level (ok, it persuaded me....he wasn't entirely persuaded until after the strenuous but enjoyable hike to Chasm Lake at the foot of Longs Peak and 3000 feet below the summit).This book is a compendium of deaths, near-deaths and rescues in RMNP since before its inception.  Each chapter is neatly divided (hiking, climbing, road accidents, murders - thankfully only a few of those).  The synopses of each case run from detailed to brief as the facts and knowledge dictate.  What emerges from the whole is not only a catalogue of incidents, but wise lessons and observations that will make the reader a more knowledgeable outdoorsman about what not to do in terms of risk.Although this book's entire focus is on mishap and rescue in RMNP, when one considers the actual extremely small number of incidents given the three million visitors the park hosts annually, the Park and the Ranger Staff offer everyone a thrilling and safe experience in the outdoors.

Will Durant, who with wife Ariel wrote an epic account of western civilization that runs to 11 volumes (and which I have not read, though my Dad has the collection), produced an excellent series of essays on the eponymously named Lessons of History.These short essays distill Durant's finding from having read deeply and widely in western and world history.  Often thought provoking, they cover broad themes like religion, economics, race, war, government, growth and decay.  Making use of patterns of human behavior and patterns generally applicable across civilizations, Durant does a very good job of describing constants in the life of man as a communal and societal animal.  I particularly liked his discussion of the seemingly never ending trade-off between equality and growth - food for thought given all the attention the "one-percent" and "disparity" are generating in our current public dialogue.At only about one hundred pages, this is a wonderfully succinct, yet thorough examination of the big questions of the human experience and what historic examination says about them.  Highly recommended.

Hampton Sides has written another good true-story in this account of the single voyage of the arctic explorer the USS Jeannette.It was a different time - when large personalities could steer national agendas and governments from the outside and where the "certainty" of science could commit resources, lives and attention (ok, these echo today with Donald Trump and Climate Change....).The voyage of Arctic Explorer USS Jeannette rested upon three personalities.  James Gordon Bennett, Jr.,  owner of the New York Herald; Geographer August Heinrich Petermann, and; U S Naval Officer George W. De Long.  In Petermann, the world had an expert, who led the argument for a popular certainy that the North Pole was a warm-water sea fed by the Gulf Stream and its Asian counterpart the Kuro Siwo.  Those streams, in scientific thinking, flowed under an outer ice ring (long observed by whalers and northern voyagers) and melted the ocean around the North Pole producing a navigable body of water.  U S Naval Officer George De Long, having participated in an arctic rescue, developed "arctic fever" and single mindedly focused on leading a voyage of exploration that would prove Petermann's theory.  In Bennett, inspiration and exploration met money and will.  Bennett, owner and publisher of the New York Herald, then the world's most influential paper, was fabulously wealthy and had an extraordinary talent for tapping into public interest with produced news chronicled in his papers that fed the public's appetite for adventure.  He was the man who joined Stanley and Livingston, having sent his reporter Stanley to the heart of Africa to find the good Doctor.  The resultant serials of the search and meeting sold a tremendous amount of newspapers.  Bennett thought that an arctic voyage to the North Pole would be the follow-on to Stanley and Livingston and saw another chance at making history in the effort.The story of the voyage is heroic and tragic.  Sides writes very well, and it is impossible to read this book without great sympathy for the men who willingly locked their ship in the ice and then endured privation that would sink most souls confronted with a fraction of the challenge the ship's crew endured for years.  Sides does a very good job of bringing the personalities of the story to life and each character becomes known to the reader with well rendered stories that describe the essence of the individual involved.  He does take a while to get to the actual voyage in the book, but the story of the personalities, preparation of the Jeannette as well as the recruiting of the crew is interesting and sets the table well for the adventure.(I would note that the current debate over climate change and the "certainties" of some scientists does make a fascinating juxtaposition to Petermann's and an earlier generation of scientists' "certainties" of an ice-free Actic Sea and the data that supposedly made it so.  Every age experiences to some extent the "arrogance of the present" and overestimates its own knowledge and understanding.  Perhaps unavoidable, but one of the great things about history is that it does give some pause to consider the human condition over time and perhaps learn to better confront the present and future).I read this book over a four day weekend - it moves and held my attention well.  For anyone interested in adventure writing, pick this book up.

This is two books - a series of essays on aspects of death in and around The Civil War; and, chapters on the how of identification, location, retrieval and reburial of the 600,000 of our fellow citizens who spent their all in the great event of our national story.Faust describes attitudes toward death prior to The Civil War - particularly the concept of the "good death" and dying well.  His book spends much of its ink on describing how various Americans reacted to the death of loved ones in service and the trauma that death away from home, often with the remains lost or in unmarked graves had on the families and loved ones who watched their men go to war.  Walt Whitman's melancholy and missionary zeal as he provided comfort to the wounded and dying during the last years of the war is recounted to poetically frame the effect such continual suffering had on individuals and the nation.  A host of unknown American's diary reminiscences are also used to underscore the effect of mass carnage and individual loss as experienced by loved ones.A little nation with a heretofore little army was not prepared to deal with the mass casualties produced by The Civil War.  The author describes the haphazard nature of body disposal and grave marking that attended most of the conflict.  The national government had to invent systems of dealing with the great amount of wounded produced by vicious battle and this took understandable priority over the care of the dead.  This lack of planning and organization meant that a generation of Americans who would have to deal with the tragedy of loss would also have to suffer the extra emotional burden of not knowing where their loved one remained near the battle that saw their demise or which one of the vast number of graves whose location was known but whose remains were not did contain their husband, son or brother.The war did, in its aftermath, spur major efforts to locate, rebury and commemorate the fallen.  This had the assistance of bureaucracy for northern dead; for the southern fallen, volunteer societies tried to assist in appropriate treatment of their lost sons.The book was hit or miss for me.  I thought the chapters dealing with reaction to loss and suffering were somewhat repetitive and ended up often underscoring the author's points over and over again.  This sense of loss is described in many histories of the conflict and while the author's focus gave it a greater scope than other works, it didn't really provide anything new to this reader.  Personally, I found interesting and learned a lot about efforts to deal with the dead and establish the national military cemeteries that I had not encountered before.  The chapters dealing with those issues were more interesting to me and I suspect would be for most Civil War buffs.

A fictionalized imagining of the "real story" of the Wyatt Earp and Doc Holiday on their way to the OK Corral that takes the varnish off of the characters of of one of the West's best known stories, as I'm sure was McMurtry's intent.This thin book is stark and to the point.  So are Wyatt Earp, Doc Holliday and Charlie Goodnight and I think the author's stylization is meant to underscore these characteristics of his characters.  The women, on the other hand, have depth and nuance and run circles around the men in terms of understanding motives and in laying plans.  Events just happen in this book as the main male protagonists react and act - often on whims that take them off the front porch or bar stool when action is required.  The women, from the bordello madam to the saucy and interesting foreign mistress of a traveling member of the English gentry, plot, think long term and understand cause and effect - even in a society whose structure at the time prevented them from putting their superior mental efforts to work very often to guide events.I found this book interesting - though nothing like the excellent Lonesome Dove.  Lonesome Dove is layered and wonderfully constructed.  Last Kind Words Saloon is well written but it is a quick little book - it lacks the depth of other McMurtry efforts.  Still, and enjoyable novel of the West.

For anyone in the health care industry who deals with studies, consultants and savings initiatives, this would be a valuable book to read.  The author presents case studies that demonstrate how some health care industry consultants violate rules of common sense in assessing program results (savings) and sometimes even make simple errors of logic and math.  Some of the cases are well known, such as a state Medicaid model that has been replicated far and wide in the country but whose results look to be based upon rosy baseline assumptions and in some cases wishful thinking.As health care delivery reform is a hot topic now, (and a costly one), this book is well timed.  The author does cite some interventions that appear to have positive results, so the book doesn't castigate the process of looking to more effectively and efficiently deliver healthcare.  It does highlight how many consultants have tremendous incentives to "produce" savings and choose assumptions that often pre-ordain their results

I received a free copy of this book in exchange for a review.This is a no-nonsense rhyming bedtime book for young children.  As most young children discover and are captivated by dinosaurs, this book ought to do the trick in terms of holding a two to three year old's attention.  The art misses on some pages, but on most there are interesting pictures that should please the eyes of those being read to - as the rhyming cadence pleases little ears.

Not bad, but photos could be better.This book is made out of hard stock, so it will survive some wear and tear (and book chewing, which my ten month old is into now).  On the plus side, 100 pictures gives young ones plenty to look at.  But, having to get to 100 leads to some choices that look like filler (dump truck and truck on the same page, for example).  Also, the picture quality was ok;  not up to the level of a DK book, but serviceable.

This story moves, propelling the reader onward.  The author is a good and descriptive writer and gives an immediate impression of the gist of each of the characters she follows.  If you are looking for a suspense read that will pull you in and make you want to finish the book in a weekend, this does the trick.Rachel, the "Girl on the Train," who imagines the lives of a couple whose house she passes every day, is a drunk.  Daily, her train also passes the house she used to call home, now inhabited by her ex-husband and the woman he left Rachel for.
