Twice daily on her commute, Rachel alternately mourns for the life she lost (and curses the women who supplanted her) and imagines the perfect couple down the street from her old home whom she views from her commuter's window but doesn't know.  Maybe due to her reliance on being drunk to cope with a life that has severely disappointed her, Rachel often is hesitant to act when contemplating a decision.  This does make some of the chapters repetitious at times, but the author's strong sense of place and use of description largely mitigates this criticism.Comparison's to Rear Window are obvious.  As with the Hitchcock masterpiece, Rachel gets involved when she witnesses an incident from her train that is out of sync with the imagined life of the couple she views every day - the couple about whom she has constructed a vivid, if alcohol fueled, perfect life.  There are a lot of plot twists, though this is the kind of book where most of them are revealed by the three protagonists and not pieced together from a well laid foundation of clues.A good book, quick read and pretty good freshman effort from this author.

This is a good book on politics (small "p").  I contrast it with Jeffrey Pfeffer's "Power...." in a class I teach and it is a useful tract.  Pfeffer studies power as it is, without any discussion of ethics or why it should be exercised.  DeLuca focuses on organization behavior and maneuvering within an ethically based paradigm (I suspect because as a consultant he had to sell his views on Political Savvy to clients who at least like to pretend all their actions are viewed through some ethical lens.)While DeLuca's book is useful, it is a little pollyannaish in that it tends to discount selfishness as a motivator in many organizational settings (not entirely, but enough that it seems the author is selling his model in a way purchases will be receptive).The strength of DeLuca's book (and there are many) is a mapping model he lays out for political assessment.  His model seeks to assign values to players, relationships and goals in situations where an individual or team seeks to move an organization from point A to point B.  This mapping tool, thus loads with assumptions, is designed to aid in the development of strategies for goal achievement.  While real life is immune to such exact representations, the model is very useful as a way to organize thinking in political situations where there will be allies and opponents, scarce resources and hidden agendas.The book is well written and wraps the author's mapping model around a corporate case study.  Very useful for students of organization politics and behavior.

Rudolph Giuliani's "Leadership" is a useful study of some of the things that made his mayoralty a success in New York City (success in that he attacked problems as he defined them and generally produced outcomes he sought).This book is not to be dismissed because it is written by a politician and would-be president.  Giuliani does an excellent job of chronicling the "how" of how he did his job.  The book is written in clear language, is direct, and is loaded with examples from his administration.I use this book to teach a course on politics and this serves my purposes well as a series of case studies.  Very critical to this book's utility is Giuliani's discussion of management and personnel practices.  His chronicling of morning meetings with senior staff shows excellent examples of how to conduct efficient and meaningful meetings as well as how to control large organizations through subordinates.  A frequent topic of the book is the new approach to policing and crimefighting his administration undertook.  While controversial to some, it can be argued that statistics portray a successful initiative.  His policing model introduces discussions of data acquisition and management, personnel and accountability as well as communication and feedback loops that are useful to those who seek how to implement new strategies that represent departures from business as it has been done.The author also discusses many other aspects of leadership such as time management, "showing-up" as the leader, and communication.  This book contains valuable lessons for any student of leadership.

Jeffrey Pfeffer's "Power: Why Some People Have It and Others Don't" has been called by some a "'Prince' for our times" (referring to Machiavelli's famous tract).That is a fairly apt description.  Pfeffer is interested in power as it is practiced.  As such (and to the dismay of some of my students and some reviewers on this site), the author seeks to describe the world as it is and how many successful people in it maneuver.  Pfeffer breaks down aspects of power such as communication, self-promotion, acting, use of anger as well as other facets.  These are outlined and described (with examples) in easy to digest chapters.  This work is a mix of study (the nature of power) as well as "how to."  For anyone involved in organizations or other political situations where there is competition for resources and rewards, this book is very useful to understand how those who are competitors are likely to behave and act.  And while it is true that many view (at least some of the time) these competitions though the lens of ethics, others do not.  Even for the ethically minded, this book is very useful in order to gain an understanding of raw power and how it often is practiced.Pfeffer is a skilled writer who is direct as well as explanatory.  An advantage over Machiavelli's work is that Pfeffer speaks to the reader in today's language.  Whereas The Prince takes some thought in order to translate the mores and references of the Renaissance for understanding, "Power...." is crystal clear in its precepts.

John Jakob Raskob was a financial pioneer and engineer who greatly helped in the building of two of the Twentieth Century's industrial giants - the DuPont Company and General Motors.  And, he engineered the several decades when DuPont controlled General Motors and in effect ran the nation's largest auto corporation as well as America's premier and dominant munitions and powder company.Relying on a wealth of research, David Farber has thoroughly explored the career and life of a very interesting and significant capitalist (as Raskob described himself).  Taking a lucky break as P.S. duPont's newly-hired financial secretary before that duPont combined with two cousins to buy the family business, Raskob proved himself to be a profitable, reliable and creative financier to duPont.  This at a point in history when duPont needed those skills to acquire and remake the family business that would give it the dominance and form it enjoyed for much of the 20th Century.  Raskob financed and organized the family company as it consolidated the gunpowder business and then rode demand for powder and munitions during World War I to fantastic financial heights.  Looking for a place to park their financial resources as well as talented managers, Raskob then engineered the investment in and financial and management overhaul of Willie Durant's General Motors (saving General Motors from Durant's excesses).His final business venture was the conception of and building (on time, under budget and during the Great Depression) of the Empire State Building in the early 1930's.Raskob was a committed Catholic as well as committed capitalist and Farber chronicles his roles as significant Catholic contributor (so significant the Pope named him to a special order - apparently an order reserved for deep pockets who were willing to underwrite church doings) and generous philanthropist.  Raskob - hence the book's title - thought the fruits of capitalism should be spread far and wide.  He took the fairly new idea of consumer credit and brought it to the financing of automobile purchase - thus allowing many more of the public to afford GM's products than was possible in the previously all-cash retail automobile business.  He also campaigned for employee investment plans that presaged today's 401k retirement funds.A man of boundless energy (he reminded me of his near-contemporary Teddy Roosevelt), Raskob found himself advancing the presidential campaign of Alfred E. Smith (a fellow Catholic and "wet" on prohibition - important touchstones for Raskob) as chair of the Democrat National Committee during the 1928 campaign.  Ever the pioneer, Raskob was the first DNC Chair to establish the national political party with a permanent structure.  Heretofore, the DNC would be resurrected every four years after a nominee had been selected then die again after the election.  Raskob and his dollars and organizational brilliance (much better than his political acumen the author demonstrates) ushered in the permanent national political party organizations we enjoy today.Though even students of American Economic History are unlikely to recognize the name of Raskob today (he never seemed to have a need to put himself at the head of his achievements, though he came to be one of the most interviewed and sought after business voices in the 1920's), his contributions are significant and his story interesting and inspiring.  A good book on a very interesting figure.
